column2: IT is strange how taste and standards change. It seems only yesterday that we had plays such as "The Green Bay Tree" or even "Tea and Sympathy," which handled the then vexed subject of homosexuality with silk gloves.

Alan Greenberg of the Yale Club and Art Lowe of the Downtown Athletic Club seeded first and second, respectively, won their quarterfinal matches yesterday in the Fowler Memorial squash racquets tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 19 Miss Jan Toni Berman and Stuart Jay Levy plan to marry in August.

GENEVA, Feb. 19 Britain urged the disarmament conference of 25 nations today to avoid getting embroiled in a discussion on whether a type of riot control gas known as CS should be outlawed as a chemical weapon.
OTTAWA, Feb. 19 The Government, confident that it has the full backing of the 10 provinces, plans to ban phosphates in detergents in two years.
MIAMI, (AP) Wheatley Stable's Brave Emperor, the 4-5 favorite, ran into a bit of bad racing luck today and finished out of the money in the feature race at Hialeah.

Mr. and Mrs. Raul A. Chavez of Mexico City have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yolanda Chavez, to William Harlough Knull 3d, son of Captain Knull Jr., U.S.N., and Mrs. Knull of Arlington, Va. A June wedding is planned.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 The Army Corps of Engineers rebuffed Gov. William T. Cahill today, declaring that it "could not make any decision now" to require immediately that all sewage sludge and industrial waste from New Jersey be dumped at least 100 miles out in the Atlantic.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19 A United Nations committee approved today "consultative status" for B'nai B'rith and its affiliates, allowing it to continue its work here. The Soviet Union and the Arab countries had sought to bar the influential Jewish organization from attending United Nations meetings.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) A young diver died today while patching the hull of the tanker Delian Apollon, which has spilled 20,000 gallons of oil into Tampa Bay. The authorities said he had been found under the ship, apparently drowned.
The New York Times Company has purchased Golf World, a British golf magazine with a circulation of almost 60,000, described as the largest in its field in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The House approved tonight a $19.4billion health and education bill for the current fiscal year in the face of a threat from the Republican leadership that President Nixon would veto the bill as inflationary for the second time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Southerners in the House and Senate waged a successful assault today on the Federal guidelines and busing plans that have been used to promote integration in Southern schools.

One of aviation's foremost inventors has won a Federal court decision enabling him to collect damages for patent infringement in manufacture of the General Dynamics Corporation's Convair 990 jet airliner.

The new decade hasn't even signed in at the history desk, and here is Geof Hewitt telling it how it is going to shape up in poetry, anyhow. These, he says, are the forms, the attitudes, the people and the general texture of the new poetry. The adjective is his. He has chosen those who, he feels, were among the best but unrecognized poets in the last half of the sixties.
LONDON, Feb. 19 President Nixon's foreign-policy statement was seen in Britain today as an unmistakable sign that America will be reducing her forces in Europe before long.
Prices of frozen orange-juice concentrate futures rose yesterday in moderate trading after dropping for some weeks.

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb., 19 Harry L. Hilyard, a former vice president, treasurer and director of the American Tobacco Company, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 25 Fernwood Road.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 More than 150 demonstrators were arrested today as hundreds of policemen turned back a protest march on the Watergate Apartments, the home of Attorney General John N. Mitchell and several other Cabinet members.
BERLIN, Feb. 19 The East Germans today renewed their criticism of Chancellor Willy Brandt's bid for open-ended talks, saying the Bonn leader failed to grant their demand for full recognition.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb 19 (AP) Former President Sukarno, who is in failing health, was allowed out of house arrest today to visit a newlywed son and his bride.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 19 Israel announced the loss of one plane to ground fire tonight as her air force attacked Egyptian positions in the Suez Canal zone for three hours. The attack followed an unannounced 48hour pause in Israeli bombing missions.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 19 Mayors of the state's six largest cities will back legislation asking the state to give 10 per cent of its personal income tax collections next year to cities, towns and villages.
SPRINGFIELD, Vt., Feb. 19 (AP) Former Senator Ralph E. Flanders, who retired from the Senate in 1958 after serving two terms, died tonight at Springfield Hospital. He was 89 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The pace of inflation in the prices of everyday items bought by typical urban consumers continued unabated in January, the Labor Department reported today.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 19 President Nixon's message on foreign policy gave no answers to the main questions Latin Americans are asking about the future of their economic relations with the United States.

On Dec. 26, 1968, two young Arab terrorists tried to blow up an El Al airliner preparing to take off from Athens Airport. Had the attackers succeeded fully, they would have killed 43 passengers and the crew of ten; actually, they murdered one passenger.
The Eastman Kodak Company posted record sales and earnings in 1969, the company disclosed yesterday.

American Ballet Theater, which had lost its previously scheduled Manhattan season to the Met's "opera festival" at the Metropolitan Opera House in June, will now appear at the State Theater from June 16 through July 12.

Max Falk, advertising director of The New York Times, announced yesterday that Joseph B. Wagner had been named advertising manager, Roger W. Atwood, assistant advertising manager and John W. Campbell, national advertising manager.

The first attempt by the State Insurance Department to punish insurance companies for alleged racial discrimination in canceling fire insurance policies in slum areas was overturned yesterday by the Appellate Division.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary submitted yesterday to more than an hour of tough questioning by four State Senators on his efforts to fight narcotics traffic here and then agreed that "I cannot say that there is no corruption in the Police Department."
The Continental Can Company said here yesterday that it planned to form a European subsidiary that initially would manufacture about $300-million worth of packaging a year.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 19 (Reuters) A six-man United States military training team, including four men who have qualified as Green Berets, is in Indonesia giving instruction in "civic mission" work in villages, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

LONDON, Feb. 19 President Nixon's maxi-statement on American foreign policy is a little like the brilliant maxicoats one sees swinging along the sidewalks of London these days: It is long, it covers a lot of territory, and it conceals the most interesting parts.

Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson formally entered the battle for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday with a wideranging attack on Governor Rockefeller and a declaration that he would seek a Negro running mate for Lieutenant Governor.

ALBANY, Feb. l9 Albany Medical College has announced the awarding of contracts totaling $8.1-million for construction of a new building that will include a library, classrooms and other educational facilities.

The Federal Reserve Board disclosed yesterday that because of objections from the Justice Department it had suspended, at least temporarily, consideration of a complex plan that would allow the Charter New York Corporation and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation to acquire banks in Rochester.
PARIS, Feb. 19 The United States tried a new approach today to get the deadlocked Vietnam peace talks into the negotiating stage but said later that it had not worked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) Representative Rogers C.B. Morton of Maryland, chairman of the Republican National Committee, indicated today that Vice President Agnew rather than President Nixon might play a major role in this year's Congressional election campaigns.

"What are you whiteys doing here this is a trial for black people," shouted an angry black woman yesterday at a group of white students filing from the courtroom where pretrial hearings for 13 Black Panthers are being held.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 19 In commenting here today on the Stennis amendment to the Senate's education bill, Mayor Lindsay said:

The Metropolitan Museum of Art conceded yesterday that it had erred in not informing the public before removing 36 full-grown trees last December. It also said it should have publicized its plans to plant more than three times that many in the spring and fall.

Martha Argerich chose the Third Piano Concerto of Prokofiev for her New York Philharmonic debut last night, and that virtuoso's vehicle proved precisely the score to introduce the young Argentinian. Miss Argerich, an attractive young woman with long black hair and all the temperament she needs to be a popular success, also owns a big technique, extraordinary power and a sensitive musical mind.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 A short, middle-aged minister with a thick Georgia accent appealed today to a Senate subcommittee to "strengthen, and not dilute or weaken the hardwon right to vote, represented by the Voting Rights Act of 1965."
A jury found two businessmen guilty yesterday of swindling the New York Telephone Company by making $146,000 worth of long-distance calls on a credit card and not paying the bills.

IF you're fashionably paranoiac and willing to believe that the whole world is plugged into a tape recorder, you'll have a zippy time with Lawrence Sanders's first novel, "The Anderson Tapes." For Mr. Sanders has given us a hero with the makings of charisma, an intriguing sex life, and an audacious plan.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Superior Court Judge Frank J. Kingfield today dismissed criminal charges brought against Gov. William T. Cahill and his secretary of state, Paul J. Sherwin, for filing false reports on election expenditures. Auto Tires to Be Recalled
Three persons were killed and at least 11 injured in a two-alarm fire that swept through a Harlem apartment building last night and early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission proposed today that the fees broadcasters pay for licenses, applications and other services be increased 500 per cent in the next fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The National Guard is about to embark upon a program aimed at attracting a greater number of experienced soldiers and cutting back the acceptance of untrained volunteers.

In September, the networks assert, television's new entertainments will pay more attention to reality and social awareness. Until then, for the rest of this winter, into the spring and through the summer, the country's 59 million television homes will watch, and rewatch, remainders and repeats of the current season's fantasies as well as some freshly turned out retreads and replacements.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb.19 A further intensification of Arab anger against the United States has been evoked by President Nixon's statement yesterday on the Middle East.
YUMA, Ariz., Feb,. 19 Dave Campbell says he doesn't know anything about the latest controversy swirling around Denny McLain, but he does know something about McLain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The Pentagon is keeping secret its plans to cut back drastically, for economy reasons, its readiness to resume atmospheric testing of nuclear weapons if the Russians violate the test ban treaty.

Red Skelton, who on Wednesday was released by the Columbia Broadcasting System from his hour-long show next season, was signed yesterday by the National Broadcasting company to do a half-hour show at 7:30 P.M. Mondays. He will precede N.B.C.'s "Laugh In" and its Monday night movie.

A meeting of the heads of Government of East and West Germany in Berlin next month now seems assured. The mere fact of such a dramatic meeting first of its kind since the division of Germany in the aftermath of World War II will be more significant than any probable early results. It will represent a considerable success for the courageous new departure in West German foreign policy under Chancellor Willy Brandt.
This week's pronounced decline in interest rates continued yesterday, and the yield on a new high-grade utility bond issue was pushed down to 8.40 per cent, the lowest since last October.

The city's rent control law will probably be temporarily extended to give the administration and the City Council time to study two pending housing reports before taking final action on the law later this spring, it was disclosed yesterday. The law is scheduled to expire March 31.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 Pride and disquiet in about equal proportion seemed to characterize Japanese reaction to President Nixon's report on the state of the world, which called for "creative partnership" with all Asian nations and said Japan had "a unique and essential role to play in the development of the new Asia."
WASHINGTON Feb. 19 Governor Rockefeller urged Congress today to keep channeling Federal anticrime funds through the states to local governments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 For eight years the Federal Government has been struggling to develop effective programs for training the chronic unemployed, high school dropouts, welfare mothers and other unskilled persons for jobs in private industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Those Prussian-style helmets that helped give White House policemen a new "palace guard" look have been scrapped.

J. Robert Guy, a general agent of Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company from 1949 until his retirement in 1968, died here Wednesday. He was 65 years old and lived at Dawn Harbor Lane, Riverside. Old Greenwich, Conn.

Eugene H. Nickerson, Nassau County Executive, said yesterday that he would investigate county contracts awarded over the last three years to a concern headed by a man who resigned from the county government five years ago.

On the last Sunday in January, one of the creative directors at Dancer-FitzgeraldSample was quoted here as saying that a lone person with the title of creative director at a major agency could only be a "figurehead."

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. Jim Schaap is a long-distance truck driver with bad teeth. It will cost $1,200 to get them fixed, but the finance company wants 12 per cent interest to lend him the money and he cannot afford it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Newburger Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, based in Philadelphia agreed today to a 10-day suspension from doing most types of institutional business and business on the Philadelphia-Baltimore-Washington Stock Exchange.

SPELLED backwards, Waldaba is a bad law. But when State Senator Waldaba Hamilton Stewart is asked if he spends his time being teased about the irony of a legislator having such a name, he smiles and says in his soft Panamanian accent, ...

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 19 Ion Tiriac lost tonight and the National open indoor tennis championships lost half of its stellar attraction. Roger Taylor of England beat Tiriac, 11-9, 61, and advanced to the semifinals where he'll meet the other half of the Rumanian partnership, Ilie Nastase.
LAGOS, Feb. 19 (AP) Relief teams report that they are being deluged by more than three million hungry refugees as they advance into the jungle area of the former state of Biafra.
Stock prices continued to rally in early trading yesterday, but the advance faltered later in the session. Closing prices were still on the upside but well below the highest levels of the day.
Ossie Davis and his wife, Ruby Dee, stars of the stage, screen and television, will receive the Frederick Douglass Awards at the fifth annual dinner sponsored by the New York Urban League.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 In a tempestuous game, the New York Rangers salvaged a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings tonight on third-period goals by Bob Nevin and Vic Hadfield after having lost their most tempestuous performer, Brad Park, with an ankle injury in the opening period.
Layoffs and possible plant closings were announced yesterday in a variety of major industries across the country.

The Association of Stock Exchange Firms, representing 513 of the member organizations of the New York Stock Exchange issued a qualified endorsement yesterday of the new commission-rate plan proposed by the exchange.

The United States Public Health Service opened a new outpatient clinic for leprosy here yesterday. The new facility, in a building at 245 Houston Street, is the fourth in the city to treat the estimated total of 100 New Yorkers who have the disease.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Andrew Wyeth, the American artist who represents unofficially a vast silent majority of his countrymen who know what they like, was a guest of the President and Mrs. Nixon at the White House today. Tomorrow an exhibition of 21 of his paintings, the first one-man show in the history of the White House, will open to the public in the East Room.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 The Soviet Union today greeted with scorn President Nixon's foreign-policy message and leveled particular criticism at his comments on Vietnam and the Middle East.

DALLAS, Feb. 19 (AP) Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., said today that it would sell its interest in Braniff Airways, Inc., and the Okonite Company so it might retain control of the Jones Laughlin Steel Company.
Pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places were halted yesterday by a disturbance caused largely by white college students.

DALLAS, Feb. 19 (AP) Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., said today that it would sell its interest in Braniff Airways, Inc., and the Okonite Company so it might retain control of the Jones Laughlin Steel Company.

BEFORE midnight next Wednesday a Little League baseball team in Vancouver, O'Doul's Angels, will be properly financed for the coming season. Up to a couple of months ago, the freespending Lefty O'Doul had always staked the little cherubs himself. But when a heart attack ook away the popular Lefty at the age of 72, there suddenly was a heavenly scratch for money.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 19 Leaders of the Student Government at Syracuse University directed a four-hour occupation of the Administration Building today. Forcing the chancellor to agree to an advisory referendum on the future of the Reserve Officers Training Corps on campus.
Jules Munshin, the film, stage and television comedian, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 270 West End Avenue. He would have been 55 years old on Sunday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (Reuters) American military authorities today dropped Bangkok as a vacation center for United States troops after the Thai Government had decided not to renew the needed airline landing rights.

THE George Washington Birthday Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel with a full roster of events spread over four days in the following schedule:
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI) Opening Bid scored her fifth straight victory by racing to a two-length victory today in the $31,650 Santa Ynez Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Santa Anita.

Youth Conference. Mr. Nixon selected Walter L. Mazan, Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs at the Department of Transportation, to direct the intergovernmental activities of the White House Conference on Children and Youth. Mr. Mazan, 48 years old, lives in Arlington, Va.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 19 Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived in Lagos today anxious to smooth relations with Nigeria and to assure the Nigerian Government that the United States would respect its wishes in efforts to get relief to victims of the Nigerian civil war.
Earnings of the General Electric Company plunged 85 per cent in 1969's fourth quarter, reflecting a 14-week strike. As a result, the full-year profit was down 22 per cent from the 1968 level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 After 13 months of study and "some confusion," a national program for voluntary action to which President Nixon gave fervent support in the 1968 campaign formally gets under way tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (AP) United States B-52's continued attacks against suspected North Vietnamese supply depots in eastern Laos today, but some of the bombers were diverted for strikes against targets in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy told Congress today that the backlog of demand for credit was so large that he "would not expect major declines in interest rates," despite the softening of the economy.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 19 Slowly but inevitably, the development techniques successful in other sport are making their way into baseball. For the New York Yankees this spring, Manager Ralph Houk has installed a daily halfhour "skull session" preceding field practice a type of squad indoctrination common in football and basketball but rare in baseball.
Four candidates for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate agreed last night that the curbing of nar cotics traffic and addiction constituted a top-priority national social problem.
MANILA, Feb. 19 (AP) Mitsutaka Kono of Japan posted a two-under-par 70 today for the first-round lead in the Philippine open golf championship.

ONE is persuaded by President Nixon's declaration of war on environmental degradation and by an everincreasing public concern and understanding of the threat it poses to our survival that there is reasonable cause for optimism.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Penguins scored three first-period goals, two of them by Bryan Hextall, and coasted to a 6-1 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Kings.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Feb. 19 Czechoslovakia's thirdranking diplomat at the United Nations, Jiri Mladek, was in hiding today with his family after having been granted asylum by the United States.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 Efforts to resolve the railroad shopcraft dispute broke down tonight, raising new uncertainties about the possibility of a strike or a lockout on the nation's railroads.

Ozark, Ala., Feb. 20 (AP) A missing 4-month-old girl, who needed medication for epilepsy three times a day to live, was found alive and aparently well tonight, more than a day after her mother reported her missing.
IS the brokerage community unwilling to speak out in favor of the new commission schedule?
Representative Allard K. Lowenstein charged yesterday that the Federal Aviation Administration had "not the slightest intention of doing anything to relieve the nightmare of noise."
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 (AP) The St. Louis football Cardinals rehired Coach Charlie Winner today for one year. His two previous contracts had been for two-year terms.
DETROIT, Feb. 20 (AP) United States auto production surged upward as the auto industry scheduled 164,857 new cars for assembly this week, up from 95,433 last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The Administration is going to ask Congress to authorize the expenditure of up to $300-million to forestall what it fears could be a dramatic drop in the flow of money into mortgages.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 20 South African security police were accused today of assaults, threats and torture by 22 Africans being held for interrogation.
SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20 (AP) Lee Evans streaked to a world record time of 54.5 seconds in the 500-yard run tonight in the San Diego Indoor Games.

The New York Chapter of the American Jewish Committee disassociated itself yesterday from a call by the Coalition for an Effective Community School System for the suspension of the scheduled March 19 local school board elections throughout the city.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 The Russian Orthodox Church has decided to permit its priests to administer sacraments to Roman Catholics.
Senator Barry M. Goldwater told a college audience here yesterday that the current generation of young people was the best he had ever known.

Assemblyman Charles B. Rangel charged yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell had "failed the Harlem of today" and said he would oppose the Congressman for the Democratic nomination in the 18th District.

Leaders of the city's major landlord groups yesterday assailed suggestions by City Council members that the rent control law be extended until the lawmakers receive and study two pending reports on the housing situation here. The current law expires March 31.

EUREKA, Calif., Feb. 20 (UPI) A barge loaded with 2.5 millions gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel collided with a jetty in Humboldt Bay today and spilled 84,000 gallons into a flammable, floating slick 300 yards long.
The New Yorker magazine, which observes its 45th birthday today without fanfare, had a little fun yesterday with Mayor Lindsay at City Hall.
LUCAYA, Grand Bahama Island, Feb. 20 In a duel that rival yachtsmen found hard to believe, Windward Passage beat Ondine across the finish line in the 104-mile Miami-toLucaya race today by 24 seconds.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 20 Dr. and Mrs. Irving Applebaum have announced that their daughter, Miss Beth Toni Applebaum, and Richard Greenwald Marcus will be married in June. The future bridegroom is the son of Robert G. Marcus, board chairman of the American Biltrite Rubber Company in Chelsea, Mass., and Mrs. Marcus of Trenton. Dr. Applebaum, who is retired, was formerly president and chief of medicine at the Beth Israel Hospital in Newark.

The Modern Rock Quartet, or MRQ as it prefers to be called, is providing a lesson in basic musical power. The group, from Ottawa, is playing through tomorrow at the Electric Circus, 23 St. Marks Place.
Nicholas E. Crane has been named vice president and manager of the option department of Hayden, Stone, Inc. He formerly held similar posts with Dean Witter Co., Inc.
A substantial volume of new security offerings was announced yesterday by Federal agencies, states and corporations.

Dr. Edward J. Donovan, former president of the New York Academy of Medicine and former director of surgery at St. Luke's Hospital Center, died Thursday here. He was 80 years old and lived at 510 East 23d Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The marriage of Miss Madelyn Jamison to Lewis M. Holmes, a physicist with the Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., took place here today. Judge E.A. Beard of the General Sessions Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20 Sylvan Hoffman, a publisher and editor, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 78 years old and had moved here in 1964 from New Rochelle, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Following are excerpts from the introductory summary of the annual defense report to Congress by the Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) Judge Howard Corcoran extended a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court today, postponing until midnight March 2 a threatened shutdown of the United States railway system.

Higher interest rates for temporary loans have cost the city an unanticipated $20-million and have renewed pessimism that the current $6.6-billion budget can be balanced by the end of the fiscal year on June 30.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 The Chicago Black Hawks obtained Bill White, an experienced defenseman, and Gerry Desjardin, a goaltender, today in a sixplayer National Hockey League, trade that dispatched Gilles Marotte, a defenseman, and Dennis DeJordy, a goaltender, to the Los Angeles Kings.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 Cook County Hospital began restricting admissions to "life-threatening" emergency situations last night because of overcrowding and shortage of personnel.

FRANKLIN, Ind., Feb. 20 Brig. Gen. James Freese, U.S.A.R., assistant commanding general of the Army Reserve's 70th Division in Detroit, and Mrs. Freese have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Susan Freese of New York, to John William Holt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Holt of Pearl River, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July at the First Presbyterian Church in Edinburg.

The M.W. Kellogg Company, a major engineering and construction organization for the oil and petrochemical industries, will move its headquarters from New York City to Houston, it was announced yesterday.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 20 Last week at the Dartmouth Winter Carnival, Coach Ralph Townsend of Williams looked at the hard surfaces on the Big Green's Skiway slopes and said jokingly:

London, Feb. 20 To complete this week's set of basic West End horrors, James Elward comes forward with "Best of Friends." The play at the Strand Theater, is an American family comedy with its heart firmly lodged in the Brooklyn Heights mansion where Nigel Patrick and Siobhan McKenna are reunited after the storms of life to rediscover the virtues of marriage.

WARSAW, Feb. 20 (AP) In a meeting described as useful and businesslike, the United States and Chinese Communist envoys in Warsaw conducted today the 136th session of their 15year-old ambassadorial talks.

Aetna Life and Casualty and the Travelers Corporation the nation's two largest shareholder-owned insurance companies reported 1969 earnings yesterday, with Aetna showing a sharp decline and Travelers showing a substantial gain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) President Nixon said today he would nominate Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, to be a member of the board of directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

One of the high points of the Newport Folk Festival last summer was the fiddle duets of two Swedes, Ole Hjorth and Bjorn Stabi. Their performances so captivated Israel Young, the guru of Greenwich Village's Folklore Center at 321 Sixth Avenue that he closed up his shop in November and went off to Sweden for an extended vacation.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 20 This country's oil, which has long heated millions of homes in the northeastern United States, is now causing a marked cooling in diplomatic relations between Washington and Caracas.
G.W. Huldrum Jr., an executive of the Shell Oil Company in New York, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 53 years old, and lived in New York.

The New York Knickerbockers enter tonight's game against the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden with an impressive enough lead (seven games before last night's action) to allow them the luxury of a bit of a letdown in the final 17 games. With 52 victories in 65 games, the aim from now until the end of the schedule on March 22 will be to get ready for the playoffs.
Commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade reacted sharply to several international and domestic events yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 More than three dozen Congressmen, former military officers, professors and other war critics met today to discuss American involvement in Vietnam in a two-day conference on war and national responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Soviet missile build-up, if it continued at its current pace, could place the United States "in a secondrate strategic position" by the middle of this decade.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20 (UPI) Jim McAndrew became the first casualty of the New York Mets' training camp when the pitcher twisted his left knee while coming off the mound today on a routine play to cover first base.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Gordon B. Turner have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michael Ann S. Turner, to Paul S. Walstad. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel. O. Walstad. A wedding in the summer is planned.
Contemporary music reached some sort of desperate nadir last night as the Musica Elettronica Viva displayed its wares at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Treasury bill rates advanced slightly at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

The second round of secret Sino-American talks this year took place in Warsaw yesterday as scheduled. Since both nations' representatives referred afterward to plans for holding additional meetings, it can be assumed that these latest talks went reasonably well even though there is understandable silence on the specifics.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 20 Anne Morrow Lindbergh, the author and conservationist, took an apprehensive look at the planet earth today, but found some hope for it if mankind can develop what she called "earth values."

A policeman on a lone foot patrol on Lenox Avenue at 136th Street in Harlem was stabbed with a 10 -inch bowie knife at 12:45 A.M. yesterday by an assailant who stole up on him, plunged the knife into his back and fled.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20 Cline B. Stephens Jr., who resigned yesterday as City Controller of Yonkers, was indicted by a grand jury here today on charges of having appropriated city funds for his own use.
Columbia, which has some of the fastest basketball players in the East, went into high gear last night and ran Dartmouth ragged to post a 107-74 victory at University Hall.

For four years a small group in the House of Representatives has been making it impossible to deal effectively with oil pollution originating from ships at sea. Since the wreck of the Torrey Canyon first focused public attention on the menace, a series of such incidents has afflicted the coastal areas of the world.

Samuel J. Melville, one of four defendants charged with a series of crimes involving the bombing of Government buildings and vehicles here last fall, faces possible contempt-ofcourt charges after calling a Federal judge a jackass yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 20 David Windsor Mitchell, executive vice president of Avon Products, Inc., in New York, and Mrs. Mitchell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Anne Mitchell, to William Burlee Zeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Zeller of Darien.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20 Dr. Joao Cafe Filho, a former President of Brazil, died of a heart attack here today. He was 71 years old.

Rich Garner, the sophomore who came off the bench to figure prominently in four Manhattan College victories, will make his first start today when the Jaspers meet Fairfield in the first game of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

AN unusual exhibition match will be played tonight at the New York Hilton Hotel about 11:30 o'clock following completion of the Open Pair Championship at the Greater New York Bridge Association's Tournament.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 21 (AP) American troops clashed with North Vietnamese forces for the second time in eight days in the Queson Valley area south of Danang, the United States command said today. It reported that four Americans had been killed and 28 wounded.
BOSTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) Attorney General Robert H. Quinn was granted permission today by the Suffolk Superior Court to review the secret documents in the Mary Jo Kopechne inquest.
For the second session in a row, the American Stock Exchange's index closed unchanged yesterday. The steadying point was 25.63. During the week the index moved as high as 25.89 and as low as 25.34.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 The New York State Conservation Council warned today against "hasty action" on Governor Rockefeller's plan to create a department of environmental conservation.
NEWARK, Feb. 20 United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey disclosed today that he and his family had been threatened with violence during his investigation of organized crime in New Jersey.

Richard Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos" will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera for the first time in six years in a performance to be given on March 12 (during the 11th week of its season. The title role will be taken by Leonie Rysanek, Reri Grist will be Zerbinetta, Evelyn Lear will be the Composer, and Walter Berry will be the Music Master. Karl Bohm will conduct.
SANTA ANA, Calif., Feb. 20 (AP) Timothy Leary, his wife and son were convicted last night of possession of marijuana on Dec. 26, 1968.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20 Julius F. Klein Jr., a Long Island racketeer, and his father and a tihrd defendant were found not guilty today of having kidnapped and extorted $175,000 from the president of a Suffolk County plastics company in 1967.

ROME, Feb. 20 (AP) James Matthew Joseph Pringle, the Associated Press photographer known for his pictures of war action and revolutions, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 51 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

Ralph Leclerq Roeder, author of "Benito Juarez and His Mexico," died in Mexico City last Oct. 22, according to word received here from the American Consulate by The Viking Press, his publisher. He was 79 years old.
The Morton Salt Company, a subsidiary of Morton-Norwich Products, Inc., announced yesterday it would raise prices of salt and salt-based products by 5 to 7 per cent, effective April 1.
ENGLISH and Irish early 19th-century cut glass should prove a fruitful field for collectors seeking new objectives.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20 Four players scored in double figures for Pennsylvania tonight as the Ivy League leaders defeated Yale, 87-71.

The oil industry and its supporters reacted favorably if not almost joyously to President Nixon's announcement that he would take no immediate action to implement majority recommendations of his special Cabinet committee on oil-import policy.

Surrogate Christopher C. McGrath of the Bronx has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Kathleen Helen McGrath, to Paul Arthur Cunnion, sales manager of the food importing concern of Calvert Vavasseur Co.

WHEN Mary Lee Fairbanks tried to beg off going to Noel Coward's 70th birthday party recently because she was tired from a round-the-world trip and felt she looked a mess, Mr. Coward comforted her with: "Don't worry, they'll only be looking at me, anyway."'

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The United States has formally apologized to the Cambodian Government and has provided payments totaling $11,400 for 35 persons killed or wounded last Nov. 16-17 in air strikes directed at Vietcong positions in Cambodia, the State Department reported today.
Two businessmen, one white and one black, rejected today the contention by some that "black capitalism" holds little prospect for the economic advancement of the American Negro.

THESE days it's a moot point as to which comes first, the dress or the accessories. There is such an abun dance of good-looking jewelry and belts that many women are reversing the traditional practice and buying dresses that set accessories off to the best advantages. The newest accessories are divided into three categories primitive, casual and a kind of throw.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, canceled orders today requiring written, detailed reports on all contacts between newsmen and officials of the National Institute of Mental Health.
ATLANTA, Feb. 20 Judge G. Harrold Carswell, President Nixon's nominee to the Supreme Court, chartered an allwhite booster club for Florida State University in 1953.

LONDON, Feb. 20 In this country, courts are treated as temples of order and tradition, detached from the noise of life. The notion of using them as a forum for social protest would be utterly unacceptable. Some Welsh students who tried a rather tepid demonstration in a courtroom the other day found themselves in jail before the day ended.

The coin collector may find refuge and prizes in a special area devoted to his specialty, while the photography buff may be attracted by the prints and other relics of an earlier day of camera art.

There is no disputing Premier Sato's prediction the other day that the 1970's will be "an era where Japan's national power will carry unprecedented weight in world affairs." At the turn of the decade, the industrious Japanese have achieved a gross national product aproaching $200 billion, third highest in the world. At present growth rates, Japan confidently expects to reach a $600-billion economy by 1980.
Another death of a teen-ager caused by heroin the 33d this year and the arrest of four more alleged suppliers of heroin to school children were recorded in the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation reported today a net income for 1969 of $7,129,000, or 71 cents a share. The 1968 net income was $6,841,000, or 68 cents a share.

The task force report -the first Cabinet-level study of the oil-import quota system since its inception in 1959-was submitted to me by Chairman Shultz on Feb. 9.

Mrs. Margaret Hitchcock Scarrone, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Hitchcock, and the late Mr. Hitchcock, the polo player, was married in Tucson. Ariz., on Dec. 31 to Walter H. Bowart, the artist who founded The East Village Other.

CHEESE-FILLED dumplings are an Old World treat that can bring variety to contemporary meals. In the menu below they are teamed with a simple veal dish but would be equally good with roast veal, lamb or boiled beef.

Federal Judge Julius Hoffman brought down the curtain on the dismal Chicago conspiracy trial with sentences which can only be explained as an act of personal vindictiveness. The F.W. Woolworth Company, the variety-store chain, disclosed yesterday in a preliminary report that net income for 1969 rose slightly to $70,658,455, or $2.32 a share, from $70,466,739, or $2.31 a share, in 1968, assuming no dilution in both years. James H. McGraw Jr., the former president and chairman of the board of McGraw-Hill, Inc., died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 31 East 79th Street.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange again slipped to low levels for the year yesterday.

ATHENS--The record 1.3 million vacationists in Greece last year almost caught the natives napping. Disheartened by a two-year slump in tourism, they had neglected to expand their facilities rapidly enough, and now they are trying to catch up with what may well be a tourist explosion this year of 1.6 million visitors.

In much the way devoted conservationists read the seasons and the health of the environment in the behavior of birds, she picks up ecological signals from life on the Mill River in Fairfield, Conn. Observation is easy for Mrs. Shaw because, with her husband and two children, she lives in the old mill house overlooking Perry's Dam and what is left of the mill pend.

VARDEN, whose death in New York last month left the photographic industry be reaved of one of its most valued mentors, had that rare combination of qualities that attracted people to him as well for his thorough technological gifts as for his fun-loving personality. WASHINGTON--A recent Secretary of Defense, so the story goes, once asked the State Department to provide him with the Government's foreign policy in the Middle East. After four months of silence he grew mildly impatient, drew up his own policy statement, submitted it to State and--after another, shorter wait--got back a grudging approval.

With production costs for fourcolor illustration soaring apace, the hand-me-down art book is getting to be an increasingly common phenomenon. Simply defined, the hand-medown, or retread, is a volume made up of previously published components that have been altered slightly, more or less to fit a readership for which they weren't originally tailored.

CHICAGO--Before the trial of the Chicago 7 ended last week with the conviction of the Out of State 5, Judge Julius Hoffman left no doubt that he understood the offense vaguely called "contempt of court" as including disdainful attitudes toward his court "and our judicial system:" Interpreted literally-- and Judge Hoffman's interpretation is not without precedent --contempt of court takes on the peculiar character of outlawing a state of mind.

TOKYO--This is The Year of the Dog in the East. But in Japan, 1970 undoubtedly will be known as The Year of the Tourist. Expo is not only the first world's fair to be held in Asia, but it also is billed as the biggest and most expensive world's fair ever.

In an era of lunar exploration, it seems anachronistic that such an old--and curable--disease as tuberculosis could break out in the halls of Congress. But such was the case last week. Two persons were dead of TB and four other cases were known among persons working on Capitol Hill. The outbreak was traced to a woman who had worked in the Senate restaurant.

IN THE current climate of art, esthetics, and critical opinion, the sculpture of Mary Frank is difficult to place. It seems, by most of the prevailing standards, to exist outside of contemporary art history altogether. It derives from no clearly defined intellectual position. It invokes no sweeping historical imperatives. Theories of any sort seem alien to its purposes.
Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey last night termed "deplorable" the criminal contempt sentencing of the Chicago conspiracy trial defendants and their lawyers.
Dr. Gerald M. Henderson, an associate professor of anthropology at Brooklyn College, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack in his home at 367 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 42 years old.

MARTIN DUBERMAN, that latter-day Proteus who teaches history at Princeton, writes assorted philosophical essays for magazines, reviews the drama for Show magazine and fashions theater works such as "In White America" and the recently cordially received, if not exactly successful "Memory Bank" has another script in the offing.
YUMA, Ariz., Feb. 21--Preston Gomez remembers 1959. He was something of a hero in Cuba that year. So was Fidel Castro.

EAST BERLIN, Feb. 21 (Reuters)--The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko is to visit East Berlin within the next few days for what observers believe will be discussions on the proposed meeting next month between the Premiers of East and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21-- President Nixon's plan to provide income maintenance for 10 million working poor is expected to clear its first--and largest--Congressional hurdle next week by winning the approval of the House Ways and Means Committee.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21--The General Motors Corporation will test next fall whether the public is willing to accept some inconvenience and possibly a little cost for a cleaner atmosphere.

I SPENT last winter at the University of California at Berkeley. I'd been invited by the English Department to teach some writing courses during the winter quarter to a group of students almost all of whom were working for teacher's credentials. I lived in the faculty club on campus and was therefore very close to, though not very actively involved in, the student strike and the uprisings and riots that followed it.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Feb. 21--Miss Sue Kessler, registrar of the New York Cultural Center (the former Gallery of Modern Art), and Stuart P. Feld, a partner in Hirschl and Adler Galleries in New York, plan to be married March 29.

Six major soccer teams in the area will resume outdoor action today, after two weeks of indoor activity and three weeks of postponements because of bad weather. The German-Hungarians will tackle the New York Ukrainians in the New York semi-final for the United States Challenge Cup, while the Greek-Americans will meet New York Hungaria and Elizabeth will oppose Kingston for the German-American League title.

Wagner College, behind the 45-point scoring of Ray Hodge, upset Hartwick College of Oneonta, N.Y., 103-92, last night at Sutter Gymnasium, Staten Island. Hartwick, New York State's second-ranked team, was stopped in its bid for its 10th straight victory.

NOROTON, Conn., Feb. 21 --Miss Sandra Conti London, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard John London of Wilton, was married here this afternoon to Christopher Francis McGratty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lee McGratty of Islip, L.I. The Rev. Michael F. Blanchard performed the ceremony in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

The engagement of Miss Joan S. Elbaum, chief legal counsel to the Mayor's Commission to the United Nations, to Harold Lewis Gordon, a lawyer who is vice president of Arthur Gordon Associates, Inc., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Elbaum of Forest Hills, Queens.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 (UPI)--Howard Porter scored 24 points and pulled down 24 rebounds tonight to pace Vilanova to a 96-85 victory over La Salle.

Horatio Alger would never have made it in Rio Verde. In Moritz Thomsen's recounting of the complexities of his relationship with the people of that small Ecuadorian town we learn why.
THURMONT, Md., Feb. 21 (AP)--The Nixon family flew by helicopter today to Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Maryland mountains, to celebrate the 24th birthday of Tricia Nixon.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21 (AP)--Margaret Mead, the recipient of the American Education Award, believes that school superintendents should teach one class a day to help bridge the "generation gap."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 21 (AP)--Bobby Orr scored two goals and set up another tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 4-2, and moved into a first-place tie with the New York Rangers in the East Division.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 21--A North Vietnamese force hiding in hedgerows has ambushed a United States armored unit south of Danang, killing more Americans than in any single previous battle this year, military spokesmen said today.

ROME--Italy has been preoccupied with the automobile and its impact on tourism during the past year. On the one hand, it has been con structing new roads to speed vehicles; on the other, it has been creating new "autobans," or pedestrian islands, to provide a respite from escalating traffic.

BRITAIN will go on decimal currency next year, but to avoid pressures on stamp print ing, three high value stamps in the current Queen Elizabeth II definitive design will be issued June 17. In addition, "to pay" (postage due) labels will also be issued June 17 in high denominations in a new design. Current postage-due stamp designs have been unchanged since 1914.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 How many injuries would it take to cripple the best pitching staff in baseball?
Wide-ranging preparations are being made for viewing a March 7 total eclipse of the sun that United States astronomers expect to be "the eclipse of the century."

Archbishop Molloy won its 10th straight Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field title yesterday, but not before getting a real scare from St. Francis Prep.

Nicholas Johnson, a liberal member of the Federal Communications Commission, was chided yesterday by a topranking official of the Columbia Broadcasting System for allegedly supporting a double standard of Government intervention in the dissemination of news.

Installation of small green markers every tenth of a mile on major highways and parkways in the city will begin this year. The purpose is to help motorists specify where they are when calling for assistance in road emergencies. The markers will also aid in road research.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 Bill Colson of Princeton powered his way to the singles and a share of the doubles honors today in an indoor intercollegiate tennis tournament at Princeton University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, suggested today a constitutional amendment to eliminate the right of trial in some cases, such as the recent Chicago conspiracy trial.
The Citizens Buget Commission proposed yesterday that the city authorize rent increases that would be used specifically for "significant maintenance and renovation" of housing.
Three more deaths from heroin overdoses, including that of an 18-year-old West Side youth, were recorded in the city yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22 An Old English sheepdog, who is a candidate for top honors as often as not and comes through now and then, became best in show in the 53d event of the Elm City Kennel Club tonight.

GUATEMALA Feb. 22 The momentum of Guatemala's presidential campaign is so strong going into the final week before the voting on Sunday that fears have passed that lastminute terrorism can disrupt the election.
PARIS, Feb. 22 Israel is counting on a new preferential trade agreement with the European Economic Community to accelerate structural changes in her industry and lift earnings of foreign exchange.

Leslie Uggams is back in the familiar, friendly safety of a supper club after two bad Falls the Fall of 1969 when her television series, "The Leslie Uggams Show," was canceled, and the Fall of 1968 when "Her First Roman," the musical in which she starred with Richard Kiley, appeared very briefly on Broadway.
A Brooklyn woman was pushed down a flight of subway stairs in midtown yesterday by a purse-snatcher who was found to be carrying heroin.

AGAWAM, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP) Mary Ann Eisel Curtis of St. Louis and Esme Emmanuel of South Africa, last year's finalists, moved closer to a rematch for the singles title in the New England women's indoor tennis championships today by posting straight-set quarterfinal victories.

GREAT NECK ESTATES, L.I., Feb. 22 Several hundred Queens and Nassau residents gathered hope in their hearts and mud on their boots today at a colorful outdoor demonstration to protest the construction of a parking lot in the salt marsh in Udall's Cove.

IF THE dress and coat segments of the fashion in- dustry are perplexed about hemlines, the footwear chapters are certainly having their ups and downs. One ray of sunshine on a otherwise cloudy horizon is the demise of the ugly shoe.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 22 (Reuters) Jordan tonight expressed deep regret at yesterday's Swissair plane disaster but said it was unthinkable that it could have been an Arab act in any way.

A New York master, Andrew Soltis, won the recent Eastern experts championship, scoring, 4 , in the five-round Swiss system event. The tourney was limited to 26 players, all rated above 2,000. Second place went to 21-year-old Robin Spital, a graduate student at Cornell. He had a score of 4-1.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 22 The Thai Government announced today that rest and recreation flights for American troops from Saigon to Bangkok, suspended late last week after a Thai official notified Pan American Airways that landing rights would not be renewed, would be resumed within 10 days.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 Agreement was announced today between the Jordanian Government and the Palestine commando organizations over commando activities in Jordan.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 22 A group of East Coast artists who want to preserve the character of Charleston contributed their works to a weekend art auction that raised more than $11,000.
Financing activity in the international bond market is picking up this month, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reported in the current edition of its World Financial Markets publication.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Goldsmith of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Jane Goldsmith, to Geoffrey Scott Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Howard of New York, Chester, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) A twice-wounded and decorated soldier whose rifle was stolen in Vietnam was not only made to pay for it but was overcharged $60, Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, said today.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 22 (AP) Harold Matzner, a Wayne newspaper executive, and three other defendants were found not guilty today of the murder of Mrs. Judith Kavanaugh of Clifton.
Orders for machine tools, which suggest far before any other economic indicator how business men view the future in terms of production planning, got off to a faltering start with the New Year.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 22 The Carolina Cougars knew it was going to be their day when their uniforms arrived almost in time for the game today.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 22 Laotian Government forces, apparently having offered only light resistance to North Vietnamese attacks on the Plaine des Jarres yesterday, are reported to have regrouped in hill positions south and west of the plain.

The American Jewish Congress called on the United States Government yesterday to take the lead in a worldwide effort to discontinue all flights to Arab nations "as long as they continue to provide protection and support that make Arab terrorism possible."

Archbishop Molloy High School, the defending champion, gained the semifinal round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championship yesterday by defeating LaSalle Academy, 74-63, for its 20th straight victory. Brian Winters led the Stanners with 27 points in the game played at St. John's University.

Sun Ra and his merry crew, the Intergalactic Research Arkestra 18 instrumentalists dressed in glittering red or gold dashikis and jauntily pointed woolen caps along with three girls who danced, declaimed and sang swarmed through the Red Garter at 15 West Fourth Street yesterday. It was a nonstop concert that lasted more than two hours.
Francis J. Ludemann, chairman of the board of trustees of the Manhattan Savings Bank, has been elected a director of Savings Banks Trust Company.
Inspired by weather that made spring seem a possibility again this year, New Yorkers shed their winter boots and took to the parks and sidewalks with their dogs, children and bicycles yesterday.

The Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra opened its second American tour at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night with a salute to American music and the holiday weekend by performing Ives's "Washington's Birthday" as the first work of the evening.

JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Feb. 22 (AP) Ingrid Lafforgue beat Barbara Cochran of Richmond, Vt., in the women's slalom today and Alain Penz and Henri Brechu finished one, two in the men's as the French continued their domination of the Wild West Classic World Cup ski races.

STRBSKE PLESO, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 22 (AP) Kalevi Oikarainen of Finland won the 50-kilometer race (about 31 miles) as the Nordic world skiing championships ended today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 22 Cambodia has taken the unusual measure of insisting on examining all incoming and outgoing diplomatic pouches, apparently to forestall an attempt by three Communist-controlled governments to introduce large quantities of illegally held or counterfeit Cambodian currency.
The University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team received its annual instruction in losing Saturday night.
Arthur J. Goldberg closed the door again yesterday on renewed efforts to draft him as a Democratic candidate for Governor.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 22 Detectives ordered newspaper editors this weekend to withhold publication of articles dealing with the activities of the security police.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay called upon 1,700 union gravediggers yesterday to accept arbitration of their six-week-old strike.
Irwin S. (Doc) Guernsey, who taught social studies at De Witt Clinton High School for 44 years, died yesterday at his home, 8 Forster Parkway, Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 22 Ilie Nastase of Rumania continued his ascendancy toward stardom today by surging from the brink of defeat to beat Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., for the United States open indoor tennis championship. The scores were 6-8, 3-6, 6-4, 9-7, 6-0.

LONDON, Feb. 22 At least six European airlines temporarily suspended cargo flights to Israel today after yesterday's explosion and crash of a Swissair jet bound for Tel Aviv in which 47 persons were killed.

The last time Michael Rabin appeared at Hunter College, in 1952, he was a teen-age violinist with a fluid tone and a dazzling technique. When he returned there Saturday evening, deputizing for the indisposed Christian Ferras, he displayed those same qualities, along with the musical understanding that only artistic maturity can bring.
MANILA, Feb. 22 The Central Bank of the Philippines has adopted a floating rate for the peso as part of a sweeping program to restore the country's ailing economy.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Popick of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Frances Popick, to Dr. Douglas Roy Rosing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Rosing of Williamsville, N.Y.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 22 The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. called today for a federalized public welfare program with payments at a rate no lower than the poverty level.
BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 22 (AP) Gov. John J. McKeithen signed today a bill against forced transfer of students to achieve racial balance.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22 This city's athletic pride received a badly needed boost today when the Bullets, who had lost nine games in a row to the Knicks since last March 12, topped New York, 110-104, before a crowd of 9,068 at Civic Center.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 Governor Rockefeller said today he was sending to the Legislature tomorrow a bill to raise the state's minimum hourly wage from $1.60 to $1.85.

A five-point program to revive America's declining merchant marine has been proposed by a Clemson University maritime specialist.

Following is a weekly listing of the net asset value of closed-end investment fund shares as reported by the companies through the Association of Closed-End Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 22 The Petersham (Mass.) Curling Club rink, skipped by Edward Cetto, won the 15th annual invitation mixed bonspiel for the Wicks Trophy today.

MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 22 Secretary of State William P. Rogers ended a 15-day tour of 10 African nations today and expressed pleasure with its results.

ROME, Feb. 22 According to the officials at the Aeronautics Ministry who take the temperature of this city, the midday high at Rome's airport was 66 degrees. The sky, they reported, was "slightly cloudy."

ATLANTA, Feb. 22 The Commissioner of Internal Revenue warned today that tax avoidance could become "a game which is socially acceptable" because in some areas very few tax evaders are being sent to prison.

A 5-year-old string quartet often has developed quite enough individuality and temperament to rule its entire life. Andre Kostelanetz revived the Archibald MacLeish/Ezra Laderman collaboration "Magic Prison" for a special nonsubscription New York Philharmonic concert Saturday night at Philharmonic Hall. The work was given its premiere by Mr. Kostelanetz at a Promenade concert in June of 1967.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Two Democratic liberals in the Senate, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Birch Bayh of Indiana, are drafting a plan to use the Administration's voting rights bill as a legislative vehicle to reduce the voting age to 18.

DENMARK, S.C., Feb. 22 (AP) Two hundred and fifty National Guardsmen and law officers moved into predominantly Negro Voorhees College before dawn today to enforce a court order against unauthorized persons being on campus.

A Westchester housewife who invariably experienced frustration during shopping trips to New York City because she found it difficult to find convenient parking garages, has provided a solution for other motorists.
With only two experienced defensemen, the Rangers moved back into first place last night, posting their 1,000th career triumph in a 5-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 22 Louis A. Lemaire, former State Senator and real-estate promoter, died last night at the Courtland Gardens Convalescent Home in Stamford. He was 74 years old and lived on Old Lantern Road here.
Mrs. Emily Vanderbilt Sloane Hammond, a leader in philanthropic activities died yesterday in her home at 136 East 64th Street. She was 95 years old.

Frank Glazer's piano recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall left the listener full of respect for his intelligent musicianship and ability to give carefully reasoned, unaffected performances of 19th-century music. Mr. Glazer plays the piano most ably, although he had brief flurries of labored fingering in highly chromatic passages, and his taste in Brahms and Schubert ran toward the simple and noble.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 (UPI) The United States moved into the first and second positions today at the halfway mark of the Kennedy international bobsled competition.
CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 22 (AP) Prince Charles gave a preview of his talents as a stage comedian today and forgot his lines.
CARBONDALE, Ill., Feb. 22 Southern Illinois University at first glance seems a most unlikely magnet for antiwar militants.

BERGENFIELD, N.J., Feb. 22 Dr. Kazuo Yanagisawa, a physician for many years at Madison Square Garden whose successful surgery on a score of Ranger hockey players and Knickerbocker basketball players gained him national fame, died today in his home at 94 Ralph Street. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) A Democratic party panel called today for substantial increases in domestic programs and cuts in defense spending, asserting that the Nixon Administration's budget "can lead only to a dead end and national decay."
Fairfield University, not at all nervous playing before 4,627 fans, scored a 6-4 victory over Iona College yesterday in the first club hockey game played at the new Madison Square Garden.

The second annual International Symposium on the Automobile has selected Lord Stokes, chairman of the board and managing director of British Leyland Motors Corporation, to be its banquet speaker, at the Park-Sheraton Hotel, April 8.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 Anil Nayar, the defending titleholder from Boston, and Sam Howe of Haverford, Pa., runnerup last year, reached the final of the national squash racquets championship today at the University of Pennsylvania.

Listening to a Puccini concert of arias and duets, with one luscious throbbing tune following another, is rather like wolfing down a large plate of superbly prepared yet very rich Italian pastries. Such was the menu at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon as seven young singers and an orchestra led by Carlo Moresco presented familiar music from nine Puccini operas.

THE myth of Oedipus is as complex as the psychia- trists would have led us to believe. The new version of "Oedipus" by Anthony Sloan now being given by the Roundabout Theater, 307 West 26th Street, is described in the program as "a free adaptation of the ancient myth." But in this freedom it allows itself. I wonder whether it has not lost some quality of myth in the retelling.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 22 Puerto Rico's sugar industry, once the mainstay of the island's economy, is on the verge of collapse. Despite government attempts to bolster the industry, production of sugar have declined.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22 Judge David Stahl of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, was found dead in the garage of his home here yesterday. He was 49 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Nixon Administration plans to seek no specific agreements with France when President Pompidou arrives tomorrow. But it hopes to clarify a series of bothersome international problems. Above all, it hopes to avoid public unpleasantness.

The city is looking into the possibility of turning 42d and 53d Streets into pedestrian shopping malls during the noon- time hours, Transportation Administrator Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff said yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 South Vietnam's defense officials are planning a major shift of village-based professional soldiers into contested areas, leaving the defense of villages considered relatively secure to unpaid local militiamen and police.

SOMERS, Conn., Feb. 22 A Little Wrecked won the regular working hunter championship at the Shallowbrook horse show today, but his days as a fox chaser are numbered.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 (AP) The United States command reported today that three Americans had been killed and 22 wounded in four enemy attacks ranging from 35 miles north-northwest of Saigon to 44 miles south of Danang.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The State Department declined comment today on the temporary restrictions on diplomatic mail imposed by the Cambodian Government.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 22 (UPI) Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, was pelted with marshmallows by a group of hecklers as he defended Judge Julius Hoffman of the Chicago conspiracy trial, at a speech given here today at Drew University.
MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 22 Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minister, flew to Munich today under tight security precautions for the first official visit of an Israeli Cabinet member to West Germany.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 Miss Judith Barnett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Barnett of Birmingham, was married here today to Dr. Donald Bruce Vogel, a psychiatric resident at the Payne Whitney Clinic of New York Hospital. Rabbi Israel Halpern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Abraham.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22 There is still no sign of a major inventory correction in steel markets.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Feb. 22 The United States touring team finished on a strong note here last night by defeating a powerful local team.

Charles Abrams, the urban planner whose views have had a major effect on housing here and abroad, died of cancer in his home at 18 West 10th Street yesterday. He was 68 years old.
