Jean Wallace Miller, a graduate of Barnard College, in 1903 and permanent president of that class, died here Friday. She was 88 years old and lived at 28 East 10th Street.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, with its bright creative reputation, today has a new creative director Bob Levenson, a 40year-old with 11 years at the agency.

The mysterious effects of "wake turbulence" invisible, turbulent air currents trailing behind big jetliners could seriously limit the growth of the nation's air transport system during the next decade, according to a new Federal Aviation Administration 10year plan.

The State Thruway Authority has reduced the speed limit for trucks using the New England Thruway in Westchester County, effective today, to 50 miles an hour. The old limit which still applies for all other vehicles was 55 miles an hour from the New York City line to the New Rochelle toll barrier and then 60 to the Connecticut line.

Two dances of a simple rhythmic nature were presented by a group called Appearance at the Museum, 739 Broadway, on Saturday evening. The first, "The Disappearance," at least had the modest courage of its primitive movement convictions, but the second dribbled out of performer control almost as soon as it began.

Barely a year and a half ago, Congress established the North Cascades National Park in northern Washington State. Because of pressures from Seattle City Light, several scenic wilderness valleys were left out of the park. Now the motivation for this compromise has become clear.

SEATTLE, Feb. 22 (AP) Bob Rule scored 11 of his 30 points in the fourth quarter today as the Seattle SuperSonics held off a San Francisco Warrior rally for a 131-127 National Basketball Association victory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 "The house is yours," Presi- dent Nixon said tonight to the cast of "1776," which had just performed the first full-scale, full-length Broadway show ever presented at the White House and received a standing, shouting ovation. It was George Washington's 238th birthday, and so, quite appropriately, the production was Sherman Edwards's tale about the drafting of the Declaration of Independence.

PARIS, Feb. 22 Ten years after President Charles de Gaulle visited President Dwight D. Eisenhower in Washington and then spread excitement in a quick tour across the United States, his successor and political heir, Georges Pompidou is to undertake the same journey starting tomorrow.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 22 (UPI) Connie Dierking scored a career-high 45 points, 19 in the third quarter, in leading the Cincinnati Royals to a 136-116 victory tonight over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.

Jerome Kretchmer, who will become the city's Environmental Protection Administrator this spring, said yesterday that the agency would consider suing New Jersey to get full enforcement of that state's antipollution laws.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The New York Congressional delegation, long on numbers, has gotten the unhappy feeling that it is short on clout.
WILMINGTON, Vt. "There isn't a piece of land I own around here that hasn't doubled in value in the past two years."
BOSTON, Feb. 22 Massachusetts, which has seen almost all manner of hats tossed into its political ring, saw for the first time this weekend the biretta of a Roman Catholic priest added to the lot.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 Peter Goodwill Hamilton, the 1968 rookie of the year on the late-model stockcar circuit, won the Daytona 500 today in a bright blue wingtailed Plymouth.
WHEN Mrs. Diane Kind was a youngster growing up in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, she used to lie in bed at night and dream about becoming an actress or ballerina or prima donna.
GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 22 Gardon Gray and Jesse Sammis 3d of the home club successfully defended their laurels in the Greenwich platform tennis invitation tourney for the third straight year today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 22 (AP) Graeme Lawrence of New Zealand won the Tasman Cup auto race series today with a second-place finish to Niel Allen of Australia in the final race.

The Democratic Study Group has postponed very briefly its attempt to do something about the seniority system, which has for so long made committees of the House of Representatives a collection of principalities, each with its own maharajah.

Channel 13 plans to rebroadcast each week's programs of "Sesame Street," the experimental educational series for children between the ages of 3 and 5, on Saturdays from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. starting this week.

Miss Jane Penneys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Robert Penneys of Philadelphia and Miami Beach, was married here yesterday morning to Milton B. Melinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Melinger of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony in his tudy at Temple EmanuEl.

Air West, which is in the process of being acquired by Howard Hughes, announced this weekend in San Francisco that the sum of money to be available to shareholders from the sale has been "substantially" reduced.

A talent for imaginative program-building enabled Richard Fagan to come to Town Hall late Saturday afternoon with a list of works that gave his piano recital special appeal even though he himself did not play it all with the authority and poise it needed.

There are many Americans, including ourselves, who have the gravest misgivings about certain aspects of current French policy, especially France's recently announced sale of more than 100 jet warplanes to Libya. But it is grossly improper to use such policy differences as an excuse for failure to extend to President Georges Pompidou every official courtesy during his visit to this country which begins today.
MONTREAL, Feb. 22 (Canadian Press) Louis Rene Beaudoin, Speaker of the House of Commons from 1953 to 1957, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

The Penn Central's three commuter lines into and out of Grand Central Terminal will be known, starting tomorrow, as its Metropolitan Region and will be under the immediate supervision of James M. Loconto, a former New York Central official who returns as general manager for operations.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 22 Kerosene flare pots were thrown at a house occupied by 10 or 12 black women students of Cornell University and a car parked in front of it early today.
The National Committee for Labor Israel reported yesterday that it had raised $4,030,000 in the last five months for the health, educational and social welfare activities of Histadrut in Israel.

Twelve members of the Patriot party, a white militant group that supports the Black Panthers, were arrested last night at 674 West 161st Street after detectives observed weapons being unloaded from a car parked in front of that address.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The two major urban public interest groups will merge a week from today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 22 Communist China reported today that it, too, faced problems of industrial pollution, but it said that they were being solved by frugality and Maoist ingenuity.

The largest containership built in this country, the Hawaiian Enterprise, is headed for the West Coast to load her first cargo. The 34,700-displacement-ton vessel is designed to carry more than 1,000 24-foot containers.

The little White Elephant gathering that started life 31 years ago as a cocktail party and grew into a ball 13 years later wilt return to the Waldorf-Astoria on March 4 for the annual dinner dance in behalf of the Child Adoption Service of the Children's Aid Society.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 22 A trip from the Far West, just to compete in the annual Fred H. Harris Memorial Invitation Ski Jumping Tournament, paid off today for Peter Robes.

WEST ALLIS, Wis., Feb. 22 (Reuters) Soviet skaters dominated the international sprint speed-skating championships today by setting a world record of 44.58 seconds in the women's 500-meter race and taking two world titles.
The police searched yesterday for an unidentified gunman who fired six shots late Saturday night on the Harlem River Expressway near 174th Street at a radio car containing two patrolmen.
PARIS, Feb. 22 A cartoon in the Paris newspaper Le Figaro shows a cobbler daydreaming about transforming his establishment into a giant shoe factory.

After a particularly brutal hockey game, when a player would suffer more than the usual bruises, Dr. Yanagisawa, the only man allowed to smoke in the dressing room, would stroll in and talk to the injured, player.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 The depth of the present recession in the automobile industry is still unmeasured. Lee A Iacocco, president of the Ford Motor Company's automobile operations, said today in an interview at the Chicago Auto Show.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 22 The task of fielding a candidate against Michigan's strong and popular senior Senator, Philip A. Hart, has left the state's Republican party in turmoil.

VERBIER, Switzerland, Feb. 23(AP) Billy Kidd, who turned professional after the recent world championships in Italy, qualified today for the final races of what is billed as the first world pro ski championships with a $30,000 purse.

The University of California, Los Angeles, which was handed its worst basketball defeat in four seasons Saturday by Oregon, dropped to second place yesterday in the sports writers' poll, but remained the nation's top team in the coaches' voting.
ATHENS, Feb. 23 Traces of a large palace heavily damaged by fire some 3,200 years ago, have been discovered in the Greek town of Thebes.

SWIRLING up and aloft on yesterday's strong winds, over the streets and across the parks, went thousands of pieces of litter, papers, tissues, boxes and cardboard, creating a surrealistic vision of an urban maelstrom.
Eddie Shore, one of the greatest defensemen in hockey history, was named yesterday to receive the 1970 Lester Patrick Memorial Trophy.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 President Nixon is prepared to take "strong measures" to combat any major rise in unemployment, Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz reported today.

FOUR famous husbands were soundly defeated by their four famous wives in a short exhibition match played Saturday night at the New York Hilton. Edgar Kaplan, Victor Mitchell, Bill Passell and Mike Moss lost a six-deal match by 26 international match points to Betty Kaplan. Jacqui Mitchell, Marietta Passell and Gail Moss. This "proved," to the complete satisfaction of the wives, that women play better than men.

DENMARK, S.C., Feb. 23 (AP) National Guard troops patroled the Voorhees College campus today to prevent students from returning to the predominantly black school, which was closed indefinitely after a class boycott.

ATLANTA, Feb. 23 (AP) The American Bar Association rejected a plea from the Nixon Administration today and reaffirmed, by a margin of four votes, its opposition to a 21year-old treaty banning genocide.

PARIS, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Finance Ministers of the European Economic Community tonight reached broad agreement that 1980 should be the deadline for a common European currency, according to financial sources here.
SYRACUSE Some students at Syracuse University are finding they can trust and actually be friends with people over 30. And in this case the people are way over 30. In fact, their average age is 70.3.
In its first four weeks in passenger service, the Boeing 747 jumbo jet carried considerably more passengers than needed to make a profit, Pan American World Airways indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) John S.D. Eisenhower, the Ambassador to Belgium, has rejected the suggestion of some Pennsylvania Republicans that he run for the Senate against Senator Hugh Scott.

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 23 Dr. Elaine Weston Riordan, a physician who practiced here for more than 20 years and the wife of Dr. John P. Riordan, died yesterday at West Hudson Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 926 Bloomfield Avenue, Glen Ridge.
ATLANTA, Feb. 23 (AP) Gov. Lester G. Maddox signed into law today a bill to prevent the transfer of students and teachers to achieve racial balance in schools.
Seven simultaneous rallies in Queens next Sunday to express support for Israel were announced yesterday by the Queens Jewish Community Council.
The runner-up for the Ivy league basketball title Columbia or Pennsylvania will not be permitted to take part in the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden next month.

OLD-LINE school administrators regard the arrival of the lean, soft-spoken young man in their halls with apprehension. Some militants consider him a sell-out for trying to work within the established system. Many disaffected high school students think him foolish for trying...

Philip Roth, the novelist, and Duke Ellington, the jazz composer, are among 15 artists, writers and musicians who have been voted into the National Institute of Arts and Letters, the Congressionally chartered honor society for the arts.
MUNICH, West Germany, Feb. 23 "Munich radiated," Thomas Mann wrote after he had moved to this southern city, the-capital of Bavaria, from his native Lubeck, in the north, near the end of the century.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (UPI) Vodka prices have been quietly doubled in Moscow's restaurants in the latest move to reduce drunkenness.
PARIS, Feb. 23 President Georges Pompidou of France is going to the United States with hopes of attracting more American capital investment in France, his aides said today.
The stock market in Montreal scored a sharp advance in light trading, but declines outnumbered advances 229 to 198.
Robert L. Luening, a retired consulting engineer and administrator, died after a heart attack Feb. 16 at his home in Bucksport, Me. He was 75 years old.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 23 An American woman, was killed and two women were slightly wounded today when the bus on which they were making a tour of the Holy Land was raked by shots close to Hebron, in Israeli-occupied Jordan.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 23 One of King Hussein's most trusted cabinet ministers re signed today in what appeared to be an expression of disapproval over the agreement reached yesterday by the King with Palestinian commando groups.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 23 Premier Golda Meir warned today that Israel would not sit long with hands folded if Arab terrorists were permitted to continue to harass or destroy her civil aircraft and those of other countries carrying passengers or cargo to Israel.

It must be a solace to fanciers of violin music to see that, just as their noble instrument seems to be falling out of popular favor, an army of superior young players is coming forward, ready to put King Fiddle back on his throne. If the restoration succeeds, thanks will be owed in large part to Oriental countries, which have become breeding grounds for virtuosos in the last couple of decades.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The House Crime Committee proposed today putting strict limits on production of amphetamines, or "pep" pills.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, announced today that she would vote against the Supreme Court nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell.

WALTHAM, Mass., Feb. 23 Morris B. Abram, president of Brandeis University since 1968, resigned today so he would "be free to explore more completely the call from many quarters to run for the United States Senate."

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 23 A former convict, now paroled and studying for his doctorate at the New York State University School of Criminal Justice; was arraigned here yesterday on charges of possessing marijuana.
Louis Lane conducted the Cleveland Orchestra in a magnificent performance of Bruckner's Eighth Symphony last night at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Hubert H. Humphrey disclosed through a spokesman today that he had asked Lawrence F. O'Brien to leave his New York political public relations firm and return to the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 23 Britain's four big commercial banks have succumbed to public pressure and disclosed, for the first time, their so-called true profits and hidden reserves. Previously, the bank reported profits only after undisclosed transfers to secret "inner reserves."

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 23 Mr.and Mrs. Henry C. Pfaff of Summit and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Elissa Pfaff, to Edward Ellsberg Pollard, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Goldwin S. Pollard of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., and Southwest Harbor, Me.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 Governor Rockefeller signed a $30.7-million emergency mass transit loan bill today. The act is designed to improve maintenance on metropolitan area commuter railroads and New York City's subway system and to help upstate bus companies.

BEREA, Ky., Feb. 23 (AP) Dr. Willis D. Weatherford Sr., a long-time trustee of Berea College and a director of a major study of the Southern Appalachian region, died at Berea Hospital Saturday. He was 94 years old.

TWELVE years or so ago Brooks Atkinson looked at Broadway and wondered whether this was the complete theatrical story of New York. At that time he was right. Today I look at Broadway and Off Broadway, and I wonder whether I am seeing the whole picture. Perhaps our theater is always on the move; Perhaps we have to be as alert to the sidestreets of Broadway as to Broadway itself.

Marion Lippert, the German soprano who made a striking impression in her debut as Turandot in the Puccini opera last season at the Metropolitan Opera, has been widening her repertory with the company this year. She recently sang the Marschallin in "Der Rosenkavalier" and last night she took the part of Senta in "Der Fliegende Hollander" for the first time here.
NEWARK, Feb. 23 The teachers' strike that has crippled schools here for three weeks appeared near an end tonight.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 23 Mrs. Lenore Romney entered the Michigan Senate race today.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Feb. 23 Mr. and Mrs. James E. Beeson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Claudette F. Beeson, to Edwin C. Walton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton of Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y.
BOSTON, Feb. 23 Class attendance was off sharply at Boston University today as students began a two-day strike to protest what they call "political repression" at the uni versity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 President Pompidou was welcomed to the United States today by Vice President Agnew. The President, Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann, their wives and other members of the party landed in a chilly wind at Andrews Air Force base in Maryland after a flight from Paris aboard a French Air Force jet.
ST. PAUL, Feb. 23 (AP) Three major railroads and two smaller lines who will merge March 2 into Burlington Northern, Inc., have announced sites of six divisional headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Suddenly it seems that the great national turnaround symbolized in the Senate approval of the Stennis amendment means that the nation is to have a more sensible and publicly acceptable approach to providing equal educational opportunity.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Senator Robert W. Packwood, Republican of Oregon, proposed today that a family should only be allowed income tax relief for a maximum of three children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The Senate Democratic lead er, Mike Mansfield, urged the Senate today to pass a big education and welfare spending bill despite the threat of another veto by President Nixon.

LONDON, Feb. 23 Three tenors in three days is a bit much even for Leonard Bernstein. But that is what the conductor has faced in rehearsals, a public performance and then a recording of the Verdi Requiem here.

AMBLER, Pa., Feb. 23 The Right Rev. Robert L. DeWitt, Episcopal Bishop of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. DeWitt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathrina Anne DeWitt, to John Philip Kaiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Kaiser of Gwynedd Valley. A June wedding is planned.
HONG KONG, Tuesday, Feb. 24 Communist China charged the United States and Japan today with promoting a movement for the independence of Taiwan.
The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had prevailed upon two local bus companies not to raise their fares on runs between Manhattan and Jones Beach.

The striking union of gravediggers will be doing thousands of bereaved families a great service if it goes along today with the plea of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay that it submit all disputed issues in its six-week-old stoppage to binding arbitration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Wives of Republican members of the 88th Congress will present a huge quilt embroidered with signatures of their husbands to Mrs. Nixon Wednesday.
The New York Yankees took to the air yesterday to drum up enthusiasm for its baseball team. They've never started a pre-season promotion so early.
More Americans died on the nation's highways in 1969 than in any previous year.
CREEZY by Felicien Marceau. Translated from the French by Jim Underwood. 122 pp. Orion. $5.95.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 23 Switzerland imposed drastic restrictions on the admission of Arab travelers today. At the same time she called for an international emergency conference on air security, at which, it was indicated, she would propose that other countries adopt similar curbs.
BAVET, Cambodia, Feb. 21 The war in neighboring South Vietnam spills over into this neutral country in a variety of ways, some deadly, most corrupting.
A warning that efforts would be made to curb gambling in golf was issued yesterday by Philip Strubing, president of the United States Golf Association.
Bob Bass telephoned from Lubbock, Tex., yesterday to make the National Invitation Tournament committee aware of his Texas Tech basketball team's 13-8 won-lost record.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 The Soviet Union today ended a prolonged silence on the capability of its antimissile defenses by asserting that they could "reliably hit" attacking missiles at any height or speed and at great distances from defended targets.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 23 (AP) Strong winds and rough seas disabled two United States boats in today's heat in the world 5.5-Meter yachting championship.

DURHAM, N.H., Feb. 23 A mass resignation by all 17 department chairmen in the University of New Hampshire's College of Liberal Arts was withdrawn today after two days of discussion between the faculty and the university president.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 23 Clarence J. Schoo, founder and president of the General Fibre Box Company of West Springfield, died after a stroke at his home here last night. He was 85 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 The Senate passed an amendment to the school-lunch program today requiring the states to file plans detailing how they spent their Federal money and to report to the Agriculture Department monthly on the number of children being helped by the program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 It has become fashionable in weighty Government declarations nowadays to dwell at some length on the subjects of "national priorities" and "resource allocation." The reason is that everyone here worries about the competing claims of large military and nonmilitary ...
PORT HAWKESBURY, Nova Scotia Every few minutes a truck piled high with logs rumbles down Granville Street, past the Strait Printing and Publishing Co., Ltd.

A man returned to a Greenwich Village bar where he had once worked, the police said, pocketed the weekend receipts and set fire to the place early yesterday, only to be trapped by the fire in the basement. He was found unconscious by firemen and taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, where he was treated for smoke inhalation and detained as a prisoner.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Tommy Clark, a New York heavyweight, was beaten tonight by a 22-year-old Briton, Dan McAlinden. The referee stopped the bout at the end of the fifth round because of the battering the American had taken.
DUBUQUE, Iowa, Feb. 23 Women are distributing holy communion in the Archdiocese of Dubuque, the Roman Catholic diocese in northeast Iowa.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 23 (AP) Informed sources said today that the Indian Government had asked the United States to close its Information Agency libraries in five state capitals within 90 days.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 23? The unified command of Palestinian guerrilla organizations announced today that a thorough investigation had shown "beyond the shadow of a doubt" that none of the commando groups had anything to do with the Swiss Air disaster on Saturday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23 A tradition died here today when 24 women were served lunch in the Yankee Doodle Tap Room of the Nassau Inn, a room formerly open only to men during weekday luncheon hours.
Young militants and plainclothes policemen clashed in Criminal Court late yesterday during the arraignment of 12 persons arrested when a cache of weapons was seized in a raid Sunday night.

Angier St. George Biddle Duke, with roots in Biddle and Baker banking and Duke tobacco money, will marry Miss Janie Corry Lee, who owns an art gallery in Dallas, on April 4 in a ceremony at her home there.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 23 Lieut. Gov. John C. West formally announced his candidacy for Governor today and pledged to preserve public education.

When the Association of Producing Artists and the Phoenix producing organization dissolved their ties last spring, T. Edward Hambleton said that the Phoenix would go on. He was, he now freely acknowledges, "saying the usual courageous words you say in such circumstances."
ATLANTA, Feb. 23 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger threw his support today behind a proposal by the president of the American Bar Association for a major study of the nation's prison system.

ONLY Bethany Beardslee would have dreamed up the kind of program she sang last night in Tully, Hall, and only she could have so carried it off. Through the years she has been an exponent of contemporary music of the most advanced variety, but she also has sung more conventional material.

LAKE PLACID N.Y., Feb. 23 (AP) Harry Petersen gave the United States its first victory in international bobsled competition since 1959 by winning the four-man bobsled event in the Kennedy Memorial winter games today.

Moscow's announcement that Soviet physicists have created and identified nuclei of anti-helium calls attention again to the concept of anti-matter, one of the most eerie ideas in modern physics. Conventional, everyday matter on this planet consists of atoms made up of negative electrons and positive protons.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23 If you don't believe times have changed, consider the not-yet-official but possible holdout of Horace Clarke, regular second baseman of the New York Yankees.
Lincoln A. Werden, golf writer of The New York Times, was honored last night at the National Awards Dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers' Association at the Hotel Americana.

HARTFORD, Feb. 23 Republican Representative Thomas J. Meskill announced his candidacy for Governor today with an attack on the Democratic organization that has ruled Connecticut for the last 16 years.
Special incentives to car owners were proposed here yesterday to keep them, from adding to the curbside clutter of abandoned automobiles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Donald Rumsfeld has informed his employes at the antipoverty agency they can once again call poor people poor.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 23 Stanley H. Fryczynski, who was elected City Commissioner at the age of 65 and served three four-year terms, died yesterday in his home at 32 East 34th Street here. He was 84 years old.
PHOENIX "Mommy," says a local 2-year-old when ever he sees, a vacant lot, what are they going to build there?"
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 23 Ralph G. Caso, Presiding Supervisor of Hempstead, announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Representative David A. Pryor is only 35 years old, but has spent much time in nursing homes for the aged as a nurse's aide helping patients and learning about their lives. What he learned sickened him and now he wants Congress to find out more about such places.
Six men were arrested early today in the theft of a truck containing television and radio sets and tape recorders valued at $1-million from a Brooklyn pier.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 23 (UPI) John Truett of England sailed Hucklebuck to her second straight victory today as British yachtsmen dominated the third heat of the 16yacht world Flying Dutchman Class championship.
RIO DE JANIERO, Feb. 23 (UPI) Should wives accompany their soccer star husbands on road trips?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Two of the Senate's leading Democratic defenders of the Safeguard program expressed reservations today about expansion of the missile defense system as now contemplated by the Administration.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 23 A Colombian Army general renowned for his victories against guerrillas has become a successful author with a novel about guerrilla war that condemns violence.

John Nuveen Co., the widely known bond dealer, announced yesterday that it was starting to trade in put and call options on Government bonds. A spokesman for the firm said that this was believed to be the first time that such an option market had been developed.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 Young men seeking fame and fortune with the New York Mets were warned today that the line forms on the right.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Eighteen per cent of the country's high school principals who responded to a Congressional questionnaire reported that their schools experienced "some form of student protest" in the 1968-69 school year. Only 1 per cent of the principals categorized their disturbances as "riots."
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 23 (AP) Dan Issel scored 47 points tonight as top-ranked Kentucky defeated Alabama, 98-89, and won its 25th Southeastern Conference basketball championship.
Three more deaths from acute reactions to heroin were reported here yesterday.
The United States showed the fourth highest increase in consumer prices between June, 1968, and June, 1969, in a study of 14 industrial countries
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) Two economists warned Congress today that the nation faces a recession unless the Nixon Administration's high interest rate policies were altered.

Oliver Rea, who for six years served as administrative director and president of the Minnesota Theater Company Foundation, which operates the Tyrone Guthrie Repertory Theater in Minneapolis, is "looking forward to a busy season off Broadway."

EAST PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23 (AP) A tentative agreement was reached today to end a three-week-old strike against the Manhattan Transit Company that has halted bus service for 20,000 North Jersey commuters.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP) Quilche, a 10-1 shot, from Chile scored an upset victory today in the $58,100 San Luis Obispo Handicap at Santa Anita, breaking the course record on the grass. The favorites, Fiddle Isle and Snow Sporting, ran out of the money.

BONN, Feb. 23 The major rivers in West Germany overflowed their banks today after a sudden thaw and widespread rainstorms, isolating villages, stopping highway traffic and inland shipping, and sweeping away one bridge.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 Anil Nayar, the Harvard graduate school student from Bombay, won the national squash racquets championship for the second straight year today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 23 (Reuters) A West German immigrant was fined 225 Australian dollars ($252) here today for attempting to stow away on an airliner from which another stowaway fell to his death yesterday.
To many, Welfare Island looks like a desolate place brightened only by the promise of the two "new towns" scheduled to be built there by the State Urban Development Corporation.
Adam Walinsky, a former legislative assistant to the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 23 Millard Rothenberg, president of Judy Bond, Inc., a manufacturer of women's blouses, died today in his home at 62 Birchal Drive here. He was 45 years old.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 23 Four Africans were wounded, one seriously, yesterday when the police opened fire after miners refused to disperse during a loud gathering and then did a war dance near Klerksdorp, in the western Transvaal.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 When the Legislature turns its attention again to the so-called Blaine Amendment, it will be dealing more with a problem of how to accommodate differing positions of legislative leaders than with the substantive issue of state aid to church-related schools.

OTTAWA, Feb. 23 (UPI) Canada is studying a request by the United States to look into Canadian union elections connected with the struggles of Joseph A. Yablonski, the slain miners' union leader, Labor Minister Bryce S. Mackasey said today.

The mounting wave of indiscriminate Palestinian terrorism against innocent travelers of many lands in airliners and on the ground in the Holy Land demands a prompt and determined response at many levels.
The elected representatives of the city's 275,000 high school students will ask the Board of Education this week to give students a major voice in determining policies and practices in their schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Congress has been urged to adopt a stringent new code of financial disclosure rules, affecting both members and highsalaried staff workers and involving property holdings and debts as well as income.

A WOMAN in public life could do a lot worse than be dressed over the years by Gustave Tassell. Her clothes would always look tasteful, even stylish. And nobody could tell how large her wardrobe was or how much she spent on clothes. They were so classic and they changed so subtly, they'd stay above fashion for years.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. Puddles of water from the previous day's rain lay in the low spots in the fields and woods of the Squash Hill Shooting Preserve, the tempperature was in the mid-40's, and the sky was heavy with clouds.

Spurred by the emergence of conservation as a potent political issue, state and local government officials across the country are responding to growing public pressure with a flood of proposals for new environmental laws.

Consumers beset by rising prices and the continuing bite of inflation responded yesterday in an unprecedented turnout for the holiday as New York stores presented their traditional Washington's Birthday "bargain" promotions.
The city's Investigation Department is offering an "exciting experience" at a starting salary of $10,500 a year to young lawyers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23?The president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America today offered four proposals to pump more money into the housing market.

MANILA, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Dollar transactions in all commercial banks in the Philippines were suspended today as bankers sought clarification of the new Central Bank ruling adopting a floating exchange rate for the peso.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) George Washington's birthday falls on a Monday next year, too, but many Americans who got yesterday off will have to work on the birthday next year.

George E. Reedy, one of President Johnson's press secretaries, contends in an article in the current issue of Look magazine that the White House has a courtlike atmosphere that shields the President from reality and can warp his political instincts.

LONDON, Feb. 23 The Government came under attack from all sides of the House of Commons today for letting airlines suspend some services to Israel after the apparent sabotage of an Israel-bound Swiss plane.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 A joint subcommittee of Congress has been set up to study whether the United States needs another nuclear-powered aircraft carrier costing $640million.

GUATEMALA CITY, Feb. 23 On the day that commemorates the death of Tecun Uman, an Indian warior, at the hands of Pedro de Alvarado, a leader of the Spanish conquistadors, Guatemalans play a game of changing faces.

POINT LOOKOUT, L.I., Feb. 23 Dr. Philip Nolan, chief physicist for the Farrand Optical Company of the Bronx, N.Y., died apparently of drowning yesterday. His body was recovered from the ocean near his home at 126 Bellmore Street. He was 61 years old.

NOROTON, Conn., Feb. 23 Miss Alice Louise Franklin, a computer programer with the Union Carbide Corporation, and John Emmett Goyert Jr., an account executive with Young Rubicam, plan to be married in the Noroton Presbyterian Church on June 20.

RAHWAY, N.J., Tuesday, Feb. 24 The faculty of Rahway High School agreed to return to work today after the Board of Education, in a meeting that ended at 1 A.M., accepted a formula designed to end the racial strife that has closed the school for a week.
MESA, Ariz., Feb. 23 Al Downing hasn't lost a team. He's gained a uniform and a pair of shoes.

The rout of Laotian forces, strongly supported by American airpower, in the Plaine des Jarres poses a serious test for the Nixon Doctrine of limited United States overseas involvement. It lends urgency to Congressional efforts to define the limits of the American commitment in that small but strategic state on the borders of Vietnam.
DETROIT, Feb. 23 The Ford Motor Company's profits in the fourth quarter and all 1969 dropped sharply despite record sales.
TOKYO, Feb. 23 Reuters The Japanese Finance Ministry said today it had decided to ease current restrictions on rates of divided paid by major commercial banks, effective in September.

With their Eastern Division lead over the Milwaukee Bucks trimmed to 5 games after weekend losses to Atlanta and Baltimore, the New York Knicks will attempt to right themselves tonight at Madison Square Garden against the Phoenix Suns, who are among their favorite opponents.
About 80 members of the Jewish Defense League picketed the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies yesterday to demand more money for Jewish schools and neighborhood selfdefense.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Progress is what people who are planning to do something really terrible almost always justify themselves on the grounds of.
President Nixon has bowed to the oil industry in shelving the recommendations of the majority of his Cabinet-level task force on oil import control.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Feb. 23 The birth of the Cooperative Republic of Guyana was proclaimed here at midnight ceremonies last night in a move to sever this former British colony's remaining ties to the Crown.
SANDY HOOK, N.J., Feb. 23 The four Representatives sniffed the open plastic bags of muck and one gingerly dipped his fingers into a bag of black goo.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23 (AP) Thousands of teachers abandoned classrooms across the state today in a battle with the Legislature over money. It was not clear how many were actually on strike because many were scheduled to be out anyway in observance of Washington's Birthday.
Martin McGrady, who has made the 600-yard run the glamour event of the indoor season, said yesterday he would challenge Lee Evans outdoors in the quarter-mile.
LONDON, Feb. 23 Roger Gresham Cooke, an active back-bench Member of Parliament, died last night in Westminster Hospital. His age was 63.

Dr. E. Richard Weinerman, a professor of public health at Yale University, and his wife, Shirley, were among the 47 victims of the Swissair jet crash Saturday near Zurich. Dr. Weinerman was 52 years old; his wife was 51. They lived at 5 Eastland Road in Hamden, Conn.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (AP) United States B52's dropped 1,500 tons of bombs on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos today, informed sources said.

MIAMI, Feb. 23 Joe Namath the outsider in the betting? And at 40 to 1, no less. So great a defiance of the law of probability was posted on the odds board before the $31,450 Florida Breeders Stakes today, and Joe Namath, a 3-year-old colt foaled in Ocala, promptly proceeded to extend the aura of success attached to his namesake by coming through with the most unlooked-for victory. His price was $83.20 for $2.

HOUSTON, Feb. 23 Mrs. Winifred Trimble Runnells, daughter of Mrs. John Parkinson Jr. of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married here today to John Boyd Carter Jr., managing partner of the Lehman Brothers office here.
In addition to producing smoke, noise and frayed nerves it appears that cities also make snow.
ATHENS, Feb. 23 Greece today scheduled for March 21 the murder trial of two Arabs charged with attacking an Israeli El Al jetliner at the Athens airport 14 months ago.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 Fortynine of the Assembly's 79 Republicans introduced a bill today that would undo $215-million in cuts made last, year in the state's school aid formulas for the 1970-71 school year.

LONDON, Feb. 23 Miss Louisa Ogilvie, daughter of the late Group Capt. Patrick Ogilvie of the Royal Air Force and of Mrs. Roger Kennaway of Reperry Manor Farm, Lanivet, Cornwall, was married Saturday to Alexis Richard Dion Oswald, son of Count de la Falaise of Paris and Mrs. John McKendry of New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 23 On this of all days, when even a man with limitless gall wouldn't attempt to stray from the truth, John Chapman sought confirmation of 148 victories not credited to him by the United States Trotting Association.
Two parades one of devotion and one of dissentmarked the observance of George Washington's Birthday here yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 23 The Supreme Court of the State of Victoria issued an order in Melbourne today forbidding the presentation of the revue "Oh! Calcutta!" The judge described it as "an excursion into depravity."
HOUSTON, Feb. 23 Scientists reported today that chemical evidence is pointing more and more to the conclusion that the moon is not a homogeneous body but, like the earth, has a crust.
Lower new-car sales during Feb. 11-20 were reported yesterday by the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 Tran Ngoc Chau, the Opposition deputy accused by President Nguyen Van Thieu of pro-Communist activities, made a surprise appearance this morning at the National Assembly and announced he would stage a sit-in there until his trial ended.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) An international horse racing bureau was started in London today and its first announcement was that the United States planned to stage an international steeplechase at Camden, S.C., Nov. 14. To be known as the Colonial Cup, the race could challenge England's Grand National as the world's premier event in a few years.
What is the role of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in relation to various New York City communities? Should it decentralize its facilities, set up branch museums, lend its art works to local groups?

Forty thousand consumers throughout the United States have filed claims to share in a pioneering settlement of illegal overcharges on tetracycline and other broad-spectrum antibiotics the so-called wonder drugs.
BONN, Feb. 23 (Reuters) The West German Economic Ministry today published a fourstage plan for the creation of a European monetary union to be operative by the end of the 70's.

Barry H. Gottehrer, a top assistant to Mayor Lindsay, said yesterday that he was giving strong consideration to running as what he called "a Lindsay Democrat" against Leonard Farbstein, the Democratic Representative from the 19th Congressional District.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 (AP) PPG Industries, Inc., has announced that it is phasing out its consumer paints and industrial coating plant at Newark.

AGAWAM, Mass., Feb. 23 (AP) Mrs. Mary Ann Curtis of St. Louis won her third New England women's indoor tennis championship by beating Pam Teeguarten of Los Angeles in the final tonight, 4-6, 6-2, 7-5.

Thomas D. Lumpkin, executive vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, disclosed here yesterday that talks had started in Madrid between the Spanish Government and a Bolivian team with regard to Gulf's nationalized properties in Bolivia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 "When you come to the White House, it's a real cultural experience," Connie Stuart, staff director to Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, said today.

BONDOUKOU, Ivory Coast The king of the Abron tribe and his four chief ministers arrived here with much glitter, incantations and beating of drums. They were borne high on sedan chairs, shaded by royal parasols and accompanied by golden scepter bearers and hundreds of followers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) The Golden Eagle Passport program of yearly fees for entrance to the national parks and recreation areas was described in a House subcommittee today as a financial failure and unfair.

LEOMINSTER, Mass., Feb. 23 (AP) Valarie Goguen, 19 years old, of Leominster, was sentenced to one year in jail today after being convicted of violating an 1899 law that forbids treating the American flag in a contemptuous manner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 After more than a year of unsuccessful efforts to oust John F. O'Leary, the director of the Bureau of Mines, the Nixon Administration is making another attempt to replace him with a man more acceptable to the mining industry and the Republican party.
TWENTY-THREE years ago a dancer named Moira Shearer took time out from doing leading roles with Sadler's Wells Ballet (now The Royal) to appear in a movie, "The Red Shoes."

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 24 (UPI) The prosecution in the Algiers Motel Federal conspiracy trial began its summation today by charging that the police had beaten and shot young Negroes and white prostitutes there "to get even for the riot" raging outside the motel in Detroit.
HOUSTON, Feb. 24 A plastic-impregnated concrete four times as strong as ordinary concrete is being tested for the construction of houses, pipelines, pavements and underwater structures.

Mike Reid, Penn State's all-America defensive tackle, was honored as 1969 player of the year in Eastern College Athletic Conference Division 1 football during the E.C.A.C.'s annual awards dinner last night.
RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 24 Rahway High School reopened this morning after a one-week shutdown because of racial clashes.

Jose de Cubas, president of the Council for Latin America, Inc., said here yesterday that an attempt would be made next month to form a new Council for the Americas to "utilize the productive abilities of businessmen" in the hemisphere.
TEMPE, Ariz., Feb. 24 The Seattle Pilots won 25 fewer games and batted 43 points less than the Cincinnati Reds last year. But this spring the Pilots look exactly as the Reds did a year ago.
A new monthly called Scanlan's, a compound of new and old journalism, including reportage by the late Ben Hecht appeared on newsstands here yesterday.
Dore Schary, the playwright and former Hollywood producer, has been named the city's first Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.
ALBANY, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) Spectacular spills resulting in injuries to two jockeys marred today's opening of thoroughbred racing at Golden Gate Fields.

Quintuplets three girls and two boys were born at the Presbyterian Hospital last night to a 27-year-old New Jersey woman whose first two children, like the quintuplets, were born after she had been taking fertility shots.

A 35-year-old Chilean was arrested in a car near his tenement in upper Manhattan yesterday while holding a shopping bag that the police said contained cocaine and heroin with a retail value of $1.5-million.

BONN, Feb. 24 The coalition government of Christian Democrats and Social Democrats in the state of Lower Saxony broke up today over the admission of a member of the extreme right-wing National Democratic party to the parliamentary ranks of the Christian Democratic party.
Frank E. Cole has been appointed president of the Electronic Instrument Division, Lear Siegler, Inc., Anaheim, Calif. He formerly was executive vice president.
THERE'S been some fear that, after a period of sartorial splendor, the American man has been slipping back into fashion squaredom. Not if Bill Blass can help it.

THE Phoenix Theater's production of "Harvey," in a carefully studied re-staging by Stephen Porter, restores James Stewart and a sense of innocence to the American theater. It also gave a certain glamour to the first-night audience, for the ANTA Theater last night seemed studded with stars of stage and screen all of them vintage and some of them of good years.

The Texas Utilities Company and subsidiaries reported gains in operating revenues and net income yesterday for the final quarter of 1969 and for the full year. The preliminary annual report placed operating revenues at $99,044,491 for the quarter, compared with $88,232, 698 a year earlier. Net income rose to $17,806,947, or 69 cents a share from $16,347,450, or 64 cents a share, reported in the final quarter of 1968.
A City Narcotics Control Commission was set up yesterday headed by Deputy Mayor Robert M. Morgenthau and listing no role for City Council President Sanford D. Garelik.

Net income of the Westvaco Corporation in their first quarter ended Jan. 31 fell to $3,521,000, or 33 cents a share, from $4,611,000, or 43 cents a share, in the 1969 period, David L. Luke 3d, president, reported to shareholders at the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 24 (AP) The American yacht, Nemesis, won the fifth race today but continued to trail Carabella of Australia and Crest of Norway for the 5.5-Meter Class championship.
WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 24 Miss Marie Louise Trigg will be married here May 23 to Robert Winslow Puffer 3d in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Supreme Court ruled today that New York could not deny welfare benefits to persons unable to show that they had moved to the state for a reason other than to go on relief.
Puerto Rican protesters took control of a capital budget hearing in City Hall for 90 minutes yesterday and shouted that the city was discriminating against their community.
LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) The British merchant fleet, after a half-century of steady decline, is again on its way to recovery, the United Kingdom Chamber of Shipping said today in its annual report.

BONN, Feb. 24 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel declared here today that West Germany must continue and expand its "special" relationship with Israel, whatever happens in the Middle Eastern conflict or in other areas affecting the two countries.

In these days, Gounod's "Faust" can survive only if it is cast with superlative singers or if it is given the kind of flamboyant production that can be found at the State Theater whenever the New York City Opera is functioning there.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 24 (UPI) Ken Harrelson, who arrived at the Cleveland Indians camp last night sporting purple bellbottoms, purple shoes and purple sunglasses augmented by shoulderlength hair, got his locks trimmed quickly today at the threat o a four-figure fine.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 24 Fear is growing among thousands of British Asians in Uganda that they will soon be forced out of their jobs, businesses and country.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 24 Ambassador Kenneth B. Keating of the United States and the Indian Foreign Ministry exchanged veiled barbs today after the ministry had ordered the United States Embassy to close five of its nine cultural centers in the country within three months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Several studies commissioned by the Government in recent years have shown that the major reason the income of Negroes lags far behind that of whites continues to be discrimination, not education or training.

The New York State Banking Board moved yesterday to prevent banks from raising capital by issuing their short-term notes to small investors, thus thwarting the plans of at least one major bank to do so.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 On the eve of their first full workout of spring training, the New York Mets signed Ed Kranepool to his contract today and reduced their holdouts to one Ron Swoboda.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia had a fractious day on Capitol Hill today, first clashing with Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana over voting rights and then stirring up a furor in the House restaurant by passing out ax handles.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 24 Yasir Arafat, the top Palestine commando leader, said today at a news conference in Amman, Jordan, that "the Unified Command of the commando organizations is now seriously reviewing the entire question of attacks on international airliners," according to the Amman radio.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 Russians can have their cake, but they need not eat a chocolate Lenin medal with it, too.

CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 24 The Chattanooga Post, one of two afternoon papers in this city, ceased publication today after the filing of a Federal antitrust suit charging that the Times Printing Company, owner of The Post, was attempting to monopolize the daily newspaper market here.
The International Air Transport Association has suggested to some member airlines the idea of using dogs to detect explosives that saboteurs might try to slip aboard their planes.

PARIS, Feb. 24 Finance ministers of the European Economic Community strengthened their resolve today to establish a European monetary "personality" and eventually common currency that could compete with the dollar.

The effort to provide new cars for the troubled Long Island Rail Road, the production of which was already eight months behind schedule, fell even further behind yesterday when the manufacturer of the cars announced that it was halting production because it had run out of critical parts.
Prices on the London stock market continued a sagging trend yesterday as key indexes again slipped to new low levels for the year.
Steel production rose 4.3 per cent last week, compared to that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
LET'S say you've got $5,000 and you want to buy a stock. Are you going to let the New York Stock Exchange's proposed new commission schedule dictate what price stock you buy?

HONOLULU, Feb. 24 Hawaii's Senate approved today and sent to Gov. John A. Burns a bill that would make this state's abortion law the most liberal of any in the nation. Mr. Burns, a Roman catholic, has indicated that he will let the bill become law without signing it.

The formation of a new business and Government systems analysis concern was announced yesterday by Ivan Selin, former acting assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Analysis, and Charles O. Rossotti, his former chief deputy.
EUGENE, Ore., Feb. 24 Former Senator Wayne Morse said today that he would not run for the House this year because it would cause a further split in the Oregon Democratic party.

CLINTON, Mass., Feb. 24 Special Justice for Massachusetts Morris N. Gould and Mrs. Gould have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally P. Gould to Kit G. Narodick of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip H. Narodick of Seattle and Honolulu. The wedding will take place in Randolph April 11.
The board of directors of General Dynamics Corporation will gather this morning for one of the most significant meetings in the history of the giant defense contractor.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit turned down today the request of Cassius Clay that his appeal from a conviction for refusing to be inducted into the Army be heard by all 15 judges of the court.

The East's three best major independents St. Bonaventure, Villanova and Niagara accepted invitations yesterday to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. But Marquette, one of the nation's top teams, spurned a bid in a controversy over the site of its regional competition. Dayton was selected as Marquette's replacement.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 24 Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Alexander G. Silberstein of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Silberstein, to Eric Liebling Herzog, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Herzog.

GROVE CITY, Pa., Feb. 24 Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller, a champion of equal rights for women and, at 95, the oldest member of the Democratic National Committee, died Today at Grove City Hospital after suffering a heart attack. She lived at Wolf Creek Farm, near Slippery Rock.
Conrad Nagel, the actor, was found dead yesterday in his home at the Park Vendome, 340 West 57th Street. He was 72 years old.

Mrs. Lila Acheson Wallace, co-chairman and co-founder of the Reader's Digest Association, Inc., has been chosen to receive the 1970 Golden Door Award of the American Council for Nationalities Service. She will be the first woman to receive the award.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 The Public Service Commission said today that it had authorized the New York Telephone Company to put into effect at 12:01 A.M. on Thursday an interim rate increase that will cost subscribers $136.7-million.
Gazing quizzically at a cartoon of himself garbed in a flowing angel's robe, Mayor Lindsay accepted a ticket yesterday to the annual lompoon show of the Inner Circle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Former Senator Daniel B. Brewster of Maryland, who has been charged with accepting bribes while he was in office, suffered a severe mental lapse and is not competent to stand trial, a doctor's report said today. The report said that the chronic effect of alcohol was a contributing cause.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 By the year 2000, Americans will be jammed together in an "anthill society" unless government and business join in a coherent national growth policy, Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said in a lecture tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 President Nixon opened the way for the first time today for a United States industry to obtain "adjustment assistance" from the Government on the ground it was being injured by imports.
The New York City Transit Authority ruled yesterday that an American flag emblem could legally be worn on a Transit Authority police uniform.

DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 24 Miss Susan Elizabeth Vann, a stockbroker with Rotan, Mosle-Dallas Union, Inc., in New York, and Anthony Phillips Hoag, an assistant vice president of Harris Upham Co., Inc., New York, will be married here April 4 in the Duke University Chapel.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 Josef Bachmann, the 25-year-old house painter who tried to kill Rudi Dutschke, a leftist student leader, in April 1968, today committed suicide in his prison cell, prison authorities said.

PRAGUE, Feb. 24 (Reuters) The Czech State Interior Ministry today announced that it had revoked the citizenship of Jiri Pelikan, Ota Sik, Ivan Svitak and Otakar Rambousek, all reformers who are now living abroad.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 24 Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Neal Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Neal, to John Patrick McVeigh, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gorman McVeigh of New York. A July 11 wedding is planned.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 (AP) Informed sources said today that North Vietnam had launched the biggest supply operation of the war down the Ho Chi Minh Trail in eastern Laos.

Goodbody Co., one of Wall Street's largest brokerage firms disclosed yesterday an operating loss of $832,000 for 1969, compared with an after-tax profit of $4,096,000 in 1968. Last year's loss would be pared to $433,000 after taxes.

BONN, Feb. 24 Axel C. Springer, the West German newspaper publisher, announced today that he will transfer one-third of his publishing empire to Bertelsmann A.G. of Gulersloh, West Germany's biggest book publisher, after his 60th birthday in 1972.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 President Pompidou today forcefully conveyed France's desire to strengthen her ties with the United States despite various policy divergences and to see the American military and economic presence maintained in Western Europe.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 Reacting to public concern over daily reports about teenagers killed by narcotics and about drug addiction among schoolchildren, Governor Rockefeller announced today a "declaration of total war" against drug abuse by those under 16.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Roper to Dr. Michael W. Marcus, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Marcus of Brooklyn, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Leo H. Roper. Plans have been made for a wedding this May in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

In its treatment of 22 blacks charged with working for the banned African National Congress, South Africa seems determined to outdo even its own appalling record for "legal" cruelty and hypocrisy. The prosecution in Pretoria was having deep trouble making a case against the defendants under the Suppression of Communism Act, so it therefore abruptly dropped the charges.
Envy: A Theory of Social Behavior, by Helmut Schoeck, translated by Michael Glenny and Betty Ross (Helen Kurt Wolff Book: Harcourt, Brace World, $7.50).

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States the third-largest insurer in the country after Prudential and Metropolitan reported yesterday that sales of individual and group life insurance rose nearly 20 per cent last year to a record of $5.7-billion.
Henry Kearns, president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank, said yesterday that his organization anticipated doing increased business with the states of the Arab world.
The Anaconda Company said here yesterday that its major affiliates in Chile would cut their scheduled deliveries of copper by 40 per cent next month because of production difficulties.
GENEVA, Feb. 24 A giant avalanche in the Swiss Alps engulfed an army camp today in a 30-foot-high wave of snow that was believed to have taken 30 lives.
TWO widely disparate worlds the world of Aquarius and the world of tournament bridge intersected here Monday when a hero of the hippie generation came close to winning a major title.

Unlike other student radicals who have relied on protests and sit-ins to force educational institutions to change alleged discriminatory practices, 85 Puerto Ricans went to the State Division of Human Rights yesterday to file what is believed to be the first discrimination complaint ever made against a college here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The United States called today for joint planning by government aviation officials over the world to protect their civil air transport from terrorist attacks.
The Southern Pacific Company announced yesterday the formation of a new subsidiary, the Southern Pacific Land Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 Dr. Edward L. Bortz, an au thority on geriatrics, died today at Lankenau Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Bala-Cynwyd.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Democratic leaders opened a new assault on the Nixon Administration's spending priorities today as they prepared to welcome Lawrence F. O'Brien as their new national chairman.

Last night's 121-105 victory by the New York Knicks over the Phoenix Suns at Madison Square Garden might seem to have been an easy one, or a meaningless one, since it was the 11th straight triumph over Phoenix. But it was neither.
Bobby Orr of the Boston Bruins, skating toward a National Hockey League mark, continued his record-breaking scoring pace last week.

The following dispatch was written by Daniel De Luce, an assistant general manager of The Associated Press, who has been admitted to North Vietnam. He and his wife were given a tour of the northern side of the demilitarized zone in what is believed the first visit to that area by a Western newsman. Here is a report filed from North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Mrs. Alice Roosevelt Longworth declined an invitation to a luncheon today. "I'm cutting down on going out," she apologized. The excuse prompted Princess Julia Grant Cantacuzene, one of the guests, to remark: "Cutting down? Well think of that.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 Bowie Kuhn said today that betting on baseball games had increased and predicted that a "network" of security agents would be created to protect the sport.

The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, which for years has been rare among internationally renowned symphonies for being almost selfsufficient economically, is running into financial trouble and is exploring possibilities of substantial assistance in the United States and other Western countries.

A terrible irony has emerged since last weekend's bomb explosions on Swiss and Austrian airplanes. Israel, the real and intended victim of the bombers, has been further victimized by several of the foreign airlines serving it, which have now imposed an embargo on Israel-bound freight and mail. Thus it has been Israel, the target, rather than the perpetrators of these outrages, that has been made to suffer.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger of Westchester County formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate yesterday and opened his campaign with an attack on the Nixon Administration's Middle East policy.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Feb. 24 Thomas Moore Bancroft Sr., chairman and former president of Mount Vernon Mills of Baltimore, died yesterday of a heart attack at Community Hospital in Glen Cove. His age was 67.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange generally eased yesterday in quiet trading.
TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 24 (A) Jim Merritt, a left-hander who was the Cincinnati Reds' top winner last season, has fractured his right elbow.

PHOUM BONG RO, Cambodia, Feb. 16 There are many villages just like Phoum Bong Ro not only in this north-central region of Cambodia but through out the flat and almost featureless country of seven million people.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Senate passed a much expanded school lunch bill today, by a vote of 85 to 0, after approving an amendment, 41 to 40, to require free school lunches for all needy children meeting new Federal eligibility standards.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP) A crowd of about 250 jeering youths broke up a scheduled lecture by former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey tonight.

The Sierra Club and Senator Edmund S. Muskie have raised a question that directly tests the determination of the Nixon Administration to protect and restore the environment against the pressures of vested interests. The question is: where are the detailed statements of the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development on the environmental impact of pending legislation to get "optimum timber productivity" out of the national forests?

CATSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 2 Three persons from Brooklyn and two children from Saratoga Springs were killed today on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway when a car skidded sideways across the median and collided broadside with another, the state police said.

Contempt-of-court charges against 105 members of the Young Lords were dropped yesterday after the militant Puerto Rican group reached agreement with the city and an East Harlem church to establish a daycare center in the church.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The Supreme Court let Stand today an Appeals Court ruling allowing the Federal Communications Commission to license pay-television stations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 25 Tran Ngoc Chau, an Opposition Deputy, was found guilty today in absentia of having damaged the national security of South Vietnam through having had dealings with his brother, a North Vietnamese intelligence agent. Mr. Chau was sentenced by a military court to 20 years at hard labor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24 Leufroy J. Bonvillain, director of public relations for the Nassau County Department of Social Services since 1961, died of cancer today in Nassau Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here at 101 Clinton Avenue.
A 2-for-1 split of the common stock of the KimberlyClark Corporation was proposed yesterday by directors of the paper manufacturing company.
WEST ALLIS, Wis., Feb. 24 (UPI) Dan Carroll of the United States, skating in the last pair, scored an upset victory in the men's 1,500-meter international speed-skating race today at Olympic Rink.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) A family doctor from North Carolina testified today that about 30 per cent of the people admitted to hospitals did not need to be.
LONDON, Feb. 24 Dr. David Thomson, Master of Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge University and an author, died today in Cambridge. His age was 58.
"For crying out loud, Cat, we've had four games in five days. Give us a rest," moaned Arnie Brown yesterday. But Brown did not talk loud enough for Coach Emile Francis to hear him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 A case testing college students' free speech rights was dismissed by the Supreme Court today because the student was also accused by the university of lying about his protest activities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the military budget described by the Administration as "rock-bottom" could be substantially cut without any danger to the nation.
YONKERS "So many bigtime Mafia members live in Yonkers," a law-enforcement officer familiar with organized crime said recently, "that we think of the city as a little Newark."

Any brass group must invariably look high and low for a suitable repertory in this area of limited compositional activity. The London Gabrieli Brass Ensemble, a very modishlooking quintet of young Britons who performed last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, resorted to a familiar solution: Renaissance/Baroque arrangements and a contemporary commission.

DETROIT, Feb. 24 (UPI) Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, whose "very helpful" information led to several arrests in a Government gambling crackdown, was one of five persons named today as co-conspirators in a Federal indictment charging 10 other men with gambling conspiracy.
