FORT LAUDERDALE, Feb. 24 The full squad almost of the 1970 New York Yankees took its first workout today, and Manager Ralph Houk observed the cheerful, low-key activities with a fairly clear idea of how he expected his team to shape up.
Eddie Bracken, the actor, and Gerald T. Arthur, a New York businessman, have formed a multimillion-dollar corporation for the purpose of buying or leasing theaters and producing shows.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 New orders for durable goods, an important "leading indicator" of the economy, declined sharply in January, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Mortgage prices rose again at this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Pentagon will announce "massive" base reductions within the next 30 days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The head of the Federal Aviation Administration said bluntly today that the noise around major airports would grow steadily louder in the foreseeable future, despite the promise of quieter planes now in production.

Southern Living, a fastgrowing monthly magazine distributed in 12 southern states, put on its first New York luncheon and slide presentation yesterday, and it was as blantant a piece of vicious, mean, rotten, soul-destroying propaganda as you could imagine.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 24 The Peruvian Government seized and fined today an American fishing boat the first boat seized on the Pacific tuna fishing grounds off the Peruvian coast this season.
Negotiations in the strike of 6,000 tugboat workers here are to be resumed tomorrow.
An expert on housing and urban affairs has recommended that all vacant housing sites on Manhattan avenues and as many side streets as possible, be rezoned for luxury apartment dwellings.

Two reptile experts at the Bronx Zoo have devised a method of telling alligator skins from crocodile skins. The system is expected to aid the enforcement of new laws banning the sale of products made from American alligator hides.
LAWRENCE, L.I. Feb. 24 The Brandeis School will celebrate its 40th anniversary at a dinner dance at the Capri, Atlantic Beach, to be held Saturday, March 7, for the benefit of its scholarship fund.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 W.A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers, will make an announcement here Thursday that the U.M.W. said today would be "of national interest."
The musical Chungs were out in force last night to help Kyung-Wha Chung make a good thing of her first New York recital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 American women may have their doubts about the midi length but Georges Pompidou, the President of France, has none. Here with his wife on an eight-day tour of the United States, he told an audience at a National Press Club luncheon, "As far as ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 Ramsey Clark, the former Attoney General of the United States, has signed a "friend of the court" brief urging that the defendants and lawyers in the Chicago conspiracy trial be released on appeal bonds.
MIAMI, Feb. 24 A pair of contests in which several eligibles for next Tuesday's $100,000 Flamingo participated featured the Hialeah card today, before 17,064 fans.

NEWARK, Feb. 24 Negotiations in the Newark teachers' strike continued this evening, with salaries and other "monetary items" reportedly the only serious differences remaining between the Board of Education and the teachers' bargaining agent, the Newark Teachers Union.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 24 An attempt was made last night to fire bomb the home of a 21-year-old policeman who acted as an undercover agent in an investigation that led to a series of arrests on narcotics charges in Morris County last week.

Although oil seepage, noxious chemicals, industrial wastes, debris and silt continue to befoul New York City's waterways, municipal experts and they are slowly winning the battle against the city's own worst contaminant human sewage.

El Al and other airlines with direct service from New York to Tel Aviv said yesterday that concern about recent acts of sabotage against airliners headed for Israel had had no apparent effect on their bookings.
ATLANTA, Feb. 24 (AP) The American Bar Association today endorsed the Judicial Reform Act sponsored by Senator Joseph Tydings as it closed its 1970 midwinter meeting.
The stock market showed a continuation of gains yesterday in some bank and oil stocks, while pollution-control issues ran into profit taking.

Interest rates on tax-exempt bonds declined sharply yesterday. Corporate bond yields, however, moved upward as the RCA Corporation and Phelps Dodge Corporation announced tentative plans to sell $250million of debt securities.
Potato futures prices reacted to reports that the National Farmers Organization had called a nationwide holding action on potatoes by rising sharply yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 24 Legislative leaders today reached "firm agreement" on a new revenue package for $178.3-million, made possible by $42.1-million in spending reductions, to resolve the state's 13-month deadlock on fiscal matters.

PITTSBURGH, Feb., 24 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dickey 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Scott Dickey, to John Marshall Gilmore, son of Mrs. Addison Leitch Gilmore and the late Mr. Gilmore.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union have been working quietly to develop a formula for settling their differences, officials close to the dispute revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Fungus infections consti tute a far greater public health problem in the world, including the United States, than most people realize, an expert told an international conference today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 A New York obstetrician told a Congressional subcommittee today that publicity generated by its hearings on hazards of birth control pills had caused "panic" among women using the drug and "dozens of unwanted pregnancies."

THE road to sports immortality has been a well-traveled passageway of recent weeks as some of yesterday's heroes were whisked toward the end of the rainbow election to various halls of fame. Although fame may be fleeting for ordinary men, any enshrinement brings a degree of permanence. New demigods have been added to the pantheon at Cooperstown for baseball and to the one at Rutgers for college football.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 24 (AP) Herb Brooks scored three goals today in leading the United States team to an 11-1 victory over Japan in the first round of the world ice hockey championship for Group B teams before a crowd of 2,500.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 21 Four white stallions have been flown from England, flowers are coming from the Netherlands, two planeloads of food from New Delhi, 200 automobiles from Japan to carry the guests and nine elephants from Nepal's own jungles.

GRENOBLE, France, Feb. 24 (AP) An avalanche poured down on an Alpine village near here today and smashed into a small hotel and a farmhouse. Officials said that seven persons were killed and five injured and that nine were unaccounted for.

Associations of high school principals and supervisors as well as individual school principals yesterday denounced the proposed student bill of rights drafted by the City General Organization Council, the recognized student governmental body.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 The State Senate passed a bill today that would outlaw the sale of Medicaid bills to collection agencies by physicians, dentists and druggists.
A record deficit of nearly $1million plagued the Museum of Modern Art at the close of fiscal 1969.

LONDON, Feb. 24 Ground crews at the London airport refused today to do regular work for airlines of eight Arab countries and El Al, the Israeli airline. The reason given was fear for the men's safety after the recent explosions on planes bound for Israel or carrying mail for Israel.

Bernard Korn, president of the Colonial Commercial Corporation, said yesterday the company would defer further consideration of a possible exchange offer for common stock of the Coburn Corporation of America pending release by Coburn of its audited financial statement for fiscal 1970, ending Feb. 28.
DETROIT, Feb. 24 The American Motors Corporation reported today that mid-February automobile sales fell 10 per cent from 1969, or to 6,532 retail deliveries from 7,269 a year ago.
The Board of Higher Education last night appointed Peter S. Spiridon to the newly created post of dean of campus planning and development for the City University of New York.
THE HAGUE, Feb. 24 (Reuters) The International Court of Justice met in special session today for the swearing in of five new judges to bring it up to its full strength of 15.

The Celanese Corporation made a sharp recovery in earnings last year with a gain of 35 per cent to $76.3-million, equal to $5.41 a share before an extraordinary gain, from $57.8-million, or $4.02 a share, on the same basis in 1968, it was reported yesterday by John W. Brooks, president and chief executive.
When commuters smile as they stream through the vastness of the Grand Central Terminal in the morning, instead of moving with grumpy determination, it's got to be something.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 24 (UPI) Hundreds of striking public school teachers descended on the Kentucky State Legislature today to plead for higher salaries and were given a cool reception by most legislators.

ATLANTA, Feb. 24 Legislators in the Deep South have resurrected a previously impotent technique of resistance to school integration by introducing a new barrage of state bills designed to impede or prevent the enforcement of recent Federal court orders.
The contradictory, and confusing outcome of the United States balance of payments last year $7-billion deficit by one measure and a $2.7-billion surplus by another has raised ...

The growing franchise business, in which annual sales currently are estimated to be in the neighborhood of $90billion, is accompanied by such abuses as "an unfortunate concentration of swindlers and con-artists" and "an alarming failure rate in some areas resulting from a 'get-on-thebandwagon' attitude," Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, declared in remarks prepared for delivery here yesterday.

SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 23 "We don't think of the Soviet Union as a hypothetical enemy," Lieut, Gen. Masakatsu Hashimoto said. "But the close presence of the armed forces of a great power is a potential threat to Hokkaido."
Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand said last night that United States military intervention in Southeast Asia "may not only be ineffective, but may even become a liability."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The portrait of the Marquis de Lafayette was wreathed with green tonight at the White House as the President and Mrs. Nixon paid tribute to all things French in honor of President and Mrs. Pompidou of France.

Two liberal Democratic candidates for Governor, Howard J. Samuels and William vanden Huevel, have been working together on a plan to boycott the nominating convention of the New Democratic Coalition, the largest organized liberal group within the party.

HELLEVOETSLUIS, the Netherlands, Feb. 24 In a year when other Northern European countries are at pains to conserve their natural surroundings, the Dutch are pushing ahead with a project to transform their southwestern seacoast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 You can put it down as a general rule that almost any criticism of the Israeli Government's policies in the Middle East will be attacked and even rebuked these days either by Israeli officials or their friends in this country or both.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Thirteen Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places, and their six lawyers expressed regret yesterday to Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh that someone had tried to bomb his Inwood home over the weekend.

The Illinois Central Railroad, which has been trying for several weeks to slow the railroad industry's move for another freight-rate increase which would be the third in less than a year is abandoning that position.

With 11 minutes 37 seconds left in the first half and the score, 13-3, in favor of Holy Cross, the St. John's rooters among the 8,186 fans in Alumni Gym last night were beginning to think, "Oops, there goes another tournament bid," but they were wrong as the Redmen roared back to win easily, 75-62.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 24 The president of a worldwide organization of 46,000 airline pilots conferred today with Under Secretary General Ralph J. Bunche on possible moves to force effective action against sabotage of civil aircraft.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 The Council of Elected Negro Democrats, which includes black elected public and party officials in the state, tonight endorsed State Senator Basil A. Paterson of Manhattan for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor.
Howard Landis of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Landis, to J. Gordon Arkin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Arkin of Yonkers.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24 (UPI) Howard W. Fitzpatrick, Middlesex County Sheriff for more than 20 years, died in the Cardinal Cushing Rehabilitation Center last night. He was 71 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird outlined today a Nixon Administration request to defend a third Minuteman site with Safeguard defensive missiles and to acquire land and do preliminary work at five additional locations.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 75 per cent controlling interest in the Wilson Sporting Goods Company to Pepsico, Inc., for approximately $63-million. This is Pepsico's first major acquisition since it acquired Frito-Lay, Inc., producer of snack-food products, in 1965. The acquisition also would put the diversified beverage and food producer into the leisuretime field for the first time.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 24 Samuel Louis Ross, who entered the field of radio broadcasting and mutual funds while they were in their infancy, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 170 East Hartsdale Avenue.

Student leaders of the city's high schools have demanded a major role in the decisions that affect their education, and the predictable response of some spokesmen for the system is one of alarm and opposition. It is the wrong response, more likely to intensify the already serious discord than to contain it.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 Governor Rockefeller and the chairman of the State Assembly's Education Committee differed today on how to distribute about $360-million more in aid to schools for the 1970-71 school a year.
LONDON, Feb. 24 The London Stock Exchange followed New York into a controversial area today with proposals to change brokerage-house commissions.
William McChesney Martin Jr., who resigned recently after more than 18 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has been nominated as a director of the United States Steel Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on whether the method of selecting members of the Rockland County Legislature satisfies the Constitution's one-man, one-vote requirement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review the antitrust conviction of the SCM Corporation of New York and the awarding of $70,000 damages and nearly $45,000 in attorney fees to the Advanced Business Systems Supply Company of Baltimore.

LAS VEGAS, Feb. 24 (UPI) The first line on the coming baseball season by oddsmakers here listed the world champion New York Mets today as the fourth choice at 9-2 to repeat as National League winners.

DEL CLINE, who is 59 years old, doesn't wear the vic tory wreath or kiss the beauty queen. He gets no applause from the crowd, which doesn't know him. The recognition he receives is usually in private, from a race driver thanking Cline for saving him from a fiery death after a collision or spill.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 24 (AP) Villanova, getting more than half its points from Chris Ford, Fran O'Hanlon and Clarence Smith, took command midway through the first period and went on to rout Toledo, 107-82, tonight.

ROME, Feb. 24 A taboobreaking movie that portrays Italian police officials as corrupt, authoritarian and immune from the laws they are supposed to enforce is drawing critical praise and standingroom only crowds here and in Milan.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (AP) United States Attorney Robert B. Krupansky told newsmen today that the Federal grand jury investigating the Yablonski murders had turned up "no surprises."

Since in France, Mozart's name is pronounced quite generally as "Moh-zahr," as if he were an adopted son instead of an alien Austrian, it was no surprise last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to hear a persuasively Gallic performance of his Divertimento in D (K. 136) by the Toulouse Chamber Orchestra.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel threatened Florida's largest power company with court action today if it did not promise immediately to stop digging a six-mile canal the Government says will damage Biscayne Bay with thermal pollution.
Sharply contested races for membership on the new decentralized local school boards are shaping up in most sections of the city.

Musically speaking, New Zealand didn't seem very far away last night at Carnegie Hall during the concert of the National Orchestral Association. John Rimmer's Symphony 1968 was played, and it might as well have been written just around the corner rather than faraway Auckland, where Mr. Rimmer studied and teaches.
More than 150 Columbia College students slept in Barnard College dormitories Tuesday night "openly and militantly" to dramatize their demands for coeducational dormitories.

NO doubt about it, the National Student Market- ing Corporation had a sub stantial Wall Street following. The company was deeply involved in the lush youth market through direct sales and a variety of related student services. Its dynamic founder and president Cortes W. Randell, was full of bullish earnings projections and he set about to deliver on his promises through an aggressive acquisition program and internal growth.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 25 (UPI) Fred W. Haise, a civilian astronaut assigned to the Apollo 13 moon flight, said today that he and Capt. James E. Lovell of the Navy planned to explore a hilly region of the moon, collect valuable subsurface samples, and possibly climb a mound 250 to 400 feet high.

Japan's decision to permit the country's investment trusts to buy foreign securities was hailed yesterday by New York representatives of the trusts as a "historic milestone" in the internationalization of Japan's securities industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon's budget is probably a good deal more restrictive in its economic impact than appears on the surface, a new analysis disclosed today.

Despite a charge that its shareholders would lose $50million, the General Host Corporation obtained overwhelming shareholder approval yesterday for the sale of its 55 per cent interest in Armour Co., for $211-million to the Greyhound Corporation.
Henry Crown, the Chicago financier and industrialist, is returning to a key role in the affairs of the General Dynamics Corporation, a giant defense contractor.
LONDON, Feb. 25 The fathom, ancient nautical measure for six feet, may soon suffer a sea change in Britain.

NEWARK, Feb. 25 The 23day Newark school strike ended tonight when teachers voted to ratify a one-year contract agreement reached earlier in the day between the Board of Education and the Newark Teachers Union.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Thursday, Feb. 26 (Agence France-Presse) Premier Souvanna Phouma announced today that he would soon ask Britain and the Soviet Union, the co-chairmen of the 1962 Geneva conference, to call a meeting of the 14 countries that signed the agreements on Laos.
CAIRO, Feb. 25 President Tito of Yugoslavia joined President Gamel Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic today in accusing Israel of expansionism and the United States of encouraging the Israelis.
Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" was given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater last night, and it was not quite enough that the performance was easily above average.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 25 Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, named as a co-conspirator in a Federal gambling indictment in Detroit yesterday, declared at a news conference today he had never had anything to do with "big-time gambling." Then, with tears in his eyes, he left the room.

All five members of the original cast of the play "Che!" as well as the producer, the playwright and the light man were convicted of obscenity yesterday for presenting what a threejudge panel called "a nadir of smut on the stage."
MONTREAL, Feb. 25 (UPI) Power-play goals by Jacques Lemaire and Serge Savard to night led the Montreal Cana diens to a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

ROME, Feb. 25 Members of the diverse, diverting and divided American art community here are slowly finding a focus, or at least common ground, in the traditionally remote cloisters of the 76-year-old American Academy in Rome.
The Nixon Administration presented its rebuttal yesterday to critics who contend that its proposals for new defense systems will mean a sharp increase in total Pentagon outlays.

Five children born Tuesday night to a 27-year-old New Jersey woman who had been treated with fertility drugs were reported to be "in good to excellent health" yesterday in Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
OLEAN, N.Y., Feb. 25 (UPI) Bob Lanier scored 23 points despite playing only half the game tonight because of foul trouble to lead fourth-ranked St. Bonaventure to a 91-68 victory over Canisius.

THE last time Dr. Raphael Jewelewicz allowed him- self an evening's relaxation was a couple of weeks ago, when he and his wife went to the opera but he left his name at the box office, just in case, and as he said yesterday: "In the back of my mind, I always had this..."

LISBON, Feb. 25 Francisco Salgado Zenha, an oppositionist who ran as a Socialist candidate in the October election, is being held by the security police for investigation into incitement of demonstrations against Portugal's colonial wars in Africa.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 25 Harold Van Houten Proskey, a retired advertising and merchandising executive, died yesterday in his home at 5 Terrace Drive. His age was 80.

Howard J. Samuels and William vanden Heuvel, two Democratic candidates for governor who have been complaining about the nominating procedures of the New Democratic Coalition, assured N.D.C. officials yesterday that they would participate in the coalition's convention.
MIAMI, Feb. 25 The $750,000 Florida pro golf tour, which opens here tomorrow, is preparing to withstand a $200,000 punch in its pocketbook.

Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand said yesterday that Asian countries should develop their regional security without relying on United States troops. He said that collectively the Asian nations might be successful in dealing with Communist China and ultimately winning its cooperation.

THE experienced expert Harry, Fajans won the Marshall Chess Club championship preliminaries after a tie-break preference with Howard Ant. The twin leaders each scored 5 -1 , topping a 32-man qualifying field in the seven-round Swiss system. The appended games are from the event.
The tantalizing taste of spring and the nasty nip of winter were both experienced by New Yorkers yesterday.

PARIS, Thursday, Feb. 26 (Reuters) French newspapers noted today that some Congressmen had boycotted President Pompidou's speech in Washington yesterday, but stressed that the warmth of his welcome there canceled out the bad impression.

SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 25 Northeast Utilities, which already has built the country's largest pumped-storage hydroelectric plant, formally announced today that it was planning to build another one up to twice as large in the relatively untouched Lower Berkshires around the Massachusetts-Connecticut border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Congress courteously welcomed President Pompidou today and applauded him as he addressed a joint meeting. The French leader, here with his wife on an eight-day state visit, touched briefly but pointedly on the problems of Vietnam and the Middle East, the principal points of policy divergence between Paris and Washington.

HONG KONG, Feb, 25 In the rugged Taihang mountains of Shansi Province members of two communes, using only hand tools, have just finished after 10 months a 15-mile water conduit by hacking 22 tunnels through mountains and constructing 13 piers of handhewn stones to support the conduit across gullies and streams.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) A Negro Representative introduced today a resolution declaring Gov. Lester G. Maddox unwelcome in the House restaurant, where the Governor distributed pick and ax handles yesterday as symbols of his resistance to desegregation.
A 40-year-old black man with 15 years of drug addiction behind him and five drugfree years since told 14 fifthgrade boys and girls yesterday:
The American missionary nurse in whose blood Lassa fever virus was first detected was on her way last night to Jos, Nigeria, where there is an outbreak of the disease.

The Department of Commerce reports that the United States sustained a $7-billion deficit in its balance of payments in 1969 the biggest liquidity deficit on record. There is one huge and innocent looking item in those figures "errors and omissions." During the first three-quarters of last year these errors and omissions totaled $3.2 billion of funds leaving the United States.
The out-of-town buyers who are currently being given the royal treatment by toy manufacturers appear to be as interested in the advertising plans as in the toys themselves.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 25 The governing Reformist party proclaimed today in a national convention the candidacy of President Joaquin Balaguer for a second four-year term.
The Board of Education bypassed the school system's two ranking deputies yesterday in naming an assistant superintendent, Irving Anker, to be the new Acting Superintendent of Schools.
LONDON, Feb. 25 A controversial new portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, showing her unsmiling and with marks under her mouth and on her left ear, was unveiled here today.
VERBIER, Switzerland, Feb. 25 (AP) Billy Kidd of Stowe Vt., won the giant slalom and the $4,000 first prize today in a pro Alpine ski meet, billed as a world championship.
Pete Maravich of Louisiana State, the greatest major-college scorer in basketball history, is coming to the National Invitation Tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) A specialist in population control testified today that suspected complications from birth control pills are secondary to the medical and social dangers of pregnancy.

CAIRO, Feb. 25 The Egyptian Government spokesman indicated today that the two United States oil companies operating in this country faced no risk of expulsion as part of threatened Arab economic retaliation against the United States for support of Israel.

MRS. CYNTHIA GUZEVICH is a woman of many tal- ents. In the dog show world, she is known for her great Italian greyhounds. In just eight years her kennel at Las Cruces, N.M., produced 35 champions of the breed. She also has bred champion miniture poodles and Pekingese.
A painting by Vincent Van Gogh of cypress trees rising from a cornfield into a sky of swirling clouds brought $1.3million at auction here last night the highest price ever paid for a Van Gogh.

The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance in more than a month yesterday when a late rally sent prices sharply higher in stepped-up trading. The uptrend started in the final hour on news that the Lincoln National Bank in Philadelphia had reduced its prime lending rate to 8 per cent from 8 per cent.
FLINT, Mich., Feb. 25 Three white Detroit policemen and a Negro private guard were found not guilty of conspiracy today in the Algiers Motel trial.
United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. announced yesterday an agreement that he said "cracks open a major union in the building and contracting field" to minority-group workers.

The New York Life Insurance Company, the fourth-largest life insurer in the nation after the Prudential, Metropolitan and the Equitable, reported yesterdway new highs in sales premium income, insurance in force and assets for 1969.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 25 A jury of seven women and five men today convicted a 60year-old physician of violating Connecticut's 100-year-old abortion law after the judge said that "the danger of [the woman's] possible suicide" should not be considered.
BUCHAREST, Feb. 25 (AP) The favored United States team overwhelmed Bulgaria, 19-1, today for its second straight victory in the Group B tournament of the world ice hockey championships.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 (AP) The Professional Golfers' Association champion, Ray Floyd, suffered a slip of the pen today and was credited with a score of 110 in the proamateur event preceding the $150,000 Doral open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Supreme Court declared today that the election of school board members and most if no all other local officials must adhere to the principle of one man, one-vote.

Voytek Matushevski is a young Polish pianist, trained in Warsaw, who came to the United States in 1965 to study for three years with Leon Fleisher. Last year he won the Young Artist Competition of the National Federation of Music Clubs, and last night he made his New York debut in Alice Tully Hall.

A Bronx grand jury indicted two men yesterday for second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide in having given a 17-year-old Barnard freshman heroin from which she died. District Attorney Burton B. Roberts said it was the first time to his knowledge that these charges had been brought in connection with death by narcotics, even though the victim had sniffed the heroin willingly.

DAMNED if you do and damned if you don't. That has been the anguished cry along Seventh and Fifth Avenues during recent months as maunfacturers and retailers confront the hemline dilemma and customer hostility in an era of sluggish business.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 25 Lowell P. Weicher Jr., the freshman Republican Representative from affluent Fairfield County, entered the Senate race today.
Just who is Farhad Hormozi? What is this secret message he promises to disclose in the Sunday editions of The New York Times and The Daily News?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The nation's Governors moved today to keep the controversial issue of school desegregation off the agenda of their national conference, despite Southern pressure to bring it up.
JACKSON, Wyo., Feb. 25 (UPI) Monique the elk was found dead in the National Elk Refuge today, probably of pneumonia.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 The New York Mets took the field today for the first time since they won the World Series last Oct. 16, and so many people turned out to watch that they created traffic jams in northwest St. Petersburg.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Senator George S. McGovern said today that Democrats must develop a "coalition of conscience and responsibility" to offset the "public relations" of President Nixon.
Yale University was placed on a 16-month probation by the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday for allowing Jack Langer to play on its basketball team.

He once worked on the fishing boats that roam for red snapper and pompano in the Caribbean off Cartagena, Colombia, and he earned about $10 a week. But now he's the world's fourth-ranked welterweight boxer, and on Monday night at Madison Square Garden, he might make as much as $7,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Henry W. Edgerton, a retired Judge from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and long a defender of civil rights, died Monday at his home here. He was 81 years old.
The bistate Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has opened a new effort to strip a license from what may be the harbor's largest marine carpentry company.

The American Bar Association displayed faint faith in American principles of law and morality the other day when it refused to revoke its 20-year-old opposition to the United Nations Convention on Genocide.
After 10 years of treating women with drugs to induce fertility, doctors are better able to control the dosage, but they still cannot guarantee that patients will have only one baby at a time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Treasury announced today that it would no longer sell Treasury bills in denominations of less than $10,000.

FRANK GRAHAM JR.'S "Since Silent Spring" (Houghton Mifflin Company, 333 Pages, $6.95) emerges with exquisite timing only a short while after the Nixon Administration's promise to wage war against pollution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Congress appeared to move closer today to another confrontation with the President with the announcement that House and Senate conferees would soon take up a Federal pay bill that President Nixon had threatened to veto as inflationary.
LONDON, Feb. 25 Britain's servicemen will soon pay for their own bed and board as this country shifts to a new and higher pay system for the armed forces, the Government announced today.

Sales and profits of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation posted new records last year, but earnings in the fourth quarter dropped sharply, according to the annual results issued in Los Angeles yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) The texts of letters on the Middle East exchanged recently between President Nixon and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union became available today. They confirmed that Moscow favored intervention by the major powers that would compel Israel to withdraw from Arab territory conquered in 1967.

IT is expected that British conductors do something about British music, and Colin Davis dad not disappoint, last night in Philharmonic Hall. He conducted the Boston Symphony in the New York premiere of Michael Tippett's Symphony No. 2, a half-hour-long work in four movements that was composed in 1947.

William S. Greenawalt, Manhattan lawyer and former Northeast regional director of legal services in the Office of Economic Opportunity, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General.

MIAMI, Feb. 25 The "wrong one" won the $63,500 Black Helen Handicap today, but that made little difference to those in the crowd of 19,274 who had backed the favored Hobeau Farm entry. Taken Aback was expected to be in front for some part of the 1 1/8-mile test for older mares, but her stablemate, Harem Lady, was figured to be first at the end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Domestic as well as for eign threats determined the final shape of the Administration's proposals for expansion of the Safeguard antimissile system. In fact, the political danger faced by a stalwart friend of the ABM, Senator Henry M. Jackson of...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Following is the text of President Pompidou's address delivered today before a joint meeting of Congress. The translation was read by his official interpreter, Constantin Andronikof.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 25 (AP) Three high school pupils were among 20 persons arrested today in predawn drug raids by the city and the state police. An Onendaga County grand jury indicted 12 of the 20 on charges of selling drugs.
THE greatest marathon match ever played draws to a close this week in Philadelphia, and an exciting finish is in prospect.

Miss Sara Christina Thomson Slats, a bacteriologist doing research at the Rockefeller University, plans to be married to Paul Worthen Higgins. The wedding will take place April 11 at St. Thomas Episcopal Church with a reception at the New York Junior League.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 The Senate and Assembly passed differing versions today of measures designed to lower the voting age in the state from 21 to 18.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 The United States warned the world's major commercial nations today that without some freeing of international trade in farm products the agency supervising their relations could collapse.

Ben W. Heineman, chairman of the Chicago North Western Railway and chief executive of its parent, Northwest Industries, Inc., has given up his dream of creating a balanced Midwestern railroad system, which he would head.

Because of the skyrocketing costs of hospital and medical care and of just about everything associated with getting sick, it doesn't take long for a major medical crisis to run up bills almost beyond belief.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Criticism of the Administration's Laotian policy broke out in the Senate today as Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., a freshman Republican from Maryland, charged that the Executive branch was subverting the will of Congress by the American military involvement in Laos.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 The Government urged the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today not to grant bail to the defendants and the two attorneys in the Chicago conspiracy trial.
The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that it would close six of its 17 assembly plants in the United States in March for periods ranging from five to 11 days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The State Department said today it supported the 12-mile limit on territorial seas but was adhering to the traditional three-mile limit until international agreement could be reached.

The Federal Communications Commission was characterized as an "indifferent" agency ridden with "inertia" yesterday as an effort to improve minority-oriented programing and fair employment within the broadcasting industry was announced jointly by the office of Communication of the United Church of Christ and the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Education Fund.
VIENTIANE, Feb. 25 (Reuters) The American Ambassador, George Godley, was called to a conference today to discuss the deteriorating war situation in the north.

VIENNA, Feb. 25 The Czech- oslovak Education Minister, Jaromir Hrbek, warned in Prague today that "the most aggressive antisocialist, anti- party and anti-Soviet elements" were still active among stu- dents.

ST. DONAT, Quebec, Feb. 25 Last fall Don Dairy, ski school director at La Reserve, made the rounds of all the major ski shows in the United States trying to sell his resort as the Laurentians' "in" place.
Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, warned yesterday that institutional membership on the exchange, if it became possible, might force small investors out of the stock market.

NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 25 Disclosures that policemen testified secretly before a United States Senate subcommittee and gave the names of people who attended a lecture here by Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader, have stirred resentment and anger in many quarters.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 25 A group of 25 college students and teachers wearing gas masks and carrying anti-pollution placards distributed leaflets on an 8 A.M. Manhattan-bound commuter train, today.
Dr. Kurt R. Schmeller, president of Queensborough Community College, announced a $31-million expansion plan yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 25 An overwhelming preference for Nassau County's program of free surplus food over the use of food stamps has been expressed by low-income and welfare families in a poll conducted by the county.

Twenty-three years ago, when the abstract expressionist movement in American painting was still a long way from winning the nearly universal esteem it now enjoys, Mark Rothko wrote: "The unfriendliness of society to his activity, is difficult for the artist to accept."

A Federal grand jury handed up an indictment here yesterday, charging a salesman and seven present or former military post-exchange buyers with conspiracy to defraud the Government through a kickback scheme.

Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh halted pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers yesterday and announced that they would not be resumed until the defendants promised, in writing, to behave in accordance with American courtroom procedure.

Students who spent summers in France at the Fontainebleau Fine Arts and Music Schools during the last 49 years will gather in Carnegie Recital Hall March 8 for the 18th annual concert in behalf of the schools.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I. Feb. 25 Ed Johnson scored 8 points in less than a minute early in the fourth quarter to break open a close game and lead the New York Nets to a 117-114 victory over the Kentucky Colonels in an American Basketball Association game tonight at the Island Garden.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 25 United States bombers continued heavy attacks today in northeast Laos, especially around Muong Soui, where a Laotian-American air base was evacuated yesterday. The raids were designed to destroy ammunition and other supplies before they could be used by the Communist-led Pathet Lao rebels and their North Vietnamese allies.
Howard (Buddy) Jacobson accused New York racing authorities yesterday of a "vengeful conspiracy" to drive him out of the sport and destroy his career.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 25 (Reuters) The Ceylonese Government today granted a special license to enable Arthur C. Clarke, science-fiction writer and co-author of the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey," to import an electronic computer given to him by an American company.
THERE were eight sewing machines and 50 women in the Palm Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The Sewing machines hummed and the women spoke Russian.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Gen. Bruce Palmer Jr., the Army's second in command in Vietnam at the time of the alleged Songmy massacre,testified for 40 minutes today before a special Army board investigating the incident.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Sargent Shriver said today that he had submitted his resignation as Ambassador to France to President Nixon.
A Bronx pharmacist who had practised his marksmanship for about a year after having been the victim of nine holdups in six months shot and killed two brothers trying to rob him last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 An experimental vaccine has been developed against an important type of human fungus disease common in the Southwestern United States.
The Ford Foundation announced $2.7-million in grants yesterday to strengthen curriculums and counseling services for minority students at colleges and universities across the country.

A National Invitation Tournament bid may be the prize as Manhattan plays Georgetown tonight in the first game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. They are among the top independent teams in the East.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25 (Reuters) A $3-million base at Laikhe near Saigon was handed over today to the South Vietnamese by the First Infantry Division, scheduled to leave by April 15.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 In a colloquy marked by grim laughter, the Assembly passed a measure today that would add three members to the Civil Defense Commission and make room for them in the state's nuclear bomb bunker.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 A survey by the National Guard Bureau shows that the low rate of Negro enlistment remains virtually unchanged despite two years of official efforts at improvement.

In an era when progress in urban affairs almost by axiom implies decentralization, it is both surprising and stimulating to read the Committee on Economic Development's report on "Reshaping Government in Metropolitan Areas."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Senator Edmund S. Muskie declared here today that "the survival of the democratic process and of man himself" might depend on this nation's willingness to spend more for economic development of the poor countries of the world.
HAPPINESS for a dance lover is the return of City Center Joffrey Ballet to the New York City Center. Happiness happened last night yet even happiness has its off-beat chords.

It was the pilot's birthday, and he got the key to New York City. A movie projector failed en route. The 258 passengers aboard applauded as the plane took off in Los Angeles and later as it landed in New York. And as they streamed off, passengers waiting, for the return hop were having a champagne party. Otherwise, the inauguration of domestic jumbo jet service yesterday by Trans World Airlines Was routine.

MOSCOW, Feb, 25 Official Soviet sources said today that they shared President Nixon's hope for improved SovietAmerican relations but took strong exception to his criticism of Moscow's policy in the Middle East and Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 A personal holdings public disclosure law for public officials that passed the state legislature easily last year has turned out to have built-in political problems that may make the new law an issue in this year's Governorship campaign.
EAST PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 25 (AP) A three-weekold strike against the Manhattan Transit Company and the affiliated Mohawk Coach Lines ended today.

In a realignment of top management the Penn Central Transportation Company has appointed three executive vice presidents and two senior vice presidents, Stuart T. Saunders, chairman, announced yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Pamela Taylor to Ronald Gary Schumann has been announced by Miss Taylor's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Gurney Taylor of New York and Center Sandwich, N.H. Dr. Schumann, a San Francisco resident, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benno Richard Schumann of Fayetteville, N.Y.
Taking his cue from the Convention on Genocide, a Yale biologist has proposed a new international agreement to ban "Ecocide" the willful destruction of the environment.
ASABA, Nigeria, Feb. 25 Like the war-shattered villages around it, the bridge that spans the broad Niger River here is finally being rebuilt.

The Alabama Legislature gave initial approval yesterday to a school desegregation law patterned after New York State's statute curbing busing. Four other Southern states have adopted similar measures.

LYDDA, Israel, Feb. 25 Tel Aviv's international airport here was fairly crowded today, not only with traveling businessmen and tourists but with airline employes working after hours to move air traffic in and out of Israel as swiftly and safely as possible.

DENVER, Feb. 25 Nathan Clark is a soft-spoken young black man, a high school graduate with no jail or juvenile offense record, who is responsible enough to head a security detail of five officers at a large discount store.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Instructions to workmen: 1. Newspaper delivery boys Always leave the newspaper in a puddle of water in front of the customer's house. In dry periods when puddles are hard to find, carry a bucket of water to create puddles suitable for leaving the newspaper in as you go from customer to customer.

In denying bail to the defendants in Chicago pending appeal, Judge Julius Hoffman has continued to act in character as a man engaged in a personal vendetta. Fortunately, the case can now be expected to move speedily into more objectively judicious hands so that the defendants' rights will be assured full protection.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Senator Edward W. Brooke, a Republican, announced on the Senate floor today that he could not support confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court.
Robert A. Rosen has been appointed president and a director of Bell Television, Inc. He formerly was the vice president of corporate finance and a director of the company.
The city was ordered yesterday to release no later than Monday a controversial Rand Corporation housing study that reportedly includes an attack on the city's rent control policy.
West Coast track and field clubs, which have settled their financial dispute with the Amateur Athletic Union, will attempt to solve the mystique of Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

LONDON, Feb. 25 Wildcat strikes and the Government's credit squeeze have wiped out profits at the British Leyland Motor Corporation for the last four months, Lord Stokes, chairman, said at the annual meeting today.
MILAN, Italy, Feb. 25 (AP) The dollar reached an all-time exchange-rate high of 634 lire at the Milan foreign exchange today in the third straight increase from the floor level.

Mark Rothko, a pioneer of abstract expressionist painting who was widely regarded as one of the greatest artists of his generation, was found dead yesterday, his wrists slashed, in his studio at 157 East 69th Street. He was 66 years old. The Chief Medical Examiner's office listed the death as a suicide.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 25 The Federal grand jury seeking evidence against the plotters believed to have ordered and paid for the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski indicted a mine union official today on charges of conspiracy in connection with the slaying of the insurgent leader of the United Mine Workers of America.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 25 (UPI) The Australian yacht Carabella, sailed by Dave Forbes, won the 5.5-meter world championship today off Palm Beach.
Mayor Lindsay announced pay increases yesterday for the city's top 60 officials. The increases will cost about $190,000 a year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 A three-week slowdown in trash collection ended today after the garbage collectors' union forced the resignation of Chief Police Inspector Joseph P. Halferty as Streets Commissioner.

Bad luck overtook the Rangers again last night, although they scored a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a scorching contest and took a 4-point lead in the National Hockey League's East Division.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) British tourists can fly to New York and stay for a week for $213.60, hotel included, under a new charter plan announced today.

William M. Witter, 47 years old, was elected chairman and chief executive yesterday of Dean Witter Co., one of the nation's largest securities houses. Mr. Witter is a son of Jean C. Witter, honorary chairman.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 25 (AP) Len Chappell, Greg Smith and Lew Alcindor starred tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks rallied to beat the Baltimore Bullets, 115-113, in a National Basketball Association game.

PORTRAIT of the Young American as an Upper-Middle-Class Idealist: Paul Cowan went to Dalton, where his grades were poor. He went to Choate, where they improved. He went to Harvard, where he was an editor of The Crimson. He dropped out, served some time at the London School of Economics, then drifted to the Middle East.
IT could be called "The Intelligent Man's Guide for Dining in Europe," and if anyone doubts the efficacy of the plan, they might ask Charles and Gloria Mandelstam.

Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, has demanded the withdrawal of the French translation of her book "Only One Year," an account of her flight from the Soviet Union, charging that it has been distorted, apparently for political reasons.
Interest rates on tax-exempt bonds again moved lower yesterday, pushing yields on securities maturing in a year or two to the lowest levels since late last May.

PHOENIXES, of course, arise from the ashes by definition. However, it might be thought gratifying to note that the Phoenix Theater appears to be well-named, and at present it is most cheerfully kicking around a most lovely lot of ashes.
Insurance will cost more starting next month for many owners of new "high performance" or "muscle" cars, so designated because of extra power for fast starts.
COLOGNE, West Germany, Feb. 25 The Rhine flood appeared to the approaching its crest almost 27 feet above normal in the BonnCologne area today. Local newspapers called it the worst flood in 70 years.
Jeffrey Eastman Fuller, former assistant director of the American Civil Liberties Union, died Tuesday of a heart attack here. He was 52 years old and lived at 144-12 Village Road in Jamaica, Queens.
John Mulholland, magician and author of books on magic, died yesterday in University Hospital, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 600 West 115th Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 Senator Basil A. Paterson, a Harlem Democrat who is a candidate for Lieutenant Governor, said today that the liberal wing of the party should forsake its "lemming syndrome" and unite behind a single gubernatorial candidate.
LONDON, Feb. 25 The Deputy Premier and the Foreign Minister of Israel will discuss air safety and the Middle East crisis generally with British leaders in the next few days.

Maine potato futures prices occupied the spotlight in commodities trading again yesterday, as the three most active months hit new highs in heavy trading. Sales totaled 3,398 contracts and prices closed 13 to 15 cents higher on the active months.

An examination of election records disclosed yesterday that Morris B. Abram had failed to maintain his Democratic enrollment and so placed in jeopardy his chance to enter the June 23 primary for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon asked the Congress today to pledge a United States contribution of $100-million to the Asian Development Bank to finance expansion in Asia in the next three years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The appointment of William E. Stafford as consultant in poetry to the Library of Congress for the 1970-71 term was announced today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) Young demonstrators set fire to a branch of the Bank of America and to a police sedan tonight in the second night of street disturbances near the University of California's Santa Barbara campus.

HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Feb. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Martin Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Martin, to Richard Goodyear, son of Mrs. John Goodyear of Washington and the late Mr. Goodyear. The wedding will take place here on June 6.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP) Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today at a news conference that the Nixon Administration spoke with a "forked tongue" on racial issues.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 Hundreds of searchers who worked from dawn to dusk today found the body of only one of the 17 remaining victims of the gigantic avalanche that struck an army camp at Reckingen in southwestern Switzerland yesterday.

CAPE CHARLES, Va., Feb. 20 The future of Virginia's barrier islands, the last wild undeveloped seacoast between Maine and Norfolk, is again the subject of bitter debate between conservationists and land developers.

MACON, Ga., Feb. 25 (AP) Ingo Buding of France pulled an upset today in the opening round of the $15,000 Macon indoor tennis tournament by downing Ion Tirlac of Rumania, 4-6, 11-9, 7-5. Tiriac was the tournament's third-seeded foreign player.
City school officials were rebuked yesterday for sluggishness in putting up needed new buildings.

WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP) Andrea Voikos of Pawtucket, R.I., a 16-year-old local favorite, spiced otherwise routine first-round action in the national women's indoor tennis championships tonight by upsetting Peggy Michel of Pacific Palisades, Calif., 6-4, 7-5.
Prices on the London stock market closed easier yesterday after a reversal of earlier gains.

The Lincoln National Bank, a small bank in Philadelphia with some $50-million in assets announced yesterday a reduction in its prime, or minimum interest rate on business loans to 8 per cent from 8 per cent effective next week.
Three city policemen were acquitted in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn last night of charges that they had received bribes from gamblers in the borough's Negro slums.

PROVIDENCE, R.I, Feb. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Leo T. Dunne have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Elisabeth Dunne of Cambridge, Mass., to Enrique Jorge Tejera, son of Dr. Enrique Tejera, former Venezuelan Ambassador to the United States and now a member of the Venezuelan Congress.

HOUSTON, Feb. 25 On a winter's day in many an American city, when a blanket of high-altitude warm air chokes off normal atmospheric circulation, the description of leaden skies is more than a figure of speech. It suggests appropriately a chemical analysis of a pollution problem already fast approaching the crisis point in cities such as San Diego.
LONDON, Feb. 25 A partisan rift that has been building up over British entry into the Common Market erupted today on the floor of the House of Commons.

Allen Kander, a newspaper broker and consultant here for 42 years and a former Hearst newspaper executive, died Tuesday of a heart ailment in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in New York and Miami Beach.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 The Bruins won their biggest game of the season tonight, stopping the Rangers, 5-3, as they muscled their way past a weakened defense and forwards who got slapped around.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Vice President Agnew told the nation's Governors today that the defendants in the conspiracy trial of the Chicago Seven were a "handful of oddballs [who] deliberately set out to disrupt the most basic protection of our country, the dignity of the courts."
HONG KONG, Feb. 26 (AP) A drought that could severely damage China's spring wheat harvest is reported to have spread through four major provinces.

"King: A Filmed Record, Montgomery to Memphis" was screened on Wednesday night for invited representatives of the media at the Little Carnegie Theater. A preview of the Magic Theater, an exhibition of electrical environments designed by eight artists, has been arranged for Sunday at Automation House, 49 East 68th Street. The event, a benefit for the Museum of Contemporary Crafts of the American Crafts Council, also will open the building as the new home of the American Foundation on Automation and Employment.
ATHENS, Feb. 26 The Holy Synod of the Orthodox Church of Greece today criticized the Russian Orthodox Church's decision to administer its sacraments to Roman Catholics.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 26 Miss Wendy Sue Wiegers, granddaughter of the late Bernarr Macfadden, the publisher, plans to be married here April 25 to Cornelius Wayne Geier, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Geier of Westbury, L.I.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 26 Israel Kramer, a retired land developer, died Tuesday while vacationing in Miami Beach. He was 83 years old and lived at Shore Road.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 26 The Government indirectly accused the United States today of having used its cultural centers in India for "undesirable" political activities.

Miss Pamela Morgan Sullivan, a researcher with the American Petroleum Institute, and William Curtis Livingston 3d, an arbitrage analyst and administrative assistant at Bache Co., plan to marry on April 4.
VERBIER, Switzerland, Feb. 26 (AP) Billy Kidd of Stowe, Vt., was beaten in the final of the special slalom of a world pro ski meet today. Kidd lost to Kurt Rechner of Austria.

IRVING ANKER, whom an associate describes as "a sort of answer man to any question anybody's got about the city's school system," was asked by a visitor yesterday how much money he would receive in his new job as Acting Superinendent of Schools.
Ordinarily, life aboard a passenger liner in port for a four-day stay between cruises is boredom and somnolence.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 Five United States marines have been arrested and charged with murdering 11 South Vietnamese women and 5 children on Feb. 19, the Marine Corps command announced today.

Awards, The President said that he would present "atomic pioneers" awards tomorrow to Dr. Vannevar Bush, director of President Roosevelt's Office of Scientific Research and Development; Dr. James B. WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 A former law partner of G. Harrold Carswell has disclosed that Mr. Carswell personally prepared the charter in 1953 for a university booster club that excluded nonwhites from membership.

ETHEL SCULL by Andy Warhol is on the road. In Plexiglas cases to protect the multiple enlarged snapshots from deterioration during museum exhibitions. Ethel Scull by George Segal is at home. Sitting plastercast immobile on the love seat in the marble hallway. Not far from two of Jasper Johns's American flags and Claes Oldenberg's stove with the papier-mache sausages and rare roast beef.
LONDON, Feb. 26 The International Federation of Airline Pilots called today for an emergency conference on air safety.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 The New York Mets solved their final holdout today when Ron Swoboda signed a $40,000 contract for 1970.

MANILA, Feb. 26 Groups of young men roamed through Manila tonight hurling rocks and firebombs after riot policemen charged into and dispersed a throng demonstrating in front of the United States Embassy.

Emilio S. Bas, who retired two years ago as master in charge of the Government ferry from the Battery to Governors Island, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 555 West 160th Street.

The S.S. Manhattan, the first commercial vessel to transit the Northwest Passage, is expected to leave April 1 for a second series of tests to determine the economic feasibility of transporting Alaskan oil to East Coast markets by ship.

The extraordinary anguish among law school faculty members and leading lawyers over the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court should alert every Senator to consider his responsibility to country and Constitution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Nixon's program to replace much of the welfare system with income mainte- nance for the poor was tentatively approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
Melville Price, a modernexpressionist painter and a professor of art at the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa, died there Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.
Bond prices staged another broad advance yesterday, spurred by the growing conviction that some relaxation of credit is imminent or already under way.

Representatives of the city's 275,000 senior high school students condemned the Board of Education's statement on student rights and responsibilities yesterday and demanded consideration of their own stronger version.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (UPI) Mrs. Ann Jones of England, the defending champion in women's play at Wimbledon, announced tonight that she would miss this year's competition because of the strain involved.

ROME, Feb. 26 Theatened by a mass boycott of Italy's most influential cultural figures, the organizers of the Venice Biennale announced yesterday that its 1970 edition would be bigger, longer and more innovatory than ever. Most details of its actual program, however, still remain to be worked out, they said.
LONDON, Feb. 26 Beneath bronze statues and towering stained glass win dows, the House of Lords opened a solemn debate yesterday over the British Broadcasting Corporation's plans for rock and Bach.

Mayor Lindsay accepted "with reluctance" yesterday Governor Rockefeller's decision to run the northern segment of the Richmond Parkway along a route that cuts slightly into the Staten Island green belt.

BUFFALO, Feb. 26 About 100 students briefly invaded the Administration Building of the State University here tonight, smashing windows and setting a small fire.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 26 Carmine Abbatiello, making the nost of his skills, has prospered from a $150-a-week truck driver to a $150,000-a-year driver of trotters and pacers.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry F. Gardstein of New York and Lido Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Joy Gardstein, to Bradley Miles Fischman, son of Mrs. Irving Goldblatt of Brooklyn and the late Louis H.O. Fishman.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 26 (AP) Silent Screen, the 2-year-old champion of 1969, heads a list of 158 nominees for the 95th running of the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico race course on May 16.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 26 The Israelis reported that their jets shot down three Egyptian MIG-21 interceptors today in what appeared to be Cairo's strongest effort to counter Israel's twomonth-old policy of Nile Delta raids.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 Controller Arthur Levitt, documenting that millions of dollars in state loans to public authorities are never repaid, urged the Legislature today to pass stricter laws to "safeguard the funds of the state and its taxpayers."
DAKAR, Senegal, Feb. 26 (Reuters) President Leopold Senghor today named Abdou Diouf, Minister of Planning and Industry, as the new Premier.

The election of Charles Raymond Dahl as president and chief executive officer of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation was announced yesterday by Peter T. Sinclair, chairman of the San Francisco-based forest-products company. He succeeds the late Francis O. Boylon, who died last week.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 26 (UPI) A bill lifting all restrictions against abortions performed by licensed physicians was approved by the Arizona House today and sent to the Senate.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 26 (UPI) An embryologist suggested today that "host mothers" might be paid someday to give birth to babies conceived in test tubes from the eggs of women unable to have children.
MIAMI, Feb. 26 Federal and state officials ordered Florida's biggest power company today to curb the discharge of hot water from a generating plant into Biscayne Bay.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Thomas Gaffney of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Gaffney, to Robert Sanford Bennett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Bennett of Worcester, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The Government's index of "leading indicators" of the economy took a sharp drop in January and industrial wholesale prices showed a smaller increase in February than in other recent months, two reports disclosed today.
Morris B. Abram brushed off attacks on his eligibility to run for the United States Senate from New York with a charge yesterday that other contenders were maneuvering "to keep me out of the race."
Jay Hall Connaway, a wellknown marine and landscape artist, died Feb. 17 in Green Valley, Ariz. He was 77 years old.

Staggered working hours to ease rapid-transit strains at peak periods will start April 1 for at least 33,000 and perhaps 100,000 employes in the Wall Street financial area, the Dowtown-Lower Manhattan Association announced yesterday.
Most prices on the American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday in quiet trading.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 26 (UPI) Werner Bleiner of Austria posted the best time in the first run of the men's giant slalom today as Canada's four-day World Cup meet opened on Grouse Mountain.

WHATEVER it is that is wrong with "Georgy," the new musical that opened last night at the Winter Garden Theater, is wrong for too long. It has some good performances, a brightly literate book, a few characterizations of a depth unusual in a musical. But it never takes off, never flies, never whirls you in the air with that special happiness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Nixon sent to Congress today a special message seeking assistance in his effort to eliminate or reorganize 57 Government programs at an ultimate annual saving of more than $2-billion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, unveiled today 22 building designs selected as part of his department's effort to meet what he called the nation's increasingly desperate housing shortage.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 387 applicants to the New York State Bar had passed the examination held on Dec. 10 and 11. A total of 640 persons took the test.
