PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (UPI) Bobby Hull scored two goals tonight to give the surging Chicago Black Hawks their fourth consecutive victory, 3-2, over the Philadelphia Flyers in a National Hockey League game.

Lindsay administration officials said yesterday that the Supreme Court's extension of the one-man, one-vote principle to all local governing boards was a mandate for a total reevaluation of the structure of city government.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26 A meeting of the major league player representatives at Miami tomorrow may determine the nature and the extent of labor peace on the baseball front for months ahead.
The Kienast quintuplets, born Tuesday night six weeks before term, were taken off their special oxygen-enriched air yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 26 (Reuters) The Syrian Foreign Ministry instructed it embassies and consulates today not to give entry visas to Swiss nationals without its approval.

MACON, Ga., Feb. 26 (UPI) Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey advanced to the quarterfinals of the Macon international tennis tournament today, but the two top-seeded foreign players and Clark Graebner were eliminated.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 26 (AP) Rhodesia, which declared its independence from Britain on Nov. 11, 1965, will become a republic at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday, it was announced today.

The tentative decision of the House Ways and Means Committee to approve President Nixon's plan for a Federal floor under family income reflects credit on the committee's chairman, Representative Wilbur Mills of Arkansas. Recognizing that basic surgery is necessary to overcome the deficiencies of the present welfare system, Mr. Mills was willing to submerge his own reservations to the Administration's approach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 A Government agency operating with an aggressive and largely unfettered management has built an obscure string of stores into one of the largest, most powerful and least visible retail enterprises in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe said today that he was willing to reconsider the need for the central link in Boston's downtown freeway system a project he had championed for most of a decade as Governor of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Feb.26 The Senate passed tonight a bill that provides $5-billion over 10 years to expand and improve the domestic airport and airway system. The money would be supplemented by state contributions of $25-billion.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (AP) The United States Command's weekly casualty report today said 83 Americans were killed in action last week and 657 were wounded. The week before, 96 dead and 589 wounded were reported.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Arthur F. Burns has begun to leave his imprint on the Federal Reserve Board

Governor Rockefeller, declaring himself "deeply disturbed" by the cemetery workers' rejection of arbitration in their dispute with 44 New York area cemeteries, moved yesterday to invoke the fact-finding machinery of the State Labor Law.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 A substance has been found in cancer tissue that makes cells grow wildly, without discipline.
Grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade were mostly lower yesterday in moderate dealings.

NORTH GRAFTON, Mass., Feb. 26 Mr. and Mrs. Augustus George Bullock of North Grafton and Jamestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Polly Primrose Bullock to Durban Alexander McGraw Jr., son of Mrs. Joseph Paterno of Osterville, Mass., and Mr. McGraw of Osterville. The wedding is planned for June in Jamestown.
In 1965, the Amateur Athletic Union held its national indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

IT IS PROBABLY true that the average man who seeks investment counsel doesn't really want it. What he really wants is an expert he can second guess. As a result, many professional investment managers spend too much time holding hands with their clients and not enough time watching stocks.

Roger O. Walther has been elected president and chief executive officer of the National Student Marketing Corporation. Mr. Walther, who had been executive vice president and chief operating officer since July 1969, succeeds Cortes W. Randell, who resigned March 19.
Brigid Brophy, the Irish author who lives in London, did not come to New York for the publication of her recent book "In Transit."
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26 (UPI) Plenty Old scored a major upset at Santa Anita today when he captured the $30,550 San Jacinto Stakes for 3-yearolds by a nose over the heavily favored George Lewis.
Member companies of the New York Shipping Association, by a vote of 58 to 3, have approved a resolution changing the basis for member assessments to pay for fringe benefits for longshoremen.

TWENTIETH-CENTURY Czech music, Janacek aside, is a bit of a mystery. We do not hear much of it, and yet the Bohemian fields and forests have spawned many composers since the death of Dvorak in 1904. Most of them are only names to American audiences.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 (AP) Lillian Hellman was turned down today by New York's highest court in her $500,000 suit against the Columbia Broadcasting System for televising the movie "The Little Foxes."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 After years of scientific scoffing at reports that remains of a massive wooden structure lie collapsed beneath a glacier on Mount Ararat, a prestigious research organization has, at least in part, been won over.

A new United States commitment to open world markets with measures to halt growing trends toward protectionism and discrimination was pictured yesterday as the Administration's basic trade-policy goal.

As Hollywood dismantles its huge production studios, movies made for television, like "My Sweet Charlie," are becoming the talk of the industry, and it is already apparent that they will play an increasingly important role in TV's immediate future.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 Dr. Walter Koppelman, a University of Pennsylvania mathematics professor, died here today two weeks after he was shot in the chest by a former graduate student.

Denis M. Hurley and Mrs. Minneola P. Ingersoll have been elected president and secretary, respectively, of the Brooklyn Public Library. The voting, by the library's board of trustees, also re-elected Jay Sam Unger as vice president and H. Elliot Wales, treasurer.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 26 George C. Wallace con fidently entered the Alabama governor's race today and promptly accused the Nixon Administration of trying to arrange for his defeat.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 26(AP) A candidate for Congress from the government's Revolutionary party and two of his supporters were shot to death last night while putting up campaign posters for presidential and congressional elections Sunday.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group reported yesterday a 9.3 per cent increase in 1969 net in come to $946-million from $865.1-million in 1968. This was the best earnings gain of any major international oil company shown for last year. Sales rose 7.5 per cent to $14,113,500,000 from $13,128,400,000 in 1968.
Easier money, which Wall Street is convinced lies just around the corner, was nowhere to be found during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.
Mayor Lindsay was sharply criticized yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame and Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr. for banding out $190,000 in raises on Monday to 60 administrative aides.
Inflation will diminish and interest rates will come down substantially later this year.
Dartmouth College announced yesterday that, after a hiatus of nearly 60 years, its medical school would resume awarding M.D. degrees beginning in 1973.
The dramatization of Brendan Behan's recollections of his prison years, "Borstal Boy," will have its American premiere Tuesday, March 31, at the Lyceum Theater.

HOUSTON, Feb. 26 A little bit of Africa, reddish dust whipped up by storms over the Sahara Desert and borne by trade winds across the Atlantic Ocean, regularly reaches the West Indies in such atmospheric concentrations that scientists suspect it may contribute to the cause of hurricanes.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 Senator William T. Conklin, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Banking Law, rejected today the idea of establishing an independent committee to study revision of bank district lines.

Claudio Abbado, currently guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic, led an uncommonly interesting program in Philharmonic Hall last night. It might have been called "Three Centuries of Austrian Composers," since Mozart, Bruckner and Alban Berg were represented, but this would be meaningless. The three works performed had nothing in common and could suggest no elements of continuous tradition.
WASHINGTON, Feb., 26 Lawrence F. O'Brien turned down today a plea from former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey that he resume the chairmanship of the troubled Democratic party.

Passengers on city-owned buses were reminded yesterday by the Transit Authority that tomorrow is the deadline for the acceptance of the old 20-cent tokens as part of the payment of the exact fare on buses.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 26 (AP) Mary Saxton and Neil Blatchford, both of Illinois, swept the ladies' and men's 500-meter events today in an international speed skating meet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 By a roll-call vote of 228 to 150, the House of Representatives refused today to consider a controversial bill to permit increased logging in the national forests.
BELGRADE, Feb. 26 (Reuters) Stanoje Simic, Yugoslavia's Foreign Minister from 1946 to 1948, died here today at the age of 77.

Ludwig Olshansky's Carnegie Hall piano recital Wednesday night provided a good deal to admire, including what seemed to be an excellent performance its first in New York, of Michael Brozen's Fantasy (1967).

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 26 (Reuters) Thai troops have stepped up their sweeps in northern border areas as part of a full alert ordered yesterday following the North Vietnamese thrust in Laos, official sources said today.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 26 American Jewish leaders adopted today a goal of $250-million for the sale of Israel Bonds this year to provide increased economic aid for Israel.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 26 A black and Puerto Rican sit-in prevented the state's Big-Six Mayors, including New York's John Lindsay, from taking their seats on the speakers' platform for more than 20 minutes at a community forum on urban problems here today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) A young leader of the Blackstone Rangers street gang, convicted of murdering a police radio dispatcher in a raid on police headquarters in suburban East Chicago Heights, was sentenced today to die in the electric chair.

Investors purchased $522,752,000 of mutual fund, shares last month, up slightly from $522,155,000 in December, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In January, 1969, purchases amounted to $875,862,000.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 26 Davis P. Harding, an associate professor of English at Yale University, died Tuesday in YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 65 Spring Garden Street in Hamden.
Chain stores and catalogue houses continued to show sizable sales gains in January compared with the year before, according to a survey by The New York Times yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Senate hearings on a 47-yearold proposed constitutional amendment to guarantee equal rights for women are scheduled for May, according to Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana.

Lawyers for 13 Black Panthers, whose pretrial hearings here have been halted pending assurance to the judge that the defendants will behave in the courtroom, expect to be back in court Monday with their answer.
A 12-year-old narcotics addict who said that he took his last fix eight days ago shocked a hearing on drug addiction yesterday when he told legislators how he had become addicted.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 Palestinian guerrilla organizations have begun to apply their own discipline in Lebanon and Jordan.

WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP) Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and Mrs. Mary Ann Eisel Curtis of St. Louis did not lose a game tonight as they led the advance of five seeded Americans into the quarter finals of the National indoor women's tennis championships.
The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices of unbleached kraft grocery bag and sack paper by $6 to $8 a ton, depending on the grade and basis weight involved.

IN EVERY women's designer, apparently, there's a men's tailor yearning to emerge. Now it's Oscar de la Renta, whose name on Seventh Avenue conjures up ruffles and low decolletages and all those things feminine girls are made of.

OTTAWA, Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) Canada produced $78,099,000,000 in goods and services last year, a 9.3 per cent increase in the Gross National Product, despite a record loss of production because of labor disputes, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) A freighter plowed into an oil-filled barge tonight, sending a bank-to-bank black mass rolling down the St. Johns River.
Five members of the New York Giants underwent elbow surgery yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

Emma Harrison, a former reporter for The New York Times who won a number of awards for her coverage of mentalhealth news, died last night after a long illness. She was 48 years old and lived at 477 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive.

An intensive investigation is going on into the murder of an informer for the Federal Bureau of Narcotics whose death last October forced a reduction of charges against three men accused of smuggling drugs.

The LFC Financial Corporation, a billion-dollar savings and loan holding company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it expected to report a net loss for 1969 as a result of losses that it had uncovered in its portfolio of loans and real estate.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 A winning performance by Harold Koerner's Petunia featured the activity at Hialeah today. The Kentucky-bred daughter of Jester was made the 2-1 favorite in the main event by the 16,093 top-coated fans, and she came through with little trouble, under a ride by Jacinto Vasquez.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 26 Defying a curfew, heavy police patrols and a declaration of "extreme emergency" by Gov. Ronald Reagan, hundreds of youths pelted police cars with rocks and clashed with policemen tonight on the outskirts of this university community.

HONG KONG, Feb. 26 Peking has designated Kuo Mo-jo, a comparatively unimportant figure in the Chinese Communist hierarchy, to represent Communist China in Katmandu at the wedding of the son of the King of Nepal tomorrow. The designation was viewed here today as underscoring Peking's continued aloofness in foreign relations.

IF YOU'VE seen one boat show, you've seen them all. "Not so," says Gerry Gasque, the director of the 17th annual Jersey Coast Boat Show. "Although we may not have as many boats as the New York show, we have boats they didn't have, some boats they couldn't
GENEVA, Feb. 26 Italy appealed to France today to end her eight-year boycott of the Geneva disarmament conference.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 National policemen seized Representative Tran Ngoc Chau in his sanctuary in the National Assembly today and dragged him struggling out of the rear gate to begin a 20-year prison sentence on charges of pro- Communist activity. The police raid, watched by hundreds of South Vietnamese spectators who had been expecting it, ended a fourday sit-in in the National Assembly by the 46-year-old.
Mayor Lindsay told the City Council yesterday that by June 1 he would propose modifications in the city's 27-year-old rent control law "to strengthen the owner's economic base."

ROME, Feb. 26 Italian officials acknowledged today that they had little or no money to spend on conservation, but said that they would nevertheless strive to make 1970, proclaimed as European Nature Conservation Year, a "starting point" for a serious attack on the country's grave environmental problems.

Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday that "I disagree strongly" with most of the proposals advanced by a housing expert to encourage construction of luxury housing.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 26 (Reuters) The Common Market's executive commission assailed restrictive trends in the trade policy of the United States in a document issued today and said world trade would suffer if a liberal policy were abandoned.

BONN, Feb. 26 West Germany's agriculture can expect to lose one million self-employed farmers and farmhands to industry by 1980, the Govenment said today in a report analyzing the long-range prospects of farming.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 The Soviet Union appeared to intensify its campaign against Israel today with the publication of letters from Soviet Jews condemning Israel and Zionism.
Tenneco, Inc., announced yesterday that its subsidiary, Packaging Corporation of America, had acquired full ownership of the Tennessee River Pulp Paper Company.
An Internal Revenue Service agent arrested on bribery charges yesterday became the ninth former or present tax official who has been arraigned since Jan. 23 for taking bribes.

The Bendix Corporation yesterday elected Christian M. Cardin to its board of directors. He is president of the Paribas Corporation. His election was announced by Bendix following its annual stockholders' meeting in Southfield, Mich.

BONN, Feb. 26 The Cabinet of Willy Brandt, the Social Democratic Chancellor, fulfilled one of his fundamental campaign promises today by approving a bill designed to give factory workers the opportunity to increase their assets.

THOSE women who worry about situations in which their sex is not afforded an even break may care to note that all 44 presidents of the American Contract Bridge League have been male. The American Bridge Association, a primarily Negro group, has been similarly masculine in its 38-year history, but recently set a presidential precedent by electing Pauline Taylor of Detroit to its highest office.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary is planning to shift 200 men from gambling-law enforcement to antinarcotics work in an effort to relieve the "crises proportions" of the city's drug problem.
AVON, Conn., Feb. 26 Second Lieut, Judith Carol Anderson, an Air Force flight nurse, and First Lieut. Arthur Reid Miller, a fighter pilot, will be married April 11.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 26 (AP) The defending champion, Rodney Pattison of Britain, sailed Superdocious into the lead over another British craft, Hucklebuck IV, today in the Flying Dutchman yachting world championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Total United States monetary reserves, swollen by the first allocation of Special Drawing Rights, rose by $432-million in January, the Treasury and Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) A House Agriculture subcommittee approved today a proposed new wheat support program that would guarantee farmers against any future cuts in price supports.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Feb. 21 was 0.8 per cent below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
ROCHESTER, Feb. 26 (AP) Col. Louis G. Kelly, who was Military Governor of the Saar Valley in Germany after World War II, died today in Highland Hospital. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) The Army will no longer keep tabs on peaceful demonstrations or publish a list of individuals who "might be involved" in a riot, the chairman of the House Invasion of Privacy Subcommittee announced today.
In one area of the South Bronx a man walks around with a carton on his shoulder. It is empty, but on the sides is a three-digit number the winning combination for the day in the numbers racket.

WASHINGTON Of all problems bequeathed by the 19391945 war, the least necessary and the most puzzling is surely Berlin which, small as it is, like Tennyson's "Flower in the Crannied Wall," symbolizes much more.
The Kimberly-Clark Corporation is planning a major expansion of its nonwoven fabric manufacturing operations, officials of the paper company said here yesterday.
Some calls from pay telephones to locations within the five boroughs will cost 25 cents under an interim rate increase for the New York Telephone Company that took effect yesterday.
Prices on the London stock market drifted lower again yesterday on lack of interest. Market indexes slipped to lows for the year.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 26 Negotiations in the teachers' strike here, stalled since before the walkout on Feb. 9, resumed tonight while teachers in Newark reported for work after settlement of a 23-day stoppage there.

City officials were urged yesterday by the principal, teachers and students of a Harlem high school with a major drug problem to restore $5.7-million to the capital budget for a "comprehensive high school" in Harlem to prepare students for college or train them for a vocation of their choice.
The Appellate Division reversed a State Supreme Court ruling yesterday and reinstated the proposed decentralized school district lines for Manhattan.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 Dave Marr couldn't bend his right knee on Tuesday and he had it drained by a local physician. Today, in the opening round of the $150,000 Doral-Eastern open golf tournament, Marr scored a five-under-par 67 and shared the lead with Jack McGowan.
MANHASSET, L.I., Feb. 26 Miss Meredith Walsh Maher and Dennis Patrick Brosnan will be married April 25 in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn.

Ninety fifth-graders in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district in Brooklyn who underwent an intensive reading course over the last three months have surpassed the national norm, according to the course's sponsors.
MANHASSET, L.I., Feb. 26 Miss Meredith Walsh Maher and Dennis Patrick Brosnan will be married April 25 in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn.

Ninety fifth-graders in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district in Brooklyn who underwent an intensive reading course over the last three months have surpassed the national norm, according to the course's sponsors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Hospital charges will rise about 70 per cent in the next five years, Senators investigating soaring medical costs were told today by the Social Security Administration's chief actuary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 United States officials said today that three days of FrenchAmerican discussions during President Pompidou's stay here had not reduced significantly the differences between the two Governments over Middle East policies.

Miss Mary Akin, a personnel associate with the McCann-Erickson Advertising Agency, and Carl Phillip Horton, an executive, with the Oldsmobile division of General Motors here, plan to be married in May.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 26 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pipers held off a late Kentucky rally and defeated the slumping Colonels, 113-106, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the physicist, has emerged as the leading candidate to become the new president of City College.
A VISIT to the Bartow-Pell Mansion in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, should convince anyone of the merits of American Empire furniture, pieces made between about 1810 and 1840.

FROM the quiet abstractions of theoretical phys- ics to the clamorous social realities of an urban campus is the quantum leap that Dr. Robert E. Marshak has undertaken in accepting the presidency of City College.
Prices on the London stock market again drifted lower yesterday on continued lack of buyer interest. The downtrend sent market indexes to lows for the year.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 (AP) A log of electronic surveillance of New Jersey underworld figures conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation contains a reference to a person with the surname of the then Hudson County Prosecutor, who is now a Federal judge.

Ben Weber, a composer who works slowly, carefully and well, is so unassuming and so undemanding of public attention that the excellence of his music is known and appreciated by far too few of his fellow Americans. But almost every time he produces a new composition, those who hear it are enriched by the experience.
Dr. Robert E. Marshak, a leading physicist who is widely known for his promotion of international scientific cooperation, was named president of City College yesterday.
ROME, Feb. 27 (AP) The Italian Socialist party rejected Premier Mariano Rumor's proposal tonight of a coalition, apparently ending his hopes for a four-way, center-left Government.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Feb. 27 (UPI) The Grumman Corporation announced today that it expected layoffs involving 5,000 employes by the end of the year.
When the hundred-grand horse races start popping up on opposite coasts, the hundred-grand jockeys start taking to the air.

The extent to which strikes drag on long after there is any conscionable justification for them is currently getting gruesome illustration in the seven- week-old strike of New York gravediggers. The employers have endorsed the recommendation of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay that all disputed issues be arbitrated; the union says no.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27 Bobby Murcer and Horace Clarke signed their New York Yankee contracts today, leaving only Jerry Kenney unsigned, and he is expected to agree to terms on Monday.

Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said yesterday that his agency "contemplates no need for action at this time which would impede normal operations" of either of the savings and loan associations owned by the LFC Financial Corporation.
An installation service for the Rev. Raymond C. Schulze as eighth pastor of Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 88th Street, will be held at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

BUFFALO, Feb. 27 Representative Richard D. McCarthy of Buffalo, a Democrat who has been elected three times from the normally Republican 39th Congressional District, announced his candidacy for the United States Senate today.
FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 27 (UPI) A 19-year-old cousin of President Nixon, Monty Milhous, makes his professional bull-riding debut tomorrow at the Pacific Indoor Rodeo here.
SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 27 Miss Diane Amy Anderson and William Blaine Asher Jr. will be married May 30 at the arboretum at Wellesley College.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP) The United States automobile industry continued to slump in February with auto makers building fewer cars so far this year than in any similar period since 1964, Automotive News reported yesterday.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 27 Middlebury overcame a fractional advantage Dartmouth had achieved in the downhill today with a solid team performance in the 15-kilometer cross-country race to take a slim lead at the halfway mark in its 39th winter carnival.
Dick Tiger injured his left shoulder yesterday and withdrew from a 10-round fight against Emile Griffith scheduled for Madison Square Garden on March 11.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 (AP) Clay L. Shaw, acquitted a year ago of charges that he conspired to kill President Kennedy, filed a $5-million damage suit today against District Attorney Jim Garrison and others involved in the case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 A computer scientist from White Plains, N.Y., thinks that the Government is approaching welfare reform in the wrong way and is willing to put $500,000 of his own money to prove it.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 27 (AP) Three Federal judges upheld today an order by the Food and Drug Administration that seven antibiotic drugs manufactured by the Upjohn Company be taken off the market because they produce side effects.

The Eastern States schoolboy indoor track championships lived up to premeet expectations last night at the 102d Engineers Armory. Five records were posted, including a national flat-floor mark in the 600 and near national standards in the two-mile run and two-mile relay.

MACON, Ga., Feb. 27 (AP) Top-seeded Arthur Ashe of the United States rallied in the final set today to defeat Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia and advance to the semifinals of the Macon international tennis tournament. The scores were, 7-5, 7-9, 6-2.

Sixteen young men from near-poverty backgrounds were graduated yesterday by the Community Film Workshop Council following their completion of a six-week course in the techniques of television journalism.
A private philanthropist, who prefers to remain anonymous, will underwrite this year's Paradise Ball on March 5 at the Plaza. The dinner dance aids 700 poor children in New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Leaders of four shopcraft unions announced today that they would return to the bargaining table for another attempt to settle their 15-monthold contract dispute with the railroad industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27 The delegates of the Big Four the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union conferred for three hours today at the Waldorf Astoria on the Middle East but, according to diplomatic sources, made no progress on any point.

LISBON The surroundings are no longer much to look at. The area is shabby, part of a working-class suburb of Lisbon. The estate, which dates back to the 17th century, is large and also has seen better days.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 Grenade attacks in the Gaza Strip took the life of a 13-year-old Arab boy today and injured 39 other persons, all but three Arab residents of Gaza.
New York State sued 11 foreign airlines yesterday on charges of having polluted the air at Kennedy International Airport with the exhaust fumes from their jet planes.

THEAY KOM, Cambodia, Feb. 16 On a map, Tonle Sap, the Great Lake of Cambodia, looks as though it were studded with islands, so densely is it dotted with villages. The villages exist, but they are not on islands. They float.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Government today granted a new trial to Tran Ngoc Chau, a 46year-old member of South Vietnam's National Assembly who was sentenced Wednesday to 20 years in prison for alleged Communist activity.

Sarah Kienast, the second of the quintuplets born to Mrs. Margaret Kienast late Tuesday evening, caused a few tense hours for doctors at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center early yesterday when she again developed a respiratory difficulty.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 John P. Cahill, 19-year-old son of Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey, was indicted by the February grand jury here yesterday on a charge of possessing marijuana.

Walter J. Hickel, Secretary of the Interior, said yesterday that he would make a decision on construction permits for the trans-Alaskan pipeline system in the next six weeks. He indicated approval was likely.

The election of Harding F. Bancroft, executive vice president of The New York Times, and Mrs. John B. Coburn, wife of newly installed rector of St. James' Episcopal Church, as directors of Greer Children's Community was announced yesterday.
Commuters from Connecticut were promised yesterday a delay of at least a month in having to pay higher fares on the Penn Central's New Haven-New York commuter service.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) Dr. Allen said last night that he expected President Nixon to announce next week the creation of a national council to assure that every school child in the nation learns to read.

YONKERS, Feb. 27 Theodore M. Pennington, who retired in 1959 as a credit investigator for the First National City Bank in New York, died here yesterday. He was 75 years old and lived at 66 Fairfield Road.
MANILA, Feb. 27 (AP) The police raided the Philippine College of Commerce today and seized 37 students and teachers, as well as guns and Communist books. The college president protested.

IN an age when tickless, tocless, faceless, hand- less clocks have created more than a flurry of interest, some people still want grandfather clocks that go dingdong not once but four times an hour and have to be wound every week. Or so the Herschede Hall Clock...

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 27 (AP) For the second time in two weeks, a Roman Catholic priest has abandoned a Colombian parish and joined Castroite guerrillas operating in jungle territory, military sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Imports rose faster than exports in January, thus checking the improvement of the United States trade surplus that had emerged in late 1969, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Supreme Court refused today to grant a hearing to seven Ku Klux Klan members who were convicted of conspiracy in connection with the murder of three civil rights workers in Neshoba County, Miss., in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Federal Communications Commission announced guidelines today on what broadcasters can and cannot report about the New York State Lottery without promoting it.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 27 (AP) Len Lylyholm and Craig Patrick led the favored United States team to its third straight victory, a 5-1 triumph over Yugoslavia, tonight in the Group B tournament of the World ice hockey championships.
The tempo of negotiations to settle the 27-day-old tugboat strike accelerated yesterday as both sides in the dispute met jointly for the second day in a row.

Ryder System, Inc., a diversified transportation service company, announced yesterday it has entered the insurance field by acquiring Southern Underwriters, Inc., one of the largest insurance service firms in the southeast, for an undisclosed amount of common stock.

"You couldn't help liking Ralphie," said Henry Schechtman, the principal of Public School 60 in the Bronx. He was referring to Ralph de Jesus, a 12-year-old student at his school who became a heroin addict.

GENOA, Italy, Feb. 27 (Reuters) The customs police today charged Ildebrando Bossi, a Genoa antique dealer, with illegally exporting a Raphael painting that is now in the Boston Museum, legal sources said.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Democratic Governors demanded today a greater voice in national party affairs, and former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey promised that they would get it.
All but about three of the nation's biggest railroads have decided they can't wait any longer, but must seek another freight rate increase of about 6 per cent.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 The scene of the alleged killing of five Vietnamese women and 11 children by five United States marines is an area fought for longer than any other in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation received a patent this week for its phototypesetting machine, which can compose...
The American Stock Exchange finished the week on a bullish note yesterday as the list advanced on expanded volume.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 (AP) Smoking is an even greater health hazard in relation to heart disease than it is to cancer, a New York heart specialist said here today.
The Lindsay Administration's top housing official declared yesterday that the city lacked the capacity to implement the Rand Corporation's program for halting the widespread decay of housing here.

From the day after their arrest last April 2 until Dec. 29, the Black Panthers awaiting trial here on charges of conspiracy to bomb public places were kept apart, scattered among seven jails in four boroughs. Now the men among them are in the same jail with some freedom to consult each other.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (Reuters) Lady Kathleen PelhamClinton-Hope, the 19-year-old daughter of the Duke of Newcastle, and Edward Reynolds, a 20-year-old conductor on the London subway system, were married yesterday.

Coaches Red Holzman of the Knicks and Gene Shue of the Baltimore Bullets may be preoccupied with injuries tonight as their clubs conclude their regular-season National Basketball Association series before an expected capacity crowd of 19,500 at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Southern Democrats teamed up with Republicans in the Senate today to approve a spending restriction that may break the impasse between Congress and the White House over a health and education appropriations bill.
Miss Joan L. Golub and Patrick J. Desmond, who have been courting backstage at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, where they are appearing in "The Front Page," plan to be married on April 5.
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation had a 19.7 per cent rise in earnings last year on a sales gain of 13.3 per cent, with both setting records, R.B. Pamplin, chairman and president, reported yesterday.
LONG VALLEY, N.J., Feb. 27 The battered body of a 28-year-old mother was found sprawled in the recreation room of her home this morning.

The Rokko Maru, a 2,700gross-ton catamaran ferry, described by the Japanese builder, Nippon Kokan, as the world's largest, is now making 70-mile runs between Kobe and Takamatsu. She measures 274 feet with a beam of 82 feet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Supreme Court has agreed to consider for the first time the impact of Federal antimerger statutes upon "small" banks those having less than $25-million in deposits.

Internal strife, murders, disappearances, weak hearts and law enforcement have caused such havoc and confusion in the organized crime "family" formerly ruled by Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno that the Mafia's national commission is reported to have appointed three temporary administrators.

NORTH VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 27 (AP) Alain Penz of France whisked down Grouse Mountain today to edge Werner Bleiner of Austria by two one hundredths of a second and win the giant slalom at Canada's World Cup ski meet.
BRIGHTON, England, Feb. 27 (AP) Sir Robert Bruce Lockhart, an author and former British diplomat who was imprisoned briefly in the Kremlin in 1918, died in a nursing home today. He was 82 years old.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 27 Mrs. Nancy Moran Noel was married here this morning to James A. Grinder of New York. Probate Judge Carl V. Nelson performed the ceremony in Town Hall.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 27 (AP) A Lagos court today convicted four Roman Catholic missionaries two priests and two nuns on charges of entering Nigeria illegally during the Nigerian civil war and ordered them deported.

Defense Secretary Laird's promise that President Nixon will not send combat troops to Laos without the consent of Congress is hardly reassuring, in the light of the secrecy that continues to surround already serious United States involvement there and the apparent ineffectiveness of American-support efforts to stem a new Communist drive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The chairmen of the Federal Trade Commission, Casper W. Weinberger, said today that the group was considering a rule requiring the pretesting of fabrics for flammability before they are marketed.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 27 Representatives of Jewish communities in the United States and Canada were told today by Premier Golda Meir of Israel that the Middle East crisis had heightened her nation's dependence on increased American Jewish financial support.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Supreme Court today denied bail to Joseph Arthur Zicarelli, 57 years old, of Cliffside Park, N.J., who has been jailed for refusing to answer questions by the New Jersey crime commission which is investigating Mafia operations.
Rhinoceros, from Los Angeles, provided a generally spectacular concert last night as its part of a benefit at Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 The Hialeah Turf Cup, elevated to $100,000 status this season, will be the main attraction for the final Saturday program of the Hialeah meeting tomorrow. Always popular with horsemen, foreigners as well as those from this country, this year's running has attracted a dozen participants.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 21 totaled an estimated 14.9 billion ton-miles. This was four per cent above the corresponding week of last year.
MANCHESTER, England, Feb. 27 Students occupied a campus building at the bleak University of Manchester today with traditional British reserve.

Dr. Eugene G. Fubini, a scientist and engineer, has been elected a director and officer of the board of Texas Instruments, Inc. He served in the office of the Secretary of Defense from 1961 to 1965 and was a vice president of International Business Machines Corporation from 1965 to 1969.

BRASILIA, Feb. 27 (UPI) President Emilio G. Medici told Brazilians tonight that he could not surrender dictatorial powers and restore democratic processes to Latin America's largest country, as he had said he would do on taking office four months ago.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP) About 150 black students from five area colleges abandoned seven buildings on the Mount Holyoke College campus this afternoon, 13 hours after they took them over to protest "academic terrorism and atrocities."
MIAMI, Feb. 27 C.L. (Gibby) Gilbert Jr., a 29-yearold Hollywood (Fla.) professional, was unawed by the big names in the event as he led the $150,000 Doral-Eastern open golf tourney today.

About 1,500 maintenance employes, attendants and technicians at nine city museums, libraries and zoos voted Thursday night to accept a new contract with the city. It will provide salary raises ranging from $1,150 for matrons to $2,150 for supervising maintainers. The present salaries range from about $4,500 to $10,000.
It's repertory time for the moment at the City Center Joffrey Ballet, an occasion that gives old-timers possible new insights and first-timers a look at the standards.
DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP) The General Motors Corporation said today it had developed a method for reclaiming metal scrap left when fenders, hoods and other body parts are stamped out.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 Led by John Hammer and Jeff Petrie, co-captains, Princeton clinched third place in the Ivy League tonight with a 65-58 victory over Cornell.
The stock market sniffed the magic aroma of lower interest rates yesterday as prices boomed ahead in the next-to-strongest session of 1970.

ATLANTA, Feb. 27 (UPI) A medical scientist in charge of research on the highly virulent Lassa fever virus said today that it might have been the agent that decimated several population centers in Africa's sub-Sahara region 15 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told a military audience tonight that it was too early to establish a deadline for ending the draft and switching to an all-volunteer military force.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (UPI) The nation's young people are being lost to a "freaking fag revolution," the chief prosecutor in the trial of the Chicago says.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Nixon declined today to raise the tariff on sheet glass as the industry had requested, but he offered the industry and its workers "adjustment assistance."

KATMANDU, Nepal, Feb. 27 With the snow-draped Himalayas for a backdrop, the lengthy wedding ceremony of the Crown Prince of Nepal began today with a bespangled procession watched by representatives from over 50 countries and several hundred thousand Nepalese.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 The Board of Regents voted 11 to 2 today in favor of the current legislative effort to repeal the constitutional bar against state aid to parochial schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Nixon sent a congratulatory message to the Organization of American States, whose new charter went into effect today at ceremonies here.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 Two Soviet generals hinted in separate newspaper articles today that the Soviet Union might increase its military support to Arab countries to offset Israeli strength.
WASHINGTON. The Senate hearings on the American consumer underscore a central issue the Federal Government's role in insuring product safety and integrity.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 Former Maj. Gen. Pyotr G. Grigorenko, once the most prominent and outspoken member of a small group of Soviet political dissidents, was declared legally insane today, according to reliable sources.
LAKE TAHOE, Nev., Feb. 27 Lake Tahoe's North Shore welcomed a triple invasion today as the $50,000 Kings Castle Grand Prix snowmobile races got under way.
Albert Gelb, the Bronx pharmacist who shot and killed two brothers trying to hold him up Wednesday night at his drugstore, said yesterday that he might give up his business and leave the city.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 27 Samuel F. Kanis, a lawyer who ran for United States Representative in the 13th Congressional District on the Republican ticket in 1960 died Wednesday night in Miami. He was 62 years old.

Operation Breakthrough, the Department of Housing and Urban Development's toppriority program to meet the housing shortage, has announced its choices for the American homes. The 22 designs released by the Government Thursday with the hope of mass production.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 27 The foreign minister of Guatemala, Alberto Fuentes Mohr, 42 years old, was kidnapped tonight and held for exchange for a university student who was arrested yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 (UPI) Vice President Agnew said tonight that the "outrageous courtroom conduct" of the Chicago "totally obfuscated the constitutional question" of tthe Federal antiriot law.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 27 Levern Tart poured in 38 points as the New York Nets, opening a big early lead, held on for a 122-113 victory over the Miami Floridians at Island Garden tonight.
Doing business on Wall Street historically has been so profitable that very little debate ever arose about the problems of the securities industry.

The disappearance of a victim's deathbed statement and the resultant dismissal of a first-degree murder indictment against a reputed arsonist for the Mafia led a legislative committee's investigation of organized crime into a new channel here yesterday.

BERN, Switzerland, Feb. 27 (Reuters) The Federal prosecutor said today there was growing evidence of a link between the explosion on an Austrian airliner Saturday and the crash of a Swissair jet the same day, in which 47 persons died.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 (Reuters) Three Un- ited States Ambassadors from Southeast Asia wound up a two-day meeting here today, a United States Embassy spokes- man said.

The city's subways the target of increasing charges of deteriorating safety and maintenance experienced new troubles yesterday, including an accident in which seven persons were injured, a rider revolt in Brooklyn and delays for thousands of passengers.

WESTBURY, L.I, Feb. 27 From their respective New Jersey homes at New Egypt and Colt's Neck, Stanley Dancer and Carmine Abbatiello sent word today that the likelihood is strong for the local season's first 2-minute-mile at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
The state's highest court will hear an appeal on Tuesday against a ruling that has reinstated the proposed decentralized school district lines in Manhattan.

Theodore C. Sorensen, one of four announced Democratic candidates for Senate, informed the New Democratic Coalition yesterday that he was withdrawing his name from consideration for the liberal group's endorsement.

There has been a deplorable lack of attention to the drug problem at all levels of government perhaps most glaringly at the local level, for it has been here that the results of inattention have manifested themselves in astronomic death statistics. Mayor Lindsay's recent promise to triple the city's addiction sensitivity program for teachers underscores how very little has been done in the educational area until now.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 With three races completed and three to go, John Potter's 57foot sloop Equation from Oyster Bay, L.I., sat on the top of the standing today for the Southern Ocean Racing Conference championship.

"I am a nightclub performer and that's all I am," said Sammy Davis Jr. last night to an audience that packed Carnegie Hall for the first of three performances he was giving there. He appeared twice last night and will perform again this evening.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 The Black Affairs Council, a steering committee for programs affecting blacks in Unitarian Universalist churches and societies, has been disaffiliated from the national assiciation of the denomination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Nixon, proposing the first major labor law changes in more than 20 years, asked Congress today for new machinery and broader Presidential powers to ward off crippling strikes in transportation.
The State Board of Regents issued a policy statement yesterday describing educators as unable to solve the problems of youthful drug addiction without the aid of students and communities.

Sending nine of their 10 men into today's semifinals, New York University took a 1-point lead after the quarter-finals last night in the Metropolitan wrestling championships in the Violets' Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) Sharply higher prices for cattle and hogs spurred the Agriculture Department's farm price index to its fifth straight increase in the month ended Feb. 15.
A Florida real-estate development concern stood out in an otherwise lackluster newissue market this week.

Judge Justine Wise Polier of Family Court yesterday placed the younger sisters and brothers of a 12-year-old Harlem boy who died last year of heroin poisoning in the temporary custody of their mothers, despite efforts by the Social Services Department to have them placed elsewhere.
EXETER, N.H., Feb. 27 The trustees of Phillips Exeter Academy voted unanimously today to make the 189-year-old preparatory school coeducational, effective this September.
OLD TAPPAN, N.J., Feb. 27 (AP) Police Chief Charles Schuh has been suspended on departmental charges of passing to a fellow policeman money received from the wife of an alleged Mafioso.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 27 Richard Rapport, former State Bank Commissioner and former vice president of the Hartford National Bank and Trust company, died yesterday in Winter Park, Fla., at the age of 67.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., Feb. 22 Phase Two of an experiment to defuse racial tensions among marines starts in the Second Marine Division March 1 and may, in the rather grim prediction of one unit leader, "last forever."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 The sun, pale yellow and shapeless in a clear blue sky, is mild and gently warming, Joe Pignatano, the coach, is punching out grounders toward first base, where the stockbroker and restaurateur. Ed Kranepool, and the Scripto vice president and restaurateur, Donn Clendenon, are fielding some of them.

The coordinating agency for 238 Protestant charities that raise $100-million a year in the city is trying to get the charities to put poor people on their largely middle-class boards of directors and to aid poor people in starting welfare agencies in their own neighborhoods.

Abraham Katz, executive director of Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., since 1954, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital, after an illness of several weeks. He was 70 years old and lived at 63 East Ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Office of Education announced today that it would require every school district in the nation to demonstrate that it was putting equal resources into all of its schools before it would be eligible to receive supplementary Federal funds for disadvantaged children.

MUSICALS come and go often with an alarming frequency but "Fiddler on the Roof" seems to play on forever. At the Majestic Theater, this musical with a book by Joseph Stein, music by Jerry Bock and lyrics by Sheldon Harnick has recently acquired a new Tevye in Paul Lipson. However, to call Mr. Lipson new to "Fiddler on the Roof" is something less than accurate.

THE final stage of the marathon match between the Dallas Aces and Omar Sharif's Circus of European stars, played in Philadelphia this week, has become a runaway victory for the American experts. They lead by 160 international match points with 42 deals remaining to be played.
ISLA VISTA, Calif., Feb. 27 Order prevailed today in this university community where youths and the police have battled with stones and tear gas for the last three nights.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 28 (AP) Vietcong guerrillas and South Vietnamese troops exchanged gunfire today in Saigon and terronists set off two bombs in the city, military spokesmen reported.

The most welcome aspect of the proposals President Nixon sent to Congress yesterday for better public protection against transportation strike emergencies is that they introduce fresh approaches into a field in which progress has been blocked for twenty years by prejudices too mossgrown to dislodge.

There is something timeless about Pete Seeger. He has grown a big gray beard to mark the passing of his 50th year, and his voice has mellowed, and maybe he does not bob about so much onstage as he used to, but his ebullience is still all there. His singing is as warmly persuasive, his playing as dexterous, his spirit of humanity as infectious as ever.
BUFFALO, Feb. 27 Students occupied four administration and classroom buildings on the State University campus here this morning without resistance and declared that the university was on strike.
WHEN tourists empty out of New York hostelries to take advantage of the city's varied night life, they leave behind them; more often than not, that family stalwart, the hotel baby sitter.
A Harvard University researcher, writing in a publication of the American Medical Association, says there is no conclusive evidence causally linking cigarette smoking to heart disease.
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices on 14 groups of organic chemicals covering 54 distinct products.
The announcement by the Canadian Government that it was making a move to cut wheat production this year caused a brief rally in the grain pits at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press) Marie Dionne, one of the Dionne quintuplets, died today after a brief illness. She was 35 years old and was the wife of Florian Houle, a court clerk here.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 27 Students at the College of New Rochelle, a small, usually peaceful women's college, went on strike today to support a popular teacher who was denied tenure at the Roman Catholic institution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Leon E. Panetta said today he believgd that the Nixon Administration had decided to "cater to the votes of the Deep South states" and that as a result the nation did not have the kind of "moral leadership" it needed in race relations.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Feb. 27 Mrs. Elizabeth Berlin Fisher, daughter of Irving Berlin, the songwriter, and Mrs. Berlin of New York, was married here this afternoon to Alton E. Peters of New York, a partner in the law firm of Bleakley, Platt, Schmidt, Hart Fritz.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 Pennsylvania won the Ivy League basketball title and the resulting National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berth tonight when its tall and perfectly balanced team defeated Columbia, 71-57, before 9,260 screaming fans in The Palestra.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) Oil from a damaged barge flowed down the St. Johns River near here today, threatening a wildlife refuge. Across the state a tar-like substance floated through another wildlife preserve.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday a "regrouping" of its top executive structure, effective with the retirement of Ben S. Gilmer as president on April 1.
OTTAWA, Feb. 27 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's austerity program will net the Government a $455-million budget surplus for the year ending March 31, it was announced today.
The Federal Aviation Administration issued a rule yesterday that officials said would reduce the peak-hour capacity of Kennedy International Airport already sharply limited by eightmonth-old quotas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Train accidents, up 60 per cent over the last five years, reached a record of 8,529 in 1969, the Federal Railroad Administration reports.

LONDON, Feb. 27 Even to raise the subject of American forces in Europe is to bring a glaze of weariness to the eyes of the average man. It is a much-argued subject, but it happens right now to be a timely and extremely important one for both of us, Americans and Europeans.
BONN, Feb. 27 To a traveler just returned to West Germany from Israel, civil air traffic in Israel seems placid compared to the way it is being buffeted about in some other places.
HARTFORD, Saturday, Feb. 28 (AP) Nine prisoners apparently used a barbell to batter their way out of the Hartford Correctional Center last night.

Martin McGrady shattered his world indoor record in the 600-yard run last night, but a bizarre 35-minute dispute after the one-mile run became the asterisk of the Amateur Athletic Union national indoor track and field championships.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks scored the game's first eight points today and breezed to a 131-113 victory over the Detroit Pistons behind a combined 82-point outburst by Lew Alcindor, Jon McGlocklin and Flynn Robinson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Nixon Administration has ended all pressure on Federal agencies to step up employment of members of minority groups, Robert E. Hampton, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, says.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 27 Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, President of Pakistan, today issued a law providing for "measures against undue concentration of economic power, growth of unreasonable monopoly power and unreasonably restrictive trade practices."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Pentagon announced today that the United Aircraft Corporation's Pratt Whitney Division had been selected to develop and produce engines for the newest fighter aircraft planned by the Navy and Air Force.
MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (UPI) Lorne (Gump) Worsley has been traded to the Minnesota North Stars, the Montreal Canadiens announced this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Four Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee declared today that confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell would "discredit" the Supreme Court. "More important, it would be a disservice to the finest ideals of the American people," they added.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Feb. 19 A sales team of the state milk trust has just left for New York to convince United States food processers that Bulgarian yogurt is supreme.
GENEVA, Feb. 27 The International trading community refused today to commit itself to the launching of another major attack on barriers to the free flow of trade in 1971.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 (UPI) At least two workmen were feared trapped when the top nine floors of a halffinished apartment building collapsed today.
Jim Dine, artist, poet and ex-princeling of pop, exported himself from New York to London three years ago, with scarcely a backward glance. Now back on a visit, he still hates every minute of it.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 The Essex County Sheriff, Ralph D'Ambola, said today that United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey was conducting a "per sonal vendetta" against him "going back seven years" when Mr. Lacey reportedly was rejected as the Essex County Republican candidate for State Senator.
James Bostwick and Gene Scott gained the final of the national singles court tennis tournament yesterday with semifinal victories at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) A belief that the Federal Government is the best agent for solving the nation's domestic ills reached its peak in the mid-nineteen-sixties but is now dead, a Government-sponsored report said today.

Charls E. Walker, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, proclaimed victory yesterday in the initial phase of the fight against inflation, but he warned that "a reasonable degree of moderation in wage settlements" would be an essential ingredient of further progress.

Ivo Vinco, an Italian bass, will make his Metropolitan debut on March 19 taking the part of Oroveso in Bellini's "Norma," and John Alexander will assume the role of Pollione for the first time in the same performance during the twelfth week of the Met's current season.
Theodore F. Shaker, group vice president of American Broadcasting Companies Inc., resigned yesterday, according to an announcement by Simon B. Siegel, executive vice president.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 The United States, Britain and France notified the Soviet Union today that they were ready to begin four-power talks on problems relating to Berlin. Diplomatic sources said they expected the talks to begin by the end of March in West Berlin.

YONKERS, Fed. 27 Dr. Joseph J. McCadden, who retired in 1962 from the education department of Hunter College after 37 years on the faculty, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 74 years old and lived at 10 Armstrong Avenue.
Negotiators for the typographical union and the four general-interest newspapers here reached an impasse yesterday and temporarily recessed their talks aimed at achieving a new agreement by March 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Representative Richard L. Ot tinger, Westchester County Democrat, charged today that Vice President Agnew and Attorney General John N. Mitchell were promoting "a new McCarthyism" by their recent actions concerning the news media and announced that he would introduce legislation to protect newsmen from "Government intimidation and coercion."

Six field goals in the last three minutes helped Hunter College overcome Lehman, 5338, while Al Krieger, with 16 points and 16 rebounds, led Queens College to a 74-67 victory over Brooklyn College in the opening games of the City University basketball tournament at Queens College, Flushing, last night.

Roger W. Straus Jr., the president of a well-known publishing house, sharply criticized the organizers of the 21st National Book Awards yesterday for their selection of judges and the preparation of the threeday book promotion program that opens here Monday.
The monthly meeting of the Columbia University Senate was disrupted yesterday afternoon by 150 chanting demonstrators.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Feb. 27 At least three persons were killed and two dozen were reported injured tonight when a chartered bus carrying skiing enthhusiasts from New Jersey to Lake Placid overturned on snow-slicked Route 87 here.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 27 This is a city where the ringing of the doorbell after midnight produces a special kind of fear, for midnight to 3 A.M. is the time when arrests are most often made.
BONN, Feb. 27 The struggle against pollution of the environment is becoming a major political issue in West Germany, judging by several developments here this week.

While stoutly declaring a "total war" on drug addiction, Governor Rockefeller has proposed an emergency program that would create additional delay and diminish the role of the state. Less a march forward than a retreat, it is in essence a program to dump the problem on the cities.
WHEN there is a bull market, it seems as if nobody questions anything. Managements make optimistic statements, stocks go up and everybody is happy.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 (UPI) President Pompidou of France said today that the worldwide youth revolt was a reflection of "a crisis of civilization."

DETROIT, Feb. 27 In a deal prompted by Don Marshall's shoulder injury, the New York Rangers obtained tonight Ted Irvine, a 25-year-old left wing, from the Los Angeles Kings in exchange for Real Lemieux and Juha Widing.

Negotiations between Public Service Coordinated Transport and the drivers and mechanics of its buses, which haul nearly a million riders daily in New Jersey, continued last night on the eve of a deadline for a possible strike.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 The player representatives of the major league baseball teams met today and rejected an offered package for a basic agreement with the owners, an offer that had to be accepted or rejected as a whole.

ROCHESTER, Feb. 28-- William J. Stolze, board chairman of R. F. Communications, and Mrs. Stolze have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Stolze, to Arthur Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Bernstein of Cedarhurst, L. I.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 28-- Dartmouth overcame a substantial Middlebury lead and beat the host school by .47 points for the team crown at the Middlebury Winter Carnival today.

As the new year begins, it occurs to me that you might find useful a general assessment of the position of Negroes at the end of the first year of your Administration, and of the decade in which their position has been the central domestic political issue.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 28 --Like a PT boat trying to battle a tank in the country, Navy was handed its worst basketball defeat of the 47game series with Army. 80-56, today.

"Student government was set up by the Board of Education not to work in the first place," said Donald St. George Reeves last week, as he submitted to the Board of Education a series of demands that would give high school students a major voice--perhaps the decisive one --in running the schools.

CLOVIS, N. M., Feb. 28--Airman August Doyle, a Negro who has just completed a 90day prison sentence ford refusal to obey an order to cut his hair, is back at Cannon Air Force Base here. But in his absence regulations had been changed. And his Afro hair style is now legal.

ALTHOUGH the weekly total of flights between the United States and Europe this spring and summer will increase only slightly over the peak season last year, the number of seats available to airline passengers will rise by more than 15 per cent.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 28 (AP)--The United States and Denmark have formally closed the case of the B-52 nuclear bomber crash near Thule Air Base in Greenland two years ago, agreeing that the accident caused no danger to man or animal and plant life in the area.

In their last meeting of the regular National Basketball Association season, the New York Knicks gave the Baltimore Bullets a few rueful memories to contemplate before the playoffs as they pounded the Bullets, 115-101, last night at Madison Square Garden.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico--A hit song played and sung all over Mexico today is called "San Luis Potosi," with the accent on the "si." It has a cheerful, animated lilt, and the words go something like this: "I am from San Luis Potosi and it is in my heart. I paint cactus in the shade, and when the eagle pauses in flight I paint him.
APARTMENT house owners in the city and a building services union have begun contract talks that are expected to produce heavy pressure for an early modification of the rent control law.
BUFFALO, Feb. 28--Outward calm returned to the troubled State University here, but in dormitories and offices on the chill campus students and administration officials still thrashed over problems.
STORRS, Conn., Feb. 28 (AP) --Connecticut won the annual New England indoor track championship today with 35 points, topping a field of 20 colleges.
Commercial television, it has been observed, is of no lasting benefit. Not so, said Miss Amy Vanderbilt yesterday, who discovered the way to a silver spoon lay in a commercials for margarine.

AFTER HEARING how difficult it was to grow roses in Minnesota, how much work was required, the various diseases they were subject to and at least, if not more, a 10 per cent winter loss of bushes, I decided I'd like to try to raise roses. As a complete amateur, I had raised everything a standard seed catalogue offered, so the general principles of horticulture were not new to me.

Lieut. Gen. Lemuel Mathewson, American commander in Berlin from 1951 to 1953 and former commanding general of the Fifth Army Corps in Frankfurt, Germany, died Thursday at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington. He was 70 years old and lived in McLean, Va.
SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 28-- Miss Cynthia Ann Gabrielson Owens, a sophomore at Drew University, and Paul Lurix Jr., a senior there, plan to be married in May.
The much discussed trading season in which American Football League and National Football League teams were expected to swap stars has produced only limited action.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 28 (UPI)--Dan Issel, the nation's, third-leading collegiate scorer, pumped in 31 points today to lead the Kentucky Wildcats to a 90-86 victory over Vanderbilt and avenge the Wildcats' only loss of the basketball season.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 28--A leading civil rights activist, the Rev. Richard C. Boone, has been convicted of second degree arson in connection with an attempt to set fire to a radio station.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28--The Chief Rabbi of Moscow came out in support today for the campaign against Zionism and Israel.

A FRIEND of mine wanted a colony of purple martins in his back yard. To attract the birds he built a martin house with sixteen separate cubicles, arranged in three stories. Then he placed the apartment high on a post in approved martin style.
KARACHI, Pakistan Feb. 28 --Indian-Pakistani negotiations on the distribution of the waters of the Ganges River appear headed for a deadlock. The talks began in Islamabad on Tuesday.
POZZUOLI, Italy, Feb. 28-- The 65,000 people of this ancient seaport near Naples, troubled by slow undulations of the earth, are poised for flight if an earthquake or volcanic eruption should strike.

WHEN the Roman Catholic sisters who teach at the Academy of the Sacred Heart of Mary in upper Manhattan decided to give a benefit dinnerdance to help pay salaries of the eight lay teachers--the sisters, themselves, don't get any--they did not expect to make a lot of money. They didn't expect to lose any, either. But they did: $90.

ATLANTA, Feb 28--The recent desegregation of several dozen Deep South school systems worked best when community leaders carefully prepared the groundwork for transition, the Southern Regional Council reported today.
BOSTON, Feb. 28--Gov. Francis W. Sargent approved today a stadium plan far Boston, giving the homeless profootball Patriots a last chance to remain here.

With this version of his Holmes Lectures delivered last spring at Harvard, Alexander Bickel opens, for the general reader, what will undoubtedly become a continuing debate about the achievements of the Warren Court. The debate has up to now been largely confined to the law reviews. Mr. Bickel, one of our leading scholars in the field of constitutional law and history, is admirably equipped to extend the debate into the general realm.

A collection of strange, indigestible, obsessive sermons, some ridiculous and many rather incoherent, appeared in Moscow in January, 1847, over the name of the well known humorist Nikolai Gogol. "Correspondence With Friends," a book which the author confidently expected "half educated Russia to read," was an unmitigated disaster. It was also, sadly, his last published work. Five years later he destroyed the manuscript of the sequel to "Dead Souls" and starved himself to death.

THE 53d annual International Flower Show opens this coming Saturday at the New York Coliseum and will remain open through Sunday, March 15. Jointly sponsored by the Horticultural Society of New York and the New York Florists' Club, the show has a new theme this year--"An American Community."

the-counter market and on the American Stock Exchange advanced last week in comparatively quiet trading.

Mrs. Frances Lamar Gurr McLanahan, a patron of music, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 69. She was the widow of Alexander Hawley McLanahan, an investment banker, and lived at 825 Fifth Avenue and the Chateau de Missery, Cote d'Or, France.

Miss Linda Beth Schwartz, who is studying for a master's degree in educational psychology at New York University, and Eric Harold Moss, a law student there, plan to be married in October.

Nearing 50, his sterile life abounds in all the negative virtues.
LONDON, Feb. 28--Legal authorities here have decided not to prosecute an avant-garde theater for showing Andy Warhol's film, "Flesh."

COMMACK, L. I., Feb. 28-- A resident of the western part of Suffolk County who needs a nonemergency operation may have to wait up to six weeks before a hospital in this area can find a vacant bed to admit him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Four persons described as Polish rebel student leaders--two men and two women--were sentenced to prison terms by a Warsaw court this week for allegedly smuggling out to the West literary materials on students' uprising in 1968.
Doctors last week reported one more link in the growing chain of evidence connecting intelligence development with early nutrition.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 28 --Long Island University edged Fairleigh Dickinson in basketball tonight, 49-48. The Blackbirds, who raised their season record to 15 victoriese against 9 losses, gave Coach Roy Rubin his 150th career victory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Federal agencies that supervise the country's banks have rejected a Congressional proposal for new "truth-in-advertising" regulations.

BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Feb. 28--Miss Mary Ellen Howard and Roger Holmes Cook were married here this morning in St. Hugo of the Hills Roman Catholic Church. The pastor, the Rev. Clement Esper performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. Henry G. J. Beck, of Lyndhurst, N. J.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP)--Persons over 65 years old can get a price break at 36 Philadelphia restaurants, beginning tomorrow.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 28--Nelson Burton Jr., who finished second in the tournament a year ago, turned on the man who beat him today and took first place in the $50,000 Buckeye open bowling tournament.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 28 (AP)--Rodney Pattisson of Britain sailed Superdocius to his third, straights world championship in the Flying Dutchman Class when he placed fifth in today's race.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb 28 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Boykin Pitts of Scarsdale and Delray Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynn Carol Pitts, to Donald Paul McKinney. He is a son of Mrs. Viola McKinney of Newport, R.I., and Edgar F. McKinney of Portsmouth, R I.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) --Levern Tart scored 44 points tonight, but the New York Nets were beaten; 119-116, by the Washington Caps in an American Basketball Association game.

WACO, Tex., Feb. 28 (AP)-- Baylor used a zone press and accurate free-throw shooting to defeat Texas A. M., 70-68, today and knock the Aggles out of a chance for a share of the Southwest Conference basketball title.

MACON, Ga., Feb. 28 (UPI)-- Arthur Ashe, the top-seeded player, defeated Bob Lutz, 9-7, 6-2, tonight to reach the final against second-seeded Cliff Richey in the third annual Macon International tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -A Senate Judiciary subcommittee has said that the National Labor Relations Board uses double standards for labor and management and shows a bias toward the maintenance of strong unions.

A transit policeman's attempt to give a derelict a summons for smoking in a subway touched off a wild shooting spree in the crowded Times Square area yesterday in which the transit policeman and the derelict were killed, two other persons were wounded and scores of bystanders were forced to rush to cover.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--The seven defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial were released from jail today in a total of $155,000 bond.

The city's Planning Department has taken the unusual step of joining in a California lawsuit that challenges the constitutionality of certain zoning techniques used by suburban towns, allegedly to exclude minority groups.

LIBERTY CORNER, N. J., Feb. 28--When William Kienast, the father of the world's newest set of quintuplets, opened his mail today, he found a letter from a woman he'd never heard of with five dollars enclosed.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP)--The nonprofit Pearl S. Buck Foundation, after two previous denials, has again been granted permission to solicit funds in Pennsylvania.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 28 (UPI)--Cambodia released today the five United States Navy men who were captured Feb. 5 when an American gunboat sailed up the Mekong River into Cambodian territory, apparently by mistake.
BUCHAREST, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The United States became the only unbeaten team in the Group B world ice hockey championships today by whipping its stiffest rival, West Germany, 5-2.

They can be living off the fruits of advertising without really being in an agency.

With four month to go until the state's primary election and eight months until New York actually elects a new governor, three Democratic candidates for that job were sitting in a television studio last week making the nervous small talk of wellbred college men chasing the same girl.

WASHINGTON--The structure of the U.S. Government has not kept pace with the quantum jump in American power and global responsibility and, despite creation of new devices such as the C.I.A., the Defense Department, a separate Air Force and a national security assistant to the President, administrative machinery continues to lag behind requirements.

BANGKOK--Although Thailand started the year badly for American visitors by reducing from 30 to 15 the number of days a visitor can stay without a visa, she remains a country of tropical landscapes, colorful temples, air-conditioned hotels and good bargains in silk.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28--President Pompidou of France was picketed here tonight by about 10,000 demonstrators, most of them Jews. Booing and shaking their fists at him, the pickets carried signs denouncing French policies in the Middle East.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 28--The Dominican revolutionary party, a left-wing opposition group, called today for "active abstention" by voters in the presidential election scheduled for May 16.

Elizabeth Longford is one of the most skillful biographers working today. Her art seems almost artless; for the speed and ease with which she can carry one through a long book is very deceptive. If one takes any individual page or section, it all looks simple enough--a scene sketched in a few sentences, excellent quotations from the records, a shrewd observation on character here and there and a firm concentration on the story line.

MIAMI, Feb. 28--While ponds and lakes caused penalty strokes today, Mike Hill took the overland route to the 54hole lead in the $150,000 DoralEastern open golf tournament today. The 31-year-old younger brother of Dave Hill, who had the best scoring average on the 1969 tour, scored a thirdround score of 69 for a 54-hole aggregate of 208.
