NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., March 29--Robert J. Fawls, a partner in Haskins Sells, international public accountants, died of a heart attack this morning at Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 46 years old and lived at 171 Marcus Avenue.

TOKYO, March 29--Anna Louise Strong, the American who spent most of her life writing books and articles extolling the virtues of Communism, died today of a heart attack in Peking, where she had lived for the last 12 years, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, reported. She was 84 years old.
LOS ANGELES, March 29 (AP)--The Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association signed tonight their No. 1 draft choice, Columbia's Jim McMillian, to a three-year contract.

Nobody got around to flying the "Blue Monday" flag on Wall Street yesterday, but stock prices did slip lower in a consolidation session following last week's rousing "primerate rally."
The Republic Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Cleveland that it would raise its prices for most types of steel bar by an average of about 4.5 per cent, effective April 15.

PARADISE, Calif., March 30 Dr. Harold E. Anthony, former chairman of the Department of Mammalogy at the American Museum of Natural History, died here yesterday of an apparent heart attack while on a family outing. He was 79 years old.

Low temperatures kept thawing to a minimum across the snow-covered Northeast yesterday the 10th day of spring but travel returned to near-normal in most sections following the 12-hour, Easter Day storm.
The annual spring luncheon of the Women's Division of the Jewish Guild for the Blind will be held at the American Hotel on April 9.
Bryant Baker, a sculptor who specialized in busts and statues of public figures, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 222 West 59th Street.

The LFC Financial Corporation issued a revised report for 1969 showing a loss of $5,989,000, or 90 cents a share on 6,690,947 average shares, including a provision of $6million for estimated losses on loans and real estate.

Much of the 75th anniversary issue of Field Stream magazine will be devoted to ecology. And, according to the publisher, President Nixon has agreed to write the lead article on "The State of the Union Between Man and Nature."
PANMUNJOM, South Korea, March 30 Representatives of the United Nations Command and North Korea traded charges today of violations of the 1953 Korean armistice agreement.

WASHINGTON, March 30 A group of 11 textile organizations, headed by the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, rejected today the socalled Kendall plan for limitation of textile imports from Japan.
BOSTON, March 30 (UPI) The Massachusetts House killed today a Senate amendment to a bill challenging the constitutionality of the Vietnam war.

YONKERS, March 30 Faced with the monumental task of clearing 10 inches of heavy, wet snow from the track and parking lots, a 50-man Yonkers Raceway maintenance crew labored through a 16-hour shift today starting at midnight.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Post Office Department officials made a new wage offer today to the seven national unions of postal employes, but received no immediate response.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended slightly lower yesterday in light trading.

A Public Service Commission official said yesterday he "assumed" the commission did not have authority to withhold because of poor service the recent $136.7-million interim rate increase granted the New York Telephone Company.

CAIRO, March 30 Street battles were reported to have broken out again in the Sudanese city of Omdurman this morning when dissidents of the Ansar Moslem sect attacked Government security patrols with swords, spears and guns.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30 A two-year-old drive to introduce "911" as a nationwide telephone number for emergencies is running into substantial opposition in major cities.
ATHENS, March 30 The military-backed regime has issued a decree setting up a national guard for the internal security of Greece in war or peace.
Bargaining on a new employer offer in the 58-day-old tugboat strike continued yesterday afternoon. Both parties in the dispute agreed to meet again this morning for further joint talks.

Americans gave $17.6-billion to philanthropies last year, an increase of 8.1 per cent over that for 1968. But within the growing annual lump sums were major shifts away from the traditional building types of programs toward more social aid for urban minorities and the poor.
HALLENDALE, Fla., March 30 (AP) Fathom, ridden by Diane Crump, came on from fourth place to score a 2 length victory today in the eighth race at Gulfstream Park.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 30 (UPI) Explorer 1, the 80-inch satellite that put the United States officially into the space age, is expected to die tomorrow somewhere over Burma.

A scheduled concert at $2 a head by the Living Stone Cowboys, a city-bred quartet of country musicians, at the Washington Square Church, 135 West 4th Street last night was transformed into a free square dance and concert with music provided by an improvised quintet that was quickly indentified as "the Living Stone Cowboys minus one plus two."

AN area of bridge on which theory is silent relates to misunderstandings: how to avoid having them; how to handle the situation when it has happened to your side; and how to reap the full benefit when it happens to your opponents. It may not be at all obvious that the opposition is on the way to a disaster, and even an expert sometimes bails the enemy out of trouble in such circumstances.

The Democratic State Committee prepared yesterday to endorse candidates for statewide offices tomorrow as divisive and sometimes bitter undertones began to surface 12 full weeks before the June 23 primary election.

Consumer plans to buy various goods and services remain firm in the face of a sharp decline of confidence in the state of the economy, it was pointed out yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board and the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center.
Bernard Shapiro, Connecticut Commissioner of Public Welfare since 1959, was named yesterday as deputy commissioner for New York City Affairs in the New York State Department of Social Services.
ALBANY, March 30 The Assembly rejected tonight a bill to reform New York State's 19th-century abortion law by a vote of 73 to 71, three votes short of the 76 required for passage.
Prices on the Tokyo stock market reached new record levels yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, March 30 (AP) The Soviet Union, avenging an opening-game loss to Sweden, swept to its eighth consecutive world ice hockey championship today, beating the Swedes, 3-1.

IT may be the dawning of the age of Aquarius, as the song goes, but is it the waning of hair? Last winter, Rudi Gernreich, the designer, predicted that both the man and the woman of the future will prefer to look as bald as billiard balls. He closed the gap between the sexes by showing a male and female model in similar, tent-like garments, both with shaved heads.
WASHINGTON, March 30 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The United States Supreme Court let stand today the convictions of three New York accountants on charges of conspiring to issue false financial statements.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Thousands of children and their parents roamed the White House lawn today to roll Easter eggs with the temperature at 31 degrees.

WASHINGTON, March 30 Both houses of Congress are expected to hold hearings within the next few weeks on proposed regulations that would authorize the opening of mail from overseas without the recipient's permission, as currently required.

The Federal Aviation Administration moved yesterday to discipline more than 1,500 air traffic controllers who have tied up much of the nation's air transport system for six days by staying home "sick," and threatened to dismiss the leaders of the stoppage.

The injured survivor of last Friday's bomb blast on East Fifth Street was reported yesterday to have been held as a material witness last year in the murder of a 16-year-old boy who allegedly was slain because he wanted to leave the Black Panther party.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 30 A $50-million Disneylandstyle amusment park was proposed today for the 1,800-acre site of a planned major petrochemical complex on Port Royal Sound in Beaufort County.
WASHINGTON, March 30 A nationwide survey by two private organizations shows that almost 1,500 Negroes are holding elective public office in the United States.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 30 (UPI) Leaders of a student strike at the University of Michigan rejected today an apology from the director of university relations for announcing that a tentative agreement had been reached on several black student demands.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Treasury bill rates climbed at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Mrs. Margaret Melville Gorman was married last Thursday to James Hancock Blackwell of New York and Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Eugene M. Pierce of the Marble Collegiate Church performed the ceremony at the home here of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ward Melville of New York and Stony Brook, L.I. Mr. Melville is chairman of the Melville Shoe Corporation.

Robert M. Morgenthau, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, charged yesterday that Meade H. Esposito, Brooklyn Democratic leader, had helped the head of a "crime-dominated union" to arrange for a $250,000 unsecured loan for his cousin.
MOSCOW, March 30 (AP) A Soviet newspaper charged today that an American woman posing as a tourist was an Israeli intelligence agent who tried to get secret information on the Soviet space program.

GREENVILLE, Del., March 30 Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fenton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Douglas Fenton, to Roger Wolcott Tuckerman, son of Mrs. Roger Tuckerman of New York and Farmington, Conn., and the late Mr. Tuckerman, who was a partner of Wood, Walker Co., stockbrokers in New York. Mr. Fenton is former board chairman of Laird, Inc., investment bankers.

Thirteen Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places here notified Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh yesterday that they were "ready to stand trial," and he set April 7 for resumption of pretrial hearings.

In an attempt to revive a feeling of togetherness for the final days of the National Hockey League season, the Rangers left last night for a four-day stay in Brantford, Ontario, only 12 miles from Kitchener, the training site from which they made their spectacular start last fall.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) Bond holders' attorneys argued before the Supreme Court today that the bankrupt New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was being sold at an under-value price.

REINHART is an American, perhaps the American, a huge 44-year-old failure of nerve. In two previous novels "Crazy in Berlin" and "Reinhart in Love" Thomas Berger liberated Reinhart during World War II, educated him on the G.I. Bill, married him off disastrously and tracked him through business flops and metaphysical pratfalls to the brink of suicide.
Handsomely gotten up, these two volumes sustain the Goliard-Grossman series as among the most venturesome in the field of poetry.

Mrs. Theodore Gothier Quintal of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Montague Quintal, to Robert Edward Berglund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mathias Werner Berglund of Amherst, Mass. The wedding is planned for late summer.

State Senator William E. Adams, who has been charged with lying about a $5,000 payment from a Medicaid bill-collecting company, denied as his trial began yesterday that he had "sold any of his power or violated any law."

The United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency reported recently that the world spent more than a trillion dollars for arms in the last six years. What's worse, military spending is on the increase, especially among the developing countries that can afford it least. Worldwide arms purchases last year alone represented a cost of $56 for every person on earth, more than many millions of people in the developing world receive in total annual income.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, March 30 A military court revoked today a conviction for premeditated murder it pronounced yesterday on First Lieut. James B. Duffy, who had been charged with ordering the slaying of an unarmed Vietnamese civilian.

BALTIMORE, March 30 Miss Anne Demarest Nelson, a senior at Wellesley College, and Mahlon Apgar 4th, an urban affairs consultant with McKinsey Co. in New York, plan to be married on May 30. The ceremony will take place in the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 The Soviet Union took a one-point lead today after completion of adjourned games of the first round of the chess match in which its top players are matched against top players of the rest of the world.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 30 Datsun captured the first two places today and was expected to take the team prize for the second straight year in the 3,200-mile East African Safari rally.

The decision of the Board of Estimate and City Council to scuttle the excellent design for police station and stables for Central Park, and at the same time to undertake still another study, represents not only some half-million dollars in waste of public funds but also an illogical distortion of park requirements.
The New Amsterdam Ensemble, a group of 11 musicians, 6 of them from the New York City Opera Orchestra, gave the first of a series of three concerts last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Contract negotiations between answering-service operators here and their employers appeared to be at a deadlock yesterday, with both sides sounding gloomy about the chances of avoiding a strike when the current contract expires tonight at midnight.

MADRID, March 30 A recent drive through the Greek Cypriote and Turkish Cypriote quarters of Nicosia underlined the communities' growing separation. Cyprus is having something of a boom, and the bustling crowds and well-stocked shop windows on Ledra Street are evidence of it. Outside the walls, new neighborhoods with four-story and five-story apartment houses are springing up.
WASHINGTON, March 30 A Federal judge substantially tempered today proposed governmental restrictions on protest demonstrations in front of the White House.

GEDIZ, Turkey, March 30 Snow fell tonight on this stricken town of about 10,000, where as many as 1,800 people may have been killed by the earthquake Saturday. The bodies of about 600 victims have been recovered and are being buried by soldiers in shallow graves outside of town.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 30 Jerome D. Ambro Jr. Supervisor of the Town of Huntington, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor.
The answer to a seaman's prayer a coffee cup that won't spill has been invented.

BELIEVING that they once again may be thwarted in their efforts to have the striped bass classified as a game fish by the New York State Legislature, Save Our Stripers, Inc., of Massapequa Park, L.I., is urging sportsmen to communicate directly with Governor Rockefeller.
Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, the institutional securities house, announced yesterday that it planned to move forward with its public offering of 800,000 common shares on April 9.

NEW ORLEANS, March 30 (AP) The New Orleans Buccaneers remained in contention for a playoff berth in the American Basketball Association Western Division race tonight by defeating the Indiana Pacers, 120-106.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The Russians test-fired two long-range missiles with multiple warheads into the Pacific over the weekend, the Pentagon said today.

Three Manhattan Representatives and the Nassau County Executive, in denouncing the automobile as a major polluter, joined yesterday in supporting a protest march against the International Automobile Show when it opens at the Coliseum Saturday.

BAYONNE, France, March 30 Under the portrait of a gaunt Christ on the cross in the Cathedral of Bayonne, a group of young Nationalists are in the second week of a hunger strike that has troubled French consciences.
THE little guys that group of investors to which all of us except rich Uncle Charlie belongs can be forgiven if they haven't yet gotten enthusiastic again about the stock market.
The Federal District Court in Brooklyn has approved a petition by Fotochrome, Inc., to reorganize its affairs under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
TAKE one part consumer resistance, one part creative urge and one part fashion ennui. Mix well and you have a trend like the loving-hands-at-home revival.

NEW HAVEN For three years, a course at Yale called "Wild Land Resources" attracted a dozen undergraduates, who trudged the mile up Prospect Street to the classroom at the School of Forestry.
JERUSALEM, March 30 Drastic changes in Egyptian civil aircraft procedures, apparently a consequence of current military developments, were reported here today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30 (UPI) Ohio laws prohibiting racial discrimination in employment have been violated by school districts in the state's eight largest cities, the Ohio Civil Rights Commission said today.

THE Emile Walters Galleries are hung with ab stract art this week and if it seems familiar to many, there's good reason. Women have been wearing replicas of the bold geometric and primitive flora and fauna paintings for a quarter of a century.

BUENOS AIRES, March 30 The Argentine Government, which refused to bargain with leftist kidnappers for the life of a Paraguayan diplomat, apvictory Saturday when the guerrillas released him unharmed anyway. At the same time the guerrillas gained prestige by their actions.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 30 Premier Lon Nol disclosed today that he had instructed the Cambodian Mission to the United Nations to request that the Security Council send a team of observers to verify Pnompenh's charges that large numbers of North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops have invaded Cambodia.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 30 Pitching was a strong point with the Yankees in 1969, relatively speaking. In sharp contrast to the Yankee batters, who ranked next to last in the league in run production, the Yankee pitchers were outdone in the matter of scoring stinginess only by the staff of the champion Baltimore Orioles.

There is a languorous sensuousness in Merle Marsicano's choreography that has the weight and feel of a satisfying stretch. Last night at the Cubiculo she presented her company of Perry Caspari, Leslie Craig and Christine Strazza in five of her dances that shared a highly similar but pleasing tonality.
IN a way, there was a new look to last night's "Mar riage of Figaro" at the Metropolitan Opera, for many of the singers were new to their roles.
Frank V. DeBiawa, Clifford J. Demarest, Michael Fedorochko and John E. Letson have been named as vice presidents of Bache Co., Inc.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 30 Cleon Jones hit his second home run of the spring and Ron Taylor pitched three perfect innings today as the New York Mets defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5-3, and ended a three-game losing streak.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered hearings for four brokerdealers charged by its staff with violations of the anti-fraud sections of Federal securities law.

An economist who was one of President Nixon's key advisers during the election campaign warned yesterday that the nation's banks, by moving "prematurely" to lower their prime lending rates last week, risked a backfire that could rekindle inflationary pressure and lead the banks to raise their lending charges again.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 30 California's Secretary of State, Frank M. Jordan, died at his home here last night. He was 81 years old, and had been paralyzed and unable to speak since he suffered a stroke last May 1.

PATCHOUGE, L.I., March 30 The Suffolk County Demo cratic Committee met here last night to select a slate of candidates in the November elections. It was expected to endorse Representative Otis J. Pike for a sixth term in Congress.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 30 (AP) An American Basketball Association record crowd of 17,678 watched the Carolina Cougars defeat the Kentucky Colonels tonight, 86-81.

JERUSALEM, March 30 (Reuters) Electronic computers have proved virtually beyond doubt that two Isaiahs, probably living 200 years apart, wrote the Biblical book of Isaiah, according to a Hebrew University doctoral thesis presented here.

ALBANY, March 30 The State Senate gave final approval today to a bill retaining the two standards of payments for welfare recipients, one for upstate and the other for New York City and seven counties near the city.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 31 Brandishing swords and threatening to explode a bomb, radical students hijacked a Japanese airliner today and demanded to be taken to North Korea. Instead the plane landed at Seoul, South Korea.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) The Senate's special hunger committee said today that a Federal program to fight malnutrition among pregnant women and children was falling far short of its goals.
Steel production advanced 1.6 per cent last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

MADRID, March 30 Not until several hours after the recent attempt to assassinate President Makarios of Cyprus did the Nicosia radio announce that the main weapon had been a Bren gun. It was hardly necessary. Awakened by early-morning shots, anyone in Nicosia except the tourists would recognize the sound at once.
The National Broadcasting Company's radio and television networks face the possibility of a strike by its technical workers at midnight tonight if agreement on a new contract is not reached.

Although their physical problems were not comparable to those of the Baltimore Bullets, the New York Knicks were on slightly sore underpinnings yesterday as they prepared for the fourth game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff series in Baltimore tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 30 Employes of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare won tonight a promise from Secretary Robert H. Finch that he would meet with them to discuss Federal civil rights policies.

SEATTLE, March 30 (UPI) Sidney C. Volinn, a referee in Federal Bankruptcy Court, listened to testimony today in the proposed sale of the financially plagued Seattle Pilots baseball franchise to Milwaukee interests. He said he would take it under advisement until tomorrow morning.

Plato would be in trouble in Greece today and so would anyone quoting him: "Only to think that having come on a visit to Athens, which enjoys the utmost freedom of speech in Greece, you alone should be deprived of it that is hard indeed."

WASHINGTON, March 30 Senator Alan Cranston charged today that the Nixon Administration had brought pressure on a black Government lawyer to get him to write a letter favoring the Supreme Court nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell.
A federal judge issued an injunction yesterday against a Bronx fuel oil company accused of letting oil leak into the East River from its tanks.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 30 The New York Yankees combined 13 hits with 10 walks, two hit batsmen and a wild pitch by Los Angeles pitchers tonight to score their highest run total of the spring and beat the Dodgers, 13-6.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 30 (AP) Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles Rod Laver of Australia and a pair of South Africans. Frew McMillan and Bob Hewitt, advanced to the semifinals of the $49,000 South African open tennis championships today.
CHICAGO, March 30 The Conspiracy bailed out today 16 men who had been fellow prisoners with the Chicago 7 in the Cook County Jail.
WASHINGTON, March 30 Following is a table showing proportion of Negroes on elected City Councils in 33 major American cities, as compiled by the Metropolitan Applied Research Center:

WASHINGTON, March 30 Springtime brings the tourist to Washington, but too often his visit to the nation's capital is spoiled by the language barrier. The following phrase booklet, tucked into a convenient pocket, should enable him to understand and make himself understood by the natives, at least on matters basic to life in Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) Johnny Cash, singer of country songs, has told the White House that he does not want to sing the controversial ballad "Welfare Cadilac" at a social on April 17.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 Lew Alcindor and the Milwaukee Bucks went on the road for a playoff game for the first time in their professional lives tonight and all they did was crush an experienced team and set a scoring record.

LONDON, March 30 (Reuters) Alan Whittle, a teen-ager, virtually clinched the English First Division soccer championship for Everton today with a goal at the eighth minute that gave his team a 1-0 victory over Stoke City.

Anne Philidor has something to answer for, wherever he is today. Philidor is the gentleman (despite his misleading name) who organized the first public concerts in France, the Concert Spirituel, in 1725, an enterprising act whose repercussions bless us to this moment.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) One-bank holding companies now have 43 per cent of the nation's total bank deposits, a Federal Reserve study showed today.

About the same time that Paul Schrage, the marketing chief of McDonald's hamburger chain, was looking for a new ad agency, so was Georgine S. Salom, public information director of the Save the Children Federation. The fast-food operation was holding up a prize labeled $7-million in billings. The charity's billing, however, read $150,000.

Three New York City police detectives, all veterans of at least 14 years on the force, were suspended from duty yesterday and charged with extorting $1,200 in cash, 105 "decks" of heroin and a variety of personal possessions from five persons in the Bronx.

Prices of live beef cattle and frozen pork bellies declined a little in moderate trading yesterday. Last week, heavierthan-expected arrivals of cattle at market terminals depressed prices a little, and yesterday the slight downtrend continued.

The Corning Glass Works had only minor gains in sales and earnings in the first quarter this year, but they were the highest for the period in the company's history, according to the results issued yesterday.
To everybody in the world of chess, Bobby Fischer is a mysterious, sullen, temperamental, unpredictable, moody, egocentric genius.

Caught between inflation on the one hand and declining support from local churches on the other, major Protestant denominations are being forced to make sharp cuts in the size of their national staffs.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 30 The heavy tropical rains are about to come to Nigeria, bringing a season of relief from the stifling heat. But in the Easters territory that was Biafra, the rainy season is also the period of the greatest hunger, even in normal times.

A 25-year-old Navy seaman, absent without leave and wanted for questioning in the rifle deaths of four young people last Friday in Enfield, Conn., surrendered early yesterday to the New York City police.

GENEVA, March 31 The Rev. Dr. Daisuke Kitagawa, an American Episcopal clergyman attached to the Geneva headquarters of the World Council of Churches, died of a heart attack on Friday at the age of 59.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Sometime tomorrow, like people in 63 million other American families, a Washington resident will fill out a questionnaire.
BUENOS AIRES, March 31 Argentine authorities disclosed last night that a deputy inspector of Argentina's federal police had led the attempt to kidnap a Soviet diplomat Sunday.

ROCHESTER, March 31 Mrs. Margaret Dulles Edwards, a former director of religious education at the Riverside Church, and a sister of the late Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, died Sunday in Strong Memorial Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived in Holly Lane, Rye, N.Y.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 31 The Government disclosed today that it had renewed an earlier appeal to the Soviet Union and Britain, co-chairmen of the Geneva Conference of 1954, to send the International Control Commission back to investigate its charge that North Vietnam and the Vietcong were stepping up their military activities against Cambodia.

Auditory specialists said yes terday that too many children with hearing difficulties were not identified in the first months of life, when treatment of the problem is best able to prevent impairment of language development.
BUFFALO, March 31 (UPI) Dolph Schayes signed a multiyear contract today to coach Buffalo's expansion entry in the National Basketball Association.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation reported yesterday slightly lower profits for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 despite record sales that were up only moderately.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 (AP) The Minnesota Twins placed Bob Allison, an outfielder, on waivers and sent 11 players to their minor league camp today as they trimmed the squad to within one of the 25-player limit.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) The police have uncovered What they described as a bomb factory in a North Side apartment building, they reported finding 59 sticks of dynamite, an explosive liquid, weapons and ammunition.

OLDWICK, N.J., March 31 (AP) A man and his wife were found shot to death in their home in this well-to-do Hunterdon County community today in what the state police described as an apparent murder-suicide.
The corporate bond market got a lift yesterday as the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company's new $150million debenture issue sold out more quickly than many investment bankers thought it would.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., March 31 Most of the 345 members of the Democratic State Committee and 1,000 more politicians crowded into Grossinger's resort hotel today and seemed to divide quickly into two groups those for Arthur J. Goldberg and those against.

Pools of calm serenity alternated with agitated flurries of sound last night in a jazz concert by Karl Berger and Company in the, Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University. Mr. Berger, a vibraharpist. Mr. Berger, a vibraharpist, led a group made up of Carlos Ward, alto saxophone and flute, Dave Holland, bass, and J.C. Moses, drums.
BRANTFORD, Ontario, March 31 As the Ranger bus sped through beautiful downtown Brantford today, en route to the Civic Center, Walt Tkaczuk asked slyly, "Hey, coach, can I skate tonight?"

IN September, 1937, a 21year old graduate of Tem ple University showed up at the Episcopal Theological School in Cambridge, Mass., with one small suitcase. He was there to see whether he liked seminary life, and it took two weeks for him to of his clothes

ALBANY, March 31 The Senate passed a bill today designed to spur the state's sluggish home-building industry by creating a state mortgage agency with an authorization to sell $750-million in tax-exempt bonds.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 John Ellis continued to tear up the Grapefruit League today, and made it almost certain he would be in the Yankees' starting line-up on opening day next Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP) The county grand jury indicted a former Internal Revenue Service agent today for the 1967 kidnapping of Kenneth Young, son of a Beverly Hills financier.

About 50,000 employes of 45 private and public concerns in Manhattan's downtown finacial district will break out of the traditional 9-to-5 office-hour pattern today in a cooperative effort to ease the strains of peak-hour commuting.
THE American Ballet Company, known popularly as Eliot Feld's company and two-week run through April 12 at the Academy last night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 31 Bobby Fischer, eight-time United States chess champion, adjourned his second-round game today with Tigran Petrosian, former world champion, of the Soviet Union. Fischer was a pawn ahead.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 31 "If you don't hit on this ball club," said Richie Hebner, "you feel very em barrassed." Not one to be discomforted, even by the best-hitting team in baseball, the Pirates, the then 21-year-old third baseman responded emphatically to the company he was keeping. He batted .301, the only rookie regular in either league to go over the magic .300 mark.

LA GRENOUILLE was a patchwork quilt of carefully cultivated country flowers, gleaming silver, starched napery and beautiful people as Bill Blass walked through the door. His perenially-tanned face broke into a genial smile; his clear blue eyes crinkled with recognition. The waves and hellos and cheek-touching the rituals of success in the right industry, at the right time, with the right people began.

ALBANY, March 31 Refusing to accept defeat, sponsors of the bill that would liberalize the state's abortion law, which failed in the Assembly yesterday, are keeping the bill alive and hope for another vote next week.

BALTIMORE, March 31 A Federal grand jury investigating reported conflicts of interest by members of Congress indicted Representative John Dowdy, a veteran Texas Democrat, today on charges that he accepted $25,000 in an alleged bribery conspiracy with Washingtonarea home remodelers.

F. Lee Bailey, executive director of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, announced yesterday that he was urging the controllers to end their seven-day work stoppage against the Federal Aviation Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Seventy-two movie and television production companies agreed today to an equal-employment plan that includes hiring, training and upgrading of minorities and sets racial quotas.

An $100-million order for two tankers to carry liquefied natural-gas, said to be the largest of their type in the world, was placed with a French shipyard yesterday by the El Paso Natural Gas Company.
Robyn Smith frowned when a freshly painted sign that said "Girl Jockey" was removed from the door of her dressing room yesterday at Aqueduct.
The typographical union applied economic pressures on The New York Times yesterday by holding meetings of printers on each shift and interrupting production in the newspaper's composing room.
YONKERS, March 31 Billy Haughton, the driver whose horses have won the most money in modern harness racing history, will make his 1970 New York debut Friday night at Yonkers Raceway.

MANILA, March 31 President Ferdinand E. Marcos has called the issue of American funding of the Philippine contingent to Vietnam an internal quarrel between the two political parties in the United States who were "dragging in the Philippines."
Two witnesses at the trial of State Senator William E. Adams testified here yesterday that Senator Adams had asked them to give false testimony to a Federal grand jury.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The American Jewish Committee said today that Roman Catholic and Protestant opinion, as reflected in major periodicals published throughout the country, has recently shown increasing understanding of Israel's security needs and increasing support of Israel's sovreignty.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., March 31 Miss Sheila Kathleen Moran, daughter of Rear Adm. Edmond J. Moran, U.S.N.R., retired, and Mrs. Moran of Darien, Conn., and Gulf Stream, Fla., and John Edward Wells, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Wells of Lee, Mass., were married this afternoon by the Rev. John A. Skehan of St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church here.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Jule M. Sugarman, who directed Head Start, one of the more successful Federal antipoverty programs, is expected to be named head of the New York City Human Resources Administration later this year, city officials disclosed today.
MOSCOW, March 31 The Soviet Defense Ministry newspaper today accused Communist China of an "openly provocative" increase of its military preparedness in areas bordering the Soviet Union and Mongolia.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 31 "All is simple why complicate things?"

WASHINGTON, March 31 The nation's trucking industry and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters recessed their negotiations early this evening, letting the clock run down on their three-year national contract.
Agreement for a $100-million loan to Venezuela by a 16-bank syndicate was completed yesterday at the main offices of the Chase Manhattan Bank, which headed the lending group.

Terry Bradshaw and Mike Phipps, the two college athletes who will command the largest contracts from pro football this year, have significantly eschewed the help of the hustling agents, the 10-per-centers who now abound in professional sports. Perhaps an age of reason is coming to pro football, which started the move toward big contracts with the famous Sonny Werblin-Joe Namath $400,000 pact of five years ago.

PATCHOGUE; L.I., March 31 The Suffolk County Democratic Committee recessed its nominating convention early this morning after designating Harvey W. Sherman, a lawyer from Babylon, to' oppose Representative James Grover Jr., a Republican, in the Second Congressional District. Represent ative Otis G. Pike was designated for renomination in the First District.

Assistant District Attorney Joseph A. Phillips said yesterday that the United States Supreme Court decision on how judges may treat unruly defendants would no doubt expedite pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers.

BOSTON, March 31 A Brooklyn man who allegedly shot and killed his common-law wife Sunday and then set a fire chat cost five other lives was arrested yesterday when he was spotted driving through Roxbury.
The critics adored Bacall, praised the rest of the cast, found the music at least serviceable, and cheered the book of Broadway's new hit musical, "Applause," which opened Monday night at the Palace.
AT a time of year when recreational skiing, usually prepares for its annual fadeout, snow running centers throughout the East are still presenting a midwinter picture.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 31 (AP) Billy Collins broke in for his 27th and 28th goals and set up a third tonight as the Minnesota North Stars stuck Los Angeles with a record-tying 5-2 National Hockey League loss and moved into fourth place in the West Division.
LONDON, March 31 The indictment of the Muller company was welcomed here as further evidence of American determination to support diplomatic efforts against the Rhodesian rebels.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The Supreme Court said today that trial judges could have disruptive defendants bound and gagged, jailed for contempt of court or expelled from court if such measures were necessary to preserve order.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 1 A United States Navy F-4 Phantom jet fighter-interceptor shot down a North Vietnamese MIG-21 jet fighter over North Vietnam last Saturday, spokesmen for the United States military command reported yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 31 Miss Loretto O'Brien Mead and Robert J. Bradley, who has served as a first lieutenant in the Connecticut National Guard, have made plans to be married here in July.
The Right Rev. J. Brooke Mosley, deputy for overseas relations of the Episcopal Chruch, was chosen yesterday to be the 12th president of Union Theological Seminary.

Judy Heumann, a 22-year-old honor graduate of Long Island University who has never been able to walk because of polio, has charged that the Board of Examiner's refusal to license her to teach in city schools discriminates against the physically handicapped.
Tugboat workers who went out on strike Feb. 1 will vote this morning on a new management offer.
Rummage and a $15 ticket will admit members of the Auxiliary of St. Luke's Hospital and their guests to a luncheon and fashion show April 15 at the Plaza.

John C. Bogle, a leading mutual-fund executive and chairman of the industry's principal trade association, charged yesterday emphasis on a "one number" approach to measuring performance had proved unfortunate. One result'has been that a trend toward broader gauges of success has already begun, he added.
Prices continued to ease in slow trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Two influential Republican Senators, George D. Aiken of Vermont and John J. Williams of Delaware, announced today that they would support the Supreme Court nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell.

ROME, March 31 The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would make a one-day visit to Cagliari, the capital of Sardinia, on April 24. He will be the first Pontiff to go to the economically backward island in more than 17 centuries.

BALTIMORE, March 31 In another rousing game, in which that famous term "momenturm" swung back and forth like a runaway pendulum, the Baltimore Bullets defeated the New York Knicks tonight, 102-92, and evened their four-of-seven playoffs series at two games apiece.

John Graham is really too good a Violist to be as selfeffacing as he was in his concert at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. By putting two modern chamber-music works at the heart of his program, he took so much attention away from himself and the viola that at least one listener began to wonder just whose concert it ...
WASHINGTON, March 31 The Supreme Court ruled today that juvenile courts may not convict children unless they are found guilty "beyond a reasonable doubt," as in adult trials.
The stock market chugged along in low gear yesterday and finished with price declines leading advances by a narrow margin.
Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said last night he had reached a decision in the case of Denny McLain, the suspended Detroit pitcher, and would announce it today.

ALBANY, March 31 The Legislature today passed the education-aid formula for the coming school year with a $388-million increase that, in effect, repealed many of the economies approved a year ago at Governor Rockefeller's request.
The city mailed 34,000 tax refund checks yesterday, the earliest this had ever been done, according to Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta.
NEW HAVEN, March 31 For the first time in the 269year history of Yale University, a woman has been named dean of one of the school's 12 residential colleges.

PNOMPENH, March 31 A brother of Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol, the Cambodian Premier, was stabbed to death last Saturday at his home in Chup, near the troubled city of Kompong Cham, by a gang of Vietnamese rubber plantation workers.

THE Sports Car Club of America will begin distrib uting this month the 1970 edition of The Road Racing Annual, a 36-page reference work containing race results, schedules and a variety of other racing information. The Annual is edited by the able Venlo Wolfsohn of Washington...

Hammering away on a favorite theme, the city's need for a "construction czar" to speed public building projects, City Controller Abraham D, Beame accused the Lindsay administration yesterday of having a "bleak record" in building schools and hospitals.

Agencies seem to be able to think up imaginative and creative titles for their imaginative and creative people, but isn't vice president for racing a little bit much? Not if it's auto racing and not if the agency is in Indianapolis.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Justice Hugo L. Black turned down today a bid to delay full integration of schools in Manatee County, Fla., by next Monday.
ALBANY, March 31 Governor Rockefeller's office said today that William T. Dentzer Jr., executive secretary of the State Council of Economic Advisers, has been named acting Superintendent of Banks.

Miss Ann Cecily Kennedy and Allen G. Bedynek-Stumm were married here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by Msgr. Andrew F. Quinn, Episcopal Vicar of the Borough of Richmond, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 The United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union agreed today to have their deputies draft a report on the results of nearly a year of Big Four meetings in search of peace between Israel and the Arabs.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 1 The South Vietnamese Army's penetration of Cambodian territory last week has caused considerable concern among United States diplomats here.
Prices closed mixed on the London stock market yesterday. British Government bonds were firm, but industrial shares eased.
VIENTIANE, March 31 Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, said in an interview today that the Communist regime in Hanoi was seeking "to reconstitute Indochina under its oun authority."

William Wrigley, president of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the chewing gum concern, and Mrs. Joan Fischer of New York were married last Thursday in Avalon, Calif. Judge Herbert Cameron performed the ceremony at the old Wrigley home on the hill overlooking Avalon Bay on Santa Catalina Island.

The chairman of the First National City Bank predicted yesterday that the "whole patterm of interest rates" including the prime interest rate on bank loans to business would contine to decline in the months ahead.
A man in New Rochelle, N.Y., looked out of his bedroom window yesterday morning and said:

GENEVA, March 31 The United States sought to assure the developing countries today of the genuineness of its offer to permit broad categories of their products to enter the American market free of tariffs.

Explorer 1, the first American earth satellite, the first to record the earth-girdling radiation belts and the oldest manmade object in space, plunged back into the earth's atmosphere yesterday after 12 years in orbit.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 31 A plan to construct a $150million oil-desulphurization plant on the shore of the Long Island Sound was scuttled today in the wake of mounting local protest against the danger of the pollution the plant might cause.

Of all the Metropolitan Opera's standard repertory productions, none is richer in the simpleminded pleasures than its "Aida," with its Theda Bara staging and Catfish Row ballets. Last night's performance, the season's ninth, introduced two new members to the familiar cast, and they subordinated their talents to the sublime absurdity of the show, which can stand, teeteringly, as a monument to the state of opera in 1970.

A STAGE, a few lights and an actor, Niall Toibin. Mr. Toibin looks at the audience and for a shocked instant, Brendan Behan, Dublin's own darling, roaring boy is among us again. The resemblence is uncanny. The moment passes, but its special magic endows the Abbey Theater's adaptation of "Borstal Boy," which opened last night at the Lyceum Theater, with a strange authenticity.

ATLANTIC CTTY, March 31 The new trend for Roman Catholic schools will be toward a kind of institution that will complement the public schools but not imitate them, the president of the National Catholic Educational Association said today.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 31 A new series of more than 300 earth tremors was recorded in the last 24 hours in the Anatolia region of Turkey, raising sharply today the official figures for dead and injured in the earthquake disaster that began Saturday night.
Miss Claire Ruestow, a great-great-granddaughter of President Ulysses S. Grant, and George J. Telecki, plan to be married on May 2 at the Hamilton College Chapel in Clinton, N.Y.
MASSENA, N.Y., March 31 (AP) The severe winter has blocked plans to open the St. Lawrence Seaway to general navigation tomorrow morning. Ice remains in the river between Montreal and Massena.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) The Atlanta Hawks blew an early 14-point lead, then rebounded from a 10-point deficit in the second half tonight to defeat the Chicago Bulls, 106101. The victory gave the Hawks a 3-0 lead in their bestof-seven National Basketball Association playoff series.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, April 1 A Japanese airliner was still on the ground at Kimpo Airport here last night after authorities gave up on a five-hour attempt to convince a group of hijackers that they had landed in North Korea, not South Korea.

SEATTLE, March 31 (UPI) A Federal bankruptcy court referee granted owners of the financially-plagued Seattle Pilots permission tonight to sell their one-year-old American League baseball franchise to Milwaukee interests.
GUATEMALA, March 31 Count Karl von Spreti, the West German Ambassador to Guatemale, was kidnapped by terrorists shortly after noon today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration budget will have to start growing again if plans for a manned re-usable space shuttle are to be realized. Dr. Wernher von Braun, the space agency's top planning officer, said today.

TRENTON, March 31 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill, exercising a Governor's veto power of New Jersey Turnpike Authority minutes for the first time, has blocked an engineering study of a combined superhighway and rapid-transit line in northwestern Bergen County.
THE Spring National Championships of the American Bridge Association begin today in Cincinnati at the Sheraton-Gibson Hotel with strong representation from the New York metropolitan area.
The Milwaukee Bucks are not volunteering to do what the University of California at Los Angeles did this season. They will try to win their championship with Lew Alcindor, not without him.

BALTIMORE, March 31 "It's a new series now. We're both starting from scratch," commented Gus Johnson in the steamy, noisy, happy Baltimore Bullets' dressing room tonight after his club had evened its National Basketball Association Eastern Division semifinal playoff set at two games apiece with a 102-92 victory over the New York Knicks.

A group of 134 young lawyers from Wall Street firms have signed a petition asking for an investigation and possible censure and removal of Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman, who conducted the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Pentagon officials said today that they expected President Nixon, to announce further troop withdrawals from South Vietnam sometime in April, despite reports that some top military men were urging a delay in the next phase of the withdrawals.
The possibility of a recurrence of the postal strike was raised yesterday by union leaders of 20,000 letter carriers in New York City and on Long Island.

TRENTON, March 31 The State Commission of Investigation, opening public hearings into alleged corruption in the shore community of Long Branch, heard testimony today about Mafia penetration of the courts, the police and the city administration there.
Copper futures drew a flurry of interest during the trading session yesterday on a report of labor difficulties at the Rhokana Corporation's mines in Zambia.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is talking with developers about erecting a large office building over the Manhattan entrance to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel.

NORWICH, Vt., March 31 (AP) Heinrich Bruning, Chancellor of Germany in the last months before Hitler took power, died yesterday in this community where he had spent his last years. He was 84 years old.

Mayor Lindsay will speak at a Vietnam peace rally April 15 in Bryant Park, the Vietnam Moratorium and Peace Parade Committees announced yesterday. Mr. Lindsay's office said the Mayor had accepted the invitation of the organizers.

LONDON,March 31 A Chesham magistrate today ordered Mrs. Joan Wilkinson, daughter of Gene Tunney, former world heavyweight boxing champion, to be held in custody on a charge of murdering here 31year-old husband, Lynn Carter Wilkinson Jr. The next pre-trial hearing will be on April 8.
PERHAPS a word should be said in behalf of the mu tual fund industry, which rightly or wrongly believes it is fighting for its life in Washington today.
At the annual luncheon of the National Benefactors Society tomorrow at the Pierre, the Jewish Theological Seminary of America will honor five women for leadership in religious and civic causes.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 1 "I thought they were filming an action scene," 12-year-old Yoshitaka Uga said.

The bizarre touch added to the style of airliner hijacking the brandishing of samurai swords by the Japanese students demanding to be taken to North Korea must not deflect attention from the enormity of this crime. The lives of 138 persons were endangered by the antics of this self-styled Red Army, which boasted of bombs as well as swords.

DETROIT, March 31-(UPI) Robert F. Williams, the former black revolutionary who returned to the United States to face kidnapping charges, was ordered today to appear for a Federal court hearing on a charge of transporting a gun from Canada into the United States while under criminal indictment.

ATHENS, March 31 Yiannis Kapsis editor of the newspaper Ethnos, its three publishers and its managing editor appeared before a military tribunal today to answer charges that an interview they had published on the Cyprus situation had caused "anxiety" to the average Greek and constituted "anti-national propaganda."

NEW ORLEANS, March 31 (UPI) The well that spilled thousands of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico was smothered by tons of mud today shortly before a Federal grand jury began investigation of offshore drilling violations.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) The State Department said today there had been a 300 per cent increase in the last year in the number of young Americans jailed in foreign countries for narcotics violations.

PARIS, March 31 Those magic vineyards in an irregular triangel of northeastern France where dreams of affluence are bottled under old family names like Moet et Chandon, Mumm and Taittinger are going through their biggest financial reorganization in centuries as part of the drive toward French industrial concentration.

HOW do you like your Morris Louis? Dry, as in the "unfurled" paintings of 1960? Rich and full-bodied, like the "bronze veil" series of 1958? Or with a light, evanescent bouquet, as in the 1960 "floral" paintings?

Robert M. Morgenthau, former 'United States Attorney now seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, yesterday attacked Governor Rockefeller and the state's Waterfront Commissioner and came under fire himself for his tactics.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) The State Department said today that agreement in principle had been reached with the Cambodian Government for the release of the United States munitions ship Columbia Eagle.

Jack R. Goldberg, the city's Social Services Commissioner, said yesterday that the new welfare grants enacted by the state were "a step in the right direction" but would still fall short of enabling relief recipients to catch up with the rising costs of living here.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) William M. Magruder of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation was named today to be director of development of the supersonic transport plane in a shift of the program from the Federal Aviation Administration to the Transportation Secretary's office.

The police said yesterday that they had identified Ishmael Brown, the City College student killed last Saturday in an explosion in an East Fifth Street apartment, as the man who planted a bomb in the Electric Circus, an East Village discotheaue.

Sheldon Feinberg, president since last September of the Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation, informed the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that the concern had an estimated loss of $35-million in 1969.
WASHINGTON, March 31 Ralph Nader and other safety crusaders filed suit here today in an effort to establish that the wheels on 150,000 General Motors pickup trucks were inherently unsafe.

TRIPOLI, Libya, March 31 Libya was gaily decorated today to celebrate the completion of British troop evacuation from the country. The day was proclaimed a national holiday, and raliles were organized in every town and village.
MOSCOW, March 31 (Reuters) The parents of Yakov Kazakov appealed to him today to end a hunger strike he began seven days ago on their behalf outside United Nations headquarters.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March. 31 (UPI) Little Rosemay Casals of San Francisco upset Mrs. Ann Jones of England, 6-2, 6-2, today and gained the semifinals of the $49,000 South African open tennis championships.

Dick Gregory tells a story of a young census-taker who tries unsuccessfully to get into a building in a black community. Undaunted, she looks at the size of the building and estimates about 12 occupants.

It was Rosina Lhevinne's 90th birthday party, but it looked like a scene from Queen Victoria's court. The world's most famous piano teacher sat in her famous green-upholstered throne last night in a reception area at the Juilliard School, receiving homage from a starry assemblage.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind. it's cold bright and snowy in Bloomington, and the blue jays, screaming in the sunlight, wheel through the blue sky. The tree branches are lumpy with tight buds. The crocuses are purple and yellow blossoms against the snow. According to Mrs. Alfred C. Kinsey, "It's getting to be that time of year main."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, April 1 (Reuters) A fresh clash between British troops and hostile Catholic republicans early today flared into the city's worst rioting this year. More than 20 soldiers were injured.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today a $38,324 grant to the New York Police Department to help finance development of a scientific "sniffer" to detect large quantities of heroin.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 31 What do the New York Mets need to win the pennant main?
BOSTON, March 31 Dr. Edward Scott O'Keefe, a pediatrician, died Sunday night at Massachusetts General Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.
LONDON, Wednesday, April 1 (Reuters) The Ford Motor Company, Ltd., today became the third major British auto manufacturer to announce price increases this year because of higher production costs.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird helped yesterday to pin a brigadier general's star on Daniel Chappie James, who thus became the highest-ranking Negro in the Air Force.
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) The Public Service Commission today blocked at least temporarily rate increases planned by Western Union and the Central Hudson Gas Electric Corporation.

Miss Ellen Anschuetz and Welbourne Walker Lewis 3d of Boston were married on Monday in the American Community Church of Beirut, Lebanon, by the Rev. Romaine Swedenbourg, a Methodist who is pastor of the interdenominational community church.

The dance world of the choreographer Yvonne Rainer is bounded by the physical properties of objects and people. They run,roll,ljump, fall, tumble and occasionally colapse. Last night at the Whitney Museum of American Art she presented "Continuous Project-Altered Daily," a piece of amorphic variety that draws and feeds upon itself.

NORFOLK, Va This port city of 315,000 people which closed six of its schools rather than desegregate them a decade ago is planning a citywide venture in racial integration that is said to be the first in the country based on the findings of the Coleman Report.

Joseph Henry Neebe, a former advertising executive who was active in the theater, died March 24 at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert S. Bunge, in New Canaan, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived at 251 East 51st Street.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second largest producer of domestic copper, raised the price of the metal by 7 per cent yesterday. The quotation for copper mined in the United States was increased, effective today, to 60 cents a pound from 56 cents.

By one means or another, since World War II, we have tried to sponsor regional groups in Western Europe and Latin America. However, this has been patently a coin with two sides.
This dispatch Was written by an Associated Press reporter who has just come out of Cambodia.

HARTFORD, March 31 Cyrus McCormick, former vice president and director of the International Harvester Company and grandson of the inventor, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in a hospital here. He was 79 years old and had lived here for about 15 years. He retired in 1931.
ANNAPOLIS Md., March 31 The General Assembly ap proved today a bill that would make Maryland's abortion law the most liberal in the nation.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has narrowed its choice of "people-movers" to ease congestion in the downtown financial area from 115 kinds of hardware "to about seven," according to Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the agency.
The city's controversial 27year-old rent-control law was extended for three years yesterday by the City Council.

NEWARK, March 31 A shot heard round City Hail was being investigated by the police today on the possibility that it had come from a weapon accidently dropped by Anthony Imperiale, a Councilman and candidate for Mayor.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 31 In an unexpected show of strength, Laotian troops have driven North Vietnamese soldiers from several hilltop positions overlooking Sam Thong and re-entered the mountain valley town, 80 miles northeast of here, it was reported today.

Mr. and Mrs. Jack Somber have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Darcy Somber, to Richard Katz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Katz. Bott families reside in Bayside, Queens.
WASHINGTON, March 31 The Government has made an "unconditional" offer of a 12 per cent pay increase to the postal workers, half of it retroactive to Oct. 1 and half to be effective next July 1.
"Sesame Street, " public television's highly acclaimed children's program, is on its way to becoming an electronic institution. These recent developments emphasize its spreading influence:

More than 60 pounds of pure heroin, reportedly one of the largest hauls of narcotics made recently, were seized yesterday by the police in a raid in a Times Square hotel. Two men were taken into custody.

WHITE PLAINS, March 31 The Westchester Democratic Executive Committee last night designated G. Russell James, a chemical engineer from Armonk, to run for the House of Representatives from the 26th District against the Republican incumbent. Ogden R. Reid.
A New York import-export concern was indicated by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of conspiring to violate regulations imposing economic sanctions on Rhodesia.

RAWALPINDI Pakistan March 31 President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, in an unusually candid news conference, said today that he would tolerate no resistance to his restoration of civilian rule, even if this meant using the army to deal with the resisters.
PITTSBURGH, March 31 Richard Mather Marshall, former board chairman of the Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old. He retired in 1961.

Millions of Americans spent last weekend warming up for their 1969 Federal income tax that is due April 15 and also pondering the newly arrived 1970 Bureau of the Census form, returnable today. The former counts your money; the latter counts you.
A strike by the city's telephone answering-service operators appeared yesterday to have been avoided by a last-minute offer from the employers that grants most of the demands of the operators' union.

"Borstal Boy," "Child's Play," "Indians" and "Last of the Red Hot Lovers" have been nominated in the bestplay category for the 1970 Antoinette Perry Awards. "Applause," "Coco" and "Purlie" have won nominations for best musical.
WASHINGTON, March 31 The State Department disclosed today that used military equipment valued originally at $3.4billion had been given to allied governments over the last 19 years.
Mario Soares, a Portuguese opposition leader jailed repeatedly for his views, is going home after breathing the "free air" of the United States and finding it good.
Richard P. Gifford has been elected a vice president of the General Electric Company, in the company's communication systems division.
President Nixon's Vietnamization program is approaching a critical test of credibility this month as the third phase of announced American troop withdrawals from Southeast Asia nears completion.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 31 (Reuters) Gerald Battrick, Britain's second-ranked player, defeated Joaquin LoyoMayo of Mexico, 6-3, 6-1, in the second round of the Caribe Hilton international tennis tournament today.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, March 31 A military court sentenced First Lieut. James B. Duffy to six months in confinement today in what the court decided was the involuntary manslaughter of an unarmed Vietnamese prisoner.
JERUSALEM, March 31 Israeli jets returned to the Nile Delta today with two attacks against SAM-2 antiaircraft sites near Mansura. Targets along the Suez Canal also were hit, officials here reported.
Dolly Madison Industries, Inc., has agreed in principle to sell its ice cream operations and furniture manufacturing division to two companies in transactions valued at more than $21-million.

The good faith of the Republican leadership in the State Legislature is at test in the battle over abortion reform, an idea whose time not only has come but is long overdue. The manner in which a strong reform bill was maneuvered into defeat in the Assembly this week after its surprise passage in the Senate raises questions about the sincerity of the G.O.P. high command in Albany.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday condemned as a "hoax" and a "subterfuge" a recently announced plan by leaders of the building industry to train minority-group members as skilled construction workers.
ROME, April 1 The happiest rumor making the rounds of Italy's depressed movie industry is that American producers have agreed to finance the making of 20 films here this year.
Herman Ehrenreich, drama critic of The Jewish Daily Forward, died Tuesday in New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 162 West 54th Street.

Alex C. Mattison, a retired employment agency executive and earlier an advertising man with The New York Times, died Tuesday at University Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 280 Lansdowne Avenue, Carle Place, L.I.
WASHINGTON, April 1 The Zale Corporation, the country's largest jewelry retailer, was charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with violating the truth-in-landing act.

GREAT NECK, L.I., April 1 Dr. Frederick Robertson Macaulay, an economist and author, who had advised banks, securities companies and investment trusts, died Friday at his home, 11 Clover Drive. He was 87 years old.
The Subcontractors Trade Association warned its members yesterday against doing construction for the city's Housing and Development Administration, charging that the agency was not paying its bills.

WASHINGTON, April 1 It is not easy for a young man to became a fool these days. In fact, it has become so difficult that it's a wonder there are so many of them still in business. Everything conspires against it.

BATON ROUGE, April 1 (AP) A Louisiana State University spokesman confirmed today that Pete Maravich and Danny Hester, basketball players, had been dropped as students because of prolonged absence.

Exclusive Dancer made her way into the winner's circle for the first time this season when she won the $27,700 Prioress at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 28,229. The homebred filly owned by the Happy Valley Farm scored after engaging in a thrilling contest with the favored Restless Life and Petunia in the stretch drive of the six-furlong event for 3year-old fillies.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board will soon make a set of policy decisions and announcements designed to induce savings and loan associations to use savings inflows this year for expansion of mortgage lending rather than for repayment of advances from the Home Loan Banks.

In the age of the drop-out, the handicapped student who overcomes obstacles to get an education and a job is a thought-provoking example in the classroom and in life. The blind student who takes mental notes and the paraplegic who wheels himself through school show a determination that exceeds the courage of more acclaimed hero-athletes in our society.

Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, will receive the 1970 Freedom Cup Award of the Women's League for Israel at the organization's 42d anniversary luncheon on April 9 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 1 (Reuters) Frew McMillan of South Africa scored one of the best singles triumphs of his career when he ousted Pancho Gonzales, the 42-yearold American, in the South African open tennis championship today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 One Philadelphia man said he did not work but his wife did. He asked: "Who is the head of the household?" The Census Bureau said: "Your wife is." He insisted that he was, since he wears the pants in the family.
YONKERS, April 1 To those harness racing fans who have been wondering "whatever became of George Sholty?", the answer is that he is training a string of 56 standardbreds at Pompano Park, Fla.
FM radio is big business, and tomorrow in Chicago the National Association of FM Broadcasters will begin a three-day convention to signalize its increased importance.
Mrs. Agnes H. Haas, wife of John Ross Haas, a partner in the Haas Securities Corporation, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She lived at 433 East 51st Street.

Obviously stunned by the size of its windfall, the New York State Council on the Arts outlined plans yesterday for distribution of more than $20-million it received last week from the State Legislature. The sum amounted to nearly $18-million more than last year's appropriation.

Robert Smith, a 24-year-old Bayonne-born harpsichordist, made his solo debut last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. He was at his best in dancelike music.
