The term, "chapel," as used in the printing trade, refers to printers' shop organizations, which may call meetings to discuss such subjects as working conditions, relations with employers and other trade union matters.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1 Miss Victoria Olson Schmidlapp was married this afternoon to Gray Frederickson, a movie producer, by the Rev. Dr. Hunsdon Cary Jr. in Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, April 1 (Reuters) Sixty-one persons were killed today in the crash and explosion of a Royal Air Maroc jetliner after the pilot apparently made a lastminute maneuver to avoid a village. Six of the 21 survivors were reported to be in critical condition tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 1 President Nixon contends that the appointive powers of the President are being threatened by Senators seeking to defeat the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., April 1 Mr. and Mrs. Earle Chetwood Adams of Hastings-on-Hudson and York, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bethana Roberts Adams, to Curtis Emerson Youngdahl Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Youngdahl of Summit, N.J.
The credit markets moved nearly unanimously yesterday toward higher prices and lower interest rates, broadening a trend that had concentrated largely in corporate bonds earlier in the week.
ROME, April 1 Pope Paul VI will name two woman saints to the honorific rank of Doctor of the Church, a title held by only 30 others, all men, the Vatican announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (AP) The Associated Press and Newsweek magazine filed memorandums today in support of the motion by Earl Caldwell and The New York Times for an order quashing subpoenas served on Mr. Caldwell, a Times reporter, in connection with a Federal grand jury investigation of the Black Panther movement.

The economics and politics of the world oil industry are in for a radical reshaping now that Soviet geologists have found enormous oil and gas deposits in western Siberia. Moscow intends to market these riches at home and abroad with all possible speed.
WASHINGTON, April 1 A member of the Federal Reserve Board proposed today a sweeping change in the way the nation conducts its monetary policy.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 Miss Deanne Gillette and Thomas John Violich plan to be married late next month in the chapel of Yosemite National Park. A reception will take place at the park's Ahwahnee Hotel.

41% Pay Rise for Tugmen Ends 60-Day Strike Here The longest tugboat strike in the port's history ended yesterday when union members accepted a contract that will increase their wages by more than 41 per cent over three years. Fringe benefits will increase the employers' over-all costs during the three-year contract to 53.5 per cent for half of the workers and 58.5 per cent for the others.
Prices on the London stock market closed generally lower yesterday as prebudget uncertainties discouraged trading.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 Jon McGlocklin, acquired in the 1968 expansion draft from the San Diego Rockets, scored the final 7 points with 1 minute 33 seconds of play remaining in a nip-and-tuck struggle tonight to give the Milwaukee Bucks a 118-111 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

RYE, N.Y., April 1 Miss Catherine Schofield Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clay Johnson, was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Richard Anton Meffert, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Forster Meffert of Weston and Branford, Conn.

CINCINNATI, April 1 (AP) Maurice Stokes, a former National Basketball Association star with the Cincinnati Royals, suffered a heart attack Monday night and is under intensive care at Good Samaritan Hospital.

Leaders in the business and cultural worlds of Spain and the United States will take part in a week of activities beginning April 26 to mark the move of the Spanish Institute into its new home at 684 Park Avenue, between 68th and 69th Streets.

The United States Court of Appeals decided unanimously yesterday to take up the question of long delays in the trial of criminal cases here and elsewhere in the state at a hearing this spring on Foley Square.

Sixteen films produced since 1927 that have been rescued from detorioration by 20th Century-Fox, the Museum of Modern Art and the American Film Institute will be shown at the New Yorker Theater, 88th Street and Broadway, today through April 29.
Charles E. Arnett and Kenneth Fulton have been elected as vice presidents of the General Foods Corporation.

CAIRO, April 1 The buildup of Soviet military units in the United Arab Republic has reached the point where they are being observed more frequently these days on the highways and, occasionally, in the cities.
LONDON, April 1 United States consulates are appealing to the thousands of Americans living abroad to complete the special overseas forms for the 1970 census.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI) Indians who have occupied Alcatraz since Nov. 20 considered today an Interior Department proposal to turn the island into a park with "Indian qualities."

VILLEFRANCHE-Sur-Mer, France, Thursday, April 2 (Reuters) Four gunmen walked out of a luxury hotel in this Mediterranean resort early today with a male hostage and drove off in a car without interference by the police they had held off for nearly 24 hours.
GUATEMALA, April 1 The West German Ambassador, Karl von Spreti, kidnapped by leftist guerrillas Tuesday afternoon, disclosed in a handwritten note this morning that he was in good health.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 1 At five minutes before noon, the telephone rang in the kitchen of Denny McLain's house. It was an assistant to the Commissioner of Baseball a man, McLain said "who holds my life in his hands."
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday on moderate volume.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1 (AP) Two Texans took today's opening events in the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor diving championships, which are being held outdoors.
THE inclusion of moderndance works in the companies is no longer a novelty, in this country at least, and the American Ballet Company headed by Eliot Feld, is no exception.

Consolidated earnings of the Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio railroads fell in the first quarter this year to $3.55-million, or 41 cents a common share, from last year's restated $4-million, or 45 cents a share.

The Scovill Manufacturing Company's annual report leads off briskly to say that earnings and sales is 1969 were "exactly on target a 10 per cent increase in per share earnings to $3.91 a share and a 12 per cent increase in sales to $444.5-million."
Marshal Semyon K. Timoshenko, the Soviet war hero, died of cancer Tuesday in Moscow, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency. He was 75 years old.

The four top Democratic aspirants for Governor were reported last night to have committed themselves to run on the Liberal party ticket this fall if given a Liberal nomination even against the winner of a Democratic primary.
Countless residents of the metropolitan area trooped to the mailboxes yesterday to deposit the long tan envelopes that will enable them to be counted by the Government.
LONDON, April 1 (AP) William James Owen, a 68year-old Labor party member awaiting trial on a spy charge, resigned from the House of Commons today.

Talk about rubbing it in! Did you see that Woman's Day full-page ad opposite this column Monday? That was the one in which Fawcett's flagship publication kicked the four other major women's magazines when they were down.

After a period of uncertain backing and filling, Peru's military Government has definitely resumed the path of radical revolution rather than orderly reform. This will have unfortunate effects beyond Peru's borders but it is bad news especially for those very elements in Peruvian society the wretched campesinos of the countryside, the unemployed of the cities that the military "revolution" was designed to help.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1 Undaunted by the previous day's unseasonable snow, which still lay six inches deep in places, hundreds of anglers were at their usual beats this morning on the Croton River watershed for the opening day of the trout season.

The departure of Werner H. Kramarsky as a special assistant to Mayor Lindsay, long rumored because of his differences with Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio, was confirmed yesterday in letters made public by the Mayor's office.

ROME, April 1-A group of 32 theologians in Rome has warned Pope Paul VI that Papai insistence on priestly celibacy is out of proportion to the issue's importance and risks schism within the Roman Catholic Church.

TORONTO, April 1 The Rangers set the stage for their weekend series with the Detroit Red Wings tonight, preserving their hopes for a sip of Stanley Cup champagne with a 2-1 victory over the Maple Leafs.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Capt. Ernest L. Medina was accused by the Army today of being "responsible" for the murder of Vietnamese civilians allegedly killed by members of his infantry company in the village of Songmy two years ago.
The Suffolk County Legal Aid Society announced yesterday that the United States Office of Economic Opportunity had cut off the society's Federal funds.

TRENTON, April 1 The State Commission of Investigation heard several witnesses testify today that alleged Mafia figures had gained control of a man's oceanfront mansion in Long Branch and then had proceeded, in an apparent conspiracy that involved arson and municipal corruption, to erect a luxury apartment house on the property.
LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) A court was asked today to decide whether a drawing by Beatle John Lennon depicting a sex act was more obscene than a similar work by Pablo Picasso.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI) Willie McCovey, the National League's most valuable player, got a clean bill of health on two fronts today and will rejoin the San Francisco Giants in Phoenix on Friday.
A CONCENSUS of critics concedes that Grandmas ter Bent Larsen of Denmark was the most successful tournament player of 1969. The judgment is based on two extraordinary performances.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1-Vera Mihajlov, mother of Mihajlo Mihajlov, the dissident writer who was recently released from prison, was detained by the police today and deprived of her passport as she was about to leave by air for the United States.
After 86 National Basketball Association games, the New York Knicks finally will play one that they can barely afford to lose.

DAMASCUS, Syria, April 1 (AP) The Sudanese Premier announced today that a rebel leader, Imam el-Hadi Ahmed elMahdi, had been killed while trying to cross into Ethiopia after his rebellion had been crushed.
The nation's airlines petitioned the Government late yesterday for authority to restrict their flights further until the mass "sick call" of Federal air traffic controllers is ended.

BECAUSE of the continued illness of William Stein berg, the 26-year-old Michael Tilson Thomas continues to flourish on the podium of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Last night he conducted the players at Philharmonic Hall in a program that consisted of J.C. Bach's Symphony for Double Orchestra in E flat, Stravinsky's Symphony in Three Movements and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 1.

Few of the City Councilmen who have voted to extend the old rent control law for three years can have any serious thought that the law will stand unchanged for that period. There is no question that the city's desperate housing shortage makes total repeal of this carryover from World War II unthinkable. There is also no question that long-term retention in its present form would be disastrous.

An Australian veteran of the Galipoli campaign of World War I was disclosed yesterday as the former owner of the British Guianar 1-cent magenta stamp that sold here for $280,000 at an auction on March 24.
Cigarette sales will be banned in the city's 18 public hospitals under an order issuued yesterday by Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 1 Bobby Fischer, the eighttime United States chess champion, triumphed over Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, in their second-round adjourned game today in the match between the Soviet Union and top players from other countries.

IDENTIFYING the strongest married partnership in New York bridge circles would be a hazardous venture there are several candidates for the title. But if the measuring stick is play in recent major tournaments, the award must go to Michael and Gail Moss, who in the last two months have had successes as far afield as Dallas and Mexico City.
ABILENE, Kan., April 1 The charisma is still there, even in death.

April 1 (AP) Brig. Gen. William R. Bond, commander of the United States 199th Light Infantry Brigade, was killed by enemy small-arms fire today. He was the fifth American general killed in action in the Vietnam war the four others died in aircraft crashes.

Carl J. Gilbert, President Nixon's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, asserted yesterday that "name calling" offered no solution to United States trade disputes with Japan and the European Common Market.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors, officers of shares listed on the exchange. The report includes the following:

A member of the House Commerce subcommittee, which is considering mutual fund "reform" legislation, predicted yesterday that the panel would move Tuesday to break the logjam that so far has prevented House action on the controversial measures.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 Jim McAndrew, who is striving to become the New York Mets' fourth starter, and Mike Jorgensen, who is just striving to remain with the club, both made successful bids in their own behalf tonight whiel the world champions were edging the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-2.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 1 Grinning and giggling selfconsciously in ill-matched, store-bought khakis and occasional floppy bush hats, eager secondary-school and university students of Cambodia are assembling on their campuses for volunteer military training.

SANTO DOMINGO, April 1 President Joaquin Balaguer challenged the seven opposition parties today to agree on one candidate to face him in the presidential election of May 16. The opposition parties have demanded his resignation:

H. Rap Brown, the missing black power leader, has been ordered to appear on April 20 in Ellicott City, Md., to stand trial in the old Greek-revival courthouse of Howard County on charges of arson and riot.

In 1924, just five years after the Black Sox scandal, a young New York Giant outfielder, Jimmy O'Connell, was thrown out of baseball for life for allegedly attempting to bribe a Philadelphia player to throw a game.

On Feb. 19, 1970, I suspended Denny McLain from all organized baseball activities pending the completion of further investigation and my review of facts obtained therefrom. I base the initial suspension substantially upon certain admissions made candidly to me by McLain. These admissions related to his involvement in purported bookmaking activities in 1967 and his associations at that time.
GEDIZ, Turkey, April 1 (Reuters) Relief supplies continue to pour into earthquake-ravaged areas of Western Turkey tonight.

Mrs. Eva Ingersoll Brown Wakefield, granddaughter of Robert G. Ingersoll, and an authority on the orator and agnostic's life and works, died yesterday, after a long illness, at the Carolton Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. She was 78 years old and lived at 144 East 24th Street. She was the wife of Sherman Day Wakefield, a retired encyclopedia editor.
ALNA, Me., April 1 Miss Carolyn Brooks Stires, a granddaughter of the late Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, who was the Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, will be married June 20 to Thomas Porter Aldrich.
TEL AVIV, April 1 (AP) Israeli planes struck along the Suez Canal today, hitting at Egyptian military targets, the Israeli command said.
The city mailed 34,000 tax refund checks Tuesday, the earliest this had ever been done, according to Finance Administrator Fioravante G. Perrotta.

Jean Dinh Van thinks they might "Jewelry is the mirror of life," he says. And, as a jewelry designer, Mr. Dinh Van thinks that what we wear on our arms and fingers or...

Price increases of about 4.5 per cent on most steel-bar products, were assured of industry acceptance yesterday when the two largest steel companies in the nation and a third major concern announced that they would match the action of the Republic Steel Corporation.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York announced plans yesterday to introduce a system of international depositary receipts to facilitate trading in international markets.

Militant students declared last night that they had closed Hunter College after blocking elevators in the 15-story building that houses the branch of the City University at Park Avenue and 68th Street.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Nixon Administration told Congress today that the easiest way for nearly half of all American families to meet their housing needs was to buy a mobile home.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Does the Republican party want Harry F. Byrd Jr. or not?
City College will offer a program of study leading to a bachelor's degree in Jewish studies, Dr. Joseph J. Copeland, acting president of the school, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 The Senate passed a $24.6-billion education bill today after rejecting a renewed Southern challenge to school desegregation policies dealing primarily with the South.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 After six months of relative quiet; the Vietnam war flared up again today with a coordinated series of enemy shelling and ground attacks against American and South Vietnamese targets throughout the country.

Ralph Astrove, who retired two years ago as president of the Astrove Plumbing and Heating Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home, 175 East 96th Street. He was 74 years old and lived at 2601 Henry Hudson Parkway West, Riverdale, the Bronx.

Some 50,000 workers in the Wall Street area went on staggered work schedules yesterday, the first day of a sixmonth experiment to ease rushhour congestion in Lower Manhattan. Most of the workers came and left 30 to 45 minutes early, but some came and left 30 minutes late.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The Automobile Manufacturers Association today released the text of a letter to Secretary of State William P. Rogers bitterly complaining about the Japanese brush off of automobile trade and investment.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Thousands of truck drivers around the country walked off their jobs this morning after a national contract between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry expired at midnight.

One of the most extraordinary scientific findings of recent years that water can be made to assume a dense, Vaseline-like form has been called into question by two groups of researchers, working independently.

WASHINGTON, April 1-A Federal judge granted a temporary restraining order today prohibiting Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel from issuing permits for the construction of an Alaska oil pipeline and a parallel road for much of its length.

When labor specialists last fall ran their fingers down the list of contract negotiations that were scheduled for this year, they sighed and almost unanimously agreed that it would be a troublesome year.

The executive board of a Manhattan-Bronx local representing 8,000 letter carriers unamimously voted yesterday to give iits president, Gustave J. Johnson, the power to take "whatever action is deemed necessary" if an agreement on a postal pact was not forthcoming.
A special deep-sea camera has recorded, reportedly for the first time, a strange tentacled animal rising from the ocean floor on a pencil-thick stem.

Negotiations between the typographical union and the city's major newspapers centered on noneconomic issues yesterday, as the printers continued to delay composing-room operations at The New York Times by holding a series of chapel, or union, meetings.

Advertisers spent over $232.8-million for billboard advertising last year and that is an increase of 4.5 per cent over 1968. The top 100 users of the outdoor medium were more enthusiastic, though, and increased their usage 14.4 per cent.
Mrs. Laura K. Hassell watches the ships go by and gets paid for it.
JAMAICA PLAIN, Mass., April 1 Miss Mary Patricia Collins and Roger Howard Potter, plan to be married here on Aug. 16 in St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church.
The Chase Manhattan Bank acting to plug the gap in mortgage money, became the first major New York bank to announce a plan to sponsor a sizable, closed-end, real-estate investment trust.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 1 A Government spokesman, asked today if concerted actions between Cambodia and American or South Vietnamese troops were being carried out or envisaged, said that the answer was negative as far as South Vietnam was concerned but that he preferred not to comment on the United States aspect.

ENID, Okla., April 1 (AP) The father and stepmother of Mrs. Birch Bayh, wife of Indiana's Democratic Senator, were found shot to death today in their home in what the authorities described as an apparent murder and suicide.

FORT LAUDERDALE, April 1 The Yankees closed their Florida campaign on a slightly sour note today when they dropped a 4-3 decision to the Kansas City Royals. An unearned run in the sixth did the Bombers in.

WOMEN who aren't committed to the long look but are open-minded enough to wonder how it feels to wear it have an easy out. Designers have come up with a relatively painless transition from fashions that practically bare all to styles that leave almost everything to the imagination: They're makine a big do about the separate skirt.
LOS ANGELES, April 1 The United Farmworkers Organizing Committee signed today with two growers in the Coachella Valley the nation's first labor contract covering table-grape pickers.

The Yale University School of Music last night gave the third of its three concerts in Alice Tully Hall commemorating the 75th year that it has offered degrees in music. Divided into two parts, the program first offered chamber works performed by members of the faculty and then the Yale Wind Ensemble, led by Keith Wilson, took over.

After a day's delay in announcing the latest awards at its weekly silver auction, the Government yesterday announced that henceforth it will sell no more silver from the Denver mint. The regular auction of 1,500,000 ounces weekly, plus a carryover of unsold silver, will continue, but delivery will be at the Assay Office in New York.
LONDON, April 1 Amnesty International, a respected private organization, has called for an inquiry into allegations that Israel tortures Arab prisoners.
If you buy a defective product on credit from a dealer who turns out to be unscrupulous, the chances are very strong that you won't get anywhere by refusing to continue payments.
Charles Evers, Mayor of Fayette, Miss., charged here last night that white businessmen had not done enough to locate industrial plants in the South and thereby provide more jobs for Negroes.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., April 1 Embattled New York Democrats, badly divided on a state ticket, received for consideration today a state platform that includes proposals for restructuring the state government.

The city's first community school boards elections have ended with a distinctly moderate to conservative trend. The choice of candidates reflecting such views rather than the often more audible radical voices is probably a more accurate reflection of majority sentiment, particularly after the bitter experience of school strife in the last two years.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 The Lebanese Government apologized today for weekend attacks on American property in Lebanon.

The Lindsay administration was warned yesterday that the 1,200 members of the Building Inspectors union would refuse to be sworn in as special patrolmen to issue and serve summonses for building violations.

Herbert B. Moeller, the retired president of the Atalanta Trading Corporation, a food importing company at 17 Varick Street, was found dead in his bed early yesterday after firemen extinguished a blaze in his sixth-floor apartment in the Hotel One Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village.

WASHINGTON, April 1 A new and more generous Government proposal to the seven national unions of postal workers will be put before George Meany tomorrow for his advice on whether the postal unions should accept it. Mr. Meany is president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

BUFFALO, April 1 Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the author and literary critic who is a professor of English at the State University here, went on trial in City Court today on a charge that he and his wife maintained their home as premises for the use of marijuana.

I always derive an enormous professional satisfaction from watching Louis Falco dance. Even though I don't understand why he choreographs only to his talent and not beyond, I would defend to the death his right to do it. Last night at New York University's School of Continuing Education he presented two works from repertory and an open discussion period afterward.

TRENTON, April 1 Frederick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said tonight that Nelson G. Gross, the Republican State Chairman and the party's leading contender foh its senatorial nomination, was being investigated for an alleged involvement with a labor union that is said to be dominated by the Mafia.
BOSTON, April 1 The Massachusetts legislature gave final approval and sent to the Governor today a bill intended to force a court test of the constitutionality of the war in Vietnam.

THE Bronx County Kennel Club show, forced out doors last Saturday when the Kingsbridge Armory became unavailable on short notice because of National Guard occupancy, will be reviewed by the members at a meeting next Wednesday. The future of the 48-year-old fixture...
LONDON, April 1 The Harkness Ballet of New York has canceled its scheduled visit to London next month because it is short of money.

MOSCOW, April 1 (Reuters) The Cambodian Embassy has issued a note to other embassies in Moscow that will remain under the direction of the deposed Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and not the new Government in Pnompenh.
PARIS, April 1-The French Government called tonight for a general conference on Indochina to make the area as a whole "a zone of neutrality and peace."
Arrests for serious crimes are increasing here among persons with previous arrests, the Police Department announced yesterday.

LAKE ARROWHEAD, Calif., April 1 A thousand acres of towering ponderosa pines in the San Bernardino Mountains, fatally afflicted by smog from nearby metropolitan Los Angeles, were turned over by the United tSates Forest Service today to a lumber company for commercial logging.

Dennis McLain, who pitched 55 victories for the Detroit Tigers the last two seasons and who was suspended from baseball six weeks ago because he was involved in a bookmaking operation in 1967, has been suspended for three more months, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.
Farbenfabriken Bayer, A.G., of West Germany, announced yesterday it had acquired a major interest in the Helena Chemical Company from the Diamond Shamrock Corporation for an undisclosed sum.
A 21-year-old narcotics addict was held without bail in Criminal Court yesterday on charges of arson and homicide, accused of having caused the death of a woman when he set fire to her apartment.

CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, April 1 (AP) Princess Maria Beatrice of Savoy daughter of former King Humbert II of Italy, was married in a civil ceremony today to Luis Rafael Reyna Corvalan, a wealthy Argentine diplomat.
The economy is in good shape, Herbert Stein, a member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, confidently stated here yesterday. He painted this picture:

BEEHIVE COVE, St. Johns, Virgin Islands, April 1-Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today that the Nixon Administration intended to give a high priority to research efforts aimed at understanding and exploiting the nation's ocean resources.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, April 2 (Reuters) British troops fired tear gas to break up a fierce street battle with hostile Roman Catholics here early today.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) The Detroit Red Wings clung to their one-point hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League's East Division tonight by whipping the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-2.
The wedding of Miss Janie Curry Lee of Dallas and Angier St. George Biddle Duke of the Biddle and Baker banking families and the Duke tobacco family, has been canceled.
The Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that it was seeking to build nuclear power plants on man-made islands off Coney Island and in the Lower Bay.
LONDON, April 1 Lieut. Col. Frederick Gerald Peake, founder of the Arab Legion in Transjordan, died Monday at Kelso, Scotland. He was 84 years old.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 Laotian forces were reported to have strengthened their hold on Sam Thong today as North Vietnamese troops pulled back from the mountain valley town they captured two weeks ago but lost to counterattacking Laotian troops yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) President Nixon signed tonight a bill that will ban cigarette commercials from radio and television starting Jan. 2.

ITHACA, April 1 A fire destroyed the three-story black studies center on the Cornell University campus today.

A new system of sticking shiny numbered patches on derelict cars to indicate targets for tow-away contractors, has speeded the city's street cleanup campaign, Sanitation Commissioner Griswold L. Moeller said yesterday.
A police lieutenant with 47 departmental awards for outstanding work lost a legal move yesterday to prevent his trial by the department for allegedly accepting a $75 bribe.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., Thursday, April 2 Arthur J. Goldberg won the Democratic State Committee's designation for Governor last night and then threw the committee meeting into chaos by announcing that he would "waive" the designation to prove he was not "the creature of the bosses."
NASHVILLE, April 1 (AP) John T. Scopes, the substitute teacher who lost his fight for academic freedom in Tennessee's 1925 "monkey trial," renewed the crusade in a classroom here today.

But, in fact, they often do play such a part, and many times they should.
GENEVA, April 1 The staid people of Geneva learned from their newspapers today that a Swiss bank had decided to identify the holders of secret numbered accounts.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, April 2 A group of about 15 hijackers holding about 100 people hostage aboard a Japanese Air Lines Boeing 727 today rejected a fresh compromise offer to allow them to fly to North Korea.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) The Navy announced today a new trial for a former Marine lance corporal serving an eightyear sentence in the rape of a woman at Camp Hauge, Okinnawa, in 1968.

Sylvan D. Freeman, senior partner in the law firm of Dreyer and Trub, died of a heart attack yesterday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived at 12 Hemlock Drive, Great Neck, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 1 A program designed to increase citizen participation in the electoral process, with a goal of a hundred million voters in the Presidential election of 1976, was outlined today by the American Jewish Committee.

SHEPARD! He is so sweetly unserious about his plays, and so desperately serious, about what he is saying.

Plans for emergency, improvements on the Penn Central's Westchester commuter lines including the purchase of 50 new cars and the renovation and painting of almost all passenger stations were announced yesterday by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

CORAL SPRINGS, Fla., April 1 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will aim its corporate muscle at environmental problems in the nineteen-seventies, the chairman of the board of the Pittsburghbased concern said today.

ATHENS, Thursday, April 2 An Athens military tribunal early today gave stiff prison sentences and fines to five newspaper executives and a former cabinet minister held responsible for publication of an interview calling for the restoration of democracy in Greece.
Despite the market decline, merger activity in the first quarter of this year was unchanged, from the like period in 1969.

MONTREAL, April 1 (UPI) Jean Beliveau scored two goals and assisted on another tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-3 victory over the Boston Bruins before a record Forum crowd of 18,848. The victory consolidated Montreal's hold on third place in the East Division of the National Hockey League.

Gloria Contreras is a thoroughly professional choreographer and ballet dancer whose concerts like the one by her company at Kaufmann Concert Hall last night never fail to please or impress in their craftsmanship.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) The Government filed an antitrust suit today to require the Healthcare Corporation of Boston to divest itself of four dental supply companies in New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 2 (AP) A wave of heavy enemy attacks that struck across South Vietnam for two days ebbed tonight, and the United States command said the worst of the fighting appeared to be over.
WASHINGTON, April 2 It looks like the sort of place President Nixon would like to walk through, part fancy hotel lobby, part English taproom.
"The only time the American people ever see a Vietnam casualty is when he's got blood running out of him on the Cronkite program. After that, he's forgotten."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 2 (AP) Gov. James A. Rhodes said today that he would file a libel suit against Life magazine because of an article about him last May that he said "was designed to eliminate me from the race for the U.S. Senate."

SEOUL, South Korea The place to be seen in Seoul these days provided you have enough won (there are approximately 300 won to a dollar) is in the Galaxy Room of the glittering, new and still uncompleted Chosun Hotel here.

GREAT NECK, L.I., April 2 Sid Barry, who retired in 1968 as chairman of the board of the Filtron Company in Flushing, Queens, an electronics concern, died yesterday at his home, 34 Shore Drive. He was 62 years old.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 2 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., smashed her way into the women's singles final today in the $47,000 South African open championships.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2 The Syrians reported today that they had shot down seven Israeli jets, including three Phantoms, as the Israeli Air Force and artillery struck at Syrian territory for seven and a half hours along a sixty-mile front. EL PASO, April 2 (AP) Dorrance D. Roderick Jr., newspaper executive and cattleman, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 45 years old.

Tugboat operations in the Port of New York returned to normal yesterday following resumption of work after the union accepted a new contract offer from management.

Leaman of Birchrunville, Pa., where the wedding will take place on May 9.

Revenues and earnings of Loew's Theatres, Inc., for the six months ended Feb. 28 were the highest in the company's history, reflecting increased profits of the hotel, theatre and tobacco operations, the concern's report disclosed yesterday. Mrs. Jacqueline Garry-Vieilleville, a commissionaire or resident buying agent in Paris for several major American concerns, died there Tuesday, according to word received here yesterday.

The Secret Service is investigating an alleged threat on the life of President Nixon by one of the 13 Black Panthers awaiting trial here on bombing conspiracy charges, but the inquiry will probably not result in the filing of charges, a Justice Department source said yesterday.

It has been the policy of the United States to seek relaxation of international tension by means of agreements on the limitation of atomic arms. We want to avoid atomic conflict and it is almost generally accepted that such conflict can be more easily avoided if limitations are set to the arms race. Negotiations with Russia are under way and the few quiet words one hears seem to give reason for cautious optimism.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 3 Dr. Shelley R. Saphire, a former professor at Yeshiva University in New York and the first dean of Yeshiva College, died in Kaiser Hospital here yesterday. He was 79 years old.

The directors of the studies the Ford Foundation has underwritten into the causes for the ebbing respect many Americans show for the judicial process need not look far to discover reasons for this dangerous trend. The assignment of Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman to preside over the Chicago trial of twelve leaders of the Weathermen and the stalled investigation into alleged police persecution of the Black Panthers are immediate cases in point.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., April 3 Gov. William T. Cahill an-, nounced today that he would move on Monday to establish a Department of Environmental Protection to assure the "restoration, protection and enhancement of this state's physical environment."

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP) Yoshi Hayasaki, a University of Washington student from Osaka, Japan, took first place in the all-around competition tonight in the 1970 National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics championships.
The Duke Power Company reported yesterday 1969 operating revenues of $342,242,000, a gain of 9.6 per cent over the $312,246,000 reported a year earlier.
Leaders of the 10 unions negotiating contracts with the city's four major newspapers reviewed the status of their talks yesterday and reported "very little progress" in economic areas.

LONDON, April 3 A Soviet delegation will arrive in London in a few days for political talks on world and bilateral issues. It is the first such Anglo-Russian meeting since August, 1968 and thereby hangs a moral tale.
PEKING, April 2 (Agence France-Presse) The ashes of Anna Louise Strong, the American journalist and supporter of Communist China, were paid last respects in a funeral chapel here today.
Reaction to the postal settlement reached Thursday ranged from outright rejection to guarded approval and ambivalence yesterday by mail-workers locals here and throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, April 3 A survey taken for the Peace Corps reports that the corps' reputation is waning among volunteers.

BONN, April 3 To cope with the growing crush of travelers and luggage at major airports, the Fried. Krupp Company has come up with a new idea: putting a number of passengers and their suitcases in containers.

BONN, April 3 Chancellor Willy Brandt has declared that his top priority in his talks with President Nixon next week would be the future relations of the United States with the European Economic Community.

The New York Stock Exchange ordered its membership yesterday to suspend certain discriminatory practices against small investors as part of an agreement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to implement a $15 surcharge on most transactions.

DARK OF THE MOON," the drama-fantasy of mountain witchcraft that started a long Broadway run back in 1945, still wears well. It does so, in its revival at the new downtown Mercer-Shaw Arena Theater, even with an omnipresent cluster of male and female witches, who wear nothing at all, and a hero who symbolically pitches in and peels down. For once, nude streamlining actually enhances a text and performance.

If 13 Black Panthers facing trial here persist in unruly behavior and have to be sent from the courtroom again, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan proposed yesterday that they be kept in touch with their pretrial hearings by means of closed-circuit television. Mr. Hogan filed a motion yesterday asking Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh to approve the plan, which would also permit use of closed-circuit TV for the actual trial.
WASHINGTON, April 3 As a result of research done by his company under a Navy contract, a New York inventor has discovered what he regards as a breakthrough ...

YONKERS, April 3 That there is no such thing as a "sure thing" in harness racing is an adage as old as the sport itself. Bettors who backed Good Chase in the $25,000 Red Sails Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight were reminded of this when the 3-5 choice, victimized by an accident, did not even finish.

DETROIT, April 3 (AP) The nation's automobile industry closed out its worst first quarter since 1962 this week, and both General Motors and Ford cut back on their production schedules for April to keep new-car inventories in line with sales.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 After six weeks of spring training, the New York Mets headed north today to defend the championship that one year ago appeared as remote to them as the moon.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The growing illicit traffic in art and antiquities which draws on the cultural treasures of Latin America, Asia and Europe and which often results in the mutilation of historical treasures has become the target of a series of worldwide control efforts.
HOUSTON, April 3 Jim Bouton pitched seven innings against his former Yankee teammates tonight as the Houston Astros beat New York, 9-5, in the Astrodome.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 3 (AP) Texas A. M.'s explosive Curtis Mills, the world recordholder in the 440, sizzled the Texas Relays new Tartan surface with a tremendous anchor leg tonight as the Aggies tied the 880-yard world relay record in 1:22.1. The standard was established by San Jose State in 1967.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 3 The mother of one United States airman and the wives of three others shot down in the Vietnam war were told today at the North Vietnamese Embassy that none of the men had ever been prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

JACKSON, Miss., April 3 (UPI)-The former imperial wizard of the militant White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan was taken to a Federal prison yesterday to begin a 10-year sentence for conspiracy in the 1964 slayings of three young civil rights workers.

THE Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra made its first New York appearance last night in Carnegie Hall, and one thing about it immediately was different. While the orchestra was tuning up, the oboist strolled through the ranks like a pied piper, sounding his A.

Nathan M. Voloshen, a lobbyist accused of posing as a member of the staff of Speaker of the House John W. McCormick, was indicted here yesterday on charges of defrauding a California prison inmate of $16,000 in exchange for a promise to get him out of jail.

GUATEMALA, April 3 The leftist guerrillas who kidnapped Ambassador Karl von Spreti of West Germany increased their price today for his release. The new demand was $700,000 and liberty for 25 political prisoners.

Early last month, just before he was scheduled to fly to the United States, Yugoslavia's most famous political heretic, Milovan Djilas, was suddenly deprived of his passport. This repressive move came as a particular shock because it contrasted so sharply with the generally liberal attitude the Belgrade regime has followed with regard to foreign travel by its citizens.
The Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company announced yesterday that it would raise the price of primary copper by 4 cents a pound to 60 cents, effective Monday.

HARTFORD, April 3 A major battle to prevent the sale of lower-cost auto insurance in New York on the payrolldeduction plan is now being waged in Albany, the Travelers Corporation said at its annual meeting here today.

Dr. Nicholas A. Ippolito, a dentist with offices at 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, who had served as chief of the orthodontia clinic at Brooklyn Hospital, died March 19 in Memorial Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 93 Willow Street, Floral Park, L.I.
The London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday in a continuance of slow trading.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) The Supreme Court turned down unanimously today an effort to delay full integration of the schools in Manatee County, Fla., by Monday.

"The Middle East relates to the essential higher strategy of any major international power and, therefore, neither of the two international sides involved in the Middle East the Soviet Union and the United States can afford to cede the region to the other nor retreat from it.... On the local level, the crisis has reached the point where neither of the two sides, the Arabs and the Israelis, can impose the peace that suits it."

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 3 Robert A. Koller of 812 Sherbrooke Drive, chief horticulturist of the Union County Park Commission for 19 years, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a brief illness. His age was 47.

A Bible printed by Johann Gutenberg has just been purchased by Hans P. Kraus, a prominent New York rarebook dealer, and is on the market for $2.5-million to $2.75-million. Mr. Kraus purchased the two-volume Bible from Arthur A. Houghton Jr., a noted collector and founder and benefactor of the Houghton Library at Harvard University. He said it had taken
A festival of jazz, rock and Latin music to raise funds for a playground on East Third Street between Avenue C and D will be held on Monday evening at Slug's, 242 East Third Street.

COTONOU, Dahomey, April 3 (Agence France-Presse) The uncompleted presidential and legislative elections that were suspended here last Saturday following a series of violent incidents have been annulled, it was officially announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The State Department announced today that Deputy Premier Chiang Ching-kuo of Nationalist China, the son of President Chiang Kai-shek, would visit Washington on April 20. He is expected to meet with President Nixon, Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week in a bearish manner yesterday as prices mostly declined in quiet trading.

MADISON, Wis., April 3 The Milwaukee Bucks, a team that went from rags to riches on the shirt tail of Lew Alcindor in its two seasons in the National Basketball Association, gained the Eastern Division final playoffs tonight by defeating the Philadelphia 76ers, 115-106, at the University of Wisconsin ifeld house.

The long-range favorite for the Kentucky Derby four weeks hence will be on view at Aqueduct today. He is the Elberon Farm's Silent Screen, a New York-bred with a record of six victories in the eight races that have made up his career in 1969 and 1970.

BONN, April 3 Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken, N.V., Eindhoven, one of Europe's largest industrial empires, has announced an ambitious goal: by 1991 the Dutch concern aspires to a consolidated annual turnover of 100-billion guilders, or about $27.5-billion.

THE children who cluster around the Unicorn Shop on East 11th Street are fascinated by the figures in the window. Their maker calls them dolls. But dolls to the local children mean idealized cherubs with frozen faces and simpering smiles. The little people who cavort on wires in the shop window look real "Hey, there's my brother," a Negro child points out.
SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, April 4 (Reuters South Korean naval vessels sank a North Korean spy vessel with its 15 persons aboard off the west coast early today, it was announced.

Dr. Charlotte F. Muller, professor of urban studies at the Center for Social Research of the City University of New York, was married here yesterday to Carl Schoenberg of Teaneck, N.J., director of publications for the Child Welfare League of America, Inc. The ceremony was performed by Criminal Court Judge Milton Shalleck at the home of the bride.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 3, (AP) Joe Frazier, the world heavyweight boxing champion, fractured his right ankle, during a dance turn in his night club act at Las Vegas, it was revealed today.

Miss Elisabeth Ward Krautter and Alexander Ferguson Treadwell, staff members of Sports Illustrated in New York, were married March 21 in the All Saints Chapel of Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka, Ill., by the Rev. Dr. William S. Lea.

MIAMI, April 3 (AP) Manuel Ycaza filed suit today seeking in excess of $2.5-million in alleged damages from Hialeah Racing Course as a result of an injury the jockey received during a race on Jan. 30.
The First National Bank in Dallas has announced a "significant" improvement in firstquarter earnings, reflecting, it said, an easing of money market interest rates.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters) Some 60,000 students from four South Vietnamese universities will boycott lectures indefinitely to protest the detention of 41 students, without trial, a spokesman said today.
CAPE CORAL, Fla., April 3 (AP) Mark Alwin of Florida State carded a 69 today and led the Seminoles to a comfortable third-round lead in the seventh annual intercollegiate golf classic.
MOSCOW, April 3 (UPI) The ashes of Marshal Semyon K. Timoshenko were placed in a Kremlin Wall tomb near the grave of Stalin today in a full-dress military funeral honoring him as a hero of two wars.

YONKERS, April 3 Mr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Goldsmith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Robyn Ellen Goldsmith, to Andrew Schaeffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Schaeffer of Wheaton, Md.

SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, April 4 The case of the hijacked Japanese jetliner reached a dramatic climax yesterday when the nine hijackers exchanged 99 passengers and four stewardesses for a new hostage and flew to North Korea.

DENVER, April 3 Gov. John A. Love announced today that he would seek a third fouryear term as Governor of Colorado, and he is expected to have solid Republican party support. Meanwhile, the Democrats have been squabbling among themselves.

THEY came from an area of the South Bronx where poverty prevails: 30 seventh graders from Intermediate School 139. Some had parents who talked to them of college, but until recently, the youngsters had not shown much interest.

THE merits of leading "topof-nothing" from a worthless three-card suit are often debated. Some experts lead the bottom card in this situation, some the middle card, and some vary their tactics, leaving partner and opponents with some guessing to do.
CHICAGO, April 3 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun a nationwide hunt for the 12 Weathermen indicted in Chicago on charges of conspiracy and violation of the Federal antiriot act.
MAJOR banks continue to draw barbed comments from customers who are disappointed with bank investment management results.

BOSTON, April 3 (UPI) Two Federal courts rejected today the first attempt by a Massachusetts serviceman to bring suit under a new law challenging the President's authority to commit troops to combat zones such as Vietnam.

BOLOGNA, Italy, April (AP) The world middleweight champion, Nino Benvenuti of Italy, will defend his title against Tom Bethea of New York, the only man ever to stop Benvenuti, it was announced tonight. The fight, scheduled for 15 rounds, is set for May 23 at Umago, Yugoslavia.
KYOTO, Japan, March 23 There are two sides to everything, especially Kyoto. A couple of years ago Kyoto's city fathers decided to count its temples but gave up when they got as far as 2,300.

Ralph G. Engelsman, a leader in life-insurance sales for many years, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home, after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

W. Stanfield Cooper, who retired as copy chief of the industrial and professional department of the J. Walter Thompson Company, advertising agency, in 1964, died Thursday in East Long Island Hospital, Greenport. He was 71 years old and lived in Southold, L.I.

Two New York University fencers, Sally Pechinsky and Ruth White, captured all their opening-round bouts yesterday in the Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association championships at N.Y.U.'s School of Education gym.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 3 Newsday was forced to publish a limited 16-page edition this morning because of a fire in its paper warehouse behind its main plant.

A Government report touched off a flurry of activity and higher prices in soybean futures yesterday. Traders reacted to Government figures that indicated soybean oil stocks had declined faster than expected.
While 25 policemen guarded Hunter College from the outside yesterday, students inside the 16-story building chanted slogans, went to classes, or danced and sang in the main lobby.
TAPESTRIES still provide surprising discoveries in this country because the great quantities collected before Depression are largely ignored today.
ATHENS, April 3 Ethnos, the only Greek newspaper openly hostile to the militarybacked regime, "indefinitely suspended" publication today, after the jailing of its principal editors and publishers.

GEE'S BEND, Ala., April 3 When the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. challenged the white supremacy traditions of Selma, Ala., five years ago, his marches and mass meetings were regularly swelled by scores of supporters from this tiny, poverty-stricken, all-Negro community.
More thorough inspection of motor vehicles by automobile mechanics was urged this week as a means to reduce accidents caused by mechanical failure.

CHICAGO, April 3 (UPI) The Chicago Bulls, sparked by a 39point performance from Chet Walker, scored 74 points in the last half tonight to defeat the Atlanta Hawks, 131-120, for their first victory in their fourof-seven game playoff series.
HOUSTON, April 3 The Yankees couldn't believe it. It has been only three years since they last played in Houston, but look at all the changes.
HAMDEN, Conn., April 3 Miss Yoke San Lee, and Bruce Lloyd Reynolds, graduate students at the University of Michigan, will be married next month in Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School.
THE multiplicity of challenging scientific and bi ological mysteries was unsatisfactorily reviewed last night on "The Unexplained," a special on the National Broadcasting Company.

Former Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that the statewide ticket endorsed by the Democratic State Committee this week was "doomed to defeat" and that he would not support it in the general election.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) A Wall Street lawyer appealed to the Supreme Court today to strike down, as an unconstitutional invasion of privacy, a 1969 New York law that requires the fingerprinting of the thousands of employes in stock exchanges and member brokerage firms in New York City.
SOLDIERS strutted, fat consumers glutted. Junkers jeered and tycoons profiteered. Bureaucrats bustled, pimps hustled, and on the Kurfurstendamm, whores paraded their wares.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 The United States chess champion, Sammy Reshevsky, today defeated Vasily Smyslov, a former world champion, in their third-round adjourned game in the match between Soviet masters and the best chess players from the rest of the world.

A crowd of 3,605 sat through a 10-round middleweight fight in The Felt Forum last night in almost complete silence. Juarez de Lima of Sao Paolo, Brazil, won the dull bout, scoring a unanimous decision over the 36-year-old George Benton of Philadelphia.

ST. LOUIS, April 3 (AP) The former president of a rocket launcher manufacturing company was sentenced today to five years in prison and fined $10,000 for illegally exporting launchers to a foreign arms concern. His executive secretary was given a five-year prison sentence on the same charge.

Freddie Hubbard's Sextet, which played last night at Carnegie Recital Hall as part of the "Jazz: The Personal Dimension" series, is one of the most polished exemplars of a style that is a heritage of the be-bop era of 25 years ago.
A New York import-export concern has pleaded guilty in Federal court here to charges of conspiring to violate regulations imposing economic sanctions on Rhodesia and was fined $10,000.
BONN, April 3 Following, in translation from the German, are excerpts from an interview conducted with Chancellor Willy Brandt yesterday by David Binder, Bonn correspondent of The New York Times:

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 Nearly one out of five front-line soldiers surveyed in an elite American combat unit in South Vietnam said recently that they smoked marijuana at least once a day, according to an Army physician's study.

William (Red) Holzman, the coach and general manager of the New York Knickerbockers, likes to say, at appropriate times, "now I'm wearing my coaching hat" or "now I'm wearing my general manager hat." Yesterday, he donned his "kindly old boss" hat and gave his players a whole day off.

About the only thing that delegates to the State Democratic Convention seem to have been able to agree on they failed even to adopt a platform is that the convention itself has lost most of its value. Its proceedings were such a shambles that its endorsements were meaningless perhaps even a liability.

Anthony M. Scotto, president of the Brooklyn longshoremen's local invoked the Fifth and 14th amendments 29 times yesterday in refusing to answer questions at a hearing conducted by the Waterfront Commission.

SAN MATEO, Calif., April 3 (UPI) The Hughes Tool Company announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements for the purchase of Air West, Inc., the nation's largest regional air carrier, for approximately $90-million.

Scrubbed and glistening like children off to their first day at school more than 600 cars were trundled into the Coliseum yesterday as the International Automobile Show was set to open a nineday stand.
The Brooklyn division of the Jewish National Fund will honor Mr. and Mrs. Marshall D. Butler of Kings Point, L.I., at its 21st annual dinner tomorrow evening at El Patio in Atlantic Beach, L.I.
Computer stocks and other glamour issues tumbled sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday while the blue-chip sector of the market held fairly steady.

The 28,000 members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association will be asked Tuesday whether they want to begin a "job action" against the city that would result in an 80 per cent reduction in the number of policemen patrolling the streets.
State Senator William E. Adams opened his defense yesterday by presenting his grand jury testimony that he had returned a $5,000 cash contribution from a Medicaid bill-collecting company.
A new plan for the creation of six community school districts in Manhattan, including one for East Harlem and another for the Lower East Side, was proposed yesterday by the city Board of Education.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 3 The new leaders of Cambodia plan to proclaim a republic soon, probably this month, one of them said today.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 3 (AP) Bob Allison went through waivers unclaimed by any American League team, and Calvin Griffith, president of the Minnesota Twins, said today a decision would be made Monday on whether to retain the 36-year-old outfielder.

Wells Fargo Co., the San Francisco-based one-bank holding company, announced yesterday its entrance into the real estate investment trust field as it registered a $100-million offering of Wells Fargo Mortgage Investors.

The Visual Electronics Corporation said yesterday that a complaint had been filed against it in the United States District Court in Massachusetts by George D. Mason, who recently resigned as president of a subsidiary, Educational Electronics. The complaint makes five claims under Section 10-B of the Securities Act of 1934 and a charge of breach of contract.
BORDEAUX, France The neophyte confronted by a choice among hundreds of wines, most of which he has never heard of, may take comfort: The Bordeaux wine trade is more confused than he is.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3 Three Princeton University seniors who belong to the radical Students for a Democratic Society were suspended today for disrupting a speech by Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel on March 5.

Samuel Kreutzer, a partner in the law firm of Lovett, Kreutzer Vittoria Lovett, 350 Fifth Avenue, and a lawyer for 35 years, specializing in corporate, finance and estate law, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 11 Bayberry Ridge, Roslyn, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 3 F. Lee Bailey read in public today a court-ordered statement urging "sick" air traffic controllers to go back to work but then predicted that none would return because they had not been promised amnesty or mediation of their grievances.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 3 (UPI) Rod Laver overcame a series of lapses in the first set today and went on to crush Frew McMillan, 4-6, 6-2, 6-1, 6-2, and capture the men's singles crown in the South African open tennis championships.
The Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday six addict deaths from acute reactions to heroin or from complications related to addiction from Tuesday to early yesterday morning.
Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer yesterday ordered the arrest of a group of blacks and Puerto Ricans who took over the operatibn of the Harlem Y.W.C.A. on March 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 A Federal district judge ruled today that a New York Times reporter must appear before a grand jury, as directed, but would not have to disclose confidential information to the jury unless there is "a compelling and overriding national interest that cannot be served by alternative means."

Mrs. Lester J. Kelly of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Sharon Kelly, to William Martin Kirschner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kirschner of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for August in New York.
BELMONT, Mass. On the morning of March 9, Edwin N. Griswold, Solicitor General of the United States, took his traditional seat at the end of a long mahogany table before the Supreme Court's bench.

The nation's retail shopping centers, despite the tight and scarce money situation that has reduced the incidence of new centers, continue to reflect dynamism in the form of new ideas to energize existing centers and to develop new types of centers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (AP) The United States infantrymen pursuing an enemy battalion toward the Cambodian border encountered heavy resistance today, and contact continued into the night, field reports said.
PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP) Johnny Jadick, former junior welterweight boxing champion, died last night at his home. He was 61 year old.

Two of President Nixon's top economic advisers have disagreed sharply over the significance of allowing the Federal budget to slip into a small deficit should this occur as a result of unexpected increases in Federal spending.

"Le Nozze di Figaro" had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last Monday, and, singers' schedules being what they are, the first repetition of Mozart's opera last night had two major cast changes.

The Liberal party is expected to designate two of its most prominent members today as its statewide candidates the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington for Governor and Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello for United States Senator.
VIENNA, April 3 The Czechoslovak koruna, or crown, has strengthened recently in the Vienna market for Eastern European currencies.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer has been subpoenaed by the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime for questioning about his relations with Nathan Voloshen, an indicted lobbyist who allegedly used the name of House Speaker John W. McCormack to obtain favors for which he was paid by businessmen and others.

LAS CRUCES, N.M., april 5 (AP) Sam Lacey, a 6-foot-10inch center who starred for three years at New Mexico State, signed a $1.1-million five-year contract today with the Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Assocition.
WASHINGTON April 3 Following is the text of a message on a pay increase for postal and other Federal employes sent to Congress today by President Nixon:
BRANTFORD, Ontario, April 3 That form of torture known as the National Hockey League's pennant race enters its final weekend today with not one of the first five places in the East Division decided.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The Senate minority whip, Robert P. Griffin, charged today that much of the opposition to the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court was an effort by liberals to prevent President Nixon from carrying out his campaign pledge to place conservatives on the Court.

WASHINGTON, April 3 The leaders of Chicago's 50,000 truck drivers rejected today the tentative national agreement reached yesterday between the trucking industry and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WASHINGTON, April 3 President Nixon urged Congress today to raise the cost of mailing a first-class letter to 10 cents, to adopt other postal increases and to speed up the collection of estate and gift taxes to finance pay increases for Federal employes.

Two homemade pipe bombs were found by the police early yesterday morning, one at an East Harlem bank and the other in a busy street in the South Bronx, just four blocks from where a similar device was found at another bank Thursday morning.
Two hundred million Americans got their first indication yesterday of some of the painful facts of life that go with the duty of making their national Government a model employer.

What was billed as a "Ballet Soiree" by the Morelli Ballet at the Fashion Institute of Technology last night turned out to be pretty ecumenical fare including Robert Blankshine, Starr Danias, moderndance, actors dancing, dancers trying to act and a young lady in the audience who called out, "damned male chauvinist" at the end of a series of successive amorous jazz duets between Matt Mattox and four women.

CHICAGO, April 3 Victor S. Kamber, 27-year-old head of the national Young Republican organization's leadership training school, was found guilty by a Federal District Court jury here today of submitting a fraudulent and forged letter to his Chicago draft board in 1968.

YES, Romanticism is back. Last night as I walked up the aisle at the Brooklyn Academy of Music after seeing Eliot Feld's new ballet, "Early Songs," my friend and colleague Walter Sorell reminded me that he had told me this a year ago.
In a cluttered basement office at City Hall, a shrewd and witty woman has rather suddenly taken on quite a role with the second Lindsay administration.

Paolo (Gigi) Buzzallino, proprietor and chef of the Rose Restaurant, 41 West 52d Street, which is patronized by television and news magazine men, died Thursday at Parkway Hospital Forest Hills, Queens. He was 82 years old and lived at 87-20 63d Avenue, Elmhurst.

WASHINGTON, April 3 According to authoritative reports reaching here, the principal Communist political and military headquarters for South Vietnam was hurriedly moved late last month from Cambodia to South Vietnamese territory.

The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest grocery chain, after the leader, the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, and Safeway Stores, realized an increase of 8.7 per cent in earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended March 21 on a sales gain of 7.9 per cent, its report disclosed yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, April 3 Don Johnson, of Kokomo, Ind., continued to set the pace today in the $100,000 Firestone Professional Bowlers Association Tournament of Champions by taking a 339 pin lead over Mike Durbin of Dayton, Ohio.

Psychiatrists at Jacobi Hospital, declaring they have been forced to give "inadequate, inhumane and illegal treatment" to the mentally ill, yesterday established new procedures in defiance of city policy.

GEDIZ, Turkey, April 3 (UPI) Western Turkey suffered its sixth straight day of earth tremors today and rescue officials in this devastated town evacuated the last building untouched by previous quakes.
The new-issue market staged a mild rebound this week from the depressed levels that have prevailed most of this year.

The Supreme Court ruling on evidence in criminal cases involving accused youth will have at least two important effects: It will almost certainly make it necessary for the Senate-House conference on the harsh District of Columbia crime bill to discard some of its tough provisions directed against juveniles. Similarly, the decision will enable family and juvenile courts across the country to apply a clearer standard of justice for youthful offenders.
ONE of the larger ironies of the current art scene is to be found in the uneven pace at which the history of modern art in America is studied, documented and exhibited.

PARIS, April 3 (Reuters) France's gold and convertible currency reserves rose by 20 million francs ($3.63-million) in March to total 22 billion francs ($4-billion), the Finance Ministry announced here today.
William E. Clow 2d, operator of a weaving business in Greece that enables poor village girls to earn their dowries, died in his sleep Thursday in his home at 30 Suton Place. He was 40 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 3 President Nixon signed today the Water Quality Improvement Act of 1970, which sharply increases penalties for oil spills and extends the liability for the cost of cleaning them up.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 3 On a cool, clear afternoon contrasted to the rain that caused yesterday's postponement, voluminous yells greeted Arnold Palmer today as he tied for the lead in the opening round of the $180,000 Greater Greensboro Open. Just before dusk, Palmer strode to the 18th green of the Sedgefield Country Club, tapped in a 30-inch putt for a 64 and drew even with Tommy Aaron, who had finished five hours earlier.
MADRID, April 3 The name is Urtain, and it rhymes with poor wine. But this has been a vintage year.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 3 Miss Marie Linda Forsman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Forsman, and Frederick Ernest Heine of Plainfield, N.J., were married today in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. James J. Halligan performed the ceremony.

NANUET, N.Y., April 4 When the Nanuet Relays were organized three years ago, the purpose of the early season schoolboy meet was "to advance track in Rockland County," according to Dave Hanson, the local high school coach and meet director.
Question: The end of the 1960's saw Grace drop or reduce some of the interests that were more or less trademarks of the company, such as shipping and Latin American activities. Why?

"The Bust Book" is not about a portion of a lady's anatomy. As its subtitle indicates, it is a handbook of legal advice for young "Movement people" who get arrested. One of the four authors, Kathy Boudin, has already achieved a separate notoriety by being identified as one of two girls who survived an explosion which destroyed a Greenwich Village town house.
DELLVVIEW, N. C. April 4 (UPI) A population explosion threatens this town's claim as the smallest in the nation.

Law-enforcement agencies have created a $100-million annual business in new electronic equipment, according to Garlan Morse, president of the Sylvania Electric Products division of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. MILTON, Mass., April 4 The engagement of Miss Carolyn Sullivan to F. Henry Savage Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Savage of Scarsdale, N.Y., his been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sullivan Jr. of Milton and Wianno.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 4 (AP) Al Hattab ended his Florida drought today by galloping past the field in the final turn and scoring a four-length victory in the $20,000 Fort Lauderdale Handicap at Gulfstream.

ALBANY, Calif., April 4 (UPI) Rancho Lejos held off the closing charge of favored Faithful Leader today to win the $25,000 added Gold Rush Stakes at Golden Gate Fields before a crowd of 17,360, Largest of the spring meet. Hanalei Bay finished third and Smugglin George fourth in the field of seven 3-year-olds.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 4 Gerry Leeman, who has been the varsity wrestling coach at Lehigh University for the last 18 years and never had a losing season, was named yesterday as an assistant to the Lehigh athletic director, Bill Leckonby. Thad Turner, a 1961 Lehigh graduate, will replace Leeman as wrestling coach.

FREDDY, 8 years old and next to the youngest in a family of five boys, felt very much left out after he came home from the hospital. He had to stay in bed for three weeks. Most of all he missed the happy roughhousing every night when his father came home from work.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The White House has come up with a pinch-thrower to open the baseball season Monday in place of President Nixon. It is his 22-year-old sonin-law, David Eisenhower.

United States Commissioner Earle N. Bishopp holds what is probably one of the leastknown posts in the Federal Government. Soon he will not even hold that, because the 730 commissioners are to be replaced by equivalent "magistrates" in the Federal courts.

"Turning lemons into lemonade." This, in the words of a motivation consultant, is the essential challenge now facing the mutual-fund industry.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand On a crystal-clear North Island crater lake not long ago, I watched a 6-yearold girl subdue a lordly five-pound rainbow trout with the help of her father. An Australian grandmother who had never fished before caught the daily limit of eight trout, with the help of a guide, and an American visitor, here for a fortnight, netted a total of 100 fish averaging more than four pounds each.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) The welfare systems of 39 states failed to meet Federal standards completely, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare disclosed this week.
WASHINGTON, April 4 The issue of the environment apparently has caught up with the Army Corps of Engineers. And the corps seems to be making a strong effort to catch up with the issue.

SAUL LESSER, a Manhattan lawyer, returned from a visit to his travel agent puzzled and irritated. In late June, he's flying from New York to Lisbon, and he wonders why he must pay $255 for a one-way ticket.

TEN clubs will participate in the 15th annual Metropolitan New York Numismatic Convention, which will be held at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street, May 14 through May 17. The show, one of the most attractive on the spring calen dar in the East, is open to the public and there is no admission charge.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland The Kerlingarfjokull ski center, where the snow never melts and where the long daylight makes it possible to ski most of the "night," was discovered by Americans just last summer and they are expected to return there in greater numbers this July and August. This glacier area of Iceland's uninhabited central highlands is accessible only in midsummer because the road to it is blotted out by snow during the rest of the year.

WASHINGTON, April 4 This is spring training time for the 1970 Congressional elections, and the Republicans are acting like the Mets. This time, they have a President, a bank-roll and Spiro Agnew, and the Democrats are tired, divided and broke.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 4 (UPI) Mrs. Ruth Cornwall Woodman, who created the "Death Valley Days" radio series 40 years ago and wrote more than 700 of its scripts, died in a hospital here on Thursday after a brief illness. She was 75 years old.

Mayor Lindsay's speech at the University of California was significant because of what he said and where he said it. He did not bring home a degree from Berkeley; Governor Reagan and his Regents deliberately denied Mr. Lindsay the traditional honor accorded a Charter Day speaker.

ARCADIA, Calif., April 4 Quicken Tree and Fiddle Isle, two stout American-breds, raced to a thrilling dead-heat triumph over an international field today in the $125,000. San Juan Capistrano invitation handicap on the Santa Anita Park turf course.

A left-hander, Bob Files, struck out 15 batters to lead Long Island University to its second consecutive shutout over Oswego State, 6-0, yesterday on the winner's field in downtown Brooklyn.

Because of tight money policies, inflationary pressures and the lack of real novelty in the 1970 models, new-car dealers are devoting an increasing effort this year to the sale of used cars to make up for the sluggish sales of the new ones.

OSAKA, Japan THE function of a world's fair, accepted at its pro fessed idealistic level, is to open channels of com munication that lead to international understanding. We all know, however, that what this boils down to is a matter of international showing off. You don't have to be a cynic to recognize that each nation's pavilion is intended as a competitive idealized self-portrait, even when the job backfires.

TONYS and Oscars are again being handed out, amid the usual pomp and circumstance. But, as always, many of the season's worthy theatrical deeds have gone unrewarded. Herewith our annual consolation prize a Toscar to some unsung heroes of stage and screen whose recent achievements merit recognition.

A traps-Atlantic race to Spain in 1972 and another to England in 1975 were made public last week by the New York Yacht Club, which will have a hand in sponsoring both. The starting dates remain to be selected, but the event to Spain will begin from Bermuda after the Newport-Bermuda race and the one to England from Newport.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 4 Neighboring private power systems and the Tennessee Valley Authority are strengthening their links to protect the reliability of service and for system economy.
