State and Federal highway user tax collections in the tristate area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut average nearly $5-million a day almost $3-million in New York, $1.4-million in New Jersey and $597,000 in Connecticut.

Miss Susan Platt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford Platt of New York and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y., was married here yes terday afternoon to Samuel Woolsey Carmalt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Woolsey Carmalt of Hastings-onHudson and Friendsville, N.Y.

The annual spring concert by the Symphonic Workshop of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association will be presented on April 19 at 3 P.M. at Kaufmann Concert Hall, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street. Maurice Levine will conduct.

HONOLULU, April 3 Lieut Gov. Thomas J. Gill, 47 years old, pointed from his office win dow in the state Capitol to the graceful upward sweep of land from sea to mountains, and to the housing projects encroaching into the farmland.

IT IS virtually impossible to lift a tree or shrub out of the ground, move it, and replant it without damaging its root system. Severe damage to the root system will so impair the plant's ability to absorb water from the soil that it can cause it serious or fatal injury. A few simple procedures, however, will help to minimize transplanting injury and insure the plant a quick recovery in its new location.
TEANECK, N.J., April 4 Coach John Orsino's surprising Fairleigh Dickinson baseball team scored its second straight Metropolitan Conference victory today by defeating St. Francis of Brooklyn, 7-6.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., April 4 The women's liberation movement, born on the campuses and in the cities and nurtured on the energy of radical politics, has come to this village on the Hudson.
BOZEMAN, Mont. (UPI) A unique camp, combining scenic beauty and oral and written instruction for deaf children, will open for the second time this summer at Hyalite Canyon south of here.

To damn him at once this early spring morning, call novelist ("This Is Goggle") Bentz Plagemann a square. He tries to pay his bills, he is interested in his church. Also call him a sentimentalist, for he likes his wife, his son and the neighbors' children.

LUSAKA, Zambia Although this copperrich African nation between Tanzania and Rhodesia is potentially fertile soil for tourism, the number of holidayers visiting Zambia since it became independent of Britain in 1964 has fallen sharply. Valiant efforts by its tourist officials to attract more visitors have met with only limited success.

STRATFORT-ON-AVON, England, April 2 The Royal Shakespeare Company has done much of its best Stratford work by focusing on clusters of related plays, and appropriately its 10th anniversary season. opens with the completion of such a series. This is John Barton's production of "Measure for Measure," which concluded his cycle of the dark comedies.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I, April 4 Four scientists and an engineer, the first aquanaut team of Tektite 2, swam down today to occupy an underwater laboratory here and begin an ambitious seven-month study of marine life.
WASHINGTON, April 4 About 50,000 people marched up Pennsylvania Avenue to a rally at the Washington Monument today to advocate "victory in Vietnam."

MONTEREY, Calif. Jan Gardner's delicate, beringed hand draws a Wide are in the air. "It's 1830," She says. "I See sun shine on the plaza, music, color, white surf on the beach, sea gulls flashing in the sun, boys in sombreros and girls in flounces rolling hoops and playing tag proud mamas promenading, horses and carriages waiting at the curb. I see scenes of old Monterey."

LIBERTY CORNERS, N. J., April 4 Dozens of builders, who ordinarily employ the men who put up houses, pitched in today with hammers, saws and their own muscle to make sure the Kienast quintuplets have a new roof over their heads when they leave the hospital in the next few weeks.

An obscure bill for the rehabilitation of Atlantic Avenue that went through the State Senate last week with barely a ripple had residents and legislators from Brooklyn Heights and surrounding communities on the battlements yesterday.

TEL AVIV, April 4 (AP) The Israeli command reported sporadic firing today along Israel's borders with Syria and Jordan. The exchange with Syria was in the Golan heights, where Syria and Israel Thursday fought their biggest land and air battles since the 1967 Middle East war.

The cruising sloop Niagara, beaten United States challenger for the Canada's Cup on Lake Ontario last September, has been given as a gift to the syndicate headed by Robert W. McCullough that is financing a new 12-Meter yacht as a possible America's Cup defender.

MIAMI, April 4 The allmale Dade County (Greater Miami) Commission, apparently bowing to "woman power," chose its first female member this week.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 4 By nearly 8 to 1, people questioned by the Gallup Poll said they would oppose the busing of Negro and white children to achieve racial balance in schools, the Gallup organization reported today.

Four men were arrested in a suite at the Peter Cooper Hotel, 130 East 39th Street at 1:30 P.M. yesterday and charged with operating a sports and policy-number betting ring that, according to the police, took in nearly $5-million in three months.

One of the sorrows of my fiction-reading life is that Edmund Crispin ceased recounting the immensely witty and literate adventures of Oxford don Grevase Fen in 1953 after but eight novels and a collection of short stories.

Bridges on supertankers all over the world are beginning to sport a special kind of black box to help them dock without damage. They show the man on the navigating platform how far off the bow of the huge vessel is moving until it is docked or anchored.

A time-honored Wall Street tradition will topple Thursday when Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., the brokerage house, becomes the first publicly owned member of the New York Stock Exchange, opening the way for the exchange community to tap the public's vast capital resources for the first time.

MANILA, April 4 The military conference of the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization said in a statement at the end of two days of talks yesterday that the organization's effectiveness should be increased in the face of increasing Communist subversion, insurgency and open aggression in the treaty area.
The Ford Foundation has announced grants totaling more than $14-million for programs to help curb the world rate of population growth.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 4 (UPI) Juan Marichal is suffering a severe ear infection and may not start Tuesday's season opener against Houston in Candlestick Park, Clyde King, the San Francisco manager, said today.
TRENTON, April 4 (AP) New Jersey's trout season opened today and the turnout of fishermen was reported as the smallest in many years.

In the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday, Miss Joan S. Elbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Elbaum of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Harold Lewis Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Gordon of New York and Mahopac, N.Y. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.
PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP) Brig. Gen. J. Harry LaBrum, U.S.A., retired, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 72 years old.

When an airline pilot is retiring after more than three decades, he may find that he is better known to ground controllers and dispatchers than he thinks. This happened last month to Capt. Robert J. Carroll on his final flight from San Francisco to New York for American Airlines.

CHICAGO, April 5 With a seven-goal spree in the third period, the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 10-2, tonight and became the first team in National Hockey League history to rise from last plate to first in consecutive seasons.

Gilda Cruz-Romo, a soprano from Fort Worth, Tex., won the top cash award of $2,500 last night in the finals of the Metropolitan Opera National Council's 1969 regional audition at the Metropolitan Opera House. Rudolf Bing the Metropolitan's general manager, made the award onstage at the conclusion of a long evening of singing and cheering, and immediately offered Miss CruzRomo a Met contract.

INUVIK, Northwest Territories, Canada, March 29 An experiment that could bear on the cost of home heat, industrial fuel and gasoline for millions of Americans is being conducted two miles outside this Western Arctic town at the top of the North American continent, where the sea will be frozen until June.

Ellsworth L. (Tim) Timberman, the 42-year-old executive, who had so much to do with the successful turnaround of Kenyon Eckhardt will be leaving the agency business to pit his youthful energies against the problem of urban blight. Maybe there is hope.

JERUSALEM, April 5 The Israeli Government tonight rejected a bid by Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, to accept what he said was an apparent invitation to confer with President Gamal Abdel Nasser in Cairo.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) David Eisenhower, President Nixon's son-in-law, said today he was seriously considering not attending his own graduation ceremonies at Amherst College to avoid embarrassment to his family.

Having given a good number of his years to the young chicks at Mademoiselle, Gordon N. Morford, the publisher, is moving along to join the more mature gals at Harper's Bazaar. The title, however, remains the same.

American Motors Corporation officials are weighing the possibility of increasing production of the company's new small car, the Gremlin. But the costs of overcoming assemblyline problems and the hazards from competition make a giant build-up of the model's output risky, company officials at the New York Auto Show said in a series of interviews.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., April 5 Jessica Fleischmann's Green With Envy captured both classes over fences to win the regular working hunter championship his second title in two weeks at the North Salem Lions horse show today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 5 Dr. Pedro A. Bacallao of the Princeton Club retained the United States national squash tennis championship today by rallying to win at the Bronxville Field Club after losing the first two games.

A moderately heavy volume of post-holiday air traffic moved through the nation's skies yesterday with few long delays as 1,000 or more air traffic controllers continued their 13-day "sick" work stoppage against the Federal Aviation Administration.

DETROIT, April 5 Delegates to the first convention of the Black Christian Nationalist movement here vowed today to work to align the traditionally strong Negro church with the growing nationalist feeling of black Americans and to make the curch a primary "revolutionary force for the liberation of black people."

Dr. Joseph Chandler Morris, former vice president of Tulane University, died Saturday night at the Biltmore Hotel, where he was attending a meeting of the Council of Library Resources. He was 67 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 6 South Vietnamese troops penetrated nearly 10 miles into Cambodia yesterday, reliable military sources said today.

WASHINGTON, April 5 Bigcity law enforcement officers are becoming less disturbed by the Supreme Court's rein on their conduct toward suspects despite new evidence that crime has been steadily outstripping their capacity to control it.

Mrs. Hope Goddard Iselin, a prominent sportswoman and long a social leader here, died yesterday in Aiken, S.C., where she had a winter home. Mrs. Iselin was 102 years old and lived in Upper Brookville, L.I. She was the widow of Charles Oliver Iselin, banker and yachtsman, who three times defended the America's Cup.

The North American Soccer League opened its 1970 season at St. Louis yesterday where the local Stars suffered a 4-0 defeat at the hands of the visiting Dallas Tornado. Mike Renshaw scored twice for Dallas while Bill Moffet and Louis Juresy scored one apiece at Francis Field before 6,100.

NEW ORLEANS, April 3 The American news media are in the grip of "a credibility crisis," according to Turner Catledge, who served for nearly two decades as the chief news executive of The New York Times.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 5 Gary Player of South Africa, who has been winning golf tournaments in the United States since 1958, passed Arnold Palmer and three others in the fourth round today and won the Greater Greensboro open by two strokes.
The trans-Atlantic passenger steamship lines have decided to increase minimum fares next year by amounts ranging from $9 to $18.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., April 5 Robert M. Shedden, retired executive officer of Dillon, Read Co., investment bankers, in New York, died yesterday at the Carolton Convalescent Hospital here. He was 75 years old and lived at 221 Tahmore Drive.

BETHESDA, Md., April 5 Jacob H. Mogelever, a former newspaper editor who retired in February as promotion manages of the Savings Bond Division of the Treasury Department, died here last night. His age was 69 years old and lived here.

BUENOS AIRES, April 5 (AP) The police reported today that an explosion had led to the discovery of a terrorist bomb factory five miles from downtown Buenos Aires and the arrest of 102 persons, including two men wounded in the blast.

BALTIMORE, April 5 For a change, Earl Monroe was not at the front of the Baltimore Bullets' offense today as they evened their National Basketball Association playoff series against the New York Knicks with a 96-87 victory.

MANILA, April 5 (AP) Australia completed a 5-0 rout of the Philippines today in the Eastern Zone of the Davis Cup elimination series as John Alexander and Ray Ruffels easily won the final singles matches.
HOUSTON, April 5 One final positive note was sounded today as the Yankees closed their finest spring in at least 15 years.
Car drivers in New York State might focus their headlights on a couple of bills now pending in Albany that could save them money and quite a few headaches.

JERUSALEM, April 5 Israeli officials believe that the United States may seek more direct ties with the United Arab Republic in the visit to the Middle, East next week of Joseph J. Sisco, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.
PNOMPENH, April 5 (AP) A Government source said today it was expected that the new Cambodian regime would form a republic by Saturday.
Special to The New York Times

GREENWICH, Conn., April 5 Wilkie Bushby, a partner in the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer Wood, and its predecessors, since 1928, died Friday here. He was 72 years old and lived in Deer Park, Conn.

Miss Joan L. Golub, an actress known as Joan Bradley, was married last evening to Patrick J. Desmond, an actor. State Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William W. Golub.
Francis J. Wier, a retired assistant general counsel of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Thursday in Columbus Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 44 Gramercy Park.
In a significant break with Wall Stret tradition, Burnham Co., the brokerage firm, has begun imposing a "custody fee" on dormant customer accounts in an effor tto offset rising costs.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 5 A new agricultural policy, stressing capital investments in farm machinery rather than the traditional reliance on human labor to meet the problems posed by an industrializing economy, was approved by the Kuomintang, Nationalist China's ruling party, at its annual session here last week.
LIBERTY CORNERS, N.J., April 5 (UPI) With a little help, the William Kienast family nearly finished their "barn-raising" today building a larger home.
KUALA LUMPUR, April 5 (AP) Graeme Lawrence of New Zealand, maneuvering through 25 minutes of driving rain, won his second straight Selangor Grand Prix auto race today.
The executive heads of three major religious organizations joined in commending yesterday the welfare reform bill now before Congress and urged both houses to pass it.
ALBANY, April 5 A 26-week training program has been developed by the State Labor Department's Division of Em ployment to free more New York City policemen for lawenforcement duties.
BERLIN, April 5 (Reuters) West Berlin policemen reported that East German border guards today foiled an attempt by a man to escape over the border wall into West Berlin.
After last month's unrest at the State University of New York at Buffalo, a faculty factfinding committee said that police should be called "only under the most extraordinary circumstances."
HONG KONG, April 5 Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China was welcomed at Pyongyang airport today by the North Korean Premier, Kim Il Sung, and President Choi Yong Kun.

IT is unusual for the honors to be shared in a major tournament, and for two successive events to result in a tie is very rare indeed. This occurred in the Spring Nationals of the American Bridge Association in Cincinnati, which ended yesterday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 5 The widow of the Moslem community leader in Capetown who died while being detained by the police last year is claiming $31,000 in damages from the Ministers of Police and Justice.

TOKYO, April 5 "As individuals they were very pleasant and polite companions," Shinjiro Yamamura, the Japanese Deputy Minister of Transportation said of the nine young hijackers he accompanied to North Korea aboard the hijacked Japanese airliner.

BRISTOL, Tenn., April 5 (AP) Donnie Allison of Hueytown, Ala., beat his big brother, Bobby, by three laps today in the Southeastern 500 stock car race before 26,000 fans at the Bristol International Speedway.
MOSCOW, April 5 Gray haired and speaking with a slow, Georgian accent, Stalin calmly refuses to give the Nazis a field marshal in exchange for his captured son.
A group of Federal judges in meetings this weekend at New York University expressed dismay at the plight of the International Court of Justice, which does not have a single case on its docket.

The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday it has raised admission prices for next season because of higher costs resulting in part from a contract settlement reached in December with the company's personnel. The last such general increase was four years ago.

The Rangers squeezed into the Stanley Cup hockey playoffs last night, but the Knickerbockers were balked in their efforts to clinch the Eastern semifinal playoff in the National Basketball Association.
CHICAGO, April 5 Ch. Special Edition, a red grizzle and tan Lakeland terrier, gained the best-in-show award tonight at the 30th International Kennel Club show in the Amphitheatre.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) Texas, the national champion, and second-ranked Penn State, the only major teams with perfect records last year, will appear twice each on a 35-game 1970 college football telecast schedule announced today by the American Broadcasting Company.

The Rev. Wyatt Tee Walker, pastor of the Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem, preached his sermon yesterday through a bullhorn while standing on the trunk of a White Mustang parked in front of the Teen City pizza parlor at 162 West 116th Street.

LONDON On March 2, the switchboard of the British Broadcasting Corporation experienced a sudden surge of worried, indignant and just plain inquisitive telephone calls from TV viewers. They were jolted by an episode in a new drama series featuring a species of superintelligent rats, ...
The Administration's decision to stay out of Cambodian politics serves the best interests of Cambodia, Vietnam and, not least, the United States.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 5 Supporters of Imam el-Hadi Ahmed el-Mahdi, the religious leader of a Moslem sect in the Sudan who was killed last week after his uprising against the Government was crushed, said that the outbreak was larger than the Government had admitted and that fighting was continuing.

DENVER, April 5 (AP) Spencer Haywood and Lonnie Wright sparked a second-half rally today, leading the Denver Rockets to their 15th consecutive American Basketball Association victory at home as they beat the Kentucky Colonels, 112-98.
Mrs. Irma Nathan Straus, whose husband, Jesse I. Straus, was Ambassador to France from 1933 to 1936, died at her Park Avenue home yesterday. She was 94 years old.

THE recipes for prune cake and apple cake given be low have been treasured in a handwritten collection belonging to a South Dakota family for several generations. The fruit and nut cake is a delectable confection of cherries, dates, pecans, Brazils and walnuts held together with a minimum of dough. It is quick to make and bake.

LANAI CITY, Hawaii The clouds churned ominous ly on the crest of the hill, but Swede said "No, the rain won't come." They were riding the Trade Winds and had been wrung out on the much higher mountains in Maui, across the channel.

The lack of debate, the refusal even to allow candidates seeking endorsement to speak, the secret decisions carefully worked out by private conference among the very few all this combined at the Liberal party's nominating convention over the weekend to turn its proceedings into a mockery of democracy.

A pleasing mix of works in various styles was presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night. Berg's Four Pieces for Clarinet and Piano (1913), Schumann's Fantasy Pieces (Op. 73) for the same combination and Berio's Sequenza VI for Solo Viola were set betwen Haydn's Trio in D major for Flute, Cello and Piano and Mozart's Quintet in G minor (K. 516).

As regiments of commuters trooped past and loudspeakers droned timetables in the background, Mrs. Theodore Malino set up camp on the concourse of Pennslyvania Station with four romping children, five heavy red suitcases, three stuffed shopping bags and a big basket of coloring books.

TOKYO, Monday, April 6 (Reuters)-Col. William V. Koch, the editor in chief of the authorized American Army newspaper, Stars and Stripes, the Pacific edition, said here today the newspaper's Saigon bureau chief would be reassigned to Tokyo later this week "as a routine change."
NAPLES, Italy, April 5 (UPI) Une de Mai set a course record today and then won the 21st Agnano Trotting Classic before an enthusiastic crowd of 90,000.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. (UPI) Rutgers University paid tribute to Paul Robeson, its best known black alumnus.
PITTSBURGH, April 5 Steel producers reported firm domestic demand last week and a surprising turn in foreign trade.

Hopes that there still might be time and willingness to break th ebitter deadlock that has developed between Washington and Tokyo over textile imports was expressed by Japanese sources here last week.

HIGH up on a remaining wall of that bombed-out house on 11th Street in Manhattan, one can make out the remains of what must once have been a comfortable den. Where the third floor used to be, suspended grotesquely above rubble reminiscent of Berlin after World War II, there is a fireplace flanked by bookshelves built into the wall. On the shelves rest the charred but still intact remains of a hundred or so volumes.

Faced with steady growth in population and industry, the borough of Queens will require "substantial public investment" and careful rezoning to maintain its present residential quality, according to the City Planning Commission.
BOSTON, April 5 (UPI) Third-period goals by Derek Sanderson and Ken Hodge, scored only 68 seconds apart, gave the Boston Bruins a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.
Negotiations on new contracts between union employes and the city's four major newspapers continued yesterday without any announced progress.

The Socialist Labor party, a Marxist party founded in 1890, yesterday nominated Stephen Emery, of Jamaica, Queens, a subway dispatcher, for Governor, and John Emanuel, a Manhattan fur worker, for United States Senator.
WASHINGTON, April 5 Despite a rising volume of complaints about barriers to trade, the total of world trade rose massively again last year, the International Monetary Fund has reported.

THE days of simple woodsmanship and marshmal lows around the camp fire are all but over. In their stead, increasingly more sophisticated fare is being offered by children's camps to compete with the lures of family travels, European tours, beefed-up summer schools and dozens of activities designed to fill the vacation months.

Work on building four 34,000 tankers at Pascagoula, Miss., is to be resumed following agreement on a change of power plants between the InIngalls East division of Litton Industries, the builder of the ships, and the Uower System division of Colt Industries.

SAMMY RESHEVSKY, a grandmaster and seven time United States champion from Spring Valley, N.Y., and America's long-shot to become the next chess champion of the world, reports three recent warm-up exhibitions from Florida.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) The New York Nets beat the Indiana Pacers, 104-99, today. It marked the fourth loss in the last five games for the Pacers, who already have clinched the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division title.
Mrs. Forsyth Patterson Watson, widow of George E. Watson Jr., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died at her home, 970 Park Avenue, Friday. She was 66 years old.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 5 (Ap) Arthur Ashe of Richmond, won the Caribe Hilton international tennis tournament for the third time today by defeating Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., 6-4, 6-3, 1-6, 6-3, in the final.

The average number of unemployed workers here increased by 0.5 per cent in 1969 after a period in which the average number of the jobless had been declining, according to a Bureau of Labor Statistics study.
WASHINGTON, April 5 A move to sidetrack the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court is expected to fail tomorrow in the Senate.

ROME, April 5 The dictates of human conscience are better guides to proper behavior than are the possibly mistaken declarations of a pope, a Roman Catholic theologian told a conference of 200 Italian moral theologians, who applauded his statement.

With one of their most important and strongest victories in their loss-strewn 44-year career, the Rangers wedged their way last night into the Stanley Cup playoffs on the final day of the tightest race in National Hockey League history.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 15 Miss Joanne Gaffney, a 1969 graduate of the Cornell University School of Nursing and a former student at Marymount College here, was married at noon today to Robert Sanford Bennet, who is in his final year at the Cornell Medical College.

Clifford Odets's "Awake and Sing," which was first produced on Broadway in 1935, will be revivied off Broadway at the end of May at the Twin Arts Theater on West 38th Street between 8th and 9th Avenues. Previews will begin May 11.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5 H. Ross Perot, the Texas millionaire, returned to Vientiane today in a Boeing 707 jetliner, full of journalists, to continue his campaign to induce the North Vietnamese to improve the treatment of United States prisoners of war.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 5 Preparations were under way here tonight for the nation's third manned flight to the moon Apollo 13 and there were already signs that the six-day countdown that began tonight would be a hectic time of grappling with technical gremlins.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 5 The Soviet Union has won the match here that pitted its 10 top players against leading players from the rest of the world. The score, after completion today of the final adjourned games in the fourth round, was 20 to 19 .

THEY cringe at the thought of having the title Reverend tacked before their names. They wear miniskirts, march in protest parades, and work in the ghettos. If somebody says "God is Dead" to them, they're apt to argue for hours.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., April 5 A small Russian Orthodox Church tucked away in the woods near Hempstead Harbor was the scene this morning of services by two groups battling for possession of the building.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP) Twenty-seven persons were treated at a hospital today after eating potato chips apparently laced with a hallucinogenic drug at a "swinging singles" party, sheriff's deputies said.

BALTIMORE, April 5 Thanks to Gus Johnson and Earl Monroe, who scored 40 of their 60 points in the second half, the Baltimore Bullets defeated the New York Knickerbockers today, 96-87, and reduced their first-round National Basketball Association playoff series to a single game to be played at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

ISAMU NOGUCHI, the sculptor who, on the side, has designed playgrounds, stage sets, costumes, gardens, furniture and fountains the ones for Expo '70 have won more acclaim from critics than anything else at the fair in Osaka has a special feeling toward his lanterns. (Most people call them lamps, but he prefers lanterns.)
BELFAST, Northern, Ireland, April 5 (AP) The outlawed Irish Republican Army threatened today to shoot a British soldier if a civilian was killed by security forces in Northern Ireland.

ATLANTA, April 5 (UPI) The Atlanta Hawks choked off a last-period rally by Chicago today to defeat the Bulls, 113107, and advance to the National Basketball Association's Western Division finals. Atlanta took the semifinal series, 4-1.

WASHINGTON, April 5 A random, unprogramed notion flashed through my mind at "Explorations," the new art-technology show at the Smithsonian Institution's National Collection of Fine Arts. It was this: that 50 years from now some of today's zappy, technologically oriented art may seem as hackneyed as Rosa Bonheur's 19th-century salon piece, "The Horse-Fair."
ST. LOUIS, April 5 A Federal grand jury will begin here Tuesday an investigation that could have far-reaching effects on campus demonstrators everywhere.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., April 4 (AP) The Bell Aerospace Division of Textron, Inc., is planning to manufacture a twin-engined, self-propelled aircushion vehicle in Canada.

The Ronson Corporation had a loss of about $1.77-million in last year's fourth quarter, figures issued yesterday by the company indicate. Ronson said the quarter showed a loss of 46 cents a share as a result of special charges of $3-million. On the basis of 3.86 million shares outstanding, this would amount to $1.77-million. Sales rose in the quarter to $27.13million from $24.89-million.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, April 1 A few days ago, at a news conference here, a Pakistani reporter asked President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan to respond to the criticism that since he had already decided so much, there was virtually nothing for the National Assembly to decide when it meets in October to draft a constitution.
The corporate bond market, encouraged by its ability to work its way through three consecutive weeks of exceptionally heavy financing activity, is optimistic it can handle a fourth.
General Motors Corporation has announced that George Russell, vice charman and chairman of its finance committee, has retired after more than 42 years with the automobile maker.
A small incendiary device was found yesterday in the West Side Branch of the Young Women's Christian Association at 840 Eighth Avenue, at 50th Street, a residence club for 250 women.
WARSAW, April 5 (AP) Jerry Pawlowski of Poland, an Olympic gold medalist, won an international saber match today, defeating Victor Sidiak of the Soviet Union, the world champion.

Jack Zanger, a free-lance sports writer and author, died at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx yesterday following surgery for a brain tumor. Mr. Zanger, who was 43 years old, lived at 470 West End Avenue.

HARTFORD, April 5 What do you do if your charity isn't as glamorous, chic and social as others? In this 335year-old city, intersected by the Connecticut River, you take over the 19th-century Union railroad station, redec orate it with a Victorian atmosphere and get some instant glamour of your own.

Fresh from his triumph at last month's Old Time Fiddlers Convention at Union Grove, N.C., where he was proclaimed "World's Champion Banjo Player," Roger Sprung gave a lively and informal concert yesterday afternoon at the McBurney Young Men's Christian Association, 215 West 23d Street.

LOS ANGELES, April 5 (UPI) Glenn Combs hit four free throws and a field goal late in the fourth period to give the Dallas Chaparrals a 131-127 victory over the Los Angeles Stars in the American Basketball Association today.

WASHINGTON, April 5 Days before the official announcement, one of the first copies of the Nixon Administration's statement turning down Israel's request for more jet fighters was delivered to Max M. Fisher, the Detroit industrialist.
BENIN, Nigeria, April 4 The postwar reconstruction of eastern Nigeria has brought new life to this ancient city in Midwestern State.
The New York and Philadelphia Lacrosse Clubs toppled foes from Baltimore yesterday.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 5 (AP) The world champion New York Mets scored two unearned runs in the ninth inning on a throwing error by Leo Cardenas, shortstop, to defeat the Minnesota Twins, 4-2, today.

LONDON According to the British Government, wage increases in this country should be no more than 2.5 to 4.5 per cent in the year 1970. That is the officially declared "norm." In fact, as opposed to theory, wages in Britain are now rising at a rate of about 12.5 per cent a year.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 5 (UPI) Jerry West and Wilt Chamberlain each scored 36 points as the Los Angeles Lakers trounced the Phoenix Suns, 138-121, and cut the Suns' lead to 3-2 in the National Basketball Association's Western Division playoffs tonight. The next game is at Phoenix Tuesday night.

LOS BANOS, the Philippines The new strains of rice, wheat and corn that are producing the so-called green revolution in Asia, holding out a promise of plenty for underfed millions, are beginning to stir objections.
BARRIO PANSOL PILA, Philippines Lucio Matienzo, a rice farmer with less than five acres of wet paddy fields, has six children and is able to send all of them to school.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 5 (UPI) Jerry West and Wilt Chamberlain each scored 36 points as the Los Angeles Lakers trounced the Phoenix Suns, 138-121, and cut the Suns' lead to 3-2 in the National Basketball Association's Western Division playoffs tonight. The next game is at Phoenix Tuesday night.

BARRIO PANSOL PILA, Philippines Lucio Matienzo, a rice farmer with less than five acres of wet paddy fields, has six children and is able to send all of them to school.

Nearly three out of five of the students attending four-year colleges and universities in New York State this year are going to private institutions, according to the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities.

New York State's Liberal and Conservative parties have scored gains in enrolling voters while the Democratic and Republican parties have slipped back in statewide tallies made public by Secretary of State John F. Lomenzo.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 5 Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida ordered pupils in Manatee County today to ignore an integration plan approved last week by the Supreme Court and personally assumed control of the county's school system.
PARIS, April 5 President Pompidou advised French farmers today to advertise their products better.
GUATEMALA, April 5 The body of the West German Ambassador, Count Karl von Spreti, was found by villagers in an abandoned hut on a dusty mountain road near the small town of San Raimundo this evening.

Following is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dual purpose investment companies as reported by the Committee of Dualpurpose Companies at the close of business Friday. Also shown are closing over-the-countar dealer-to-dealer asked prices on the New York Exchange for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount for premium) between the net asset value and the asked price of the capital.

Thomas Scherman's Little Orchestra was littler than usual for its concert last night in Alice Tully Hall. The reasons were entirely musical ones, for Mr. Scherman, with his customary enterprise, had unearthed four unusual works all requiring reduced orchestral forces.
President Nixon, Seattle, Denny McLain and Curt Flood will be among the missing when the baseball season opens today and tomorrow before crowds expected to total 330,000.

ABOUT 10 years ago, Judge Wilfred J. Paquet of the Massachusetts Superior Court sentenced two convicted bookies to 10 years in jail. Two weeks later he ordered them released and explained that he had decided the sentences were too sever.
SIHANOUKVILLE, Cambodia, April 2 The future of this small seaport, which Prince Norodom Silhanouk named after himself and tried to make into a Riviera-like resort, is not a cheerful one.
A mining company has begun to strip away the sea bottom in the Bahamas to extract a commercially valuable mineral in what could be by far the largest underwater mining operation in the world.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5 Curtis C. Cutter, the United States consul in Porto Alegre, thwarted a kidnapping attempt late last night, struck one of the attackers with his car, ran over him and escaped in a burst of machine-gun fire.
MONTAUK, L.I., April 5 Members of the Nixon Administration displayed support this weekend for an unusual library project that was rebuffed by the Johnson Administration.
ALBANY, April 5 (AP) The New York State Department of Education reports that the cost of building public schools in New York dropped slightly for the six months from September, 1969, to March, 1970.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 5 Lumber prices, depressed for almost a year, have started to firm and probably will be steeply higher by the end of this year.

ROCHESTER, April 5 New York Republicans began gathering here today for a twoday meeting that is expected to designate Governor Rockefeller and Senator Charles E. Goodell to head the party's 1970 state ticket.

LEONIA, N.J., April 5 Miss Nan Barbara Marcus, daughter of Percy Marcus of Englewood Cliffs and the late Mrs. Rose Fox Marcus, was married here this noon to Michael Jay Blecker, son of Mrs. Benjamin Blecker of Bayonne and the late Mr. Blecker. Rabbi Zelick Block performed the ceremony at Congregation Sons of Israel.

ATHENS, April 5 The special military tribunal in Athens, which is trying 34 Greek intellectuals on charges of sedition and of setting off bombs, tacitly accepted pleas today by six of the defendants that their confessions to the police be disregarded as untruthful.

WASHINGTON, April 5 President Nixon has assembled, with the aid of his political strategists, a slate of Republican Senatorial candidates that is expected to make an aggressive race against the Democrats this fall.

About $1-million will be spent to repair and reinforce the deteriorated structural steel of the elevated portion of the West Side Highway over the Penn Central's freight yards between 59th and 72d Streets, according to Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, the city's Transportation Administrator and Arterial Highway Coordinator.
PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (UPI) The Ecuadorian consul in Philadelphia was held on charges of smuggling narcotics today after his embassy refused to post his bail.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) Motorola, Inc., closed today its only color-television-tube plant and announced a two-week shutdown of five color-television assembly plants in Illinois because of a drop in sales of color television sets in the last year.

WHAT D. Keith Mano has been up to in his first three books is nothing less than an attempt to pump fresh plasma into the Christian novel. It's as though, on the death of Flannery 0'Connor, someone had to pick up the burning cross and carry it like a flashlight into the mysteries, the swamps of faith.

YONKERS, April 6 George Wampetich was whistling a happy tune as he worked at Yonkers Raceway this morning. The Hungarian-born trainer of standardbreds had good reason to be in such good humor, because the word from Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I., was that Good Chase, the New Zealand pacer who was injured and did not finish the race last Friday night, was going to be all right.
CONCORD, N.H. A century ago when the New Hampshire Fish and Game Commission was formed, its first major assignment was to bring the Atlantic salmon back to the Connecticut River.

TOKYO, April 6 (UPI) Official broadcasts from North Korea today described the nine Japanese youths who hijacked an airliner to Pyongyang last week as "strangers who came uninvited" and said "our officials concerned will take appropriate steps after necessary investigation."

A 24-pound cache of pure heroin, which police estimated would have brought a total of $6:9-million in street sales, was seized yesterday in a Bronx apartment whose occupant was accused of being a courier.

The Knicks will begin their playoff series with the Milwaukee Bucks at 2 P.M. Saturday at Madison Square Garden, with the basketball court laid over the ice to be used for hockey that night and Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 Robert Townsend urges business executives to telephone themselves occasionally. "When you're off on a business trip or a vacation, pretend you're a customer," he suggests. "Telephone some part of your organization and ask for help. You'll run into some real horror shows."
Prices moved steadily downward on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in the lightest trading day in two weeks.

When Ernest Hemingway began his apprenticeship on The Kansas City Star on Oct. 1, 1917, the 18-year-old cub reporter was handed a style sheet with four basic rules: "Use short sentences. Use short first paragraphs. Use vigorous English. Be positive, not negative."

Responding to sharp criticism from political and community opponents, State Senator Waldaba H. Stewart proposed yesterday a series of amendments to his Atlantic Avenue Development Authority bill, limiting the scope of the controversial renewal project in central and downtown BrooKlyn.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 6 H. Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire who is trying to get better treatment for American prisoners held by Hanoi, staged a seven-and-a-half-hour sit-in near the North Vietnamese Embassy here today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) President Nixon made a belated appearance at the ballpark today, but his rooting could not prevent the Washington Senators from losing to the Detroit Tigers, 5 0, for their eighth opening-day defeat in a row.

NEW YORK contingent of 100 players came home empty handed from the American Bridge Association's Spring National Championships in Cincinnati. The association, a primarily Negro body, ended its tournament Sunday at the Sheraton-Gibson Hotel, and almost all the major titles went to Ohio players.
Glamour stocks the favorites of last year's bear market were battered again yesterday while blue-chip issues continued relatively firm.

Thirteen members of the Rockaway Park chapter of the American Jewish Congress have charged "deliberate decesption" by Western Union in the handling of telegrams they sent to their Assemblyman in Albany on the abortion reform bill.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) A suit charging the National Archives in Washington with suppressing documents concerning an alleged plot to assassinate President Kennedy in Chicago was filed today in Federal District Court.
LIVINGSTON, N.J., April 6 Dr. Milton Neibrief, a surgeon, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived at 315 West End Road, South Orange.

The New York Knickerbockers, Who electrified their public and broke open the National Basketball Association race with an 18-game winning streak last fall, turned on their fullblended power again last night in beating the Baltimore Bullets, 127-114. They thus cleared the first of three giant hurdles on the path to the league championship.
The courts in the metropolitan area, as nearly everyone connected with them readily admits, are overcrowded, understaffed and months behind in their work.

WHEN Emilio Pucci decided to introduce a collec tion of clothes for men, he had fewer problems than most designers. He merely put into mass production the styles he had been creating for himself for years.
The publisher of Good Housekeeping, who has had a thing or two to say recently about advertising rate cutting, has gone further into the subject as a result of last Friday's column.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 6 Lucy Talcott, one of the first archeologists associated with the excavations of the Athenian Agora, died of cancer today in Princeton Hospital. She was 71 years old and lived at 27 Haslet Avenue here.

WASHINGTON, April 6 A colleague of G. Harrold Carswell on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit said today that he had conducted a telephone campaign among Federal district udges in the South that resulted in their endorsement of President Nixon's nominee to the Supreme Court.

Meade H. Esposito, Brooklyn Democratic leader, has been subpoenaed by the Joint Legislative on Crime for questioning about his relations with Anthony J. Scotto, vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association.
BALTIMORE, April 6 (UPI) Don McCafferty, a soft-spoken and popular assistant coach, was named head coach of the Baltimore Colts today by Carroll Rosenbloom, the club owner.
Peter C.R. Huang, vice president and director of corporate development at the City Investing Company, has been elected to the board of the Home Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, April 6 The Government won a major round today in its efforts to end the 13-day-old walkout by Federal air traffic controllers after a day of bitter courtroom jousting between F. Lee Bailey, the criminal lawyer from Boston, and Carl Eardley, a softspoken Deputy Assistant Attorney General.

The Conservative party is expected to nominate Dr. Paul L. Adams, its candidate for Governor in 1966, and James L. Buckley, its candidate for United States Senator in 1968, for those same offices when its State Committee meets tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) Wholesale prices increased two-tenths of 1 per cent in March, or twice the amount indicated by preliminary figures released two weeks ago. Despite the higher-than-expected increase, it was still the smallest gain since September.

The current "sick" walkout by members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization has placed a strain on fellow PATCO workers who have stayed on the job, in the opinion of two New York area controllers. But it is a strain on loyalties rather than job pressure.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6 A student protest movement is rapidly gathering momentum in South Vietnam despite Government efforts to stifle it.

JERUSALEM, April 6 The Israeli Government came under sharp internal attack today for rejecting a reported proposal for a meeting between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress.
State Senator William E. Adams was praised as a reputable official and assailed as corrupt during the summations of his trial yesterday in Federal Court.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 6 Prince Norodom Sihanouk is a difficult act to follow, but the leaders who deposed him as Chief of State are still holding the stage three weeks later.

ORLEANS, France, April 6-The suspense grew along with the daylight early this morning as hundreds of French boys and girls stood or sat or lounged on the floor of the littered Palace of Sports in Orleans. They were waiting for a youth named Jean-Pierre Chassine.
Twelve colleges and universities have agreed to participate in the National Theater Institute, established last December by the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.
The New York Mets the only team in major league baseball that has never won an opening game will open their title defense this afternoon in Pittsburgh against the Pirates.
NEW HAVEN, April 6 A gift of $500,000 to Yale University by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Cullman of New York and Stamford, Conn., was announced today by Kingman Brewster Jr., president of the university.
CINCINNATI, April 6 (AP) Maurice Stokes, the former basketball star with the Cincinnati Royals, died today after suffering a heart attack March 30. He was 36 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6 Four enemy ground assaults were reported by allied spokesmen in the last 36 hours. In addition, 41 enemy shelling attacks were reported for the 24-hour period ending at 8 A.M.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 6 (AP) Editors and publishers belonging to the Inter-American Press Association were told today that freedom of press in the Western Hemisphere "is at the lowest ebb since World War II."
Almost 100 colleges, Vassar and Wellesley included, have a crew program and the number climbs each year. The oldest of the intercollegiate sports apparently has never been more popular.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 6 (AP) The Maki brothers, Bob and Don, of Ishpeming, Mich., rolled their way into second place of the regular doubles standings of the American Bowling Congress tournament today by registering 1,310 pins.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 6 (AP) The Providence Worcester Railroad announced today it wants to separate itself from the Penn Central and become an independent shortline railroad.
Public television station and program managers from around the country will meet here from tomorrow through Friday for the 1970 Public Television Conference.

WASHINGTON, April 6 The Nixon Administration said today that it was ready to cooperate with the United States District Court in Florida in enforcing a school desegregation order that Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. has defied.

The Society of the Silurians, an organization of veteran newspapermen, honored Turner Catledge of The New York Times at its annual awards dinner in the Americana Hotel last night. Mr. Catledge, who served for nearly two decades as the chief news executive of the newspaper, is retiring on April 30.

ROCHESTER, April 6 With portraits of Governor Rockefeller smiling from almost every wall, the Republican State Committee met today to begin the quiet process of nominating him for re-election and designating a statewide ticket he has chosen.

Just as Wall Street began believing that the bear market had finally ended, a wave of selling shifted into the so-called glamour stocks, those issues that somehow had been able to maintain super price-earnings ratios in the face of adversity elsewhere in the market.
WASHINGTON, April 6 A visitor from Texas was served breakfast in the White House today and then got a guided tour of the working space used by President Nixon.
To passing motorists on the East River Drive, the new 22-story Bellevue Hospital building at 26th Street and the drive, appears almost ready for its first patients tients.

THE auburn hair is gamine chic, the comlexion girl ishly flushed, the petite, 41year-old figure trimly packaged in a brown knit turtleneck dress. There is no despair in th epale blue eyes. Only the accent that marks her torrent of fluent English betrays her national origin.
I'M not sure that I can reasonably explain the pleas ure I take in Marguerite Duras's "Destroy, She Said," much of which I find unendurable, but an explanation on some level is worth trying.
Steel production declined in the week ended Saturday by 0.9 per cent, compared to output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Disturbed by what he termed a violent reaction to the final, improbable day of the National Hockey League season, Clarence Campbell, the president, said yesterday he was "making inquiries" into the actions and words of Coach Sid Abel, whose Detroit club was trounced by the Rangers.

The engagement of Miss Selina (Tina) Schroeder Croll to Albert Constantine Bellas has been announced by her parents, Joseph D. Croll and Mrs. William C. Breed Jr., both of New York. Mr. Bellas is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine M. Bellas of Steubenville, Ohio, where his father is president of the Bellas Company, wine importers. Mr. Croll is a limited partner of Asiel Co., stockbrokers here.
Dave DeBusschere's neighbor in Garden City, L.I., saw the rugged New York Knickerbocker forward take his year-old daughter, Michelle, out for a walk yesterday afternoon.
Supporters of the Judson Health Center will pretend they are sipping cocktails in Hong Kong at their cocktail dance and buffet dinner April 22 in the Pierre's Cotillion Room.

Gil McDonald's debut as Fordham baseball coach, which was delayed for over a week, was not a glamorous one yesterday. The former Yankee took the Rams to Jamaica for their opener and got a chilly reception and an 8-1 setback by St. John's.

A bench warrant was issued here yesterday for the arrest of Mark Rudd, a leader of the Weatherman faction of Students for a Democratic Society, when he failed to show up for a Criminal Court trial but his $2,500 bail was freed for return to his father.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the leading producer of American primary copper, raised its basic price by 4 cents a pound yesterday, and thus removed any doubts that the 7 per cent increase imposed last week by competitors would stick.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 6 (AP) Scores of disabled war veterans battled policemen with stones, bottles, clubs and hammers today near South Vietnam's Presidential Palace.

Sidney Hall, a former assistant to Coy Smith, a Human Resources Administration official, pleaded guilty yesterday to four counts of an eight-count indictment before State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh.

Rank Xerox, Ltd., in its report issued yesterday for the 28 weeks ended Jan. 10, showed a 37 per cent increase in earnings on a gain of 29 per cent in operating revenues, both set ting new records for the period.

WASHINGTON, April 6 The Ford Foundation recently made grants totaling $1 million for studies of the public's confidence in the American judicial process. Such confidence, McGeorge Bundy, the foundation's president, described as "essential to the maintenance of both liberty and order in a democratic society."

The season ended last night for Wes Unseld with 24 seconds of play remaining in the game. The Baltimore Center, who had averaged 11.8 points in the previous six playoff games and at times intimidated Willis Reed, the Knick center, fouled out of the game.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., April 6 A grand jury of 10 men and 10 women, sternly enjoined to secrecy, opened today an investigation of the death of Mary Jo Kopechne. The jury began calling witnesses this afternoon.
CHICAGO, April 6 Scheduled and unscheduled happenings enlivened the first session of the National Association of Broadcasters convention here today.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., April 6 (AP) The Army said today it had advised Capt. Jeffrey R MacDonald that he would be questioned as a suspect in the slaying of his wife and two young daughters.
Theodore W. Kheel, mediator in the city newspaper dispute, warned yesterday of a possible newspaper shutdown unless the impasse was resolved by the weekend.
LAGOS, Nigeria, April 6 (Reuters) The Anglo-Dutch oil enterprise Shell-BP today announced a 66-million ($160million) expansion of its oil operations in Nigeria.
The election of Richard C. Gerstenberg as vice chairman of the board and chairman of the finance committee was announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation.

Two members of a gang of five men who allegedly robbed five banks of more than $120,000 in Harlem and the South Bronx last year were sentenced to 10-year and 15-year prison terms in Federal Court yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6 Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, who was convicted in a controversial trial of the slaying of his first wife and then acquitted after nearly 10 years in prison, died here early this morning. He was 46 years old.
The S.S. Kresge Company, one of the country's largest retail chains, and three other chains reported substantial gains in sales for March over the same month a year ago.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 Gary Player, the favorite to win the Masters tournament that begins here Thursday, believes some of the "romance" has been taken out of the Augusta National Golf Club course, site of the annual event.

One of the first men to walk on the moon paid tribute yesterday to Matthew A. Henson, the Negro explorer, who, in Admiral Robert E. Peary's expedition, was one of the first men to set foot on the North Pole on April 6, 1909.

The rash of political kidnappings that over the weekend brought death to the West German Ambassador in Guatemala and injury to an American diplomat in Brazil reflects, like the recent epidemic of aerial hijacking, a reversion to the conditions of banditry that infected and inhibited international life and travel in centuries past.
The bond market started to falter yesterday. Prices declined and new issues of corporate and tax-exempt bonds failed to attract investors.

HONG KONG Unless you've wired or phoned or written or telegraphed in advance, one of the hardest things to come by at certain times of the year in Hong Kong outside of an invitation to visit mainland China is a room at that monument across the harbor in Kowloon, the world-esteemed Peninsula Hotel.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 6 The creation of a post of ombudsman at Princeton University was recommended today by a special committee of faculty members and students who have been considering reforms in the university's structure for nearly two years.

The Church Street Dance Company of Washington, which performed last night at the Cubiculo, is not so much a conventional modern-dance group as an apparent commune. It is a refreshingly different troupe marked by a flower-power togetherness, expressed both in the themes of its dances and in the obvious friendship that governs the relationships of the dancers 20 one another as people.

Several hundred representatives of ethnic-minority business enterprises were given an opportunity yesterday to question Government officials about the problems of obtaining Federal contracts for goods and services.
"Our liberty," said Thomas Jefferson, "depends on the freedom of the press, and that cannot be limited without being lost."

DALLAS, April 6 (UPI) The Management of Intercontinental Industries, Inc., said today it was surprised and disappointed at news that the Securities and Exchange Commission had approved delisting of the company's shares by the American Stock Exchange.
ROVANIEMI, Finland, April 6 (AP) Rosee Fortna of Warren, Vt., won her second event at the World University Games today by capturing the women's giant slalom at Phyaetunturi.

PARIS, April 6 The distribution of the weekly magazine L'Express was delayed today by official objections to a page of advertising that made President Pompidou appear to be endorsing an outboard motor.

Truck drivers across the country stepped up picketing and wildcat strike activity yesterday. In Chicago, an official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters suggested that selective strikes might be used to avert a total walkout.
Mayor Lindsay asked the Legislature yesterday to take housing code violations out of the jammed Criminal Courts and allow city housing officials to levy fines in such cases.
WASHINGTON, April 6 A Senate committee took the first steps today toward speedy enactment of a retroactive pay increase for all Government employes.

THE PRESIDENT Volunteers. The President named Henry Ford 2d to be chairman of the board of the National Center for Voluntary Action. Mr. Ford, 52 year old, has been a director of the Ford Motor Company since 1938.
LOS ANGELES, April 6 (UPI) Potato chips and corn chips that sent 27 persons on hallucinogenic trips during a weekend singles party were individually laced with LSD, the sheriff's office said today.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 6 Allegations that the Uruguayan police regularly torture political prisoners have prompted a Congressional investigation and set off a Government scandal here.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 6 Measles posed a slight threat tonight to plans for launching the Apollo 13 moon mission this Saturday.

TALLAHASSEE, April 6 Torrential rains in Florida's Salad Bowl farm region have damaged crops severely and caused concern for thousands of migrant laborers whose livelihood depends on harvesting spring vegetables.

Cocoa futures rose yesterday, following the issuance on Friday of a "guesstimate" by a leading dealer that first-quarter grinding results in the United States would show a decline of about 5 per cent compared with the 1969 quarter.

RYE, N.Y., April 6 Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Thayer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Warren Thayer, to Michael John Candela Jr., son of Mrs. Joseph Nickerson of Westwood, Mass., and the late Mr. Candela.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, April 6 (UPI) Tom Koch beat Jaime Fillol today in the final singles, 6-I, 6-3, 4-6, 4-6, 8-6, to give Brazil a 3-2 victory over Chile in the South American Davis Cup tennis semifinal.
Patrick J. Douris, chief property man at Radio City Music Hall since 1941, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 310 West 55th Street.

The president of Hunter College, Mrs. Jacqueline Grennan wexler, agreed yesterday to establish a temporary congress, half student and half faculty, to propose a new governing structure for the school. The proposal would be submitted to a college referendum.

WASHINGTON, April 6 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he "would like to see" the termination of interest rate ceilings on bank deposits, "at least as far as instruments of the money-market type are concerned."

PARIS, April 6 French diplomats have been active in a number of capitals to advance the proposal by France last Wednesday for general peace negotiations involving all the countries concerned with Indochina.

THERE are so many people who will tell you that Bernard Shaw's "Candida" is a masterpiece, whereas I regard it merely as a moderately successful but sadly dated play, that clearly I begin at a disadvantage in considering the merits of its revival, which opened last night at the Longacre Theater. It starred Celeste Holm, incidentally, but not very brightly.

CHIPHOU, Cambodia, April 6 Two Japanese television newsmen were captured by the Vietcong well inside Cambodia today during the Governmentsponsored tour to show to foreign correspondends the extent of Vietnamese Communist penetration into this country.

Earnings reports from the nation's largest banks started to come in yesterday, showing higher net incomes for the first quarter, but markedly lower profit margins because of soaring interest payments.
Jule M. Sugarman was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday as the next head of the Human Resources Administration, the city's largest superagency.

Duck Dance of the Hobeau Farm contributed the most impessive performance on the program at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in a sprint that preceded the main event, Duck Dance sped to a six-length triumph under the guidance of Johnny Ruane.

WHITE PLAINS, April 6 A father and son accused of setting up "Las Vegas Nights" in Westchester country clubs ostensibly to raise money for charity, were arraigned today on charges of promoting gambling and possession of gambling devices.
Sixty-three retired members o+f the police force, ranging from sergeant to inspector, returned to duty yesterday to take advantage of an opportunity to earn higher pensions.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 1 today that a man acquitted once may not be tried a second time on what is essentially the same evidence.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he was undecided whether to continue Robert M. Morgenthau's office of Deputy Mayor during the absence of Mr. Morgenthau, who took a leave of absence to campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
TORONTO, April 6 (Canadian Press) The Ontario government today ordered the suspension of all commercial and sports fishing in the Detroit River, Lake St. Clair, St. Clair River and the ...

BRADENTON, Fla., April 6 The 17,000 public school students in Manatee County on Florida's west coast went to their old schools today as Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. declared himself to be the county's chief school official and refused to obey a Federal court's racial integration order.

There were more ticket-buyers than tickets at the Felt Forum yesterday as 2,000 seats for the Rangers' playoff games were sold in 40 minutes. In their wake, the mostly young crowd left broken police barricades, dirty blankets, transistor-radio batteries and brown paper bags stuffed with partly eaten sandwiches.
The newly formed RCA operation, which is expected to become a nationwide TV repair service, may not have a name yet, but it's got an ad agency Carl Ally, Inc.
Alfred Feinberg, an anatomical illustrator, died Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 87 years old and lived at 270 Riverside Drive.
WASHINGTON, April 6 The Committee for Economic Development expressed strong support today for the Nixon Administration's welfare reform plan, on which a House vote is expected this week.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 The written works and personal papers of Marianne Moore have been acquired by the Rosenbach Foundation.

The Jersey Central Power Light Company is proceeding with plans to file a claim against the General Electric Company for delays in completion of the Oyster Creek nuclear generating station. Jersey Central is an operating subsidiary of the General Public Utilities Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 6 The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 3, that it is not unconstitutional for states to set limits on the amount of welfare benefits that any family may, collect.

ST. LOUIS, April 6 Worried farmers from throughout the United States abandoned their traditional stubborn independence today and joined hands in an effort to improve the deteriorating lot of agriculture.
The firsst imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG) into the metropolitan New York area were completed last week at Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation's storage terminal on Staten Island.

PASADENA, Calif., April 6 Dr. Alfred Henry Sturtevant, a major figure in American genetics for many years, and a former professor of genetics at the California Institute of Technology, died of cancer at a hospital here last night. He lived here and was 78 years old.

There is a fair-sized communications gap between New York and Albany, and it isn't going to be helped by the bill that would create an Atlantic Avenue Development Authority. This legislative sleeper, which breezed through the Senate and is due for consideration by the Assembly tomorrow, came as an unwelcome, surprise to city officials, planners and local communities.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 6 The Nassau Democratic County convention met at the Garden City Hotel tonight to nominate candidates for Congress and the Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 Tht investment committee of the University of Pennsylvania unanimously voted today to support the consumer-oriented proposals of the Washingtonbased project for Corporate Responsibility.
SAUGUS, Calif., April 6 Two gunmen killed four highway patrolmen in a gun battle outside a mountain cafe near here late last night.
A note of guarded optimism for the future of the arts in the United States was sounded here yesterday by the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and by two Congressmen.

IT was blue Monday with a vengeance for the little guy on Wall Street yesterday. The New transaction charge went into effect amid mountains of confusion. And, meanwhile, Burnham Co. announced that it would begin charging customers $50 every six months they didn't do enough business to generate that much in fees for Burnham.
Jack L. Kroner, a professor of labor law at New York University, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 110 Bleeker Street. He was 44 years old.
WASHINGTON April 6 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 Two Philadelphia policemen were arraigned today on charges of aggravated assault and battery in a growing controversy over alleged police brutality.

physicians at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn were accused yesterday of having improperly collected more than $750,000 for Medicare patients treated in one year at Kings County Hospital.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 6 President Joaquin Balaguer today closed all urban public schools for two months to reduce student agitation against his plans to run for re-election.

WASHINGTON, April 6 The Food and Drug Administration has licensed the muchdiscussed drug lithium carbonate for treatment of a common form of mental illness, the manic phase of manic-depressive psychosis.
WASHINGTON, April 6 Miss Doris Anne Swain, a member of the professional nursing staff of George Washington University, and Dr. Robert Francis Dyer Jr., an internist, plan to be married in June.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 Brewery signs still outnumber Brewers' signs in this beer producing city, but Schlitz and Miller High Life had to take second place to Dave Bristol and Lew Krausse today in satisfying the appetites of baseball thirsty fans.
Mayor Lindsay released a report yesterday saying that employes in the Fire, Sanitation, Correction and Police Departments were taking off more time for illness than in the past.

PITTSBURGH, April 6 (UPI) A young man who was upset because he thought he was being flown to Boston entered the cockpit of Trans World Airlines Flight 90 with a gun today, but was disarmed and the plane landed here without incident.

The Senate's defeat of the motion to recommit to the Judiciary Committee the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell clears the way for a final decision tomorrow on the fundamental question of Mr. Carswell's confirmation as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. On this basic issue each Senator has the obligation to vote not in accordance with party loyalty but in accordance with his own conscience.
United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. announced yesterday an "expanded program to crack down on white-collar criminals."
Another large Wall Street brokerage house has had to use red ink in writing its annual report for 1969.

WASHINGTON, April 6 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird is provoking a possible confrontation between the executive and legislative branches by declining to testify before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on expansion of the Safeguard missile defense system.

MOSCOW, April 6 The Soviet Government today confirmed reports that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin had been hospitalized with influenza and that President Nigolai V. Podgorny and two other members of the party's ruling Politburo were incapacitated because of illness.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today barred Hagen Investments, Inc., of Oklahoma City and its president, Ed J. Hagen, from engaging in the securities business. Mr. Hagen and his concern consented to a decree accusing them of selling unregistered stock.

Yoko Morishita, obviously a young woman to be reckoned with as one of the world's firstrate ballet dancers, made her local debut Sunday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall. If Miss Morishita, Yukiko Mushanokoji and Yuriko Kawaguchi, all of Tokyo's Asami Maki Ballet, are representative of their country's classic dancers, then the ballet counterpart of Japan's celebrated new breed of young virtuoso musicians already exists.

ONCE upon a time the opening of a baseball season was an event of transcendental importance in the world of sports. The long winter vigil was over and the single-minded hibernation of the fans was at an end. Such was the situation for a considerable part of professional baseball's first century, one that was completed with notable hoopla last year.

Eleven committees composed of 89 judges, lawyers and laymen met here for the first time yesterday to begin devising methods to "substantially improve" the overburdened and often malfunctioning courts of Manhattan and the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, April 6 Senate opponents of Judge G. Harrold Carswell's Supreme Court nomination failed today, by a 44-to-52 vote, to recommit the nomination to the Senate Judiciary Committee.
TUKTOYAKTUK, Northwest Territories Willy Felix, who is 19 years old, is a blocker in the Tuk Fur Garment factory.
TOKYO, April 6 (Reuters) Official Japanese sources said today the Japanese Government would soon relax the present restrictions on foreign portfolio investments in Japanese stocks.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 6 About 100 black students made a brief invasion of the new Cornell University Campus Store today, carrying off clothing, rock records and books as "payment" for the black studies center that burned down during the Easter recess last week.

The principal effect of the two-week-old disruption of air traffic by "sick" air controllers has been to make clear the insubstantiality of many of their grievances. The recent postal stoppage was just as illegal as the controllers' stayaway from their Federal jobs, but the mailmen did make the country aware of how shabbily the Administration and Congress had treated them on wages.

WASHINGTON, April 6 The Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare voted unanimously today to impose a new contract on 48,000 railroad shopcraft workers, rather than run the risk of a national rail shutdown next weekend.

The Boothe Computer Corporation and Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation announced yesterday that they have signed a letter calling for continuation of negotiations fog a possible merger or consolidation of the two computer leasing companies.

WASHINGTON, April 6 Gordon S. Macklin Jr., a general partner in the Cleveland brokerage firm of McDonald Co., has been named president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the association announced today.
About 800 Long Island Rail Road commuters were trapped for more than two hours yesterday morning when a train stalled in a tunnel under the East River.

PARIS, April 6 With its newly specialized product line and an intensified cost accounting program, Machines Bull, the French Company, has reported a profit for the first time since the stunning G.E. take-over in mid-1964.

They called Maurice Stokes "Mighty Mo" in college, but his efforts on the basketball court dimmed in comparison to the heroics he performed in hospital therapy rooms during a 12-years struggle to regain the use of his body.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 6 Arthur J. Blank, a lawyer, died at New Rochelle Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 991 Plymouth Street, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

AN affirmative statement of the national pleasures and rewards of an unpolluted and noncommercialized environment was made last night by Lester Cooper in his special TV film entitled "This Land Is Mine." The program was seen on the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

WHEN a group of United States Senators investi gating hunger in America flew unannounced to Immokalee, Fla., last year for a first-hand inspection of migrant squalor, they were greeted by a furious Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., April 6 Miss Noel Gignoux will be married here May 23 to David N. Spevacek of Washington, D.C.

A group of black and Puerto Rican teen-agers who had occupied the Harlem Y.W.C.A. for more than a month left quietly yesterday morning shortly before the sheriff arrived to arrest them on a contempt-of-court charge.
The London stock market closed lower yesterday after a brief opening rally.
No matter what the weather is like today, it was worse on that afternoon in December when Polly Ware bought her husband a brass bugle and a Baseball Encyclopedia for Christmas.
ISTAMBUL, Turkey, April 6 (Reuters) Students of the right and left fought with guns, knives and gasoline bombs on the campus of Istambul University today.

CINCINNATI, April 6 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds got what they've been looking for from Jim Merritt today as the 26year-old left-hander pitched 61/3 innings of no-hit ball before winding up with a threehit, 5-1 victory over Montreal in the National League opener.
