SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 6 A former, Army helicopter pilot charged today that an Army major killed 33 unarmed men, women and children as they ran across an open field in a 1967 incident in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) The Supreme Court today sustained the power of police to arrest street speakers who refuse orders to move on when crowds grow tense and hostile.

BONN, April 6 The West German Government, shocked and infuriated by the murder of Count Karl von Spreti, its ambassador in Guatemala, moved swiftly today to reduce to a bare minimum its diplomatic relations with Guatemala.
ROCHESTER, April 7 Getting a candidate from Buffalo was reported uppermost in Republican thinking here today as the party; in a quick switch, designated Edward V. Regan to run for State Controller.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Evidence that safety-related automobile repairs are often inadequately performed particularly when the cost is covered by new-car warranties has been developed in a study commissioned by the National Highway Safety Bureau.

As his face smiled from posters decorating almost every wall, Governor Rockefeller yesterday received the enthusiastic endorsement of delegates at the Republican state convention to run for a fourth term. He is now the official G.O.P. nominee. There will be no Republican primary to match the Democratic primary.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 The head of a three-man United Nations committee investigating Israeli practices affecting human rights in occupied Arab territories offered today to convene the committee in Cyprus to hear any Israeli or Arab under Israeli occupation who may be willing to testify.

MOSCOW, April 7 High Soviet officials suggested today that no city, including Los Angeles, was as historically, culturally and statistically prepared to be the site of the 1976 Olympic Games as Moscow.

WASHINGTON, April 7 A Federal district judge ruled today that the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization had violated a law forbidding strikes against the Federal Government and held the group in contempt of court.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 7 Miss Linda Susan Svirsky and Robert Dana Gordon will be married July 9 in New York.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 6 On the outskirts of Vientiane the signboard at the entrance to a spacious military compound of the old-fashioned, tree-shaded colonial type reads "Mission Militaire Francaise d'Instruction."

Representative Richard L. Ottinger, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator, announced his resignation yesterday from the American Bar Association because a committee of that organization endorsed Federal District Judge G. Harrold Carswell for the Supreme Court.

The Typographical union increased its economic pressure on The New York Times yesterday by extending chapel, or union, meetings and thus stopping production in the composing room for about four hours a shift.
ITHACA, April 7 Cornell University began judicial proceedings today against a group of black students who broke windows and stole items from the new university store.
Selected glamour issues came under renewed selling pressure yesterday, while the threat of a new policy of economic changes in Peru weakened prices of certain oil and copper stocks.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 Jack Nicklaus resumed practice today for the Masters Golf tournament and admitted recent changes to the course were advantageous to him.

Dr. Seligman B. Bamberger, who retired in 1961 as vice president of the Delaware Chemical Company in Tottenville, S.I., died in a hospital here Monday after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 251 West 98th Street.

John D. Rockefeller 3d is retiring from Lincoln Center, the cultural complex he was instrumental in creating. On May 11 he will be succeeded as chairman of the board by Amyas Ames, currently board chairman of the New York Philharmonic.
Nytronics, Inc., announced yesterday that it had increased its interest in Eastern Air Devices, Inc., to about 84 per cent of the outstanding shares by acquiring an additional 33.8 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The Department of Justice brought suit today against the use of Mississippi state funds to pay teachers in private segregated schools.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Two organizations long active in Southern civil rights activities asked President Nixon today to investigate the actions of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the death of a woman member of the Ku Klux Klan and the wounding of her male companion, also a Klansman, nearly two years ago.

MORE anguish than usual is mixed with the pre season hysteria on Seventh Avenue these days as fall collections take shape in design rooms. Most designers are as perplexed as the women who wear their clothes over the descent of the hemline. Should they make any short clothes? How can they make long ones look young and snappy?
LONDON, April 7 The British Hovercraft Corporation, developer of air-cushion vehicles, announced today that it would close one of its two plants and reduce its work force because of a lack of orders.
A strike by operators of telephone-answering services began here last midnight. oMre than 100,000 people were affected, about half of them physicans and nurses.
MILWAUKEE, April 7 Born out of bankruptcy after 4 years of gestation, the Brewers brought major league baseball back to Milwaukee today, but in name only.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 7 Carl Mueller, a painter and illustrator, died today at Courtland Gardens Convalescent Home after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived on illustrator, died today at Court Carl Mueller, a painter and Comstock Hill Road, Silvermine, and Greenfield Hill, Fairfield.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (Reuters) President Nixon will announce a decision this month on the next United States troop cut in Vietnam, the White House said today.

A joint board of governorsfaculty committee at the Fieldstone school has informed parents, alumni and students that severe sanctions, including possible expulsion, will be invoked in the event of further disruptions.
MINEOLA, L.I. April 7 Twenty youths, most of them high school students and one of them the son of a high school principal, were arrested today on drug charges.

THE comparison of scores by teammates following play in a head-to-head match often produces surprises, both pleasant and unpleasant. Perhaps the biggest surprise ever suffered by two players in these circumstances occurred on the diagramed deal played Sunday in the Connecticut Valley Sectional Championships at Chicopee, Mass.

LE TRETEAU DE PARIS, a producing organization that sponsors French productions abroad with French Government support, led off a month-long run at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater last night with "Le Grand Vizir" and "Le Cosmonaute Agricole," two one-act plays by Rend de Obaldia.

Mrs. John L. Pool of New York and Leonard A. Yerkes Jr. of Wilmington, Del., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Remsen Yerkes, to Robert Z. Bodan. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Casimir Bodan, also of Wilmington.
MASSENA, N.Y., April 7 (AP) Regular shipping began on the Saint Lawrence Seaway today.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 7 The Roman Catholic Church in Rhodesia protested today against newly enacted laws to increase the segregation of the races and indicated it might refuse to obey the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

PITTSBURGH, April 7 The magic that enabled the New York Mets to share top billing with the moon landings in 1969 survived the winter and enabled them today to achieve another first, the last unconquered horizon left for them:

ALEXANDRIA, Va., April 7 (AP) The wife of Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, and seven leaders of a "Mass for Peace" in the Pentagon were found guilty today of violating Federal regulations governing use of the building.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 7 The enemy's countryside upsurge on the battlefield appeared to be waning today after six days of intense fighting.

WASHINGTON, April 7(AP) Terry Bradshaw, pro-football's No. 1 draft choice, and two of his Louisiana Tech teammates met President Nixon at the White House today and presented him with an autographed ball.
The Conservative party's state committee nominated two of the party's best vote-getters yesterday for Governor and United States Senator.

Pretrial hearings for 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places here resumed yesterday and continued quietly all day, with consistently dignified behavior among defendants and spectators.
WASHINGTON, April 7 President Nixon announced today the appointment of Albert L. Williams of Armonk, N.Y., as chairman of the President's Commission on International Trade and Investment Policy.
TOKYO, April 7 Osahi Shimbun, one of Japan's leading newspapers, demonstrated today a home facsimile newspaper receiver it has developed for printing both sides of a sheet simultaneously.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 (AP) Gene Sarazen predicted today that tour caddies would be extinct in the near future in big-time tournament golf and would be replaced by boys driving golf carts who would merely service their professionals and not offer advice.
THE stage at City Center where Marcel Marceau began a three-week engagement last night is alive with fools, pretenders, losers, clowns. This is a one-man show only in the most literal sense.
WASHINGTON, April 7, (AP) The Senate passed 79 to 0 today a $6.2-billion bill to extend and expand the HillBurton hospital aid program. The measure goes far beyond President Nixon's recommendations.
WASHINGTON April 7 The Senate voted today to require the Treasury to offer a new type of savings bond bearing interest at 6 per cent.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 7 H. Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire, was again rebuffed by Communist representatives here today in his campaign to represent the interests of military prisoners in the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce paved the way today for a forced Government resolution of the 18-month-old dispute between the nation's railroads and their 48,000 shopcraft workers.

The Franklin New York Corporation, parent company of the $3-billion Franklin National Bank, reported yesterday that its net income declined 2 Per cent in the first quarter to $4.79-million from $4.9-million last year.
A ballot asking New York City's 24,100 policemen whether they will support a job action involving an 80 per cent reduction in police service is to be mailed today.

WASHINGTON, April 7(AP) Acting quickly in the aftermath of the first postal strike in history, a Senate committee approved unanimously today a bill to give all civilian and military Federal workers a 6 per cent pay increase.
WASHIGTON, April 7 (UPI) The Population Reference Bureau guessed today that the 1970 Census would show 205.5 million Americans, plus "at least" 5 million more persons who were "lost" 10 years ago.
Silver futures prices on the New York Commodity Exchange here fell yesterday, in line with slightly lower prices obtained at the Government's silver auction in Washington.

JERUSALEM, April 7 The Israeli Government said in the Knesset, or parliament, tonight that it had rejected Dr. Nahum Goldmann's effort to meet President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic because Dr. Goldmann was an "unsuitable emissary" for such a role.

The first United States-only Stanley Cup playoffs open tonight on four fronts, while fans continue to shake their heads in bewilderment over the most bizarre finish in the National Hockey League's 53-year history.

The Dana Chapel at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mrs. Diana (Didi) Lippert Auchincloss to Francis Alexander Shields, an account executive with the investment banking house of Loeb, Rhoades Co.
Rector Bailey, a musician who taught and played numerous instruments, died of cancer Saturday at Flatbush General Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 57 years old and lived at 813 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

OTTAWA, April 7 (AP) The Canadian Government was asked today whether it had agreed to a United States shipment through Juan de Fuca Strait off Vancouver Island of nerve gas bound from Okinawa to Oregon.

In these days of labor turmoil, it is a minor miracle that railroad shopcraft employes have stayed on the job through the 37 days of wage frustration decreed for them by Congress. The legislated truce expires Saturday, and it would be reckless for Congress to push its luck by letting the new deadline pass without definitive settlement of a dispute that has been on a sputtering fuse for a full year.
Price increases continued yesterday for primary copper and the copper content of a variety of fabricated products.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The Senate appeared almost evenly divided today on the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court, with the final vote on confirmation set for 1 P.M. tomorrow.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 5 The Venezuelan economy, the strongest in Latin America, is preparing to go into orbit again following a year that witnessed the peaceful change in Administration and the attendant business caution.
Robert Montgomery, the film and television star and one-time television consultant to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, has resigned as president of the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center.

Eli Lilly Co., a major ethical drug maker also in the agricultural and packaging products field, again, posted the first quarter this year, it was reported yesterday from the company's Indianapolis headquarters.

A controversy has flared at New York University over Dr. Ivan L. Bennett Jr., dean of the Medical School, with some faculty members demanding his ouster for past research on biological and chemical warfare.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The West German Defense Minister, Helmut Schmidt, opened conferences with Senior United States officials today on the future of American military commitments in Europe
PYHAETUNTURI, Finland, April 7(AP) Eric Poulsen of Olympic Valley, Calif., clinched the combined Alpine skiing title at the World University Games today by finishing second in the special slalom.

All National Guard members called to duty for one or more days during the recent postal work stoppage are eligible for a number of veterans' benefits to which they would not otherwise have been entitled.

The current series of Dodge commercials, whose Southern sheriff star has already gained national Prominence, are well on their way to becoming a mini-"Peyton Place," at least to the folks in Bristol, Tenn.

AMISTAD, a new biannual paperback periodical, takes its name from both the Spanish word for friendship and the name of a ship on which a successful slave mutiny occurred in 1839. Judging from the first issue of Amistad, the paradox in the title is fitting. Subtitled "Writings on Black History and Culture" and intended to provide regular supplementary reading to black-studies college courses, Amistad comes in peace and shuns the rhetoric of violence (so far).

TOKYO, April 7 The state visit of the Chinese Communist Premier Chou En-lai, to North Korea, which began Sunday and ended today, is being viewed hre by analysts of Communist affairs as an index of North Korea's success in putting its relations with Peking back onto a normal basis.
The London stock market closed mixed yesterday as some late selctive buying partly offset an extended decline.

WASHINGTON, April 7 With all the fervor of an oldtime evangelist, Representative Wilbur D. Mills told today of his "personal conversion" to the Administration's modified guaranteed annual income plan for the nation's poor.
WASHINGTON, April 7(AP) Del Unser batted in four runs with a bad-hop single and a triple and Mike Epstein and Lee Maye hit homers as the Washington Senators routed the Detroit Tigers tonight, 14-4.

Miss Hedy Apte Cohn of Rio de Janeiro was married here yesterday to Claude E. Erbsen of London and New York, business manager and administrative director of the AP-Dow Jones Economic Report with headquarters in London, where the couple plan to live.

A coalition of black political and social activists demanded yesterday that President Nixon authorize a "fact-finding team composed of our elected officials and a local community resident" to investigate the imprisonment in Vietnam of a black soldier accused of assault and resisting arrest.
WASHINGTON, April 7 Mortgage prices rose again at this week's auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the association reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 Peter T. Sinclair, chairman of the board of Crown Zellerbach Corporation, died early today at Mount Zion Hospital, of a kidney ailment. He had been ill for several months. His age was 63.

In an effort to avert a strike of building maintenance men April 21, the city's Rent Commissioner said yesterday that the Lindsay administration might raise the ceiling on the amount of wage increases landlords are permitted to pass on to tenants of rent-controlled apartments.

CHICAGO, April 7 Herbert G. Klein, director of communications for the Nixon Administration, said today that the White House would ask the commercial television industry at a conference on Thursday to assist the Government's drive against drugs.

SAN DIEGO, April 17(UPI) Nate Colbert's three-run homer capped a five-run third inning and Pat Dobson, making his National League debut, throttled Atlanta tonight as the Padres cuffed the Braves, 8-3.
OTTAWA, April 7 (AP) The trial of Ted Green of the Boston Bruins began today with an attempt by the defense to have the charge of common assault quashed on a technicality.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7(AP) Chris Short, returning after being sidelined a year by a back injury that necessitated surgery, pitched a five-hitter today as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Chicago Cubs, 2-0, in a National League baseball opener.

BEVERLY, Mass., April 7 Mrs. Robert Edwin Munsell has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Deborah Ann Munsell of New York, to Raymond Emory Hartz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hartz of Bernardsville, N.J.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its fourth consecutive loss yesterday as the list declined in very quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The builder of the F-111 attack airplane withheld evidence of "major increases" in the craft's expected weight for several months of the original Senate inquiry into the program in 1963, a Navy expert testified today.
The Southern strategy of the New York Yankees failed in its first Northern exposure yesterday.
Mrs. Edith Lowman Wile, a biochemist and wife of Walter D. Wile, a retired lawyer, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 49 East 96th Street.

TAMPA, Fla., April 7 A Federal district judge ordered today that control of the Manatee County schools be returned immediately to local officials and that a previously ordered integration plan be put into effect by Thursday morning.

ONLY two works occupied the program Seiji Ozawa conducted last night in Philharmonic Hall, but since one of them was the hour-long Symphony No. 4 by Bruckner, nobody felt cheated. Schubert's "Unfinished" Symphony was the other work. Mr. Ozawa was at the helm of the Philadelphia Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, April 7 The Federal Government made public today a compromise warning statement to be given to women with each package of birth control pills.
CAIRO, (UPI) April 7 The Sudanese Premier, Maj. Gen. Gaafar al-Nimelry, announced an amnesty today for insurgents in a recent anti-Government uprising, the Omdurman radio said.
LONDON, Arpil 7 The new wave of tension in Northern Ireland brought a pledge from Prime Minister Wilson today that British troops would stay as long as needed to maintain order.

ALBANY, April 7 Supporters of legislation to reform the abortion law will begin to revive the issue tomorrow when the Legislature returns from a week's recess and begins the push for final adjournment of the 1970 session.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 7 Mrs. Christine Frederick, a home economist, author and lecturer, died of heart disease at a convalescent home here yesterday Mrs. Frederick, the former Christine McGaffey, was 87 years old.
A handful of black hecklers forced Mayor Lindsay to discard his prepared speech at ground-breaking ceremonies for a new Model Cities housing project in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section yesterday.

MORE often than in any previous space mission, the three astronauts who head for the moon in the Apollo 13 spaceship scheduled for lift-off Saturday afternoon will have something resembling normal eating habits. They'll be able to use spoons more frequently, eat their food from bowls and spread sandwich fillings on slices of fresh bread.

The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday that the offering price of shares in Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., would be $15. First Boston is the managing underwriter of the 800,000-share issue, which will be offered publicly tomorrow.
Walter Lotz couldn't see the tote board at Aqueduct yesterday, or the white clouds that drifted lazily in a clear blue sky.
THE new board chairman of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts regards the center as "almost the the equivalent of a cathedral a symbol like Chartres, a symbol of our devotion to the arts."
LOS ANGELES, April 7 John Wayne was named the best actor of 1969 for his role in "True Grit" tonight at the 42nd annual presentation of awards by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, April 7(UPI) The Federal Trade Commission has accepted provisionally a consent decree to end a tie-in sales complaint against the SCM Corporation, a New York maker of typewriters and business machines.

Michael I. Sovern, a 38-yearold Columbia University Law School professor who played a major role in efforts to reunite and reform Columbia after student disorders two years ago, was named dean of the Law School yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 The National Federation of Catholic Physicians Guilds and four other groups today filed suits seeking to restrain Thomas Jefferson University Hospital here from performing abortions.
WASHINGTON, April 7 One-third of all first-born children in the United States from 1964 through 1966 were conceived out of wedlock, a Government survey disclosed today.
The American Basketball Association is giving temporary financial air to its Miami franchise while the Floridians undergo reorganization.

NEWARK, April 7 (AP) Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, who has been criticized for failing to aid black residents, has been endorsed by 50 black ministers who contend he has done more for Newark than any mayor has done for his city.

WASHINGTON, April 7 The House passed and sent to the White House today the most expensive education legislation in history, a $24.6-billion bill that will probably preserve the Johnson Administration's education programs until after the next Presidential election.

The New York Knicks, having successfully got past one of the outstanding oneon-one players in the National Basketball Association Earl Monroe of the Baltimore Bullets must now contend with another Flynn Robinson of the Milwaukee Bucks.
The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has received so many complaints recently that it is now asking volunteers to pitch in and help.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 7 Charles Pisano, the founder and president of the Citrus and Allied Essential Oils Company Inc., of Floral Park, L.I., died of a heart attack at his winter apartment here yesterday. Mr. Pisano, who lived in Garden City, L.I., was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 7 Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Robert H. Finch, insisting there would be no "backward motion," predicted today that the number of black children in school with whites in the South would double by fall.
WASHINGTON, April 7(AP) A House committee suggested today that the penalty for a first conviction for possession of marijuana be reduced to no more than a week in jail.
Charlie Cappello, a left-hander, pitched a four-hitter and struck 12 attbers to lead Long Island University to a 1-0 victory over C.W. Post College yesterday at the winner's field in Brooklyn.
Several dozen students at Staten Island Community College continued their take-over of college offices yesterday to press their demand for a larger voice in school administration.

THE other night, a couple asked a cab driver to take them to West 35th Street and 12th Avenue. The cabbie did, but when he arrived at the destination, in a rather deserted neighborhood full of railroad cars hard by the West Side Highway, he pulled a gun on his passengers and said: "All right. What are you trying to pull? Nobody lives here."
WHAT, Watkins Glen without Cam Argetsinger? It seems unthinkable. But it's true, and we shall have to live with it.
BEDFORD, Mass., April 7 Miss Carol Else Fernsler plans to be married early next month to Donald W. Rose, son of William A. Rose, president of the New York Athletic Club.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 7 President Joaquin Balaguer closed the national university and the headquarters of two major labor unions with tanks and troops today in a show of military backing for his re-election campaign.

Spreading wildcat strikes by rebellious teamsters made thousands of trucks idle in transportation centers across the nation yesterday, paralyzed freight movements in some cities and triggered mounting layoffs in industries.

The stage at Carnegie Hall was a fortress last night a side-to-side barricade bristling with vibrahraps, kettle drums, chimes, cymbals and a field drum and, in secondary depth, xylophones, gongs, bongos, conga drums and such minutiae as triangles, whistles, claves, bell trees and assorted producers of scratches and rattles.
For the first time, all welfare recipients in the city who cash welfare checks will be given identification cards, it was announced yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Jack R. Goldberg.

The Apollo 13 astronauts are scheduled to land on the moon at 45 centilunours past 22 lunours in the ninth lune of the 585th lunation, according to Dr. Kenneth L. Franklin, astronomer at the Hayden Planetarium.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 7 Stalin's daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, who defected to the United States in 1967, and William Wesley Peters, an architect, have obtained a marriage license here.

A few giddy minutes after the Knicks had subdued the Baltimore Bullets, 127-114, and advanced to the Eastern Division final of the National Basketball Association playoffs, Coach Red Holzman was asked what had inspired Dick Barnett to such a fine competitive edge?

WASHINGTON, April 7(AP) Congress must begin revamping the nation's oil-import program if the Nixon Administration fails to be "responsive to the needs of the people," Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today.
A West German chemical concern announced yesterday that it had suspended plans to build a huge chemical complex at Port Victoria, S.C., pending discussions on the formulation of pollution controls.
MANILA, April 7 Six persons were killed and scores were injured today in an earthquake that shook this city and most of the northern half of the Philippines.

CLEVELAND, April 7(UPI) Dave Johnson drove in three runs and Paul Blair doubled home two today to lead the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians behind the four-hit pitching of Dave McNally.

PARIS In former days international law was ultimately maintained by the threat of war, and gunboat diplomacy was supposed to teach lessons to nations whose own police departments failed. Now, however, the threat of war as such does not exist as a means of maintaining order since formal conflicts are excluded by everyone as too dangerous and informal conflicts aren't recognized as existing.

COLUMBIA, Md., April 5 A woman in her thirties who has lived in this once-rural area for almost a decade walked into a modern clinic here six months ago to receive her first physical examination in many years.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 7(AP) Denny Mendoza's sixth-inning double tied the score and Larry Robertson followed with a two-run triple to pace Rutgers to a 10-5 baseball victory over Columbia today.

BALTIMORE, April 7 (UPI) A construction company official who was indicted last week with Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, for perjury, conspiracy and bribery, pleaded guilty today before Judge Roszel C. Thomsen in United States District Court to a charge that he gave Mr. Dowdy $25,000 in cash at the Atlanta airport in 1965.

Every member of the United States Senate has the duty today of making a decision that could affect the course of government in the United States for years to come. It is a decision for which each Senator will have to answer to his own conscience.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 7 Vietnamese Communist military pressure on the Cambodian border province of Svayrieng increased last night and this morning and brought heavy fighting.
State Senator William E. Adams was acquitted yesterday of charges that he had committed perjury and obstructed justice in an investigation of Medicaid.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., April 7 The Dukes County grand jury voted today to indict no one in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne. District Attorney Edmund Dinis said, "The case is closed."

A former partner in the investment firm of Lazard Freres Co. was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday and charged with having failed to file tax returns on his income of $318,000 from 1963 to 1965.
Carl W. Andrews Jr., headmaster of the Collegiate School, the nation's oldest independent day school, has announced his resignation effective June 30, 1971.

Max Boryk, a popular performer in the Yiddish theater here, collapsed offstage after finishing a performance at Town Hall Sunday afternoon, and died, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

YONKERS, April 7 Twentyfive colts and two fillies that was the story today as post positions for Friday night's three-race second round of the $65,000 Ed Sullivan Series were drawn at Yonkers Raceway today.
Vatican legal experts have completed a new draft of a set of "fundamental laws" intended to serve as a constitution for the Roman Catholic Church.
The Israeli World Cup soccer team will face a New York allstar team in a special exhibiion at Randall's Island on May 10.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., April 7 Frank J. Cavanaugh, a retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Bank of New York, died yesterday at a nursing home in Guttenberg. He was 73 years old and lived here at 7200 Boulevard East.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which has long been the principal "hawk" on the need for economic restraint in the Federal Reserve System, indicated yesterday that it had softened its view on the economy a bit. In the April issue of its official Monthly Review, the bank said that "the latest business news continues to indicate slowing in the United States economy."
VIENNA Sitting on top of mammoth, newly discovered reserves of natural gas, the Soviet Union and the Netherlands are locked in a titans' struggle for the energy markets
Ben W. Heineman, who last year lost his battle for control of the B.F. Goodrich Company, may make another bid for the tire and rubber concern, which he insists is "under-managed."

The Dominican Republic's second presidential election since the 1965 civil war now seems certain to be a farce one that will increase the danger of another explosion instead of strengthening a fragile democratic system. None of the parties is blameless, and any path out of the crisis will be perilous.

UNION MILLS, Md., April 7 In this tiny pre-Revolutionary War hamlet, where the German ancestors of R. Sargent Shriver began their rise to prosperity in the New World by grinding corn, the former Ambassador to France began building on his own hopes for a new life in America today.

OFF BROADWAY is at last warming up again. At the weekend we had the engaging "Dear Janet Rosenberg, Dear Mr. Kooning," and now I can also most warmly recommended a new domestic drama that arrived last night at the MercerO'Casey Theater. It is a new play by Paul Zindel and it is one of the best of the season so far.
British West Indian Airways has Lucian J. Hunt as its managing director and chief executive officer. Mr. Hunt has been president of American Flyers Airline Corporation since 1966.

The Children's Television Workshop, producer of the popular children's series, "Sesame Street," yesterday announced programing plans for next season and for a new reading series for older children. At the same time it confirmed reports that it had become an independent corporation.

A world of fear, violence, filth and degradation has been described by many of the prisoners who answered an uncensored questionnaire about their living conditions while awaiting trial in the Tombs, the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.
Bond prices declined for the second straight day yesterday and yields on new issues were increased without inspiring much enthusiasm from investors.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 A memorial service was held at the Princeton University Chapel Sunday for Dr. T.H. Vail Motter, a historian, author and former teacher, who died at his home at 49 Palmer Square last Wednesday, after suffering a stroke. He was 69 years old.

UDINE, Italy, April 7(AP) A Hungarian Air Force lieutenant flew his Sovietbuilt MIG-15 fighter into Italy today and landed near where his former instructor brought in a MIG eight months ago. He immediately asked for political asylum.
PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (UPI) General Manager John Quinn announced today that Curt Flood had been placed on the Philadelphia Phillies' restricted list for failure to report.

WHILE the Nixon Administration expresses confidence that the slowdown in the nation's economy has been tamed that the slowdown is neither too deep nor too shallow concern exists at some private observation points that the decline is deepening unduly.

The Supreme Court has rightly refused to substitute its own judgment for that of the states on the wisdom of putting a top limit on the amount of welfare payments any poor family may collect. In effect, the Court has ruled that the Constitution leaves it to the Federal and state governments to establish standards of adequacy and thus decide how much of governmental resources will be allocated to welfare.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 7 Doctors were keeping a close watch tonight on the Apollo 13 astronauts after blood tests indicated that two of the three men may be fighting off the German measles.
WASHINGTON, April 7(UPI) President Nixon presented the nation's highest award for bravery today to the families of 21 American servicemen killed in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 7 A prestigious Administration advisory committee has recommended that the United States propose to the Soviet Union an immediate moratorium on further deployment of strategic weapons when the talks on control of arms resume in Vienna next week.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 7 In the Arab Middle East it is usually taken for granted that the great political problems, such as the Arab-Israeli conflict, are never solved. One just learns to live with them.
A decline in consumer buying, combined with an earlier Easter than last year, provided disappointing sales in March for seven of New York City's largest department stores.
BANTEAI-CHEI, Cambodia, April 5 "The 'Government of Salvation' is here," said the youth, placing his left fist on the far left edge of the table.

WHEN the New York Knickerbockers were ruthlessly bulldozing their way through the league with their record 18-game winning streak during the early stages of the season, they appeared to be and undoubtedly were the finest basketball team in the land. But then the law of averages, along with normal wear and tear, began to erode that image. The once superhuman Knicks appeared alarmingly human at times.
ROCHESTER, April 7 The Republican State Committee designated Governor Rockefeller for re-election today along with his chosen running mates.

BUFFALO, April 7 The defense for Dr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Fiedler began preparing its case today after City Judge H. Buswell Roberts denied several motions for dismissal of the marijuana-related charges.
BONN, April 7 Among all the other things, it turns out, Adolf Hitler was a tax dodger.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 7 Several companies of national policemen continued to patrol the downtown streets of Saigon tonight after clashing with 100 disabled South Vietnamese veterans.

The Swiss Government, long reluctant to cooperate in any way with United States law enforcement authorities on the subject of secret bank accounts, may now be willing to relent a little, Randolph W. Thrower, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, implied here yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., April 7 Nathaniel G. Burleigh, professor of industrial management emeritus at Dartmouth College and a former acting dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration, died here yesterday at the age of 80.

A.E. Richard de Jonge, an engineer and teacher, and a lifelong student of kinematics the branch of mechanics that deals with motion in the abstract died at St. Luke's Hospital Monday of emphysema. He lived at 875 West End Avenue, and was 87 years old.
Meade H. Esposito, Brooklyn Democratic leader, was questioned yesterday at a closed session of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) California vintners restocked today the wine cellars of the White House with a variety of table wines and champagnes produced in President Nixon's home state.

ITHACA, N.Y., Thursday, April 9 More than 100 black students at Cornell University marched through the campus last night, breaking scores of windows in at least six buildings and overturning two parked cars.
LONDON, April 8 An organization of British jurists is urging the appointment of independent civilian investigators to deal with complaints against the police.
Computer stocks recovered somewhat yesterday from their recent battering while leading industrial issues held to an even keel.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 8 Former President Juan D. Bosch is to return here next week to lead his Dominican Revolutionary party in the crisis over the presidential election.

MONTREAL, April 8 (UPI) Richie Allen, making his first regular-season appearance in a St. Louis uniform, drove in three runs with two doubles and a homer today as the Cardinals scored a 7-2 victory over the Montreal Expos, tallying five runs in the ninth inning.
SAN DIEGO, April 8 (AP) John S. Alessio, who rose from shoeshine boy to millionaire manager of a race track, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of income tax evasion and fraud.

YONKERS, April 8 Mr. and Mrs. Merv Wanless, the owners of Lucky Creed, the Australian stallion who will compete in the $150,000 International Pac- ing Series on May 8, 15 and 22 at Yonkers Raceway, have hardly stood still since they arrived in this country on March 30.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 8 (UPI) Pressmen struck Morris County's Daily Record here today and were quickly joined on the picket lines by printers, causing the paper to suspend publication.
McCarthyism this time emanating from elements of the New Left instead of the Old Right is beginning to reappear on some college campuses.

ALCATRAZ, Calif., April 8 The Indians on this former prison island in San Francisco Bay rejected yesterday a Government proposal to turn the island into a park that would have "maximum Indian qualities."

The City Planning Commission has worked out an unusual change in the zoning law, including a transfer of air rights tailored ot a private developer's plans to put up a 50-story building at the foot of Broadway.

The State Assembly has decided to take a new vote today on the abortion reform law that narrowly missed passage last week. The Senate already has given its approval to this urgent measure; it would now be on its way to Governor Rockefeller for signature if parliamentary maneuvering by Speaker Duryea had not kept it from mustering the requisite majority in the Assembly when it was first considered.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Former Representative Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat of Texas, exercised today his right to appear on the House floor.

ROME, April 8 (AP) Italy indicted Raffaele Minichiello today on eight charges but did not accuse him of having hijacked the Trans World Airlines jet he seized at gunpoint over California last November.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 8 The Rev. Dr. Otis A. Maxfield, senior minister of the Second Congregational Church here, and Mrs. Maxfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Maxfield, to David W. Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donal B. Duncan. A June wedding is planned.
GENEVA, April 8 The United Nations Commission on the Status of Women adopted a strong resolution tonight urging Secretary General Thant to give women more high-level jobs on the United Nations staff.
CONCORD, N.H. In a few years, if all goes well, New Hampshire fishermen will be catching an unusual Canadian brook trout, the Assinica, that often weighs 6-11 pounds.

ST. LOUIS, April 8 (AP) The contract of Guillermo Montanez, a first baseman, has been assigned to the Philadelphia Phillies as compensation for Curt Flood's failure to report, the St. Louis Cardinals' general manager, Bing Devine, said today.

VIENNA, April 8 President Ludvik Svoboda of Czechoslovakia returned home today from Moscow amid signs that the Communist leadership in Prague was puzzled by the widespread rumors of possible power shifts in the Kremlin.

The Federal Aviation Administration announced that yesterday that emergency flight restrictions imposed 10 days ago in New York and Chicago because of the air traffic controller "sick-out" would be reduced because some controllers had returned to work.
DETROIT, April 8 Mayor Lindsay and seven other bigcity Mayors pressed demands for antipollution devices today in a private luncheon meeting with the presidents of three automobile companies.

ONCE upon a time in Long Beach, Calif., a high school sophomore started an underground newspaper. It was banned on campus by his principal, who warned him that he was jeopardizing his future; that his reputation as a troublemaker would go into a Federal Bureau of Investigation dossier; that he persisted only because he wasn't good enough to make the official student biweekly.
The view that the economy was slowing down was given further support here yesterday as top-level bankers forecast that 1970 would be the first of two or three years of substandard growth.
The Board of Education's plan for redistricting Manhattan received a mixed reception yesterday at a public hearing attended by several hundred borough residents.

Operators of telephone answering services rejected a new contract offer last night and continued their day-old strike that has cut off service for 100,000 phone users, about one-third of them doctors and nurses.
From truck drivers to answering services, rebellious unionists are striking at the foundation of collective bargaining by upsetting agreements negotiated in good faith by their union leaders.

There was agreement among governmental and civic organizations yesterday that something ought to be done about the Jersey Central lift bridge over Newark Bay. There was disagreement, however, on how the job should be tackled.

PITTSBURGH, April 8 To- morrow night the New York Mets will play at Forbes Field for the last time. Even if Three River Stadium, the new home of the Pittsburgh Pirate, is not ready on May 29, the scheduled moving day, it will be before the Mets return here on Aug. 7.

ARCADIA, Calif., April 8 (UPI) T.V. Commercial, with Bill Shoemaker in the Saddle, won the $33,200 San Marino Handicap today. It was the fea- ture of the 48th and final day of the winter meeting at Santa Anita.
ALBANY, April 8 Constance E. Cook has led the fight for abortion reform in the State Assembly this year in a tailored, matronly manner, rarely raising her voice and never doubting ultimate success.
EL HUSSEINIYA, United Arab Republic, April 8 Israeli jets attacked the nearby village of Bahr el Bakar today, and Egyptian officials put the dead at 30 elementaryschool pupils and one teacher.
Winners of the Margo Jones Awards, given annually to com- panies fostering the works of new playwrights, were an- nounced yesterday.
Commuter service on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson rail line was close to normal last night as a slowdown by Local 1330 of the International Brotherhood of Carmen appeared to be nearing an end.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The House Armed Services Committee voted today in a closed session to instruct the Army to make a comparison "shoot off" test between an existing antitank missile system, the Shillelagh, and one under development, the TOW.
Volume on the American Stock Exchange fell to its lowest level in more than two years yesterday as prices continued to decline.

The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board warned yesterday that a proposal by Governor Rockefeller to force savings banks in New York to make mortgage loans on oneand two-family properties in the state at rates below the current market could backfire and result in less, rather than more, money for housing.
Singing as they were led away, 45 young Jewish activists were arrested yesterday after taking part in a six-hour occupation of the midtown offices of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

WASHINGTON, April 8 Senator Marlow W. Cook of Kentucky, who held one of three Republican votes crucial for the confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court, said today that he finally decided to vote against confirmation after attending a White House ceremony yesterday for the posthumous presentation of 21 Medals of Honor.

THE die is cast. Seymour Fox cast it this week. Not with frivolous, faddy "fun" clothes. With serious coats and suits, the kind that take weeks to tailor properly and cost from $300 to $500. They're for rather conservative women who don't go in for kicky fashions and they're all below the knee.

The Senate's rejection, by the astonishing vote of 51 to 45, of the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court is a triumph of constitutional responsibility over political partisanship.

JERUSALEM, April 8 Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that a number of influential Israeli Cabinet ministers who voted against his proposed meeting with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic were in favor of such a mission as a private venture.
WASHINGTON, April 8 Emergency legislation designed to avert a threatened railroad strike sped through Congress today and was sent to the White House.

THE team championship of the Metropolitan Com mercial Bridge League, contested over a five-month period, ended recently in a slender victory for International Business Machines, whose team won nine of its 12 matches.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 8 (Reuters) Premier Tran Thien Khiem told the Senate today that President Nguyyen Van Thieu intended to send legislation to Parliament to enable him to govern by decree.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The Government entered the controversial Charlotte, N.C., school desegregation case today, suggesting that a United States district judge had committed "an abuse of discretion" by ordering an "extreme" busing plan.

Thirty-five students at Benjamin Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens, were arrested yesterday after they allegedly barricaded the principal in a conference room and restrained him from leaving when he told them that their discussions of student demands could not take place during class hours.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 8 The United States launched a pair of nuclear-detection satellites early this morning from its East and West Coast launching centers.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 8 For the first time since 1966, Army has opened spring football practice following a losing season.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 8 Like his leap into national prominence, Judge G. Harrold Carswell's goodby today was brief.
WEST SOUTHPORT, Me., April 8 Gustaf Adolf Tenggren, illustrator of children's books, died Monday in a Boothbay Harbor hospital after a brief illness. He was 73 years old.

PITTSBURGH, April 8 (AP) Nick Harbaruck, a Pittsburgh Penguin rookie who is a native of Poland, scored a controversial goal with just over seven minutes remaining tonight that gave the Penguins a 2-1 victory over the Oakland Seals in the first game of the National Hockey League quarterfinal playoffs.
CLEVELAND, April 8 (AP) Mark Belanger's two-run single capped a three-run Baltimore spurt in the second inning today and led the Orioles to a 3-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
Soybean oil futures advanced to new highs for the season in the two options offered, while meal and soybean futures also closed strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

John P. Fishwick, hailed as the "father" of the plan for merging the Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio railroads into the Norfolk Western Railway, was named president and chief executive officer of the N. yesterday.

Outdoor "freedom Seders" during Passover that will combine prayers from a new Haggadah with political protest against the modern "pharaohs" of business and government are being planned for New York, Ithaca and Washington by a coalition of Jewish peace groups.

Sixteen years of broken promises on land reform provide warrant for skepticism about the new legislation President Thieu has signed, yet there is now more reason than before to believe that tenant farming at last will be virtually ended in South Vietnam.

LONDON, April 8 A grand slam for Trevor Peacock, who wrote its book and score and appears as its star, "Erb," at the Strand Theater, amounts to another broken date in the British musical's flirtation with labor relations subjects.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service prepared today for the traditional last-minute rush by taxpayers trying to file returns before the April 15 deadline. The I.R.S. said that through last Friday two of every five taxpayers had still not filed returns for 1969. Of some 77 million income tax returns expected, 46.3 million have been received.

WHILE thousands of visitors streamed into the Coliseum the other night to view the gleaming new cars at the annual International Automobile Show, Steven Israeloff stood outside, holding court as he leaned against his purple Dodge Challenger.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) An association of Roman Catholic priests from the Chicago archdiocese, the nation's largest, will ask Pope Paul VI to rescind the rule prohibiting priests from marrying.
Richard Phelps, 28 years old, the chief recruiter in Penn's four-year growth from college basketball oblivion to a nationally ranked power, was named yesterday as the Fordham coach.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark today called this "a sad day for the Supreme Court because it has been subjected to a confrontation between it and the President and with the Senate."

WASHINGTON, April 8 The Administration's top Middle East negotiator, Joseph J. Sisco, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, left today for quick visits to Arab capitals and Israel, pursuing the drive for greater flexibility in the long-stalled peacemaking efforts.
WASHINGTON, April 8 Income-tax time usually brings out the worst in everybody, or at least in everybody who has to pay income tax.
PARIS, April 8 Prince Felix of Luxembourg, husband of the Grand Duchess Charlotte, died this morning at Fischbach, his castle in the Grand Duchy. He was 77 years old.
GUATEMALA, April 8 (Reuters) A group of rightists today clubbed a Communist to death in revenge fo rthe killing of ambassador Karl von Spreti of West Germany.

WHOEVER imagined that William Alfred's verse drama "Hogan's Goat" could be made into a Broadway musical? The answer is now history, for last night this musicalization opened at the Broadhurst Theater. It was called "Cry for Us All." I found myself crying only for Mr. Alfred.

Mrs. Paula Melhado Washburn and Roswell Gilpatric, who was Deputy Secretary of Defense under President Kennedy, have set May 12 as the date for their wedding. The ceremony will take place at Mrs. Washburn's apartment here.

ST. LOUIS, April 8 (UPI) Ab McDonald and Terry Crisp scored two goals each tonight in leading the St. Louis Blues to a 6-2 victory over the Minnesota North Stars in the first game of their Stanley Cup quarter-final series.

SSC has lengthened its roster of executive vice presidents with the addition of Michael G. Turner, a senior vice president at Ogilvy Mather. He will also be a director and a member of the executive committee when he starts to work on May 1.

Four years after the Democratic primary for Manhattan Surrogate was waged over the issue of reforming the court's patronage practices, the two judges who administer more than $1-billion worth of estates a year are pursuing contrasting legal concepts that are expected, once again, to become important campaign issues.
LONDON, April 8 Sweden, in a shift of policy, is now eager to join the Common Market if her special political needs can be met.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 8 Public approval of President Nixon's performance dropped to a new low just before he dispatched troops to move the mail in New York City, the Gallup poll said today.
A neighborhood antipoverty group will operate a psychiatric clinic under a contract with the city, the first such agreement ever made, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

A tall man stepped into a southbound EE local of the IND subway after it stopped at the 34th Street station yesterday and, for no apparent reason, walked over to a 75year-old man and slashed him with a long knife on both sides of the face.

ALBANY, April 8 Responding to protests by a group of Brooklyn homeowners, the sponsors of a controversial bill for the rehabilitation of Atlantic Avenue said today that they would withdraw the legislation from consideration this year.

MACON, Ga., April 8UPI) A Mercer University official said today that Judge G. Har- rold Carswell would receive the school's distinguished alumnus award on May 2. The official added that it was "dirty pool" to say the judge had been turned down for an honorary doctor's degree.

ONE of the games that Henri Bendel enjoys the most is called "surprise" and the idea is to always come in first. The new Plant Stand that takes up a large 57th Street window and greets customers as they are ushered through the front door of the store is a case in point.

The Contemporary Music Society likes to give New Yorkers a look at what composers are doing around the country, and Tuesday night at the Guggenheim Museum it presented members of the Center for New Music from the University of Iowa. What they are doing there is what they are doing here.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 8 Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Stalin, confirmed today that she was married to William Wesley Peters, the vice president of the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 8 (UPI) Two Colorado men moved into the top 10 in regular singles and all-events today in the American Bowling Congress tournament.
Student demonstrators blocked elevators and chained corridor doors at Hunter College yesterday, disrupting most day and evening classes at the 19,000student branch of the City University.
MOSCOW, April 8 A Soviet conservation official, call ing for stricter laws to protect natural resources, has declared that water pollution alone is costing the economy more than $6-billion a year.

MRS. WILLIAM OWEN, an English professor who recently took her doctorate in 18th-century poetry, has plunged right back into the tomes of 200 years ago, but with a different focus. This time it's on the cooking of Colonial America.
A task force to speed payment of bills by the city to contractors and suppliers of materials was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, April 8 The executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters held an emergency meeting here today, hoping to reassert its leadership as labor chaos mounted in the trucking industry.

CHESHAM, England, April 8 (UPI) A magistrates court ordered today that Joan Tunney Wilkinson be held in custody for another week while the police continue their investigation of charges that she murdered her husband.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 Gary Player of South Africa and two United States professionals, Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer, were considered prime favorites today to win the Masters golf tournament that begins here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 8 Bully for Bob Finch! He managed at his news conference Tuesday to make the Nixon Administration seem bold and progressive on school desegregation, and that was no mean feat.

A group of tenant organizers released their own report on housing yesterday, contending that landlords were enjoying "superprofits" and proposing that the city confiscate poorly maintained buildings and let community organizations manage them.

VIENTIANE, April 8 Long after many observers here had expected the twin towns to fall, Laotian forces today were still holding off North Vietnamese attacks against Sam Thong and Long Tieng, 70 to 80 miles northeast of Vientiane.

John's Bargain Stores Corporation announced yesterday it has completed the previously announced acquisition of Sprayregen Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, for $16-million in preferred stock of one of its subsidiaries.

About 350 radical students clashed with campus security guards and broke several windows at Columbia University last night after hearing a speech in which William M. Kunstler, defense attorney in the recent Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, advised against violence as "not the right tactics at this time."

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 8 Mr. and Mrs. John W. Knittle of Cold Spring Harbor and North Baldwin, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Schell Knittle, to Second Lieut. Scott Cromwell Noble, U.S.A., son of Joseph L. Noble of Rochester and St. Croix, Virgin Islands, and the late Mrs. Kathryn Cromwell Noble.

With the return of spring bringing a crescendo in demonstrations and disruptions in colleges and universities across the country, New York University's president says a clear, strong policy can help preserve everyone's best interests.

CHICAGO, April 8 Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told the nation's broadcasters today that they should not regard him as their friend in Washington or as their foe, but as the man charged with seeing that they serve the public. Further, he criticized television's programing for children.

WASHINGTON, April 8 A junior Republican member of the House Commerce subcommittee initiated an attempt today to break the deadlock in the subcommittee that has blocked adoption of mutualfund reform legislation for three years.

With the intention of further increasing revenue from thoroughbred racing to the state treasury, as well as attracting more patrons, the New York Racing Association announced yesterday that it would offer exacta betting at its tracks.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 8 (Reuters) Australia and France, vying for the right to challenge the United States for yachting supremacy in the 1970 America's Cup series, will meet in an elimination test starting Aug. 21, the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron said today.

A year ago the Hanes Corporation (a name to conjure with in hosiery) came to Dancer-Fitzgerald-Fitzgerald (a big name in package-goods advertising) with a shriveledup pair of stockings and an equally shriveled set of pantyhose. Hanes, a leading brand in department store sales, wanted to get into supermarkets and drugstore chains to compete with some 600 brands sold there.

BOSTON, April 8 The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court agreed today to hold up release of the transcript of the secret Mary Jo Kopechne inquest pending a decision on the status of the inquest stenographer's notes.
LONGBINH, South Vietnam, April 8 This is probably the first war in American history in which the Army cleans off its battlefields and sells the scrap to the highest bidder as it fights.

The First National City Corporation, parent company of the First National City Bank, the largest in New York, reported figures yesterday showing that its net income declined 6.4 per cent in the first quarter to $29.97-million, or $1.10 a share, from $32-million, or $1.19 a share, in 1968.

WASHINGTON, April 8 Artificial blood, milky and opalescent in appearance, may have a future in medical emergencies in some kinds of special medical treatment and in preserving tissues for transplatation, a scientist suggested today.
SAN DIEGO, April 8 (AP) Rico Carty drove in four runs with a homer and sacrifice fly tonight as the Atlanta Braves defeated the San Diego Padres, 6-1, behind the five-hit pitching of Pat Jarvis.

It was disclosed yesterday that, when Paul A. Gorman was hired by the Penn Central Company as its president and chief executive officer last Dec. 1, directors of the transportation company gave him an employment contract under which his salary was $250,000 a year.
DETROIT, April 8 Detroit's school board approved last night a decentralization plan and boundary changes aimed at dispersing the white minority students among the city's high schools.

The Parvin-Dohrmann Company, which has been involved in a welter of controversy for more than a year on charges ranging from illegal stock dealings to seeking influence with Federal officials, plans to change its name to the Recrion Corporation.
THE MEETINGS took place at Boston College last week while the students were on their Spring vacation.
The Dreyfus Fund, one of the nation's oldest and largest mutual funds, expressed opposition yesterday to fund membership on the New York Stock Exchange.
OSAKA, Japan, Thursday, April 9 A total of 72 persons were killed and 282 injured yesterday when a series of gas explosions ripped a subway construction site in downtown Osaka.

ALBANY, April 8 Supporters of abortion reform revived their bill to end the present state law after tortuous parliamentary maneuvering during which 12 absent members were ordered brought to the chamber "by whatever force necessary.
DURBAN, South Africa, April 18 Prime Minister John Vorster called last night for ending the divisions that have long prevailed in South Africa's white minority.

DETROIT, April 8 American Motors Corporation chairman, Roy D. Chapin Jr., in a speech before automotive analysts in New York City today, the text of which was released here, said "1970 will be a loss year." The auto manufacturers' fiscal year ends Sept. 30.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 8 Dr. Robert M. Scoon, chairman of Princeton University's philosophy department from 1934 to 1952, died today at his home here. He was 83 years old.
The Men's Glee Club of the University of California at Los Angeles paid its respects to German baroque sacred music at the start of its concert in Alice Tully Hall last night.

VIENTIANE, Laos, April 8 (UPI) The Laotian Premier Prince Souvanna Phouma, reportedly proposed today that peace talks suggested by the pro-Communist Pathet Lao be preceded by a cease-fire and a halt in United States bombing except against the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

ROCHESTER, April 8 Governor Rockefeller announced today that the chairman of his re-election campaign would be R. Burdell Bixby, the chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority and the head of an informal committee that has been planning Rockefeller political strategy for the last year.
MIKHAIL TAL, a former world champion, has pre sented another combinational gem, destined for future anthologies. The finale is unique and without parallel.
WASHINGTON, April 8 The Senate passed a 6 per cent raise today for 5.6 million Federal employes.

PARIS, April 8 The West German Foreign Ministry is quietly canvassing opinion on placing a former Nazi diplomat on the Executive Commission of the European Economic Community, arousing strong unfavorable reaction in Brussels, Paris and The Hague.
Four previously unperformed songs by Ralph Shapey were sung by Neva Pilgrim, soprano, at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in a recital sponsored by Carnegie Hall-Jeunesses Musicales.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 9 (AP) Enemy attacks killed 754 South Viet- namese soldiers last week, the highest weekly Government toll in more than two years and the second highest of the war, South Vietnamese headquarters announced today.
TRENTON, April 8 Nelson G. Gross resigned as New Jersey's Republican state chairman tonight and will announce his candidacy tomorrow for his party's nomination for United States Senator.

ATHENS, April 8 The prosecutor at the Athens military tribunal trying 34 intellectuals on sedition charges asked today for one death penalty, four life sentences, prison terms totaling 288 years, and three acquittals.

A professional handler's performance in the show ring is only "the tip of the dog-training iceberg," said Mrs. Lois Meistrell at the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon yesterday at the Overseas Press Club. "It's the part of the iceberg that isn't seen," she said, "that means ...

WASHINGTON, April 8 There is no simple explanation or the votes of the 51 Senators who rejected Judge G. Harrold Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court today. Many votes were cast automatically for liberalism or against conservatism.

The Southern Company plans to spend $1.5-billion on new electric operating facilities in the three-year period ending 1972, Harllee Branch Jr., chairman, told a luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday in Oakland, Calif., that it would raise the price of primary aluminum to 29 cents a pound from 28 cents and would impose corresponding increases on fabricated products.
MOSCOW, April 8 (AP) Hans Alser of Sweden won the men's singles title and Zoya Rudnova of the Soviet Union gained the women's crown tonight in the European table tennis championships.

THE elegant stretch of Madison Avenue between 59th and 74th Streets has decided to fight back against the fading of its image, against competition from boutiques and department stores in other sections of the city, and against holdups and vandalism.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 8 Defying a Federal district judge for the second time in three days, Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida tonight again seized control of the Manatee County school systeam and canceled an integration plan that the judge ordered put into effect by tomorrow morning.

Is it really possible to become a Pelleas or a Melisande in, and for, just one performance? Richard Stillwell and Lois Crane may have asked themselves that question Tuesday night as they took over the title roles of Debussy's opera in the New York City Opera production at the New York State Theater.
DENVER, April 8 (AP) Samuel I. Newhouse has proposed the public auction of some 15,000 shares of The Denver Post as part of a Federal District Court settlement between Mr. Newhouse and the newspaper.
WASHINGTON, April 8 The Department of Transportation announced today that more than 42,000 Goodrich automobile tires had failed Federal safety tests and "could be hazardous under certain conditions."

REAM, Cambodia, April 8 The hijacked freighter Colum- bia Eagle, her cargo of 1,753 long tons of napalm and her crew of 13 were returned to United States control today, and she sailed quickly out of Cambodian waters.
WILLIMANTIC, Conn., April 8 D. Robert Ingalls, assistant to the athletic director at the University of Connecticut, died today at Windham Community Hospital. He was 51 years old.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 8 Apollo 13 mission planners announced tonight that they may replace one of the astronauts who is susceptible to German measles with a backup pilot in order to launch the scheduled moon flight on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 President Nixon was described today as being "disappointed" by the Senate rejection of Judge G. Harrold Carswell but determined to press his search for a conservative candidate for the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, April 8 The Senate, turning down President Nixon on a nominee for the Supreme Court for the second time, rejected Judge G. Harrold Carswell today, 51 to 45.
The New York-Boston Turbo Train became a birthday party on wheels yesterday its first anniversary in service as passengers were served free cake and coffee to commemorate the event.
The pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers accused of potting to bomb public places were conducted quietly yesterday for the second day.

Fifty-five per cent of all television viewers in an eightcity survey watch public televivision, the 1970 Public Television Conference was told yesterday. What is more, 65 per cent of the 8.5 million households covered by the survey reported that they watched public TV during the week of the survey.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 Mrs. Alice MacBurney Riggs, widow of Dr. Austen Fox Riggs, an internationally known psychiatrist and author, died today at her home here. She was 93 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 8 Canada has taken action here to protect her rights to defend her Arctic coasts against possible oil pollution if tankers begin using the Northwest Passage.

NEW ORLEANS, April 8 (AP) City Councilman Moon Landrieu, a Democrat, was elected Mayor yesterday in a general election that showed surprising Republican strength and gave the Legislature its only G.O.P. Representative.

It took more than 300 years, but the common stock warrant a kind of security disdained in the best of corporate circles until now has gained respectability. Next Monday, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will start selling 31,386,540 of them.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, April 9 Official sources said that Cambodian troops killed 300 Vietcong early today after a late-night ambush between the town of Svayrieng and Prasot, 16 miles from the border with South Vietnam.

CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) The Chicago Black Hawks spot- ted the Detroit Red Wings the first goal tonight and then rallied on scores by Pit Martin, Stan Mikita, Chico Maki and Eric Nesterenko for a 4-2 victory in the opening game of their Stanley Cup playoff series.

James L. Buckley, the Con- servative party candidate for United States Senator, predicted yesterday that his party would do better at the polls this year than ever before because "the trend is toward the conservative view."

LONDON, April 8 In the twilight gloom along Commercial Road, the dull redbrick homes are locked and silent. The Pakistani children peer wide-eyed through white window curtains, gazing nervously at the strangers passing on the street.
For the second consecutive year the Newspaper Guild of New York has conferred its annual Page One Award on The New York Times for the "Best Example of a Crusading Newspaper."
PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 8 Miss Katherine Jerusha Sauer and Peter Kornel Gogolak, place-kicker with the New York Football Giants, will be married May 31 in Plainfield.

Amid much pomp in London, the International Lawn Tennis Federation authorized yesterday an experimental Grand Prix circuit of 18 men's tournaments this year, including the Wimbledon and United States Open championships.

LONDON, April 8 Mrs. Robin Butler, London editor of Vogue, and Rupert Nicholas Hambro, a member of the English merchant banking family, were married here today at the Chelsea Registry Office. The civil ceremony was followed by a service of blessing at noon at the Chelsea Old Church.

Arthur J. Goldberg, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, urged yesterday that New York legislators support a bill that questions the right of the Administration to send conscript troops to Vietnam.

Time Inc. and the Columbia Broadcasting System appealed to news organizations throughout the world yesterday to help assure the safety and gain the release of five newsmen, including two Americans, who are reported to have been captured by the Vietcong in Cambodia on Sunday and Monday.
The bond market, which faltered early this week after a recent sustained advance, resumed its upward course yesterday.
Eight reputed Mafia members were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of bribing Internal Revenue Service agents. A ninth was indicted for not paying his income tax.
A 12-year-old boy was seriously burned yesterday in Crotona Park, the Bronx, when he was thrown into a rubbish fire by three teenaged boys. He suffered second-degree burns of the face.

WASHINGTON, April 8 A team of investigators directed by Ralph Nader issued a report today portraying the Food and Drug Administration as a tool of the food industry, controlled by political pressures and unable and unwilling to protect the consumer.
A Bronx patrolman was wounded in an eye yesterday afternoon by a ricocheting shotgun pellet after kicking open the door of an apartment in which an armed man had attempted to take refuge.

The Celanese Corporation earned $15.7-million, or $1.10 a share, in the first quarter this year, down 16 per cent from a net of $18.4-million, or $1.31 a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales of $259.5-million compared with $299-million in the first quarter of 1969, a decline of 13 per cent, reflecting primarily the sale of the company's petroleum subsidiaries effective January 1.
Negotiators for the printers and the city's major newspapers began to grapple with the critical money issue yesterday after having made some progress on noneconomic matters.

STONY BROOK, L.I., April 8 The State University here announced today that it had suspended the director of its high school equivalency program and three of his staff members pending an investigation of charges that the staff members had threatened, beaten and pistol-whipped four youths in the program.

WASHINGTON, April 8 McGeorge Bundy, who was national-security adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, proposed today that the United States take the initiative in the forthcoming talks with the Soviet Union on control of strategic arms by deferring its planned deployment of a missile-defense system and of multiple warheads for offensive missiles.
In an internal reorganization at Harcourt, Brace World, Inc., William Jovanovich has stepped down as president to become chairman of the board, while reretaining the title of chief executive officer.
BOSTON, April 8 With a smirk, Derek Sanderson held up his hands with the peace sign tonight, the ultimate insult toward the end of the game in which the Boston Bruins trounced the Rangers, 8-2.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 8 The Rabbinical Assembly, an international association of Conservative rabbis, elected Rabbi S. Gershon Levi of New York as president of the 1,000member body today.

IS every three-dimensional object featuring some variety of photographic image on one or more of its surfaces necessarily a work of sculpture? This is the question posed in the exhibition called "Photography Into Sculpture," which opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art.
PARIS, April 8 Several hundred mayors sporting the tricolor sash of their office marched through part of the Left Bank of Paris today to protest the poor state of municipal finances.
For 27 years, Helen Thompson have been giving professional advice to symphony orchestra managers. Yesterday, she started seeing how her own advice works.

Immigration. The President signed a bill amending the Immigration and Naturalization Act to eliminate delays experienced by fiancees of Americans in getting immigrant visas. Financees of United States citizens and the fiancees' minor children can be admitted for permanent residence provided the marriage takes place within 90 days of entry into the country. The bill also makes it easier for aliens with special skills to work in this country.
